HEADLINE: Clinton Said to Seek Increase in Intelligence Funds

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS JEHL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
President Clinton has asked Congress for authority to spend even more money on spy agencies, satellites and other intelligence activities in the 1994 fiscal year than it allotted for 1993, Congressional and Administration officials say.
The request is hidden in classified sections of the Defense Department budget that on the whole reflects Mr. Clinton's plans for significant cuts in military spending. 
 But the Administration has concluded that at least a short-term increase in the intelligence spending is needed before similar deep reductions can be made in the budgets of the Central Intelligence Agency and other spy agencies.
The new Director of Central Intelligence, R. James Woolsey, had signaled earlier that the Administration would oppose sharp immediate cuts in intelligence spending. But the request for an increase has surprised some lawmakers because Mr. Clinton had promised to slash intelligence spending by $7 billion over four years.
Nearly all of the new spending, Administration officials said today, is to be devoted to launching spy satellites that can replace several older ones, saving money in the future.
While some members of both parties have expressed support for such an effort, other lawmakers have privately voiced some distress at the proposal. The request is expected to be the subject of a sharp debate next week when members of the House and Senate Intelligence Committees meet behind closed doors to review the budget.
While the size of the nation's vast intelligence budget remains an official secret, Administration and Congressional officials disclosed today that it would total about $28 billion if the increase requested by Mr. Clinton is approved. They said the previous estimates putting the figure at $29 billion had been exaggerated.
Of the total, the officials said Mr. Clinton had proposed that $17.8 billion be set aside next year for the C.I.A. and other intelligence agencies. That request represents an increase at nearly double the rate of inflation from this year's final appropriation of about $17 billion, they said.
At the same time, Congressional officials said Mr. Clinton proposed only minor cuts in the other component of the intelligence budget, the military programs intended to gather the information used in battle. They said that total remained at $10.1 billion.
By comparison, after accounting for inflation, Mr. Clinton proposed a 5 percent reduction in overall military spending.
Administration officials have told members of Congress that the increase will allow intelligence agencies to consolidate programs and make deep cuts in the years ahead.
They also argue that Mr. Clinton has not violated his budget-cutting pledge because his request represents a substantial reduction from what President George Bush had planned to spend in 1994. Mr. Bush had set aside $19 billion for national intelligence programs.
Because Congress last year authorized about $400 million more for intelligence than it finally appropriated, an Administration official said last night, the White House intends to portray its proposal as a freeze, not an increase, once inflation is taken into account.
The new Administration hopes such arguments and party loyalty might blunt any Democratic impulse to renew battles that party members fought with the Bush Administration to cut intelligence spending. But some Congressional Democrats have already made clear that they intend to fight the new request, even though it comes from a Democratic President.
An influential Democratic lawmaker who spoke on condition of anonymity said the request for more money showed that the new Administration had failed to gauge the opposition to the proposal.
"This increase is just not going to happen," the Democratic lawmaker predicted. "They're going to get cut severely."
Even Representative Dan Glickman, the Kansas Democrat who heads the House Intelligence Committee, said in a recent interview that he had not yet decided whether to support the White House request. "I'm not going to be thrilled about an increase," Mr. Glickman said. "But we'll have to see where the increases are coming from."
Further evidence of the proposed increases is in a public version of Mr. Clinton's 1994 Defense Department budget request.
While the unclassified document leaves blank the spending requests for specific intelligence programs, simple calculations show that a research budget includes a request for a $150 million increase to be divided among the Defense Intelligence Agency, the National Security Agency and the new Central Imagery Office, which handles requests for spy satellite photographs.
A separate Air Force procurement budget shows a $570 million increase for a category designated only as "selected activities," a category that experts outside government said was used to disguise money set aside for the C.I.A. and the National Reconnaissance Office, which operates spy satellites.
Administration officials confirmed that the proposed new financing would go for the consolidation of the nation's spy satellite systems. Although new reconnaissance or eavesdropping satellites can cost as much as $1 billion, officials say that at least one satellite now under construction can fulfill the duties of several others, eliminating the cost of their operation.

HEADLINE: Pratt & Whitney Threatening To Shut 2 Connecticut Plants

BYLINE: By GEORGE JUDSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 14

 BODY:
Pratt & Whitney threatened today to close two Connecticut plants and to eliminate 2,300 additional jobs unless it receives concessions from its unions and tax breaks from the state.
The threatened closings shocked Pratt employees and their communities, but Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. and other state officials quickly vowed to meet the company's requests and to avoid the loss of more jobs on top of 6,700 that are already scheduled to be eliminated. 
 In seeking the concessions, company officials said that building jet engines in Connecticut costs 30 percent more than in states like Georgia and Maine, where Pratt plants are not closing.
"We have said for a long time that Connecticut is a very expensive state to do business in, but that it is our traditional home," said a Pratt & Whitney spokesman, Mark Sullivan. "This is the first time we've done a dollar comparison."
Governor Weicker said that Pratt officials were most concerned about gaining relief from local property taxes -- they pay $22 million a year in five communities -- and gaining greater benefits from a state tax credit for research and development, on which Pratt spends several hundred million dollars a year.
 
Wider Industry Problems
 Economists said that the additional layoffs would have only a small effect on the state's economy, but that the plant closings and movement of jobs out of state would cost towns millions of dollars in taxes and could endanger the hundreds of Pratt subcontractors in the state. Pratt's employment in the state has already fallen to 17,290, from 28,800 in 1986.
Analysts say Pratt & Whitney has little choice but to cut back to compete amid a severely depressed commercial aviation market. But in a state where the recession has already eliminated 180,000 jobs, Pratt's decisions are pushing Connecticut to compete more directly with other states for its manufacturing jobs, and its unionized employees here to compete with nonunion work forces at sister plants.
"We will assist Pratt & Whitney to whatever degree is necessary," Governor Weicker said at a news conference at his regional office in Bridgeport.
"In the quest to be competitive, they have to downsize their own operations," Mr. Weicker said. "If we want them in Connecticut, clearly we have to meet the competition when it comes to business climate."
Andrew Romegialli, president of District 91 of the machinists union, told The Associated Press that the company described the closing plan to union leaders as a "worst-case scenario." Labor costs, he said, were a small part of the state's higher costs.
"They're going to want something," he said. "We don't know what it is yet. If they have specifics, like they did for the state, they can come and talk to us about it."
 
Concern in Southington
 In Hartford, Democratic and Republican leaders in the General Assembly pledged to work with Mr. Weicker and Pratt to prevent the further loss of jobs.
Pratt's president, Karl Krapek, said no final decisions have been made on its nine plants in Connecticut, pending talks with state officials and the machinists union, which represents shop workers. But in East Hartford, Southington, and North Haven -- where a third plant is scheduled to be partially shut -- employees, neighboring merchants and town officials felt like it was the end.
"The outlook is pretty dim," Southington's town manager, John Weichsel, said after a meeting this morning with plant executives. "They made it clear there was nothing more that Southington could or should have done."
The closing there would not only put 1,300 people out of work, but jeopardize the $3.8 million in property taxes that Pratt paid this year toward the town's $66 million budget.
One advantage Connecticut does offer manufacturers is a skilled work force built up over generations, but now the thousands of layoffs will include men and women with a dozen or more years of experience, many of them in their 40's and 50's who have little prospect of finding comparable jobs.
"I'd have to leave the state, plain and simple," said Nicholas M. Pisani, 50, a process planner in the North Haven plant's manufacturing and engineering department. "There are too many unemployed people in this state now, and I don't think I'd have much of a chance to find a job in Connecticut at my age."
 
Keep Connecticut Presence
 Connecticut has seen other industries, notably the brass industry in the Naugatuck Valley, slowly move its operations out of state while wringing concessions from their workers. But Mr. Krapek said today that Pratt, whose headquarters are in East Hartford, wants to maintain a major presence in Connecticut, and few analysts questioned the company's need to cut costs and seek concessions from the state and unions.
Analysts said that Pratt has higher costs than its competitors, General Electric and Rolls-Royce, and has been affected more by the commercial aviation industry's troubles. Furthermore, its greatest costs are in Connecticut, they said.
"The costs there are much higher than in Georgia, Florida and probably Maine," said Nicholas P. Heymann, an analyst at NatWest Securities.
The Connecticut workers are highly skilled, he said, but "Pratt & Whitney is going through an immense historical transition. At this point, we'd assume that people would come to the table and would want to talk."
That transition could take Pratt further in reducing its work force than its officials are now projecting. Pratt has said its target is a worldwide work force of 30,000 by the end of 1994, down from 44,400 in 1991, but Michael Lauer, an analyst at Kidder, Peabody & Company, is forecasting that the company will have 27,000 employees in 1995.
The cutbacks are likely to fall more heavily on Pratt's home state than officials had originally expected. Just last month, the company was saying only 6,700 of 10,664 layoffs would come within the state; now 9,000 are scheduled.
Mr. Krapek said a study conducted this winter found that average hourly costs per worker in Connecticut plants were $6 to $8 higher than in Georgia and Maine, and officials from those states have since proposed economic-development packages that increased their advantages.
In addition, Pratt has found that it can cut the cost of many parts by nearly a third simply by having subcontractors supply them.
"We're not trying to start a bidding war between states," said Mr. Sullivan, the Pratt spokesman. "We're trying to address a very serious cost problem for the company."
Edward Deak, an economics professor at Fairfield University, said, "What Pratt has done now is only to underscore what other parts of the business community have said before: It's tough to do business in Connecticut. You've got to take them seriously when they shut down the plants."

HEADLINE: YELTSIN IS BACKED AT TALKS IN TOKYO

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 14

 BODY:
The world's seven leading industrial nations pledged support today to President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia but were still struggling to assemble an aid program to promote his economic reforms and to help him win a nationwide referendum in less than two weeks.
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan opened the two-day conference saying that Russia was at a "critical juncture, with the reform efforts under the leadership of President Yeltsin facing tremendous challenges both politically and economically." 
 He called it "incumbent upon the international community to send a clear message that it expects Russia's reforms to be pursued irreversibly."
 
Effort to Please
 Mr. Miyazawa's statement reflected a marked effort by Japan to accommodate its other industrialized partners despite its lack of enthusiasm for aiding a country that is still occupying territory claimed by Japan but seized by the Soviet Union at the end of World War II.
Mr. Miyazawa's address to the meeting participants contained Japan's pledge of $1.8 billion in aid to Russia this year, a figure that disappointed some Administration officials because all but $300 million of it was in the form of loans -- not grants -- that are intended to promote Japanese exports.
By contrast, most of the new funding by the United States will be in outright grants, rather than in loans or credits.
The United States plans to announce on Thursday a new $1.8 billion aid package, some of which Administration officials said would have to be funded by an emergency aid request from Congress.
The new aid would be in addition to the $1.6 billion of previously appropriated money announced by Mr. Clinton at the summit with Mr. Yeltsin earlier this month. In addition, the United States has offered $2 billion of Export-Import Bank credits to finance Russia's purchase of American oil, gas and other energy equipment.
 
$30 Billion Package
 The seven countries are hoping to unveil on Thursday a package of $30 billion in bilateral grants, loans and credits as well as funding from international lending institutions. But there were still differences of opinion today on how much of the aid pledged represented previous promises. In endorsing Mr. Yeltsin, Secretary of State Warren Christopher sounded a little like a campaign manager, saying the Russian president "was far superior to any of his likely successors in terms of commitment to the market process." He added that any successors to Mr. Yeltsin "would probably be less committed" to this process.
As part of its aid initiative, the United States proposed today the creation of a $4 billion fund administered by the seven nations -- known as the Group of Seven -- to help Russia sell off its unprofitable large-scale state-owned industries, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen said.
 
To Aid Privatization
 He added that the United States is ready to spend some $500 million on the initiative, with other funding coming from Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy and Japan, as well as the World Bank and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development.
The American initiative also calls for the creation of another international fund to help share the costs of dismantling nuclear weapons in Russia, the Ukraine, Belarus and Kazakhstan.
Despite the American pressure, it is not clear that it will spur others into spending more money. German officials said today that their government, which has provided Russia with more than half of some $80 billion in international support, was unlikely to offer any new bilateral aid at the meeting.
In presenting the United States plans for expanded aid, Mr. Christopher acknowledged that there had been delays on the American side.
Officials said the delays resulted from an initial unwillingness by Mr. Clinton to consult with Congress on the Russian aid issue until his economic stimulus package was passed, and by the death of his father-in-law.
 
Pressure on Japan
 Mr. Bentsen also told reporters that he expects Mr. Clinton to urge Japan to participate in the new American initiatives when he meets Prime Minister Miyazawa Friday in Washington. "Given the strength of the economy, I'm sure the President will be urging them to participate," Mr. Bentsen said.
Mr. Clinton has come up with an entirely new aid package so that he would not open up the United States to criticism that it was doing very little, senior Administration officials said.
Even as the ministers were praising Mr. Yeltsin and his reforms, the war in the Balkans intruded as Douglas Hurd, the British Foreign Secretary, told the group that Mr. Yeltsin needed to reform not only his economy and his political system but also his foreign policy, British officials said.
Later, Mr. Hurd said that Russia must endorse by the end of April a pending Security Council resolution imposing tougher sanctions on the Serbs for their failure to sign the United Nations-brokered peace accord.
But none of the parties to the conference are willing to link aid for Russia to its cooperation on the Balkans.
Officials said Mr. Christopher only mildly raised the possibility that at some point there should be consideration for lifting the United Nations arms embargo in the Balkans in order to "level the playing field" by aiding the lesser-armed Bosnian Muslims.

HEADLINE: Thatcher Assails West's Bosnia Policy

BYLINE: By WILLIAM E. SCHMIDT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 14

 BODY:
In a sudden and furious assault on Western policy in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Lady Thatcher has sharply condemned allied leaders, including her successor as Prime Minister of Britain, saying they lack the resolve to take stronger action on behalf of Bosnia's embattled Muslims.
In two days of television and radio interviews, and remarks late today in the House of Lords, where she now sits as a member, Lady Thatcher urged Britain and its Western allies not only to help arm Bosnian Muslims, but also to support what she described as "aggressive" air strikes against Serbian positions. 
 On Tuesday, in an interview on British television, she went so far as to describe members of the European Community as behaving "a little like accomplices to massacre" because, she said, they had done nothing to stop the killing.
Lady Thatcher's comments, first delivered late Tuesday when she summoned television reporters to her office for interviews, appeared to add fuel to the sometimes convulsive and so far inconclusive debate among Western governments, including the United States, over how to respond to repeated Serbian aggression inside Bosnia, including "ethnic cleansing," or efforts to forcibly displace Muslims from territory the Serbs now claim as their own.
 
The 'Iron Lady' Again
 Lady Thatcher has spoken out before on the need for tougher military steps in Bosnia. But in condemning current Western efforts as inadequate, she unlimbered the kind of no-holds-barred commentary and foreign policy toughness that often marked her tenure as Prime Minister, when she was known as the "Iron Lady."
"If these governments are not moved by those pictures of death and suffering, if they are not moved by the position of ethnic cleansing in Europe, two million refugees, mass graves being found in Croatia, then they should be," she said in a television interview today with NBC News, adding: "We cannot let things go on like this. It is evil."
In Britain, Lady Thatcher's sudden outburst touched off a political dispute as members of Prime Minister John Major's Government moved quickly to the defensive to blunt the fierceness of their former party leader's attack.
Defense Minister Malcolm Rifkind at first described her remarks as "emotional nonsense." In a more politic statement before the House of Commons today, he reiterated existing British policy in Bosnia, and rejected her plea that Britain and its allies lift an international arms embargo against the Bosnian Muslims.
 
A Clash in the Lords
 Late today, Lady Thatcher and Baroness Chalker, the Foreign Office's Minister of State, clashed in the House of Lords. Lady Thatcher rose to challenge Britain's refusal to lift the arms embargo on the Muslims, arguing that it left them "defenseless in the path of a determined dictator-aggressor."
Lady Chalker replied, "It is not a question of leaving people unprotected; it is a question of making sure that we work together to stop an all-out war, which many of the solutions advocated by you could well cause."
Until now, the British Government and Western allies have been reluctant to endorse any increase in military activity against the Serbs, primarily on the ground that it might endanger United Nations peacekeeping missions already in Bosnia, including 2,600 British troops helping to escort supplies of food and medicines to besieged Serbian towns.
Instead, they have favored what one British newspaper described today as a policy of "good intentions and political realism," or relief aid combined with pressure toward some sort of diplomatic or political resolution.
 
'Anger and Pent-Up Rage'
 A former aide to Mrs. Thatcher said her remarks reflected her own "anger and pent-up rage" over the situation in Bosnia, which boiled over after the artillery attack Monday on the Muslim town of Srebrenica, in which more than 50 people were killed and approximately 70 wounded.
Lord Owen, who heads the peace efforts of the European Community, said today that Lady Thatcher seemed to be speaking more out of emotion than reasoned analysis. "Sometimes Lady Thatcher makes it appear very simple," he said. "It is not, unfortunately."
Some Conservative Party members critical of Lady Thatcher said she appeared to be using Bosnia to pummel Mr. Major, with whom she has been at odds in recent months over his support for ratification of the treaty on closer European political and economic cooperation, which she opposes.
Associates of Lady Thatcher say she has become increasingly disenchanted with Mr. Major, whom she picked as her successor in November 1990, when a rebellion in Conservative Party ranks forced her resignation.
Aides to Mr. Major seemed infuriated by remarks Tuesday that what Britain now needed was a Prime Minister like Winston Churchill, whom she described as having "a lionheart."

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Mediator Talks of Air Strikes
 WASHINGTON, April 14 (Special to The New York Times) -- Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans, says the West should consider air strikes against Serbian forces if the Bosnian Serbs refuse to agree to a peace accord.
In an interview with Foreign Affairs, Lord Owen argued that air attacks could be an effective means of persuading the Bosnian Serbs to join a peace settlement.
"We can increase sanctions and perhaps then tilt the balance of force by the use of air power," Lord Owen said in an interview on Feb. 16 with the magazine, a quarterly journal published by the Council on Foreign Relations.
"Tipping the balance to force a recalcitrant party to accept a just and equitable peace package is, in my view, wholly legitimate diplomacy."
Lord Owen's former partner in the negotations, Cyrus R. Vance, has also recently suggested that the use of force could help bring the warring parties to reach a negotiated settlement.
Lord Owen, a former Defense Minister, said, "I don't hold the view of the Pentagon and the British Ministry of Defense that we cannot use air power without also putting in large national ground forces."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Fed Move Nudges Treasuries Up

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Treasury prices moved a little higher yesterday as the Federal Reserve helped support the market by buying Treasury securities.
The discount rates on Treasury bills moved lower for the second straight day as more investors seemed to bet that the economy was growing so slowly that the Federal Reserve might have to reduce short-term interest rates. 
 In secondary trading, the price of the 30-year bond rose 12/32 , to 10424/32 , as the yield fell to 6.75 percent from 6.78 percent on Tuesday. If the price of the long bond rises another third of a point, the yield will drop to 6.72 percent, which was the closing low reached on March 8. The prices of shorter-term Treasury notes were also higher.
On Treasury bills, the discount rate dropped to 2.80 percent for three-month bills and 2.93 percent for six-month bills. Both rates are below the Federal Reserve's 3 percent target for the Federal funds rate, the interest charged on overnight loans between banks and the presumed floor for short-term interest rates.
 
'Good Bid' in the Curve
 "Now that some doubts have crept back into the market about the strength of the economy and the Fed is not likely to tighten interest rates soon, the whole curve is going to have a good bid to it," said Alan Levenson, money market economist at UBS Securities, referring to investor interest in Treasury securities from bills to notes to bonds.
The market was not going anywhere in the morning, as traders and investors waited to see if the Federal Reserve would do what is called a coupon pass -- buy Treasury notes or bonds, which have a coupon, in an effort to add reserves to the banking system. The Fed does this when it is concerned that normal seasonal events, like income tax payments, will alter its monetary policy goals, in this case making them more restrictive than desired.
But such a coupon pass was expected for some time, and the market was disappointed when it did not occur on several other trading days recently. But after noon, the Fed did the buying, and the prices of notes and bonds began to rise.
Mr. Levenson said that for the near term he expected traders and investors to focus on the theme of slower economic growth. Until the employment data for April are released in early May no statistics are expected that could shift the focus because bad weather has had a negative impact on all the March data.
Mr. Levenson said that it would take another run-up in the Commodity Research Bureau's index of commodity prices, which closed yesterday at 211.95, up 0.11, or a surprising decline in initial jobless claims, which are to be released this morning, to shake the market.
"As a tactical short-term matter the market will have a good tone to it until it is clear that the March data were weather washout," he said.
 
Corporate Bonds
 More than $4.8 billion of new corporate bonds have been sold so far this week, according to Technical Data, as the rally in the Treasury market has reawakened interest among corporate treasurers.
But the flood of new issues by the end of the week may turn out to be a little less than expected. And one reason may be that the sluggishness in the economy, as exemplified by the 1 percent decline in March retail sales, is leading more economists and forecasters to suggest that interest rates will fall to new lows before rising again.
"A lot of economists are advising people that rates will be lower," said James B. Quigley, managing director of the global financing desk at Merrill Lynch. "There doesn't seem to be such a sense of urgency."
He said that to open the floodgates to a surge in corporate sales that would match the record volume of $36.78 billion in January, long-term interest rates would have to drop lower and short-term interest rates would have to rise.
The rise in short-term rates, he said, is what it will take to force some companies to decide that it is now cost effective to move their borrowing horizons out to longer maturities along the yield curve.
The impact of the rise of interest rates from mid-March to the end of last week on issuance of new corporate bonds is easily seen in Securities Data Company figures. January's record issuance of $36.78 billion was followed by near records of $34.25 billion in February and $34.41 billion in March, when interest rates hit their recent lows. But by mid April, the pace had dropped to $7.79 billion.

HEADLINE: U.S. ENVOY ISSUES WARNING TO SERBS

BYLINE: By CHUCK SUDETIC, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ZAGREB, Croatia, April 14

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's special envoy to peace negotiations on the former Yugoslavia warned today that the United States would support lifting an arms embargo against Bosnia and Herzegovina unless the Serbian forces who have carved up the country agreed soon to a United Nations peace proposal.
"We are continuing to pursue the diplomatic track," the envoy, Reginald Bartholomew, said here at a news conference. "If the Serbs do not come to terms reasonably soon, we cannot see this as an extended process. We will do our part to pursue the lifting of the arms embargo together with our allies." 
 At a meeting later in Belgrade, Mr. Bartholomew pressed the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, to sign a proposed international peace plan that would reorganize Bosnia into 10 semiautonomous provinces dominated by various ethnic factions. Leaders of the other two factions in the Bosnian war, the Muslims and the Croats, have already agreed to the settlement.
"The Bosnian Serbs have to come to an agreement to the plan now," Mr. Bartholomew said in the Yugoslav capital. "The military and humanitarian horrors have to stop now."
 
Stalling by Serbs Suspected
 But, in what many envoys view as an effort to stall both the United Nations negotiations and calls for tougher action against Serbian forces, Mr. Karadzic again today called for Muslims, Croats and Serbs to enter into direct talks to resolve the Bosnian war without international mediation.
"I'm calling on Muslims and Croats for talks, face to face," he said. "There is no settlement without direct talks."
Scattered Serbian shelling was reported today in Srebrenica, a largely Muslim enclave in eastern Bosnia where thousands of refugees have taken shelter. United Nations monitors quoted by The Associated Press said the Serbian fire had abated somewhat there since Tuesday, when 8 people were killed and 21 were wounded, or on Monday, when more than 50 refugeesin the town were killed, including many women and children.
Monday's attack outraged senior United Nations officials in Bosnia, who charged that the Serbs were willing to kill anyone who lay in their path.
Bosnia's Muslim-led Government has appealed repeatedly to the United Nations Security Council to end the embargo on weapons shipments to Bosnia and other countries of the former Yugoslavia so that its out-gunned forces can defend the towns they still control.
In seizing 70 percent of Bosnia's territory over the last year, Serbian nationalists have relied mainly on tanks, aircraft and heavy artillery supplied by Serbia and Montenegro -- the two republics comprising what remains of Yugoslavia.
The Bosnian Serbs have refused to sign the peace plan because it would commit them to withdrawing from a third of the territory they now hold , including a critical corridor linking Serbia with a huge swath of Serbian-held land in western Bosnia and most of the land that Serbs hold in neighboring Croatia.
Despite growing international condemnation, the Bosnian Serbs have continued an operation of "ethnic cleansing" aimed at expelling the Muslims from eastern Bosnian lands along Serbia's border.
Mr. Bartholomew said that Yugoslavia would face unparalleled economic and diplomatic sanctions if the Serbs did not halt their offensive. Economic sanctions have pushed the Yugoslav economy to the brink of collapse since they were adopted by the United Nations last June, but the Bosnian Serbs and their financial backers in Serbia have shown little willingness to halt the fighting.
"If they persist in these actions, the international community will make of Serbia a pariah state for as far ahead as we can see," Mr. Bartholomew said. "You have very firm, very tightly organized international pressure building up."
 
Balkan Update
 Sporadic shellfire was reported in SREBRENICA yesterday as international pressure mounted to stop Serbian aggression in eastern BOSNIA AND HERZEGOVINA.
At the UNITED NATIONS, a group of countries on the Security Council tried but failed to force an early vote on tighter sanctions against Yugoslavia. Russia wants to delay a vote until April 26.
In BELGRADE, the new United States envoy seeking peace in the Balkans, Reginald Bartholomew, unsuccessfully pressed the leader of the Bosnian Serbs, Radovan Karadzic, to sign a peace settlement for Bosnia. The envoy warned that the United States might seek to lift an embargo and let weapons through to Bosnia's Muslims if the Serbs did not sign soon.
Lady Thatcher drew sharp criticism in LONDON for urging that Britain and its Western allies not only arm the Muslims, but also bomb Serbian positions.
But air strikes were also described as an option by Lord Owen, the European Community's mediator on the Balkans, during an interview in WASHINGTON. President Clinton meanwhile told Congress that he does not expect American planes to engage in combat while enforcing the current ban on flights over Bosnia. NATO aircraft flying from bases in ITALY reported no violations of the flight ban yesterday.

HEADLINE: Union Rule Faces a Rare Fight;
Dear to Labor, Wicks Contracting Law Is Debated in Albany

BYLINE: By SARAH LYALL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 14

 BODY:
As long as there has been a Wicks Law, which is 72 years now, there have been people trying to repeal it.
"It's a horror," said Henry Stern, president of Citizens Union, a nonprofit government monitoring group. He and other opponents of Wicks, which requires local governments to hire at least four separate contractors rather than one general contractor for most projects, say that it inflates construction costs on public projects across the state by $400 million a year.
Despite perennial efforts to rescind the Wicks Law, it has stayed off the legislative agenda for decades, mostly because of the sophisticated lobbying and generous political contributions of its prime beneficiaries -- the state's plumbing, electrical and heating trades. 
 But this year opponents are organizing a new campaign. For the first time in memory, legislators in both houses have introduced a bill to give local governments the option of following the law or not. Most say they would not, given the choice.
Construction trade unions, which have long supported the Wicks Law, are mobilizing for a fight to defend it. The law allows them to negotiate contracts directly with public agencies, instead of having to go through a single general contractor.
Although critics charge that the system results in higher public contracts, the unions argue that the problems in public construction have nothing to do with Wicks and everything to do with inefficient government.
The solution, they say, is for public agencies to send in good contract managers to oversee the agencies' projects and resolve construction disputes.
The opponents of the law are trying to bolster their case by citing a new report from one of the most active public building agencies in the state, the New York City School Construction Authority. The authority was exempted from the Wicks Law four years ago by the Legislature as a kind of experiment to test whether the law creates as much inefficiency as opponents claim.
That experiment has a year more to run. But in the meantime, the authority has just completed a study of the impact of the Wicks Law on other agencies in New York City and concluded that projects exempted from Wicks cost 13 percent less and were completed an average of 15.6 months more quickly than Wicks projects.
 
Opponents Are Encouraged
 The report, prepared by a team of outside economists hired by the construction authority, based its findings on an analysis of 163 public projects built in New York City during the 1980's, like housing, schools and firehouses. Eighty-six of the projects were subject to Wicks; 77 were not, because some agencies are exempt from the law or are only required to follow it for some of their projects.
Though the consultants said they would not be able to complete their analysis of the authority's own experience until next year, when the five-year experiment is up, their study, which the authority describes as the most comprehensive study of the law ever conducted, has greatly encouraged Wicks's opponents.
"This report strongly supports our contention that state and local agencies should be given the choice to build with or without the Wicks Law provision," said State Senator Roy M. Goodman, a Manhattan Republican, who is sponsoring the bill with Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat.
 
Multiple Contracts Required
 Most states handle public construction by hiring a general contractor, who in turn hires and oversees subcontractors for specialized work like plumbing and air conditioning.
But New York's multiple contract law, first passed in 1921 in response to corruption in the construction industry, forbids that practice by requiring that the governments negotiate directly with at least four contractors: a general contractor and contractors for heating, electrical and plumbing work. In 1946, a measure sponsored by State Senator Arthur H. Wicks expanded the law to include public housing.
The law was supposed to lower costs for the public by encouraging competition among contractors. But its opponents say that its drawbacks soon became apparent.
"When you have a problem on the job, it's very difficult to identify the responsible individual," said Rudolph J. Rinaldi, New York City's Commissioner of Buildings. "The different groups all have their own ambitions. They're not concerned about the project, but about their own profit and their own schedule."
 
Pipes Burst Amid Argument
 In a classic case, the city says, a $3.7 million project to build 88 units of housing for the homeless in the Bronx in 1988 was delayed for months while the plumbing contractor and the general contractor squabbled about whose job it was to shut off the pipes during the winter.
While they argued, a city report said, "the pipes froze, causing substantial damage to the plumbing system, walls, ceilings, hardwood floors, tiles, kitchen cabinets and paint." The plumber refused to repair the damage, was charged for it anyway, and later sued the city.
In another example cited by critics, a Queens sanitation garage was finished in 1991, six years after contracts were awarded under Wicks rules. The electrical contractor at one point walked off the job, resulting in several months' delay, even though that contractor was responsible for only 3 percent of the work. The report said that a single general contractor could have forced the subcontractor to do the job by withholding payment.
But the trades, who chafe under the firm grip of general contractors, say that the public agencies, not the Wicks law, are to blame.
"It has really become a scapegoat for construction problems that have nothing to do with Wicks," said George V. Whalen, executive director of the Plumbing Foundation of the City of New York, who says that the problem isn't the law, but rather public agencies' inability to properly manage construction.
 
Price Shopping Is Feared
 Mr. Whalen and others also say that the single-contract system leads to a practice called price shopping, in which general contractors negotiate a contract for a project, then go back and force the subcontractors to lower their bids to keep the job. The subcontractors are thus under pressure to cut corners while the general contractor keeps the profit, he said.
In a 1991 report, lobbyists for the Wicks Law cited the success of a $40 million project to build a command center at Rikers Island: there were 12 contractors, and all their bids totaled $2 million less than the city's Department of General Services had budgeted. According to the report, the project was completed on time and 8 of the 12 contractors received bonuses for finishing ahead of schedule. The report said the efficiency was due to the city's staying deeply involved in the project and hiring an efficient construction coordinator.
The new Sanders-Goodman bill may well face an uphill battle in the Legislature, whose members have traditionally been loath to offend the generous trade groups.
The trade groups say that for every report concluding that the Wicks Law wastes money, there is a counter-report saying the opposite.
 
Debate and Influence
 "It's comical how everybody gets in and fights over this," said Denis M. Hughes, executive assistant to Edward J. Cleary, the president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O. "There is nothing that shows conclusively that repealing the law will save money over long periods of time, and yet the issue has taken on a life of its own."
But beyond the substantive debate, the unions plan to use old-fashioned political influence in their cause. The unions are a mainstay of political support for legislators in both parties in Albany, reliably giving money to both parties each year, attending fund-raising events and providing manpower at election time for phone banks, pamphleteering and the like.
Legislative leaders, who thought they had successfully managed to put off the issue until 1994, when the School Construction Authority is to release its final report, said that they were taking a wait-and-see attitude toward the interim report and would take up the issue when they returned from their vacation next week.
'All three sides agreed when we did the school construction bill for New York City that we wouldn't do anything until we heard what their experience was," said John E. MacArdle, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino. "But he's willing to look at any proposals that are out there."

HEADLINE: Chile: Japan's Backdoor to the West

SERIES: Japan: The Consummate Trader: Two Case Studies -- Second of two articles.

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
Reaching across thousands of miles of the Pacific, Japan and Chile have been quietly forming close economic and political ties in the last two years, ties that potentially challenge the long-standing dominance of the American business presence here.
Since 1991, Japan has become Chile's largest export market as everything from fish meal to refined copper to wine is making its way to Japan, and surpassing Chile's exports to the United States, which, with one exceptional year, had dominated trade with Chile for the last 20 years or so.
Both big and small Japanese companies, ranging from the Mitsubishi Corporation to the Sakata Seed Company have made commitments in the last two years to sink $700 million into Chile, more than all Japanese investment in Chile in the last two decades. And the number of Japanese companies operating here in the last three years has almost doubled, to 55.
 
Foothold for Japan
 The new relationship, though relatively small in global trade terms, has some trade experts trying to figure out how Chileans have been able to penetrate the Japanese market, often closed to American exporters.
[President Clinton has criticized Japan's barriers and will undoubtedly tell the Japanese Prime Minister that Japan must buy more American goods when they meet on April 16.]
Indeed, some in Washington are concerned that by establishing closer ties with Chile, Japan is getting an important foothold in Latin America, expanding its economic influence and potentially getting the biggest share of mineral, paper and fishing resources well into the next century.
Others worry that Japan will improperly use business ties with Chile as a back door to the North American free trade zone envisioned for Canada, Mexico and America.
"Chile has to push itself to move even closer to the Pacific Basin," Terusuke Terada, the senior officer at the Japanese Foreign Ministry in charge of Latin American affairs, said in an interview recently in Chile's leading newspaper, El Mercurio. "No other Latin American nation could do this kind of mission."
Whatever the motive, the number of deals by Japanese companies is growing almost monthly.
The Sumitomo Metal Mining Company, joined the Phelps Dodge Corporation of Phoenix in a $1.5 billion investment signed last year in La Candelaria mining project near the northern city of Copaipo, which will become a huge copper and gold mining operation. In 1991, Sumitomo, Sanyo Kokusaku of Tokyo and Chilean investors created a $57 million joint venture in land and a wood chip factory in southern Chile to export wood chips to Japan.
Last year, the giant Japanese paper concern, Daio Paper, completed an investment of $70 million for more than 160,000 acres in southern Chile, on which it is planting eucalyptus and pine. C. Itoh & Company is a 10 percent partner in the investment.
The Mitsubishi group took a 20 percent stake in the $1 billion Escondida copper mine in the North, which started producing in 1991. The company, which also owns pulp mills, was awarded a $150 million contract last year by Chile's state-owned power company, Chilgener, to build a power generating plant.
Even small Japanese companies are entering Chile.
Sakata Seed, a unit of the Nissho Iwai group of Tokyo, moved here in 1992 and is developing better strains of vegetable seeds to ship to Japan.
And Nito Seimo, a tiny maker of commercial fishing nets, transferred a third of its assets here and is selling to the local market in the northern city of Iquique.
"We have 4,000 kilometers of coast on the Pacific Basin," said Fernan Ibanez, who stepped down last month as executive director of the Government's Foreign Investment Committee. "The Japanese tell us that if it weren't for the ocean, we would be neighbors. If you just look at the growth numbers of the countries there, we have to move more in that direction."
What Japan finds attractive are Chile's big natural resources of minerals, lumber, fish and agricultural products, riches Japan sorely lacks. Also, the Japanese hope to use Chile, along with Mexico, to circumvent tariff barriers in the Latin American market and ultimately into the North American market. And the Japanese consider Chileans to be industrious, honest and concerned with quality control.
"Japan is surrounded by water and that has made us a more closed society," said Koji Mizuno, president of Mitsubishi here. "If you look at Chile, it is surrounded by water and mountains, and Chileans also tend to be a closed society. Chileans are honest, very hard workers, very shy and timid, like Japanese. Chileans are sentimental about lifetime employment and loyalty, like Japan. We are much more comfortable doing business with Chile than other countries."
Mitsubishi found in its investment in the Escondida copper mine that using Chilean contractors, the project was finished six months ahead of time and $150 million under budget.
 
A Shift for Chile, Too
 For its part, Chile, with the most robust economy in Latin America, has turned more attention to the Pacific Basin countries, particularly Japan, hoping Chile will be the "bridge" of choice for the Pacific Basin countries into Latin America.
Chile is not the only country trying to lure investment from Japan, Hong Kong and other Asian countries. Late last month, President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru announced he would waive a two-year waiting list for foreigners applying for naturalization in an effort to attract skilled professionals. And Mr. Fujimori is actively negotiating with Japanese businesses on investments in Peru's privatization program.
After Mr. Fujimori's seizure of near dictatorial powers last April, the Japanese Government did not withdraw hundreds of millions of dollars in vital foreign aid at a time when the rest of the international community was isolating Mr. Fujimori.
Many Chileans welcome the Japanese as good corporate citizens, noting plans by Daio paper and other Japanese to reforest 250,000 acres in southern Chile.
But some companies have recently been cutting native forests, and Japanese fishing companies are periodically accused of over-fishing the Pacific off Chile's territorial waters.
There have also been accusations of illegal purchases by Japanese of tons of locos, a large, tasty Chilean mollusk that is secretly shipped to Japan, seriously depleting an endangered shellfish.
 
Favorable Trade Balance
 Chile's balance of trade with Japan last year was a $733 million surplus, compared with a $336 million deficit with the United States. Next year, Chile will become the first Latin American country to export fresh fruit to Japan, having met the rigorous import inspection standards. A visit to Tokyo last November by President Patricio Aylwin was the first by a Chilean head of state.
The closer ties to Chile in many ways reflect a new look at all of Latin America by Japan, after many Japanese businesses suffered huge losses in 1980's when governments and corporations defaulted on loans and debt.
For years, Japan has been concentrating investment in Mexico because the country borders the huge United States market. And it has been cautiously reinvesting in Argentina, buying interests in fishing and building the luxury Cesar Park Hotel in Buenos Aires, as it waits to see whether the deep economic changes and anti-inflation policies of President Carlos Saul Menem will last.
"They are investing little by little, but I don't know if it is an investment of large scale," said Kazuo Omi, general manager of the Bank of Tokyo. "This is a time of being very conservative. They don't want to expand either in Japan or abroad. They don't want to run new risks."
 
Political Insurance
 As for Chile, the Japanese seem intent on insuring that the current political environment continues after presidential elections in December.
In an extraordinary push to the front-running candidate, Eduardo Frei, a member of the Aylwin coalition and son of a former Chilean president, the Japanese Government has invited him to visit, just months before the election, in what amounts to something just short of a presidential-style visit.
"Frei is seen as the continuation of what now exists, and that as a businessman he might bring even more ideas," said a Government official who asked not to be identified. "This is Japan trying to make sure a good formula does not change."

HEADLINE: Stephen P. Taylor, 69, Economist And Federal Reserve Statistician

BYLINE: By BRUCE LAMBERT

 BODY:
Stephen P. Taylor, an economist and a retired official of the Federal Reserve System, died last Friday at a hospital in Arlington, Va., his hometown. He was 69.
He died of injuries suffered in a fall from a bicycle, his family said. 
 Mr. Taylor worked for 32 years at the Federal Reserve's headquarters in Washington in the Flow of Funds and Saving Section, which he headed from 1961 until he retired in 1985.
The flow-of-funds system tries to track all significant parts of the economy, including borrowing, lending, saving and investment. Other countries have adopted the system.
Mr. Taylor integrated the statistics into a single system and was responsible for its early computerization. He also helped to develop the United Nations' national capital finance accounts, and devised a measure of private holdings of credit instruments called the Kaufman debt proxy.
 
Head of Statisticians Group
 He became assistant director of the Federal Reserve's Research and Statistics Division, and was president of the Group of Financial Statisticians of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an international group based in Paris.
In retirement, he was a consultant on balance-of-payments discrepancies for the International Monetary Fund, helped Indonesia on statistics for the Agency for International Development and last year joined a mission to Kyrgyzstan in the former Soviet Union for the World Bank's first report on the new nation.
Mr. Taylor was born in White Plains. He served in the Marines after graduating from Cornell University in 1944 and received a master's degree from Columbia University in 1949.
His first wife, Natalie, died in 1989. He is survived by his second wife, Phyllis; three daughters, Carol Taylor of Eureka, Calif., Valerie Taylor of San Rafael, Calif., and Wendy Kafka of McGrath, Minn.; a sister, Mary T. Peterman of White Plains; six grandchildren; two stepchildren, Henry D. Lockhart 3d and Melissa L. Harlow, and four stepgrandchildren.

HEADLINE: Raises at Fed Are Criticized

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 14

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve, the Government agency charged with controlling inflation, has given its employees raises nearly two-thirds greater than last year's inflation rate, the chairman of the House Banking Committee said today.
In a letter of complaint to President Clinton, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, a Texas Democrat, said the Fed staff members who report to the board of governors in Washington would get 4.8 percent raises this year. Employees who work for the Fed's 12 regional banks would get raises of 4.3 percent. 
 Those rates compare with an inflation rate of 2.9 percent in 1992. Wages and salaries nationally, as measured by the Labor Department's Employment Cost Index, rose just 2.7 percent last year. Other Federal employees received a 3.7 percent increase in January.
"There is a certain irony about the nation's chief inflation fighters giving themselves raises greater than the rate of inflation," Mr. Gonzalez wrote. He has introduced legislation that would bring the Fed under greater scrutiny.
Mr. Gonzalez also complained that 12 senior Fed staff members in Washington would earn $161,800 this year, considerably more than Cabinet officers, who receive $148,400, and Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, who will earn $133,400.
In a March 11 letter to Mr. Gonzalez, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed's salary structure was intended to retain senior employees who could draw top pay in private jobs.

HEADLINE: Strictest Curb on Smoking In U.S. Backed by Cuomo

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 14

 BODY:
Citing new information about the dangers of secondhand tobacco smoke, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed legislation today that would prohibit smoking in schools and many restaurants and prevent advertising for tobacco products on all billboards and signs.
If passed, the proposal would give New York State the toughest laws in the nation governing smoking in restaurants and advertising for tobacco products, Mr. Cuomo's aides, restaurant organizations and several anti-smoking groups said. The New York City Council and several state legislatures have already passed laws prohibiting smoking in schools. 
 But the plan is almost certain to face opposition from an array of groups, including those representing the tobacco, restaurant and advertising industries. And the New York Civil Liberties Union said today that Mr. Cuomo's proposed restrictions on advertising would be overly broad and would violate the tobacco industry's right to free speech.
"A total prohibition cannot survive constitutional scrutiny because there are less drastic alternatives that New York State has at its disposal," said Norman Siegel, executive director of the civil liberties group.
Mr. Cuomo said he was motivated largely by a recent report by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency showing that secondhand tobacco smoke causes the deaths of an estimated 3,000 nonsmokers a year and subjects hundreds of thousands of children to respiratory disease.
Mr. Cuomo has pushed tough anti-smoking proposals in the past, not always with success. Last year, a proposal to ban smoking in schools and to require the tobacco industry to help pay for anti-smoking advertisements failed in the state Senate.
 
Skepticism in Senate
 Today, leaders of the Republican-controlled Senate said they were concerned about the economic impact of Mr. Cuomo's proposal on small businesses and restaurants, particularly because the Legislature recently approved a 17-cent-per-pack increase in cigarette taxes. That increase will give New York State the highest cigarette tax in the country, 56 cents per pack.
Bill Stevens, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, Republican from Muttontown, said a ban on signs and items advertising cigarettes could hurt sales at newsstands and candy stores. "If mom-and-pop stores are going to be hurt by the imposition of an additional 17-cent tax, is this going to further hurt them?" Mr. Stevens said. "It is one thing to sheer the sheep; it's another to simply to cut off its head."
But Mr. Cuomo said the E.P.A. study "ought to change some minds" by providing "clear proof" that children are hurt by adults' smoking.
"The Senate is very sensitive to lobbyists," he said in an interview today. "I foresee trouble whenever people with a lot of wealth who are willing to invest in lobbying efforts line up against you. That's what will happen here."
 
Broadening the Rules
 The proposal would broaden existing state restrictions on smoking in several important ways. First, it would prevent smoking inside schools and on school grounds, public or private. Current law allows adults to smoke in designated areas of schools and outside of school buildings. The proposal would also prevent smoking in a number of places frequented by children, including indoor zoos, youth centers and child-care centers.
In a provision aimed largely at fast-food restaurants and other family-style eating places, the plan would ban smoking in all restaurants that do not have full liquor licenses. And for restaurants with 50 or more seats, it would require a separate room for smokers. The current law allows for designated smoking sections.
The proposal would also prohibit smoking anywhere in public transportation terminals and food stores. And it would outlaw the sale of individual cigarettes, known as "loosies."
"This would make New York State the leader nationally on protecting the public from the dangers of secondhand smoke," said Blair Horner, legislative director for the New York Public Interest Research Group.
The proposal is expected to receive the support of the union representing most of the state's public school teachers, which could provide an important boost in the Legislature. "I'm sure there will be teachers who will be unhappy, but we are interested in people's health," said Linda Rosenblatt, spokeswoman for the New York State United Teachers.
But a spokeswoman for a tobacco industry trade association called the proposal "severe" and unconstitutional.
"I can think of no other state with regulations that are so far reaching," said Brennan Dawson of the Tobacco Institute in Washington.
Fred Sampson, president of the New York State Restaurant Association, which represents about 6,000 food businesses, said the proposal would drive customers away from businesses that prohibit smoking and create problems for larger restaurants required to build separate smoking rooms.
Esthetic concerns, for instance, might prevent restaurants such as Le Cirque and the Rainbow Room, with their grand dining rooms, from creating walled-off sections for smokers, he said.
"Cigarettes are not our business, but hospitality is," Mr. Sampson said. "We would have to enforce a law that would put us in a very uncomfortable position."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The Labor Secretary's Spin On Jobs Data Lifts Eyebrows

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
At a time when the economic outlook is confused and the President's economic stimulus package faces opposition, it should come as no surprise that the Clinton Administration is eager to put its own spin on politically charged economic statistics.
Most administrations do. 
 But a recent episode at the Labor Department has touched off much clucking within the economics community and within the department itself.
 
 
An Inconvenient Fact
 On March 5, just half an hour before the acting commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics was due to testify on February employment statistics, Labor Secretary Robert Reich held his own special news conference. The February figures showed that the economy had created 365,000 new jobs in February, the biggest monthly gain in years -- a politically inconvenient fact for an Administration fighting for a big new jobs program.
The commissioner's testimony was fairly upbeat. In contrast, Mr. Reich maintained that while there were job gains in February, they did not make the stimulus program redundant because "90 percent of the new jobs that have been created are in involuntary part time, that is, the contingent work force."
This claim took many of the economists in his agency by surprise. As it turns out, there was no way for anyone to know what proportion of the payroll jobs were part-time, since the Labor Department simply does not ask businesses whether their payroll jobs are full- or part-time when it surveys them each month.
But Mr. Reich and his chief economist, Lawrence Katz, a labor economist from Harvard University, derived the 90 percent statistic by going to a second Government survey, the so-called household survey by the Census Bureau, which asks individuals whether they worked in the previous month and, if so, whether they worked full time or part time.
But that survey produces totally separate data, and conclusions drawn from that data cannot be applied to the business payroll survey; for a variety of reasons, trends in one do not necessarily track trends in the other.
But that is what Mr. Reich and Mr. Katz did. They took the one-month jump in the number of Americans who said they were employed part time because they could not find full-time jobs, and applied it to that month's increase in the total number of Americans who said that they had jobs in February.
Their 90 percent figure was picked up by major news organizations and widely repeated as fact for weeks afterward.
The fact that the Labor Secretary had put out such a statistic created a furor among the department's career economists and statisticians. They drafted an internal memorandum -- for use in answering telephone queries -- to explain why one could not conclude what Mr. Reich had concluded from the data.
"The rise in total employment may have been largely persons working part time for economic reasons, or it could have been all new full-time workers," the internal memo said. "We are unable to explicitly link the two movements."
 
 
Volatile Data
 What many of these economists and statisticians recognized is that the part-time data are extremely volatile from month to month, and that the rise in February was a blip that followed a sharp move in the opposite direction the previous month.
As the department's internal memorandum put it: "The trend over approximately the last year and a half has been flat, at a level of about 6.4 million even with periodic sharp monthly fluctuations (like this month for instance)."
Mr. Katz, for one, now admits that the calculation was indeed an error. "The notion that a lot of jobs created in this recovery are temporary and part time is an accurate perception," he said. But in using the 90 percent figure, he continued, "we made a mistake."
Economists outside the Labor Department were also quick to attack the Labor Secretary's calculations.
"How come they didn't say in the previous month that there was a big decline and this was a monthly blip?" asked Marvin Kosters, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute, who had been chosen by President Bush to be the next Commissioner of the Bureau of Labor Statistics had he won re-election.
And Steven Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley, called the Labor Secretary's approach "shenanigans."
 
 
'Cooking the Numbers'
 "It smacks of cooking the numbers when it's convenient to do so, but walking away from reality when it doesn't fit the script," Mr. Roach said. "It's unconscionable for a Cabinet level department at a critical juncture."
Some economists, however, said the episode reminded them of the time in 1971, during the Nixon Administration, when the Labor Secretary canceled the traditional briefing by the economist in charge of the monthly employment report. Instead, the secretary issued his own rosy interpretation of some disappointing statistics. At that time, in 1971, much like today, unemployment was proving particularly stubborn.
 
Changing Course
 In any case, Mr. Reich did not use the same approach this month, when the March jobs data were released.
"Using his methodology, the economy would have created 255,000 full-time jobs in March," said Mr. Roach of Morgan Stanley, pointing out that such an inference would have been ridiculous, though no more so than the contrary claim of the prior month.
Indeed, an April 2 public statement released by the Bureau of Labor Statistics sets the record straight from the Labor Department's perspective. Involuntary part-time employment, it said, has bobbed around the same level for a year and a half. And 25 percent -- not 90 percent -- of the payroll jobs created in the last year or so have sprouted in temporary help firms. And finally, it said, despite no further gains on either the unemployment or jobs-creation fronts in March, "the general trend in recent months has been one of slow improvement."

HEADLINE: Outside the Gates, Losing A Definition of Security

BYLINE: By ARI L. GOLDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: EAST HARTFORD, April 14

 BODY:
The manufacturing operation at the Pratt & Whitney headquarters here is known as the mother plant, the oldest and largest of Pratt & Whitney factories. The jet engines that rolled out of its bays led the world in aviation technology.
Over the last decade, company employees have grown accustomed to layoff notices. Today, they had to absorb the most shocking news of all: The plant itself may have to close, with a loss of 2,200 jobs. 
 Under the plan, administrative offices, engineering and experimental testing would remain open at a down-scaled headquarters operation here. Manufacturing would continue at other sites.
For Herbert Nolan, a 37-year-old machinist who has worked at the plant for 20 years, the news was unthinkable.
 
Once, Real Job Security
 "When I got out of high school, my uncle said, 'Get over to East Hartford,' " Mr. Nolan recalled, nursing a beer at Hockanum Restaurant, near the main gate of the plant. " 'If you have a job there,' he told me, 'you are set for life. Between Government contracts and commercial contracts, there will always be work.' "
Now, he said, people with 25 or 30 years' experience are being let go. "People are afraid to go out to dinner with their families, let alone buy a car," he said. "It's too risky."
Mr. Nolan was one of six patrons at the vast U-shaped bar at 3:30 this afternoon, the hour when the morning shift ends and the evening shift begins. The scene at the bar told part of the story.
"In our heyday, there was a line out the door and it was three deep at the bar," said the bartender, Jamie Valbona. It's not just that they don't come in anymore, she said; "There aren't many left."
James Parent, a spokesman for the union that represents most of the workers in the plant, said that he had seen the plant shrink from 22,000 when he was hired in 1965 to about 2,200 today.
The union, District 91 of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, announced that it would do everything it could to keep the plant open, but employees leaving the gate after the morning shift were not hopeful.
"People are scared in there," said Lisa Biveinis, a secretary who has been with the company three years. "Everybody's wondering what's going to happen. I'm thinking about getting my resume in shape. I don't want to wait until they lay me off."
But another employee said that some last-minute agreement or change in the economy might yet save the plant. "This is kind of like the New England weather," said Norman Pietruska, an engineer with Pratt & Whitney for 10 years. "You never know what's coming."
Few expressed bitterness toward the company. At the bar, Mr. Nolan ticked off the names of many relatives who had enjoyed long and steady careers with Pratt & Whitney: three uncles, two aunts and numerous cousins. Still he said that he expected a layoff notice soon. "When I get it," he said, "I plan to open my own business. That way I know I won't get laid off."
At an East Hartford automobile dealership on Connecticut Boulevard, two salesman sympathized with the families of Pratt employees.
"They've worked there, their fathers worked there, their fathers' fathers worked there," said Roger Donzello, "and now, not to have a there is a terrible, emotional thing."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
HILTON HOTELS CORP. (N)

 BODY:
The Hilton Hotels Corporation, based in Beverly Hills, Calif., reported a 19 percent increase yesterday in its first-quarter net income, to $26.5 million, or 55 cents a share. The earnings were in line with analysts' expectations of 50 to 60 cents a share. But before the cumulative effect of accounting changes, the earnings were equivalent to 48 cents a share, a bit less than the analysts had forecast.
The company adopted two accounting changes at the beginning of the year, one for income taxes, which lifted net income by $8 million, and one for retirees' benefits, which resulted in a charge of $4.6 million after a deferred tax benefit of $2.3 million. 
 Operating income rose 13 percent to $54.6 million, from $48.5 million a year earlier.
"Our gaming segment continues to perform well," said Barron Hilton, chairman and chief executive, "while results from the hotels division are down slightly," hampered by overbuilding and the weak economy. The gaming division's operating income increased 18 percent to $48.3 million in the quarter, from $40.8 million a year earlier. The hotel division's operating income slipped 3 percent to $12.8 million, from $13.2 million.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
First Fidelity to Buy Peoples Bank

BYLINE: By JEANNE B. PINDER

 BODY:
Continuing an aggressive expansion campaign, the First Fidelity Bancorp, based in Lawrenceville, N.J., said yesterday that it would acquire Peoples Westchester Savings Bank, based in Hawthorne, N.Y., for $233 million in cash and stock.
The offer price, of either $43.90 in cash or 0.8693 share in First Fidelity, was considered disappointing by some analysts since it did not offer a premium to Peoples' stock prices. 
 Shares of Peoples Westchester fell $2.25 in Nasdaq trading yesterday, to $41. Peoples had turned down an offer of $30 a share from an investor group in January. First Fidelity closed at $50.125 yesterday, down 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
"Peoples Westchester was down because the deal was struck very close to the current market, and recent speculation had the price much higher," said Frank R. DeSantis Jr., an analyst with Donaldson Lufkin & Jenrette. "And on First Fidelity, for right or for wrong, the market is taking a show-me attitude. Any time you close a deal where you issue stock, you create near-term uncertainty about the effect on earnings per share."
 
Bank Supports Deal
 The sale needs approval from regulators and shareholders of Peoples Westchester, whose management said it would support the First Fidelity offer.
First Fidelity has been expanding broadly over the last year and a half, becoming one of the nation's fastest-growing regional banks, with $30 billion in assets making it the 25th-largest bank holding company in the country.
Yesterday's move, combined with the purchase of Village Financial Services of Port Chester, N.Y., and several American Savings Bank branches, makes First Fidelity the second-biggest bank in the Westchester market behind the Bank of New York.
Anthony P. Terracciano, chairman and chief executive, said more expansion was likely. "I'd like to see the franchise stretch from Boston down to Baltimore if that's possible," he said.
First Fidelity reported on Tuesday that its first-quarter net income increased 41 percent to $95 million, or $1.12 a share.
Peoples Westchester, a $1.8 billion savings bank with 32 Westchester County offices, has done well despite the economic downturn in the Northeast. It has been discussed as a takeover prospect at least since the beginning of the year.
Nancy A. Bush of Brown Brothers Harriman said "there was nothing about this deal to hate." She also said further acquisitions were to be expected from First Fidelity.
"Their weakest link right now is Bergen County, which is an area they're quite interested in, and I'm sure they're scouting out deals there," she said. "They will continue to consolidate their ring around New York City, in the more affluent commuter suburbs, where they cannot only emphasize lending, but also private banking and trust services."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Shares Drop As Goodrich Reports Loss

BYLINE: JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:
The B. F. Goodrich Company reported a $7.6 million first-quarter loss yesterday, a surprise that led to heavy morning selling of its stock. Its shares tumbled $3.125, to $44.875, in early trading on the New York Stock Exchange but later partly recovered to close at $46.875, off $1.125.
The loss was far deeper than the operating loss of $1.9 million reported in the first quarter of 1992, when a $286.5 million charge for adopting a new accounting standard for retiree health-care benefits resulted in a net loss of $288.4 million. First-quarter sales fell 1.4 percent, to $596.8 million, from $605.3 million a year earlier. 
 Leonard Bogner, senior chemical analyst at Prudential Securities, called the results "a major disappointment."
"We saw a loss, but this is worse" than expected, Mr. Bogner said.
The loss was equivalent to 38 cents a share, compared with a forecast loss of 10 to 15 cents a share. For the year, Mr. Bogner sees "an orderly pattern of real earnings," with a sharp bounce back in the second quarter.
 
Subsidiary Turns Around
 Goodrich, based in Akron, Ohio, provides aircraft systems, components and services and manufactures a wide range of specialty chemicals.
Its subsidiary, the Geon Company, makes compounds used in construction products, business machine components and appliance parts. That business turned around in the quarter, reporting an operating income of $2.2 million, in contrast to a loss of $500,000 a year earlier.
Goodrich said it planned to offer 50 percent of Geon's stock to the public and to use the proceeds to expand its aerospace and specialty chemicals businesses.
One reason for the selloff on Wall Street yesterday morning, Mr. Bogner said, was "disenchantment on the part of analysts that they are selling it off" at this stage.
 
Rebound Expected
 Many people had been following the company "in expectation of an up-cycle in chemicals," he said, especially the commodity chemicals represented by Geon. The two other businesses are underperforming, he said.
The aerospace segment had operating income of $16.6 million in the quarter, down from a record $22.7 million a year earlier, when the Persian Gulf war lifted sales. The specialty chemicals business essentially broke even for the quarter, the company said, down from operating income of $5.4 million a year ago.
John D. Ong, the company chairman, said: "Our aerospace businesses continue to meet our expectations, and we should achieve record income this year for the 10th consecutive year. Many of our specialty chemicals businesses also performed well during the quarter, but results for the segment over all continue to be hurt by weak demand in construction-related markets and by generally poor economic conditions in Canada and Europe."

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Yields of Money Funds Off As Inflation Worries Ease

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were down in the latest week, reflecting some easing of investor fears about inflation, according to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report.
Tax-exempt money fund yields fell sharply in the week that ended Tuesday. The IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield for a tax-exempt fund fell 9 basis points, to 1.89 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield also down 9 basis points, to 1.86 percent. The 30-day average compounded yield is 1.94 percent and the simple yield 1.92 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent. 
 Not including state and local taxes, the taxable bond equivalent for the average seven-day yield is about 2.63 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket and about 2.74 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
 
Outflow Considered Small
 Tax-exempt fund assets fell $326 million to $103.5 billion. The outflow was considered small, said Walter S. Frank, chief economist at The Money Fund Report. Lower yields elsewhere kept more money from flowing out, he said.
Money fund managers elected to hold their tax-exempt positions, and the average days left to maturity of securities held in portfolios was unchanged, at 50, for the second consecutive week.
Among the tax-exempt funds with assets greater than $100 million, The Money Fund Report said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund was the top performer this week, with a yield of 2.58 percent, down 4 basis points from last week's best.
Assets of taxable money market funds rose by $1 billion in the week ended yesterday, to a total of $483.5 billion, with assets of institutional funds up by $2.1 billion, and retail assets down by $1.1 billion.
The money moving out of retail funds is probably coming out for tax purposes, among other things, analysts at The Money Fund Report said.
 
Higher Yields Sought
 Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios rose to 62, from 60, as managers sought higher yields in the longer maturities.
IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded yield on a taxable fund slipped 3 basis points, to 2.68 percent, with the seven-day simple yield also down 3 basis points, to 2.64 percent.
Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund had the highest return among general purpose taxable money funds, with a yield of 3.47 percent.
For the purpose of comparison, banks are offering an average yield of 2.59 percent. The yield is down a basis point from a week earlier.
