HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Edges Up as Talks Open Among the Group of 7

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar advanced modestly but broadly yesterday in trading driven mostly by technical factors. The trading occurred as finance ministers of seven of the world's leading industrial nations began a two-day meeting in Tokyo.
The meeting of representatives of the Group of Seven served "as a background deterrent to selling the dollar," particularly against the Japanese yen, said Randolph Donney, research director at Pegasus Econometric Group in Hoboken, N.J. 
 Mr. Donney said there were unconfirmed reports that the group was working on an agreement to support the dollar against the Japanese yen, should the American currency fall sharply.
 
Fine-Tuning the Yen
 The United States and many of Japan's other trading partners have advocated a stronger yen to combat trade imbalances by raising the foreign prices of Japanese goods, and the yen has advanced about 10 percent in the last three months.
"But that hasn't done anything to help the trade imbalance," Mr. Donney said. On Tuesday, Tokyo announced an economic-stimulus package that had elements intended to help trim the huge trade surplus with the United States.
"The market is just bracing itself for what comes out of the G-7 meeting," Mr. Donney said. The week will culminate in President Clinton's meeting in Washington tomorrow with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan.
 
German Sales Down Sharply
 The German mark was depressed by a report that retail sales there plunged 8 percent in February compared with those a year ago. The British pound gained against other European currencies, as London reported a 1.6 percent jump in industrial production for the month of February.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 113.47 yen, up 0.14 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, it rose to 113.90 yen. In New York the dollar settled at 113.88 yen, up from 113.40 yen on Tuesday.
The pound fell in London to $1.5520 from $1.5591 late Tuesday. In New York it cost $1.5515 to buy a pound, down from Tuesday's $1.5580.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday rates, included: 1.5935 German marks, up from 1.5820; 1.4590 Swiss francs, up from 1.4475; 5.3885 French francs, up from 5.3495; 1,544 Italian lire, up from 1,524, and 1.2630 Canadian dollars, up from 1.2615.

HEADLINE: Stormy Caterpillar Meeting

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., April 14

 BODY:
Caterpillar Inc. and angry union members sparred orally today as company officers tried to convince shareholders that long-term prospects were bright despite 1992 losses.
At an annual meeting held under heavy security, Caterpillar's chairman, Donald V. Fites, said the company had to reach a labor contract that recognized a global marketplace. 
 A five-month strike by 11,000 United Auto Workers union members ended April 14, 1992, after Caterpillar, based in Peoria, Ill., threatened to hire replacement workers. The employees have since been working without a contract. At the meeting, both sides said they were ready to resume bargaining, but neither indicated that would happen soon.
Mr. Fites was peppered with remarks and questions from U.A.W. members. The "vast majority" of Caterpillar union members want a chance to vote on the company's last contract proposal, he told shareholders and union members.
Because of a three-year $1.8 billion factory modernization program and management changes, Mr. Fites said, Caterpillar is poised to show a profit when the United States and world economies rebound. In 1992, it lost $2.43 billion after adopting new accounting standards for post-retirement benefits and deferred income taxes. Without the accounting changes, it would have shown a loss of $190 million, compared with a loss of $404 million after charges in 1991.

HEADLINE: Wallace Stegner Is Dead at 84; Pulitzer Prize-Winning Author

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN

 BODY:
Wallace Stegner, the novelist and short-story writer whose work celebrated the American West and won him the country's highest literary awards, died on Tuesday night at St. Vincent Hospital in Santa Fe, N.M. He was 84 and lived in Los Altos Hills, Calif.
The cause of death was respiratory failure, said Lynn Stegner, his daughter-in-law. On March 28, Mr. Stegner was seriously injured in a traffic accident in Santa Fe, where he had gone to give a lecture. 
 In a literary career that covered more than 50 years and produced more than two dozen novels, historical works and collections of stories and essays, Mr. Stegner found the Western frontier spirit of boundless optimism receding. But he saw in its place, as he once expressed it, "a respect for the heroic virtues: fortitude, resolution, magnanimity."
 
The Potential for Dignity
 His preoccupation with these upbeat qualities separated Mr. Stegner's writing from the despair and alienation in the work of many of his contemporaries. His characters seem propelled by the author's conviction "that man, even Modern Man, has some dignity if he will assume it, and that most lives are worth living even when they are lives of quiet desperation."
To appreciate the West, he once remarked, "You have to get over the color green; you have to quit associating beauty with gardens and lawns; you have to get used to an inhuman scale."
He also turned upside down the stereotypical characters of the West: the barroom beauties with hearts of gold and the lean, heroic cowboys in their chaps and Stetsons. In "Remembering Laughter," he portrayed two sisters who are a complex mixture of youthful exuberance, penance and hatred; in "All the Little Live Things" (1967) and later in "The Spectator Bird" (1976), the recurring character Joe Allston, a fearful retired literary agent, struggles to extricate himself from a tragic past.
 
'The New World's Last Chance'
 "The West does not need to explore its myths much further; it has already relied on them too long," he told a reporter in 1981. "The West is politically reactionary and exploitative: admit it. The West as a whole is guilty of inexplicable crimes against the land: admit that, too. The West is rootless, culturally half-baked. So be it."
Despite all this, he continued, the West remains "the New World's last chance to be something better, the only American society still malleable enough to be formed."
He won the 1972 Pulitzer Prize in fiction for "Angle of Repose," a novel about an elderly, sickly man who learns to accept his anguish when he studies the lives of his grandparents and realizes that their lives, too, left much to be desired.
In 1977, he won a National Book Award for "The Spectator Bird." His work has been nominated several times for the National Book Critics Circle Awards, including this year for a 1992 collection of essays, "Where the Bluebird Sings to the Lemonade Springs: Living and Writing in the West."
 
Dream of the Easy Life
 Among his most popular novels was "The Big Rock Candy Mountain" (1943), a semiautobiographical work in which two sons learn to cope with life by coming to understand their father's failings. When Mr. Stegner was a child, his father had shuttled the family from North Dakota to the state of Washington, and from Saskatchewan to Montana and Utah, pursuing the dream of an easy life that was always just out of reach. The book's title is taken from the hobo song about an imaginary land where life is never less than ideal.
An important theme of that and other works was the fragility of the environment. In an essay for The Saturday Review in 1964, Mr. Stegner compared the way Americans were learning about the environment to the cracker-barrel joke about the boy who twisted the mule's tail and "isn't as pretty as he once was, but knows more."
"There is nothing in the history of the West that indicates any great concern for the environment or for the renewability and sustainability of the economy," he said in an interview last year. "Nor for the labor force used in that exploitation. Those are all serious mistakes."
His "Beyond the Hundredth Meridian" is a biography of John Wesley Powell, who explored the Colorado River. "Wolf Willow" is a history of Saskatchewan.
Another significant nonfiction work was "One Nation" (1945), a collection of photographs illustrating the corrosive effect of racial prejudice in the United States. The book was a co-winner of the Anisfield-Wolfe Award for the best book of the year on race relations.
 
A Teaching Career
 Besides writing and editing, Mr. Stegner had a long career as a teacher of creative writing and literature at the University of Utah, the University of Wisconsin, Harvard University and Stanford University, where he was the director of the Creative Writing Center from 1945 until his retirement in 1971.
His students at Stanford included a number who went on to become notable writers, including Larry McMurtry.
Wallace Earle Stegner was born on Feb. 18, 1909, in Lake Mills, Iowa, the son of Scandinavian immigrants. He received a bachelor's degree from the University of Utah in 1930, a master's degree from the University of Iowa in 1932 and a doctorate from Iowa in 1935.
He then taught English at the University of Utah, and began his literary career in earnest after winning a $2,500 Little, Brown novelette contest in 1937 with "Remembering Laughter," a tale about an adulterous triangle in Iowa farm country.
In addition to his daughter-in-law, he is survived by his wife, Mary; a son, Page Stegner, who is a novelist and professor of American literature and creative writing at the University of California at Santa Cruz, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: Where Artifacts Find Shelter After Many Storms

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
THEY live in an uncluttered six-room apartment in Manhattan with their two children, a pair of green shutters, a few well-worn porch columns and a sprinkling of weather vanes, cast-iron urns and hand-painted signs. All of which -- except the children -- are the pillars and posts of a decorating style that also encompasses salt-glazed crockery, wooden building blocks, primitive paintings and twig rockers.
But that was last week. Don't expect the same things to be there from one day to the next. Judith and James Milne are antiques dealers who specialize in folk art and quilts but also have a predilection for architectural fragments like stair banisters, roof finials and arched windows that they call "bits of history." 
 On buying trips north to New Hampshire, Maine and Vermont, south to the Maryland shore and west to the Ohio River Valley for their East Side shop, they often fall for eight-foot-high trellises, patinated garden gates and louvers with more peeling paint than not. And when the items don't sell, the Milnes take them home. "I usually give things a few weeks, sometimes even a few months," Mrs. Milne said. "If no one wants them, I don't feel guilty taking them home."
Mrs. Milne has a penchant for objects whose surfaces are witness to years of rugged weather. As far as Mr. Milne is concerned, the distressed surfaces so much in vogue these days are nothing new. "Even in the 20's, a core of collectors appreciated furniture in its original condition," he said.
But that may not have included barn doors, fan lights and screen doors that are now having a reincarnation indoors.
"Architectural elements have come into their own in the last five years," Mr. Milne added. "Old columns, for example, are not a lot of money in comparison to what it would cost to have them handmade." (The Milnes' weather-beaten wooden columns start at $375 each, in the shop.)
"You bring this stuff in and create your own atmosphere," Mrs. Milne said. A shutter, for example, "can look romantic, country, even Gothic."
The Milnes seem to have profited from, and may even have been instrumental in jump-starting, the kind of decorating in which a trellis is displayed on its side above the mantelpiece and a finial rests on the coffee table. They have been in the antiques business about 20 years, and although the nature of their wares has changed -- more furniture and paintings and fewer quilts -- their tables, chairs, pedestals and mirrors are still usually in transit somewhere between their shop and their apartment. And sometimes back again.
Mrs. Milne relishes the memory of how aghast her husband's colleagues looked when the sofa they were sitting on in the Milnes' apartment was whisked out from under them.
The shop, called Judith and James Milne, is situated at 506 East 74th Street (East River Drive).
Before getting into antiques, Mrs. Milne was in the garment industry for 10 years, buying and selling fabrics. "With textiles, I knew what was old and what was new," she said. "Quilts were one area I couldn't be tricked in."
So, when she decided about 20 years ago that she wanted to work from home, buying and selling antique quilts seemed right. Her husband, then a manager for a pharmaceutical company, had just been moved to Indianapolis from New York.
"I wouldn't move out there," Mrs. Milne said of the city whose claim to fame, she said, "was its large number of war memorials." So, Mr. Milne went alone. And Mrs. Milne, her mother and her 2-month-old son, Greg, had plenty of time to drive around looking for quilts.
One Monday morning about six months later, Mr. Milne called home and said, "How would you like to pick up your unemployed husband at the airport?"
"Jim decided he hated the Midwest and corporate life," his wife said. Instead of looking for another job in the pharmaceutical field, Mr. Milne joined his wife.
As their business grew, she continued her quest for quilts. He became more interested in furniture. And they both looked for folk art pieces. "We learned by osmosis," he said, adding that buying and selling the folk art pieces eventually became "a whole life style."
Before their children were old enough for school, they were taken along. Greg, now 16, would collect baseball cards; their daughter, Rebekah, now 12, doll furniture. "That gave them the incentive to come with us," Mr. Milne said.
The Milnes' social life revolved around people in the same business. During the week they would be at their shop. On weekends they would be out looking for merchandise or tending a booth at an antique show. "It's 18 hours a day, seven days a week," Mr. Milne said.
Now, they have a system. "I do the schlepping and take care of the financial aspects," he said. He also does 95 percent of the driving. "She does the buying and selling," he added of his wife. "Timewise, it works out pretty evenly."
For 13 years, the Milnes have lived in an apartment on Fifth Avenue in the 90's with a glorious view of the reservoir in Central Park. Two years ago they renovated the space, moving and opening up the kitchen, getting rid of the formal dining room, painting all the walls white and installing track lighting.
In the living room most of the furnishings are in a more or less stable holding pattern.
The folk art pieces look particularly graphic displayed against white walls.
One wooden cow weather vane from about 1880 (priced at $6,500 when it stood in the shop) is poised atop a modern white cabinet. The effect is exceptionally fetching when a remote control lifts into view a television set that is often tuned to Mr. Milne's favorite station, the Weather Channel.
A rustic chair made from craggy rhododendron branches stands in a corner, its original paint flaking nicely. "I took it to an antiques show for a weekend," Mrs. Milne said. "No one bought it, so I brought it home."
A similar fate attended the green shutters that hang over the sofa. "I always wanted to take them home from the shop," Mrs. Milne said. "But I needed merchandise for a show." So the shutters went to a show on a Manhattan pier. "Everyone loved them; no one bought them," she added.
And what about a four-foot-tall country-store barrel that dates from the 1860's? "Six months at the store and I suggested to dozens of people how to use it," Mrs. Milne said. No one was convinced. Now, it's in the corner of the Milnes' living room and filled with firewood.
"We're not like Syms, where things are marked down," Mr. Milne said.
Mrs. Milne added: "We price the things based on what we paid for them, not what the market will bear. And we don't change the prices either when we bring them home or take them back to the store."
But as sure as spring follows winter, as soon as a bench, cupboard or sign is out of the shop, a customer calls. "That's when they really want it," Mrs. Milne said. "And sometimes it's too late, because we've gotten attached."
A pair of painted duck andirons sat unsold at the shop for three months. Now, they sit in the fireplace. "They're my favorites," Mrs. Milne said.
There are exceptions to the Milnes' special kind of recycling. The two sets of columns that frame the foyer and the fireplace, for example. "They're 19th-century columns from a New England porch," Mrs. Milne said. "We nailed them into the wall. They're not going anywhere."
Neither are the pieces that literally have their names on them. A salt-glazed stoneware crock that is emblazoned with a blue "J" and "M" was a birthday present to Mr. Milne from his wife about 15 years ago.
And over the door to their daughter's room is a graceful wooden arch with "The Rebekah Rooms" carved into it. "It's from a hotel in Saratoga, N.Y.," Mrs. Milne said. "But it's also exactly the way she spells her name."
Then there is the huge sign on the wall across from the open kitchen and near the large dining table: "Lunch Room." The sign, which originally came from Connecticut, spent a year in the Milnes' shop. "When we redid our apartment, we had just the right place for it," Mrs. Milne said.
"Don't you just love it?" she continued.
"Yes, yes," was the answer, along with the sense that as far as these antiques dealers are concerned, nothing, attached to the wall or not, is forever.

HEADLINE: Upstairs, Downstairs: A Way to Manage Both

BYLINE: By JULIE LEW

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
WHEN Mark O'Connell decided to change careers, he never thought he would have to learn how to balance glasses on his head or to pack trousers without wrinkling them.
But those were among the skills he gained in an intense 10-day immersion in the world of household management taught by Ivor Spencer, who many in England believe has breathed new life into the grand old profession of being a butler. 
 At the Ivor Spencer International School for Housemen here, the American branch of Mr. Spencer's International Agency for Butlers and Housemen in London, Mr. O'Connell, 34, previously a poster salesman, was transformed from man to manservant. "I'd thought about going into this field, but I never knew there was a school for it," he said.
Now, there is. The $3,000 houseman course, which was established in February and will be offered six times a year, alternating between San Francisco and Los Angeles, covers such essentials as answering the telephone properly, coping discreetly with an employer's sleep-over guest the morning after, organizing a party, serving tea, matching wines with food, cleaning antiques and packing a suitcase. (Tip: To keep pants unwrinkled, use a suitcase that is wide enough so they will have to be folded only once; then stuff tissue paper into the fold).
If polishing up such skills sounds a bit too pompous, and therefore unrealistic, for the back-to-basics, low-key 90's, the job market indicates otherwise. The weekend after graduating, Mr. O'Connell packed for a flight to Dallas for a job interview (paid for by the prospective employer). Three other employment possibilities are on the horizon in case that one falls through, he said.
"A lot of people feel that a butler is too grand for them or too expensive," said Mr. Spencer, who trained butlers for the Duke and Duchess of York, King Hussein of Jordan and Rupert Murdoch. "But there is a big market for housemen. A lot of couples work all day long today. When they come home, a meal will be ready, messages taken, the shopping looked after, the cleaning done, the dogs walked."
All this for those who have $20,000, plus room and board and medical benefits, to spare for such help. (Butlers will set you back $35,000 or more, and they don't clean house.)
Most housemen, the American equivalent of the English housekeeper, are not trained, Mr. Spencer said.
"When they come to the door, they shuffle," he said. "They're not clean." They may not know what kind of voice to use to address a guest (an octave lower than normal) or the proper attitude (nice but not overpowering).
Mr. Spencer, who is 59 and as English as a palace guard, wants to rectify that, using the same fastidious methods he used in modernizing the butler's profession.
"We want the person, when they walk to the door, to have a presence," he said. "We want the visitor or the guest to really see somebody who looks immaculate. We clean our teeth 10 or 12 times a day. We shower twice a day. There's nothing worse than body odor or bad breath when somebody is serving you. He manicures his nails. What's the sense of having lovely food, a beautifully set table, but his hands are dirty?"
James Swan, who manages the San Francisco branch and teaches the courses here and in Los Angeles, said that since the course was established, he had received a call a day from prospective employers around the country asking if graduates were available.
"The demand is exceeding our supply," said Mr. Swan, a San Francisco interior designer and a graduate of Mr. Spencer's butler course. "These are people who lead very demanding lives and who believe they have to have appropriate staff on hand to manage a house for them."
Mr. Swan said he worked hard to counter the impression that houseman -- or household manager, as the job is also known -- is a man's job. "We're fighting the Jeeves-the-butler image," he said. "We think it's a career opportunity for women, too." But he said few women have taken up the challenge. "Perhaps women feel they don't need to study up to be a household manager," he said. "Maybe they think that's the role society already expects of them."
Mary Starkey, the founder of the Starkey International Institute for Household Management, in Denver, the only other school in the country that trains high-level household managers, said that despite the recession, demand had grown steadily for her graduates since she started her program in 1990.
"I get about 60 phone calls a week from all over," she said. She attributed the growing appetite for highly trained household help to a desire by working couples to have not only dual careers but also a well-run home.
"We have proved that if you hire a household manager, that manager will save you 20 percent in what the average family pays for convenience food, cleaning service and other extras," she said. "And the quality of life doubles." Ms. Starkey has operated a placement service for household managers for 12 years.
Mr. Spencer's lessons are taught through role-playing and with such techniques as balancing wine glasses on the head to encourage proper posture. He also likes to throw out hypothetical problems to students. For example, one sticky situation might arise in the bedroom in the morning.
"One of the pair is out of town," he explained. "You knock at the door, you go in and you see a strange face on the pillow. What do you do?"
First, he said, you should not stare. "Ignore that person. You place the tray with the morning paper and breakfast on the master's side of the bed. Draw the curtains. You go out and prepare a duplicate drink and place it on the master's side of the bed." You do not speak to the strange face unless it speaks to you.
In another lesson, Mr. Spencer emphasizes the importance of keeping notes on everything you need to know to run the household smoothly. The efficient houseman will note down the likes and dislikes of regular guests, the employers' favorite hotels, the wines served on a certain special occasion, the name of a favorite maitre d'hotel, birthdays and the family's clothing sizes.
In short, the houseman will do everything a butler does and more, and for a smaller salary. Which is not to say that butlers are an endangered species. "Seriously rich people who've got apartments in New York and a home in the country still think of butlers as a big status symbol," Mr. Spencer said.
One big difference between butlers and housemen is their styles. "A butler wears a uniform, and a houseman wears a white shirt, navy tie and black pants, and a jacket for dinner service," he explained. "If they were both working together, you would notice the butler has more style in serving, more of a touch of theater."
The houseman also does more cleaning and cooking. "A butler is a person who usually runs a home with a staff of two or three," Mr. Spencer said. "He may clean the silver, but he won't do toilets."
Today's butlers are also different from those of the past. When Mr. Spencer started his agency in 1981, there were only 70 butlers left in England, he said. Early in this century, there were 30,000, but most became casualties of huge inheritance taxes that their employers' children could not afford to pay. The estates were sold and a generation of Jeeves es was let go.
Although he was never a butler, he learned the art of graciousness and service as a chef and an accomplished caterer, and through his 38 years as a toastmaster, Mr. Spencer said. He also founded a guild of professional toastmasters in England.
"I was able to easily teach how to become a butler, and I was able to change things," he recalled. "I wanted all the lovely qualities of the old butler: discreet, affectionate, friendly but not familiar, immaculate, and he served beautifully. But the old butlers didn't manage. Now, we purchase everything for the house. We book travel, plan menus. We're executives today. Some are spending more money running a home than it takes an executive to run a small business."
Mr. Spencer and Ms. Starkey have found that would-be butlers and household managers come from all walks of life, from headmaster to pilot to biologist.
"Some things you do are very mundane, some fascinating," Mr. Spencer said. "But it's very lovely to become part of someone's life. You truly miss it when you retire."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
When to Forgive and Forget

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
Let's say it's authentic -- the document found in old Soviet archives in which a North Vietnamese general says Hanoi held three times the number of U.S. prisoners of war it had acknowledged to Washington. Suppose, further, that Hanoi killed the P.O.W.'s to destroy the evidence.
It would be a nightmare. It would confirm all our worst fears about North Vietnamese brutality and malice. Yet it would still leave open the wrenching question of what U.S. policy toward Vietnam should be now, 18 years this month after Marine helicopters swooped down onto U.S. Embassy rooftops in Saigon to rescue the last American diplomats from advancing Communist troops. 
 The question applies not only to Vietnam but to a host of other "outlaw" states, terrorist or dying Communist regimes whose cardinal sins lie in a steadily receding past and some of which now profess good behavior. Namely, Iraq, Iran, Libya, North Korea and Cuba.
There are no good answers. There are only gut feelings, risks, political pressures and imperfect guidelines.
Washington's policy has been to pressure, punish, isolate and even oust outlaw leaders. But increasingly, other nations are refusing to join these enterprises. Increasingly they are forgiving and forgetting and getting on with the business of making money. They argue that the best way to transform bad guys into tolerable guys is not to isolate them but to deal with them.
The U.S. itself has used just such "conversion" arguments to justify exceptions to its own policy. Washington stroked Janos Kadar, who held power in Budapest by pulling out fingernails, and thus helped bring Hungary around to mild "goulash socialism." By refusing to break with the "butchers of Tiananmen," President Bush aided some Chinese economic reformers. Most notably, Washington never gave up trying to create common interests with a hostile and dangerous Soviet Union.
Today, the Clinton Administration courts President Assad, terrorist and mass killer, hoping to coax Syria toward moderation. Even Israel, ever aware of Jewish blood spilled by Damascus, now eagerly seeks peace with its sworn enemy.
How to decide when to engage and when to stiff-arm an old adversary?
Size and power count, but not always. The U.S. talked arms control and commerce with Moscow throughout the cold war, but tried to isolate Beijing for over 20 years.
Hard-headed balance-of-power considerations are not always decisive either. The U.S. now sees Iran as a greater threat in the Persian Gulf than Iraq. Yet it won't build up Baghdad as a counterweight as long as Saddam Hussein hangs around. But is Saddam a badder guy than Assad?Washington won't open the door to Vietnam either, though it could help balance off future Chinese power.
Even powerful business interests have been largely unsuccessful over the years in persuading Washington to go easier on outlaws. Other nations have been stealing the march on markets in Iran, Libya and Vietnam -- and still Washington won't budge on trade restrictions.
Most often, the decision to spurn an outlaw state comes down to U.S. politics. For many reasons, including many good reasons, most Americans want no part of Fidel Castro, Saddam Hussein, Iranian ayatollahs, Muammar Qaddafi or any North Vietnamese leaders who fought against the U.S. The feelings are too raw and too bitter. These guys harmed Americans. And few politicians will risk moving counter to these feelings -- even when U.S. strategic interests call for direct contacts and deals.
There are generally only two ways around this problem. One is for the bad guys to die. Americans would then be willing to work with successors. The other is for the bad guys to admit their misdeeds.
Public confession sounds silly to foreigners. But it isn't, especially not to Americans. It's very hard to trust anyone tomorrow who denies yesterday's proven sins. Confession isn't everything -- and maybe Washington needs to do a little of its own. But honesty can start the process of reconciliation.
In the case of Vietnam, U.S. economic and strategic interests will eventually dictate a new relationship. Whether this happens sooner or later depends on Vietnamese leaders, on their willingness finally to clear the air over American P.O.W.'s.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: My 'Middle-Class' Family Lives From Paycheck to Paycheck

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As the Federal Government considers a national sacrifice economic plan, I wonder if Beltway politicians truly understand the daily middle-class plight. I wish one of them would spend a month in my parents' Brooklyn "upper middle class" home. 
 At a $75,000 yearly income, my parents are certainly on Washington's list of middle-class Americans ripe for sacrifice. While middle-class Americans once took one or two vacations a year, my parents would cherish two nights in Atlantic City once every two years. My parents proudly recall their last new car -- a 1973 Plymouth Fury. Like many in today's middle class, my parents live each week from paycheck to paycheck. Bill maneuvering and management have replaced the Tuesday card game for many like them.
A $75,000 salary seems enough, but politicians ought to analyze why my parents' salary is increasingly modest. Federal, state and city taxes cut a New York City paycheck of $75,000 in half. As my father said last week, "Your mother and I work Monday, Tuesday and part of Wednesday for ourselves, and the rest of the week is for the Government."
But taxes alone are not their sole expenses. Insurance has emerged as the second leading culprit for the disappearance of middle-class America. After car, health, life and home insurance premiums, my parents' $38,000 after-tax income has been reduced to approximately $23,000.
Like many Americans, my family of four enjoys living in a three-bedroom home. Luxuries of this nature entail at least $1,000 a month in rent or mortgage payments. Thus, after rent or mortgage, only $11,000 can go toward utilities and automobile fuel. Essentially, my middle-class parents are left with $7,000 a year for food and some little extras.
My sister and I cannot have paid tuitions for college and graduate school. Thus, as a law student, I mortgage my future every day with accumulating loans. My sister, a student of occupational therapy, is concerned about her loans.
Living at home inexpensively during my legal and college educations, I have witnessed my parents' endless daily sacrifice. Instead of depositing money in savings accounts, they struggle to maintain the checking account in the black.
Nonetheless, my family's predicament raises the question of those less fortunate. Do they live in crowded homes? Do they depend on public transportation or bicycles? Can they even dream of a college education?
I hope that those concerned with the strength of the American family at least consider the majority of Americans who earn significantly less than $75,000. They too sacrifice every day. While it is noble to combat the nation's debt, Washington's priority obligation ought to be the American family.
 
GEORGE SILFEN
Brooklyn, April 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Egypt's Trampling of Rights Fosters Extremism;
Some Other Cairo

 BODY:
To the Editor:
As a yearlong resident of Cairo, and a member of its expatriate community, I was outraged by the tone and content of your March 31 article Cairo Journal, which maintains that the fury of Islam has dimmed the sparkle for expatriates on the Nile. The city you describe is not the city in which I live. 
 I have never heard of "vials of acid tossed at foreign women" as you blithely assert without attributing this experience to any source. As a foreign woman, I would like to know exactly who has had such experiences and in what context.
Your perceptions of Cairo's foreign community are stilted and inaccurate. As an administrator at the American University in Cairo and a freelance journalist for Cairo's English-language press, I know many foreign residents of Cairo, and none of them live in the manner you describe so disapprovingly. You seem to confuse the opulent lifestyle of upper class Cairenes with the habits of the expatriate community.
At the very least, you do readers a disservice by implying that all foreigners live more luxuriously than all Egyptians. While some foreigners may indeed live lavishly in Cairo, I also know many wealthy Egyptians who spend their leisure time at exclusive clubs and surround themselves with "maids, errand boys, drivers, cooks and nannies" as you state foreigners do. I grew up on the Upper East Side of New York City, and I have never seen so many Mercedes-Benzes in one city, almost all driven by Egyptians.
I find your assertion that recent terrorist incidents have made "most of the 35,000 Americans and Europeans alter their daily routine" improbable. I cannot believe that your reporter actually spoke with "most" of these people. Of the couple of hundred foreigners with whom I have daily contact, only a few have changed their lifestyle at all.
You state that the American University in Cairo and Cairo American College have "made concerted efforts to lower their profiles and have increased their security staff." I work in the public relations office of the American University and can state that while we have tightened our security, we have not made any attempt to lower our profile.
Overall, your tone is exaggerated and biased. The few direct quotations are surrounded by such slanted text that the reader interprets far more fear, anger and desperation in the comments than is actually stated.
This is not to say that there is no fundamentalist terrorism in Cairo; there is. I am very sensitive to the local political climate, and I take potential threats very seriously, but irresponsible and inflated reports fuel the flames of frustration without conveying accurately the atmosphere in Cairo.
 
PATRICIA SMITH
Cairo, April 8, 1993

HEADLINE: Population Control Doesn't Cure Poverty

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Birth Control 'for All People' " (editorial, April 2) draws attention to the opinions of two Republican Presidents on international population control programs. Dwight D. Eisenhower, you remind us, favored such programs on the ground that without them "the expectation of future generations" would be limited "to abject poverty and suffering." Ronald Reagan denied them funds on the ground that population growth was a "natural phenomenon" that could stimulate economic growth. Neither state
ment enables us to reach any conclusion on population control. They are opinions, not arguments. 
 You offer no compelling arguments for population control. You state that "at least 500,000 pregnant women, most of them in poor countries, die every year." This is an appalling statistic. Undoubtedly, if more women availed themselves of birth control there would be fewer deaths attributable to pregnancy, but only because there would be fewer pregnancies.
Death rates for pregnant women would remain the same because the acute problems that ultimately cause those deaths -- drought, unrelievable heat, lack of medical and hygiene facilities, and primitive agricultural technology -- remain unsolved in the third world. Financing population control programs does not address the health concerns of poor women.
Advocates of such programs assume "overpopulation" causes poverty. In "The Economy of Cities" (New York, 1969), Jane Jacobs points to Ireland's experience as evidence that what is taken as axiomatic by "population experts" is at the least open to question. Before the 19th-century potato famine, Ireland had nine million people, not a large population for a country of its size. Nevertheless, the Irish were very poor.
"From starvation, disease and emigration, they were swiftly reduced to less than three million," she writes. "The fewer poor people were still poor. Their marriage and birth rates became the lowest in the world, but this did not make Ireland well off."
"One wonders," Jane Jacobs concludes, "how much a population is supposed to be reduced before prosperity comes."
 
EAMON HALPIN
Baton Rouge, La., April 6, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1583 words

HEADLINE: 7 NATIONS PLEDGE $28 BILLION FUND TO ASSIST RUSSIA

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 15

 BODY:
Seeking to help President Boris N. Yeltsin's political fortunes, the leading industrialized nations committed themselves today to $28 billion in aid for Russia, most intended to be delivered this year, although much of it was contingent on austerity steps that Moscow may find difficult to adopt.
Most of the package announced today is to be provided by various international lending agencies, not the United States Treasury. But it did include about $2 billion in United States credits or loan guarantees to pay for Russian imports of American goods, and separately the Administration announced a new commitment of $1.8 billion in direct aid that seems likely to require Congressional approval. 
 The package was announced at the end of two-day emergency meeting -- the first of its kind -- of the foreign and finance ministers of the so-called Group of Seven nations.
 
Addressed the Pitfalls
 Ministers said the aid had been designed to avoid the pitfalls of the West's efforts to prop up the Russian economy last year, when only about half the $24 billion in aid pledged by the West was actually disbursed.
But many participants expressed doubts about whether Mr. Yeltsin wields the political power necessary to meet even the watered-down conditions on which much of the new aid depends, including a requirement that Russia curb its runaway inflation, now running at close to 25 percent a month.
It was also doubtful whether Mr. Yeltsin would be aided at all in his campaign for approval of the April 25 referendum on his policies since most Russians would not feel any effects for months.
 
'Year of Real Breakthroughs'
 Russian officials attending the conference said they were pleased with the results, largely because much of the support is aimed at highly visible projects that the donors hope will compensate for the jobs lost by the closing or conversion of inefficient state-run factories and enterprises.
"This year will be the year of real breakthroughs," Boris G. Fyodorov, a Russian Deputy Prime Minister, said at a news conference here this afternoon. "The amounts of money in the package are not so important as the practical, visible approach we feel."
Despite the doubts expressed here about Mr. Yeltsin's power and future, Secretary of State Warren Christopher pressed several countries to provide even more aid in coming weeks, warning today that "the world will be a considerably more dangerous place if Mr. Yeltsin does not prevail."
Today's pledges include roughly $22 billion in new aid, but they are not the only steps announced this year to help Russia. In a separate move, various commercial banks, international lending institutions and governments have agreed to permit Russia to defer about $15 billion in payments of principal and interest on past loans falling due this year.
 
New Aid of $4.5 Billion
 The Administration's additional commitment today of $1.8 billion brings its total new commitments to Russia in recent weeks to $4.5 billion. Some part of that commitment may eventually be counted in the overall package announced in Tokyo today.
There was considerable uncertainty about the aid numbers, however. Administration officials said they did not know how much of this package should be included in the G-7 totals because some of the Clinton Administration's commitments will have to be matched by other countries in a fund to rehabilitate large industries before the money is disbursed.
Most of the funding announced today is intended to pass through international lending institutions, such as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund, and much of it is aimed at building ways for Russia to increase exports and earn hard currency more readily, chiefly through oil production.
Administration officials traveling with Mr. Christopher and Secretary of the Treasury Lloyd Bentsen said that they had not yet determined how they would pay for the new $1.8 billion in aid, which is mostly in the form of grants. They also said they would have to negotiate with Congress over specific projects to provide assistance with such needs as nuclear power safety, medical help in rural areas, housing for displaced Russian military officers and dismantling of nuclear weapons.
Clearly concerned that the new aid commitment would meet considerable opposition at home at a time when President Clinton is talking about tax increases and federal spending cuts, Mr. Christopher went before the television cameras to announce that "the U.S. effort to aid reform in Russia is in no way a program of charity, in no way a handout."
He and Mr. Bentsen said repeatedly that if the reform effort in Russia is thwarted, the United States will face not only a potentially renewed military threat but also the risk of "the loss of large potential markets for our businesses."
Despite Russian assurances that economic reforms would be carried out this year, the ministers in Tokyo were clearly concerned. This morning they quizzed Mr. Fyodorov, the Deputy Prime Minister, and Andrei V. Kozyrev, the Foreign Minister, on their commitment to rapid changes on the West's terms.
"It was a bit of an oral exam," said one European diplomat who observed the encounter in a giant hotel ballroom in downtown Tokyo. The two Russian ministers spent most of recent weeks negotiating over how to make the aid package usable. Mr. Christopher said today that he had spoken with Mr. Kozyrev "every day for the past 10 days."
 
Money Was Never Spent
 While the figure for the total multilateral package announced by the Group of Seven countries was a little more than $28 billion, a bit more than $6 billion was appropriated last year by the International Monetary Fund to stabilize the value of the ruble against other international currencies. A stable exchange rate is regarded as essential for Russia to increase its trade and investment.
But the money was never sent because Russia's Central Bank, which is answerable to the Legislature and not to Mr. Yeltsin, has not yet adopted the monetary and credit controls that are conditions of the aid. Instead, it has pumped credits to deficit-ridden state enterprises so they would not have to lay off workers.
Another concern about the new program is that much of it may be delayed for years -- including, for example, an estimated $10 billion in "export credits" offered by the seven governments on which Russia can draw to purchase equipment and other goods in each of the countries.
While the export credits were described today as if they are readily available, in fact they must be approved on a project-by-project basis by the export-import banks of each of the donor countries involved, a process that could take quite some time.
 
A Turning Point
 For the Japanese, the host of the meeting, the session marked a tremendous turning point. Japan had initially been reluctant about holding the emergency session for fear that it could upstage its July summit of the leaders of the Group of Seven.
Japan also feared that the meeting this week would place even more pressure on Tokyo to lift its longtime linkage of aid with progress on getting Russia to return what Japan calls its "northern territories," four forbidding islands in the Kurile chain that the former Soviet Union seized at the end of World War II.
The issue remains a potent one in Tokyo, where public opinion is decidedly against large-scale aid. As the talks went on his morning, right-wing nationalists in giant gray sound trucks cruised Tokyo's streets, demanding return of the islands over loudspeakers and playing their signature martial music. But they never got through the heavy security lines to within earshot of the ministers.
In the end the Japanese came through with a $1.8 billion package of their own, though all but $320 million of it is in loans and trade insurance. More important, though, by the conclusion of the session they appeared to have dropped all pretense of making substantial aid contingent on the islands dispute.
 
A Different Approach
 The critical question at the conference is whether the new aid would be any more effective than the $24 billion promised to Russia last year -- much of which was never disbursed, either because of disarray in Russia or because Mr. Yeltsin could not meet the stringent conditions.
"We are trying it differently this time," a senior Clinton Administration official who insisted on anonymity said this morning. "The idea is to prime the pump with some initial money so that the effects can be felt, and then to have more flexible conditions for the rest."
For example, an initial $3 billion in the aid will be disbursed through a new fund to ease the transition to a market economy, administered by the International Monetary Fund. Half the money will be paid out after a "clear political commitment" to stabilizing the currency, American officials said.
The threshold is sufficiently vague that it means the money can flow almost immediately if the Russian Central Bank takes step to control the issuance of credits and currency, as it recently said it would. The second half of the money would be sent after initial progress in getting inflation under control.
The new aid program also includes a larger "standby" loan from the International Monetary Fund, amounting to $4.1 billion, that officials said would have less restrictive conditions than last year's loans. Only $1 billion of the $3 billion commitment last year was disbursed.

Chart: "New Aid to Russia"

HEADLINE: After National Search, Yale Picks Its Graduate Dean to Be President

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

DATELINE: NEW HAVEN, April 15

 BODY:
After a nationwide search for a president to lead it into the 21st century, Yale University turned to its own campus today and selected Richard C. Levin, a 46-year-old economist who has spent nearly half his life at the university, most recently as dean of its Graduate School of Arts and Sciences.
Mr. Levin, who will become Yale's 22d president on July 1, faces high expectations. Faculty, students and others will be looking to him to rescue the university from the economic troubles and low morale that plagued his predecessor, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., who resigned last May.
 
Traits Other Than Experience
 Though Mr. Levin has less administrative experience than other candidates who were said to be under consideration, trustees and other university leaders say he brings important compensating traits to the job: leadership, an insider's knowledge of the institution and an ability to bring factions together on the 11,000-student campus. 
 Faculty members and students also seemed cheered by his selection. Many said they hoped it would end the antagonism that marked Mr. Schmidt's tenure.
"I think it's a good and important thing to have someone from the inside, who understands Yale and has the ability to seek and find consensus," said John Merriman, a professor of history.
At the announcement of his selection, in a wood-panelled hall of the august Sterling Library, Mr. Levin said he was humbled by the appointment. He talked of renewing and revitalizing Yale at a time of serious financial problems and low morale and said he welcomed challenge.
"Time and again in the history of this institution, its leaders have expressed grave concern about the university's financial health and the deterioration of its buildings," he said. "History gives us hope."
In explaining why the search committee had taken so long to name Mr. Schmidt's replacement, Vernon R. Loucks Jr., chairman of the Yale Corporation, the university's executive board, tried to counter speculation that Yale had been turned down by more desirable candidates.
He also denied speculation that the university was looking only for someone with links to Yale, saying that more than 400 candidates, including the presidents of several colleges and universities had been considered.
"Dean Levin is the only person to whom the corporation extended an offer," he said. "After a long and a very far-reaching search he has emerged clearly as the person best qaualified to lead Yale.
 
Students and Faculty Surveyed
 Although all but one of Yale's presidents have been chosen from among the faculty, Mr. Loucks said that "history was not considered at all by the search committee" and that "there was no presumption in favor of an internal candidate; quite the contrary."
He said the search committee had spent the first four months surveying students, faculty, alumni and educators from around the nation about what kind of person would best lead Yale.
"No search in Yale's history has been more comprehsive, or more exhaustive," he said.
Yale's provost, Judith Rodin, who preceeded Mr. Levin as graduate school dean, was once thought to be the front-runner for the job. At today's news conference she described her relationship with Mr. Levin as "wonderful" and said she planned to stay on as provost.
The search committee, which for the first time included faculty members, was unusually secretive. Others who were said to be in line for the job included David Kennedy, a Stanford University historian, Donald M. Crothers, chairman of Yale's chemistry department, and James Duderstadt, president of the University of Michigan.
 
New Kind of Leadership
 To many, the selection of Mr. Levin, a popular professor and administrator, seemed a solution to rocky relations between the university and Mr. Schmidt. Faculty members were angry about an academic restructuring committee Mr. Schmidt had appointed to determine which departments and disciplines were expendable. Graduate students were angered by his tough stance against their efforts to organize a union.
Many students, bothered by what they perceived as Mr. Schmidt's inaccessibility and frequent absences from campus, put up signs on the lawn asking, "Where's Benno?"
In an interview today before the announcement, Mr. Levin refused to criticize his predecessor. He applauded Mr. Schmidt for raising $570 million to improve campus buildings, and for his efforts to improve relations with New Haven.
"We really owe him a debt of gratitude for that," Mr. Levin said.
Before Mr. Schmidt's tenure, he said, there had been "a lot of 'town-gown' tensions and conflicts. Benno really took that issue seriously and worked very hard to forge a new partnership."
Mr. Schmidt likewise praised his successor. "I think Rick is an excellent choice," he said. "He is one of the best and most widely respected and people on the faculty of Yale."
He added: "I knew when I asked him to be dean of the graduate school that he was one of people who had one of deepest understandings of the university."
Mr. Schmidt also defended his tenure as president. "I think my years at Yale were very good ones," he said. "The problem was that we had to reckon with long-standing problems as we faced the pressures of escalating costs associated with academic excellence. So we and other universities were faced with tough choices, but Yale's financial situation is very strong."
 
'He's a Mensch'
 After Mr. Schmidt's departure, the coporation named as acting president Howard R. Lamar, a professor of Western history. Because they were so pleased with his tenure, during which campus tensions were considerably eased, corporation members announced today that they would formally recognize Mr. Lamar as Yale's 21st president.
Faculty and students described Mr. Levin as an affable and down-to-earth administrator.
"It's obvious he's a mensch, and that means a lot to me," said the writer Calvin M. Trillin, who is a member of the Yale Corporation. "He's someone whose basic honesty and decency are just the first things people mention when they talk about him."

HEADLINE: ACCORD IS REACHED TO AID FOREST BIRD

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Trying to defuse the battle over the Endangered Species Act, the Clinton Administration said today it had approved a plan by the Georgia Pacific Corporation to protect the red cockaded woodpecker, a forest bird that is declining in much of its range in the South.
The agreement, which was announced by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, calls for Georgia Pacific, the nation's largest timber company, to keep at least 10 acres of trees and brush standing around each colony of red cockaded woodpeckers that live on its forest lands in Arkansas, the Carolinas, Louisiana and Mississippi. 
 The focus of the agreement is a small, wood-boring forest bird with a splash of bright red on its head. It was once widespread in the Southern forests from Virginia to Texas, but logging and development eroded its habitat, and in 1973 it was among the first animals listed for protection under the Endangered Species Act.
 
What the Company Gains
 By agreeing to restrict operations on more than 50,000 acres, the timber company won a promise that the Government will not invoke the species act to further curtail logging throughout the rest of Georgia Pacific's 4.2 million acres of Southern timberland. The agreement calls for Georgia Pacific to protect any newly discovered woodpecker colonies on any of its lands.
Mr. Babbitt said today that the Government's acceptance of the company's plan would help maintain the woodpecker's numbers in the South, although most of the 10,000 red cockaded woodpeckers in existence live in national forests and timberlands on military bases in the South. Thus, they are not affected by the agreement announced today. But they continue to be protected under the general provisions of the species act, which prohibits killing a threatened or endangered species or harming its habitat, whether on public or private land.
The Fish and Wildlife Service estimated that 300 to 400 birds would be directly affected by the agreement, including the last surviving population of the species in Southern Arkansas. But the importance of the accord was clearly as much symbolic as practical.
Georgia Pacific's plan is emblematic of a new approach by the timber industry to avoid political and legal problems caused by the Endangered Species Act and other environmental laws that affect their huge land holdings. Mr. Babbitt said the Interior Department had opened negotiations with other Southern timber companies to protect the woodpecker.
 
An Important Precedent?
 The most important effect of the Georgia Pacific plan, Mr. Babbitt said, could well be the precedent it sets in helping to establish a less politically incendiary approach to safeguarding endangered wildlife and their habitat, especially on private land.
The Georgia Pacific accord marks the second time in a month that the Clinton Administration has collaborated with industry to forge an agreement meant to protect the environment while advancing economic goals. In March, Mr. Babbitt declared the California gnatcatcher a threatened species and then announced that the Administration would cooperate with developers and conservationists to decide how to divide the land where the bird lived for new housing and for habitat.
The Endangered Species Act allows for such flexibility, though it was rarely exercised during the previous two administrations, environmental lawyers said today.
Instead, the lawyers asserted, both Republican administrations delayed protecting species and seemed to encourage conflicts to gain support from property owners, timber companies and farmers to weaken the act.
 
Was Conflict Predictable?
 Leaders of farm and timber groups and those seeking to protect private property said the conflict over the Endangered Species Act was a logical result of the law's protections for endangered plants and animals. But they said the law did little to encourage the Government to take into account the economic harm such protections could have on working people.
Mr. Babbitt said today his intention was to protect the Endangered Species Act by improving the Government's management of all wildlife. In doing so, the Government could avoid the last-ditch efforts to save a threatened species that have characterized the struggle in the Pacific Northwest over the northern spotted owl.
The Georgia Pacific plan, which has been under development for nearly two years, was a good start, he said: "Lands can be managed in a way that a bird species is not destroyed and its habitat is preserved."
 
Chief Executive Comments
 A. D. (Pete) Correll, the president and chief operating officer of Georgia Pacific, said today that the primary motivation for drawing up the plan was to avoid lawsuits and Government action while also being able to cut timber for a growing market.
At the heart of the Georgia Pacific plan are several assurances by the company and the Government. The first is the company's vow to protect 110 colonies of woodpeckers by prohibiting cutting on 10 acres surrounding each colony, or 1,100 acres.
The company also said it would more carefully manage some 510 additional acres that surround each colony of birds, though executives today were vague about how much timber it would take from these buffer zones. The company, which had revenues of $11.8 billion last year, can log the rest of its 4.2 million acres in the South.
Michael Bean, a lawyer from the Environmental Defense Fund, endorsed the Georgia Pacific agreement today. "Creative solutions are necessary if we are to conserve endangered species," he said.
Other environmental groups reserved judgment, though most said they had confidence that Mr. Babbitt was probably doing something worthwhile.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall Sharply

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
New claims for jobless benefits fell sharply last week, the Labor Department said today, but economists cautioned that the drop might be largely attributed to a workweek shortened by the Good Friday holiday. 
 First-time claims for unemployment benefits fell 38,000 in the week ended April 10, to 335,000, the lowest level in two months. The drop was the largest since a decline of 131,000 in the week that ended on Aug. 1.

HEADLINE: G.M. to Make Toyota Cars for Sale in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Friday, April 16

 BODY:
In a deal that would increase American car exports to Japan, the General Motors Corporation has tentatively agreed to make up to 20,000 cars a year in the United States for sale by the Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan under the Toyota brand name.
The arrangement, confirmed by G.M. today, would be a reversal of the usual pattern in which Japanese companies have made cars in Japan that are sold to American consumers as G.M., Ford and Chrysler cars. 
 The "conceptual" accord, as G.M. called it, came to light as the Japanese Prime Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, was to meet with President Clinton for the first time in Washington today. Mr. Miyazawa is expected to come under heavy pressure from President Clinton to take concrete steps to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States.
 
American Actions to Lift Exports
 Automobiles and automobile parts account for much of the trade gap, and the Big Three Detroit auto makers have been pressing Mr. Clinton to take action to increase American exports to Japan or to decrease Japanese exports to the United States.
Exporting American-made Japanese cars to Japan is not new. Some 37,000 American-made cars were imported by Japan last year, but about 20,000 of them were Hondas.
And G.M. and Toyota, the largest auto manufacturers in their respective countries, already have a history of cooperation. They operate a factory in Fremont, Calif., that makes both G.M. and Toyota vehicles, some of which are exported worldwide. But for General Motors, which sold only about 9,000 passenger cars under its various brand names in Japan last year, selling 20,000 to Toyota would represent a big jump.
The Toyota agreement was reported in this morning's edition of the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, a Japanese economic newspaper, and then confirmed by G.M. Toyota said it was premature to comment on specifics of the reports of the agreement.
The American company said that its chief executive and president, John F. Smith Jr., had met with Tatsuro Toyoda, Toyota's president, in Washington on April 5 to discuss ways of increasing G.M.'s exports to Japan of cars and car parts.
The two executives "agreed conceptually to pursue an arrangement whereby G.M. would build a Toyota-badged right-hand-drive vehicle in the United States for sale by Toyota in Japan," G.M. said in a statement. "A working group has been formed to finalize model specifications, exact timing and other details."
A G.M. spokesman in Japan, David G. Bodkin, said the number of cars involved could reach 20,000 a year and that sales are likely to begin around 1996 or 1997.
Mr. Bodkin would not say which factory will be chosen but said G.M. does not plan to use a plant that is now scheduled to be closed in the company's restructuring. The company said it is too early to speculate whether the new arrangement would allow it to retain any workers that are now scheduled to be laid off.
The Japanese newspaper reported that the cars to be sold will be new versions under G.M.'s line of subcompacts, including the Chevrolet Cavalier and the Pontiac Sunbird.
Selling the car under the Toyota name, through Toyota distribution channels, could help G.M. overcome the resistance among some Japanese consumers to American cars.
 
 
A Hard Sell
 American car companies have had a notoriously hard time selling in Japan. Critics have been saying that American cars are too big and expensive, have a reputation for poor quality and do not come with the steering wheel on the right side. American executives say the quality and price issues have been addressed and that problems stem from formal and informal trade barriers and difficulty in obtaining distribution.
Indeed, the American cars that are now selling best in Japan are those made by the Japanese themselves at their American factories. Honda just became the largest importer of cars to Japan. That is largely because the Japanese can use their brand names and existing distribution channels.
In January 1992, President Bush came to Japan with the heads of the Big Three auto makers to press for increase access to the Japanese market. At that time, Japan's auto makers collectively pledged informally to sell up to 20,000 American cars in Japan each year. As part of that agreement, Toyota said it would import and sell 5,000 G.M. vehicles a year.
 
Implementation of Agreements
 But implementation of such agreements has been slow to materialize. In the case of G.M. and Toyota, G.M. itself did not want to circumvent its longtime Japanese distributor, Yanase & Company. But in the new arrangement, since it will be making Toyota vehicles, G.M. apparently does not have to go through Yanase.
Still, analysts said that the agreement might have a bigger impact politically than it would on reducing the United States trade deficit with Japan.
Japan's car exports to the United States are more than 1.5 million cars a year, a number that has been held down in recent years by a voluntary limit of 1.65 million cars a year. And Japanese companies make cars in the United States using many parts imported from Japan.
Compared with that gulf, "20,000 cars coming from the United States seems like a drop in the bucket," said Peter Boardman, an auto industry analyst for UBS Phillips and Drew International in Tokyo.
"It's well-timed news to calm the political pressure," he said. "It's a politically motivated agreement and I haven't seen too much success in these types of relationships."

HEADLINE: Both Sides Talk of Pact On Jobs Bill

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
Suspending their public quarrel over President Clinton's $19.5 billion plan to stimulate the economy, Mr. Clinton declared today that he was willing to scale back his proposal, and Senate Republicans signaled they were ready to discuss an agreement.
"I have been working with the Senate to come up with an adjusted package that meets some of the concerns of those who've been blocking action on the jobs plan," Mr. Clinton said during a ceremony in the Rose Garden. "I am willing to compromise so long as we keep the focus on jobs, keep the focus on growth and keep the focus on meeting unmet national needs." 
 White House officials said the President's comments were intended to show that he, and not the Republicans, was initiating efforts to reach a compromise. But Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader, also sought to take the initiative by calling Mr. Clinton about the package.
 
'We Are Both Adults'
 Recalling one of two telephone discussions last night, Mr. Dole, who was traveling in New Hampshire, said: "It was a very good conversation. We are both adults. We understand politics." He said at several appearances today that Republicans were not seeking to "embarrass" Mr. Clinton but merely disagree with him.
But while the tone was decidely friendlier in public today, it was far from clear that any real accommodation was forthcoming. Both sides were careful not to spell out specifics of the negotiations, and aides on both sides emphasized that the talks were of a general nature.
The aides said, however, that there seemed to be some agreement on preserving big-ticket items like jobs programs and unemployment benefits, and that the compromises would probably be over trimming other elements.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Dole had what the aides described as two productive phone conversations on Wednesday about the stimulus package. The President said he urged Senators George J. Mitchell, the Democratic leader, and Robert C. Byrd Jr., chairman of the Appropriations Committee, to continue the talks today with Mr. Dole.
Mr. Clinton said he told Mr. Dole that "I was prepared to reduce the package and I wanted to break the gridlock, and I told him I was working on a reformulation" so that the package "would become even more focused on jobs and the kinds of issues that I thought the American people wanted us to address."
 
Carrots for Republicans
 In a reference to Mr. Clinton's criticism earlier this week that the Republican filibuster of the package was at the expense of children like those at the White House Easter egg hunt, Mr. Dole said he told the President, "We've been throwing Easter eggs at each other long enough."
Even as he was talking about cuts, Mr. Clinton sought to sweeten the package for Republicans who favor a strong emphasis on law enforcement. He called the Rose Garden ceremony of law-enforcement officials to announce that he was adding $200 million to the package for rehiring local police officers who were laid off because of the recession. He said the $200 million could lead to putting as many as 10,000 officers back on the job.
George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, said it was unlikely that the two sides would reach an accord before Congress returns next week from its Easter break. "This is the beginning of the process," he said. "It's hard to imagine that it would get finished before the Senate returns but it's not impossible."
When the Senate reconvenes on Monday, new versions of the Clinton package may be offered by Mr. Dole and by Mr. Mitchell. A vote on one or both of those versions has been scheduled for Tuesday, but the Senate could put that off if the current talks are making progress.
At a news conference in Concord, N.H., Mr. Dole said that Mr. Clinton had told him he was "focusing on two or three areas" for a compromise. While the President did not say what those areas would be, Mr. Clinton made clear what programs he wanted to keep.
"I want the summer jobs," Mr. Clinton told reporters gathered for the Rose Garden event. "I want the highway program. I want the police program."

HEADLINE: NEW MOVES IN U.N. TO RESTRAIN SERBS

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 15

 BODY:
The Security Council is expected to hold an emergency session on Friday to consider imposing tough new sanctions on Yugoslavia immediately if the besieged Bosnian town of Srebrenica falls to Serbian forces.
"I would definitely convene the Council, and I personally think we should move ahead immediately with the new sanctions," Jamsheed K. A. Marker of Pakistan, this month's Council president, said after reports that the Bosnian defenders of Srebrenica are negotiating the town's surrender. 
 Mr. Marker spoke after the Security Council had agreed to hold a two-day debate next week on Bosnia and Herzegovina. But at the same time the Council agreed, at the urging of Russia and the United States, to postpone a vote on new sanctions until April 26, the day after Russian voters vote in a national referendum on the political future of President Boris N. Yeltsin.
Mr. Yeltsin's opponents in the Russian Congress support the Serbs, and the postponement of the vote was meant to avoid embarrassing him or playing into his opponents' hands.
 
Response to Third World
 Mr. Marker said there was an understanding among Council members that the agreement to delay the sanctions vote would be abandoned if Srebrenica or Sarajevo fell and that Russia would not use its veto to block new punitive measures against the Serbs.
The decision to hold an open debate next week, at which all members of the United Nations can air their views, is an attempt to deal with the anger many third-world and Muslim countries feel at finding the Council powerless to act against the Serbs. The Bosnian Government is largely Muslim.
If the new sanctions, as expected, are adopted by the Security Council on April 26 -- or earlier -- the United States, France and Britain are likely to support Russia's call earlier this week for another Council meeting at foreign minister level in the second half of May, diplomats said today.
Moscow has suggested that such a high-level meeting should discuss rising ethnic tensions throughout the world and also review the suggestions Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali has made for strengthening the United Nations peacekeeping role.

HEADLINE: A Peek Inside the Health-Care Debate

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
In opening the door to an indirect form of national sales tax, the White House has provided an unusual public peek into the private conflict about how to finance a costly new Government-supported health-care program.
A health-care task force headed by Hillary Rodham Clinton has reached no conclusions about the cost of the various elements of the program or how to pay for them, although officials say there are at least 20 financing alternatives under consideration. 
 Moreover, last week several senior Administration officials contacted Ira C. Magaziner, the adviser in charge of the health-care proposal, to express their displeasure that no cost estimates had been forthcoming for a plan that outside experts say could cost from $30 billion to $90 billion a year.
 
Billions Are Envisioned
 In light of that need, the value-added tax, imposed on goods and services at each stage of production, would be a lucrative financing tool.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, such a tax assessed at 5 percent would raise $35 billion in its first year if provisions were included to relieve the burden on the poor by exempting food, housing and medical care. The revenues would rise to $65 billion in the fourth year.
But the tax has been dismissed as regressive by advocates for the poor, as anti-growth by retailers and as excessive by industries that have already been wary of President Clinton's proposal to increase energy taxes. Even Mr. Clinton seemed to dismiss the idea in February.
But as George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director, conceded today, "Certain things have changed."
 
A Balloon Deflated?
 The President's political advisers were unwilling to predict how far the value-added proposal would progress, and there is a good chance it will go nowhere.
"There are lots of things under discussion," said Stan Greenberg, a political adviser who conducts polls for the White House. "This is not one of things that is percolating to the top."
The trial balloon that was sent aloft by two senior Administration officials in seemingly coordinated remarks this week was premature, critics and even some Clinton aides said today.
Republicans were quick to note that the debate about it erupted on the day income taxes are due, and even Democrats who had supported the idea grimaced over its sudden appearance.
"Today is tax day for millions of Americans, but judging from the latest White House trial balloon, this Administration is considering making every day tax day," said Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the Republican leader.
During a morning jog today, Mr. Clinton said he had not changed his position on a value-added tax. But he also said he had not yet fully reviewed the matter. "A lot of business and labor people are for it," he said.
Later, at a Rose Garden ceremony, the President cautioned against comparing his plan to stimulate the economy -- which he would dearly love seeing passed over Republican objections -- to the tax proposal.
"I have made absolutely no decision that would even approach that, on that or any other kind of general tax," Mr. Clinton said.
"The real issue is how quickly we could recycle the benefits of all the savings to cover the costs," the President added, noting that polls show broad support for restructuring health care. "Everyone knows that if you do what we're proposing to do, if you streamline the insurance system; if you fix the system so there's no longer an enormous economic incentive to over-utilize or over-provide certain services; if you provide primary and preventive care in places where it isn't now, every single analysis shows absolutely massive savings to the health-care system."
But the analyses also show that in the short run such savings would not be enough to cover the costs of expanding insurance coverage to those who lack it and of adding expensive options like long-term care.
The President's advisers had hoped this week to work out the fine points of ending the Congressional impasse over his plan to stimulate the economy without giving Republicans more ammunition with which to tar him as an unrepentant tax-and-spend Democrat.
But the timing went awry this week after both Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, and Alice M. Rivlin, the deputy budget director, suggested that the value-added proposal was under consideration.
"It seems like a very strange time to float a gigantic tax," offered one Democratic Congressional aide.
Jerry Jasinowski, chairman of the National Association of Manufacturers, said: "It not only doesn't make any substantive sense, it doesn't make any political sense. You can't make all these changes and fight on all these fronts at the same time."
Bad timing aside, testing the political waters in this manner has become a Clinton Administration tactic to give the President room to maneuver.
Administration officials used a similar approach earlier this year when Leon E. Panetta, the budget director, proposed freezing cost-of-living increases for Social Security recipients. Once he had suggested to a group of influential senators that such an approach was under consideration, the outcry allowed the White House to gauge the discontent and eventually win support for a less onerous plan to increase the tax on benefits only for wealthier recipients.
And the value-added tax proposal has the advantage of having previously won support from several influential members of Congress and from members of the Clinton Administration, including Ms. Rivlin, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and a key economic adviser, Lawrence H. Summers.
In Congress, those who have supported different versions of the tax include Senators Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico; Paul Sarbanes, Democrat of Maryland; Sam Nunn, Democrat of Georgia, and David Boren, Democrat of Oklahoma. Many are attracted to the idea because it would shift the burden of taxation from income to consumption, thereby providing an incentive for savings and expanded investment.
