HEADLINE: Hispanic Enclave Braces for Verdict

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HUNTINGTON PARK, Calif., April15

 BODY:
At the Fancy Hair beauty salon here, Vivian Granillo and her mother, Milagro, stay close to a television that hums from the counter, the volume low but the set on all the time as the women await a verdict in the Rodney G. King beating trial in nearby Los Angeles.
Last year, after the first trial, they were taken by surprise by a band of looters armed with a sledge hammer who invaded their shop and left with $46,000 worth of shears, swivel chairs and beauty potions. This year, the Granillos say, they will pack the equipment they can carry the moment a verdict is reached and hustle it home. 
 A few blocks away, on a sun-dappled residential street that is quiet now but for bird songs, Feliciano Mendoza and his wife, Margaret, are figuring out how to get their three daughters safely home after a verdict, since the girls are in schools scattered around distant Los Angeles neighborhoods.
They have decided that two of the girls, 6-year-old Alice and 12-year-old Lisa, will join their mother at her office at the University of Southern California, a secure compound that was untouched in last year's disturbances, although rioters roared nearby. The third daughter, 14-year-old Mariella, will ride the school bus home on a circuitous route that has been revised by school officials to avoid areas most likely to explode in violence.
 
Recalling the Destruction
 Just like their neighbors in Los Angeles, residents of Huntington Park are worrying and planning as the Federal jury continues its deliberations, which broke off late this afternoon and are to resume for a seventh day on Friday. This Hispanic enclave just a few miles southeast of the big city was not far from the epicenter of last year's mayhem and many stores were looted and burned.
Mr. Mendoza, a fifth-grade teacher at Miles Elementary School, vividly recalls the aftermath of last year's verdict: Pillars of smoke, wailing sirens and the rattle of automatic gunfire just blocks from his stucco bungalow. There were long lines at gasoline stations as frightened families fled. Shoe boxes littering the main commercial boulevard, where footwear, electronics and liquor stores were the most popular with looters.
But Mr. Mendoza, a fourth-generation American of Mexican descent, has been challenging neighbors who say they have armed themselves this time around. Most of the violence, he tells them, was against commercial property, not homes or people. They have little to fear, he said, unless "they end up killing each other."
"It was an economic riot, not a race riot," Mr. Mendoza concluded.
Huntington Park, where 90 percent of the 55,000 residents are Hispanic, is a paradigm for what the Latin community in the larger Los Angeles area might be, a place where Mexican-Americans who have been here for generations live comfortable lives, vastly different from those of the impoverished newcomers from the south.
"There is a big difference between those people and us," said Mary Castillo, a teacher's aide at Miles Elementary, which operates year round and still bursts at the seams because of the flood tide of immigrants who have made this one of the densest corners of the county. "We appreciate what we have. We have a foundation here and we take pride in our city."
 
New Culture Atop the Old
 The Mexican-Americans of long standing in Huntington Park own their own homes, including stucco bungalows like Mr. Mendoza's and impressive stone dwellings surrounded by lush gardens.
Many of the newcomers, by contrast, are crowded into illegally converted garages or live doubled or tripled in tumbledown shacks at are the edge of town, near steel and auto plants that were idled years ago. The city is rather like an archeological dig, with the new culture superimposed on the ruins of the old. Along Pacific Boulevard, the sort of small-town commercial strip rarely seen in Southern California, old buildings that once held the likes of the J. C. Penney Company are now home to Joyeria Alberta and Clinica Medica.
To listen to longtime residents here, it was the struggling immigrants, many of them here illegally, who participated in last year's looting, joining outsiders who stormed in from Watts and South-Central Los Angeles.
Jerry Meza, a teacher's assistant at Miles Elementary, said he stood outside Tommy's hamburger stand here and watched streams of people headed east on Florence Avenue, toward Huntington Park, where eager locals then joined them. Martha Pena, another teaching assistant at the school, added that many of her newest students said later that they had gone looting with their parents.
"They were very excited about getting things they never had," Ms. Pena said.

HEADLINE: Dinkins Reports Higher Income

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
While New York City's economy may still be in the doldrums, Mayor David N. Dinkins did much better financially in 1992 than in the year before, according to income-tax returns he released yesterday.
His taxable income rose 12.5 percent last year, largely because of speaking honorariums and expiration of a 5 percent cut in his salary for part of the year, the returns showed. 
 The documents also showed that Mr. Dinkins was more generous with his money. He gave $17,462 to charity last year, or about 12 percent of the $144,997 he and his wife, Joyce, reported in taxable income. That compared with $15,000 in contributions the preceding year. For last year, Mr. Dinkins and his wife paid $38,009 in Federal, state and local taxes, compared with $33,100 a year earlier.
Tax returns released by his Republican challenger for mayor, Rudolph W. Giuliani, showed he gave $10,888 to charity last year, about 3 percent of the $363,441 in taxable income reported by him and his wife, Donna K. Hanover, the television reporter.
Andrew J. Stein, the City Council President who intends to challenge Mr. Dinkins in the Democratic mayoral primary, filed for an extension, as he has for the last few years. Victoria Streitfeld, his chief of staff, said that Mr. Stein's accountant had not yet completed the returns but that Mr. Stein paid an estimated amount.
Besides his salary, the income of Mr. Dinkins and his wife came from $4,963 in interest on savings accounts, $3,381 in taxable dividends and $6,649 in pension benefits for Mrs. Dinkins, who had worked with the State Taxation and Finance Department before retiring when Mr. Dinkins took office. His income also included a $145 payment for an appearance on the television program "Law and Order." That episode was never broadcast.
The subject of the Mayor's charitable contributions has been a thorny one for him. Two years ago, he took some heat for having made cash charitable contributions of just $190. He responded by saying he had donated time to several charities in ways that could not be measured in dollars.

HEADLINE: Donors Also See Gain in Aid Package

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 15

 BODY:
While there were arguments here today over how much of the $28 billion in aid pledged by the wealthy industrial nations will reach Russia quickly, there were fewer doubts about another group likely to benefit: foreign businesses eager to finance risky operations in Russia.
No sooner had the delegates to the conference on Russian aid handed out fact sheets explaining their complex new program, than they moved on to the issue of expanding trade and developing jobs -- in their own countries. 
 Clinton Administration officials, mindful that Americans might be less than receptive to big foreign-aid programs when budgets are declining and taxes rising at home, said the package would generate huge orders for American oil and gas equipment and benefit as many as 9,000 American workers.
Norman Lamont, the Chancellor of the Exchequer, gushed, "Russia could be one of the biggest export markets for British firms in the next decade. We want to help and encourage them to get in on the ground floor and to establish links with Russia at an early stage."
To some extent, of course, such comments were intended to persuade legislators back home to support big new appropriations for aid to Russia.
It also seemed clear that the aid package would likely suffer some of the same problems that plagued last year's package: Of the $24 billion committed by the seven nations last year, only about half was disbursed because the Russian Government was unable to take the tough economic measures called for.
The $6 billion ruble-stabilization fund announced here, for instance, is really a fund set up last year that Moscow could not draw from because it failed to get inflation under control. Curbing inflation would involve ending the subsidies that have kept hundreds of deficit-ridden state enterprises afloat and millions of Russians employed.
The turbulent political situation in Russia makes it uncertain whether Moscow will be able to use all the import credits being offered this year either.
 
Meeting Immediate Needs
 A senior United States official said the whole point of the new program was to get aid more quickly to the areas that need it most. About $2 billion from a new type of International Monetary Fund program -- called, somewhat awkwardly, the systemic transformation facility -- is likely to be disbursed within three months, the official said; the only condition is that Moscow express a commitment to economic change.
That still leaves the Russian Government with the difficult job of reducing inflation and slashing its budget deficit before billions of dollars in additional assistance can be disbursed, particularly from a $4.1 billion I.M.F. loan program offered here.
But the sudden interest in commercial prospects in Russia is, in part, a product of the unusual way the new package was drawn up and its pragmatic, commercial emphasis on building the private sector.
A total of $10 billion in the new package, for instance, is in loans and guarantees for exports to Russian enterprises. Much of the money is intended to help Russia purchase equipment that will produce quick returns by modernizing and expanding its major export industries, including oil, gas and minerals. Several billion dollars in World Bank loans could be used to finance energy development.
 
A Russian, Hard at Work
 The conference ended with a call for a $300 million fund at the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development to provide loans to promising small and medium-sized companies, a form of grass-roots support that was absent last year.
The new approach was one reason Boris G. Fyodorov, Russia's Finance Minister, discouraged nitpicking over the prospects that all the new money will hit the targets.
"This is not wishful thinking," he said of the $10 billion in trade credits. "We're already negotiating with various countries on this."

HEADLINE: Pentagon Speeds Plan to Lift Gay Ban

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 15

 BODY:
After two months of delay and indecision, the Pentagon is hurrying to prepare an executive order to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military and to agree on the practical steps to carry it out.
The Defense Department has established a 50-member military working group in an office six blocks from the White House, and ordered the panel to deliver a list of policy options to Defense Secretary Les Aspin by May 5. Two dozen experts from the Rand Corporation, a research organization, are conducting a separate review for Mr. Aspin that is due in early June. 
 Under the direction of a senior aide to Mr. Aspin, Rudy de Leon, top civilian Pentagon officials are seeking to write an executive order by July 15 that meets President Clinton's goal to end discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation, and that is acceptable to Congress and the armed forces.
 
'Practical Resolution'
 "Our working approach is that we can come to a practical resolution to this problem," said one senior Defense Department official.
Advocates of gay rights expressed relief today that the Administration, and the Pentagon, in particular, had started a fact-finding and policy-review process after more than two months of inaction.
President Clinton ordered the Pentagon on Jan. 29 to draft an executive order lifting the ban and an accompanying study to support it. Senior policy makers, distracted by other issues, said they did not focus on the task until they were embarrassed by published reports last month that the armed services were using the policy vacuum to continue to resist lifting the ban.
President Clinton only worsened the confusion last month when he said at his first news conference that he would consider restricting the deployment of gay soldiers. Under criticism from gay rights groups, Mr. Clinton quickly backed away from his remarks.
Administration officials say the review is now moving along smartly.
 
Overcoming 'Emotionalism'
 "There are official and unofficial conversations, strategies and options being discussed all over the Beltway by Administration officials," said Bob Hattoy, a White House adviser on gays issues who last month criticized the Administration's handling of the issue.
Senior Pentagon officials are cautiously optimistic that they can reach agreement with military leaders on issues like greater privacy in latrines and showers, and public displays of affection among same-sex personnel. But they worry aloud that Congress is a wild card that could upset a brokered deal between the White House and the armed services.
"I'm concerned whether a practical solution can overcome all the emotionalism that exists in politics," said one senior Defense Department official.
A dozen staff members from the Senate Armed Services Committee quietly visited about 20 military installations around the country this week and last week to canvass officers and enlisted personnel on the ban, and to prepare for field hearings the committee will hold in May.
Staff members representing Democratic and Republican lawmakers interviewed scores of troops at bases in New York, California, Georgia, Illinois, South Carolina, Texas, Virginia and Washington. Staff members said that most troops voiced support for the ban, but that there were some calls to lift the prohibition.
 
Criticism on Interviews
 Senator Sam Nunn, the Georgia Democrat who heads the committee, strongly supports the ban but has insisted the panel's hearings will be "fair, thorough and objective." The Armed Services Committee held its first two hearings in early April, and will hear testimony later this month from experts of foreign militaries that permit declared homosexuals to serve in their ranks.
Advocates of homosexual rights have expressed anger at the committee's recent visits, contending that commanders handpicked the troops that staff members interviewed and that the interviews were conducted in large groups, inhibiting any dissenting opinions.
"This methodology is inherently flawed and will inevitably yield skewed results," said Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the Campaign for Military Service, a coalition of gay rights groups that oppose the ban.
A committee spokesman, Scott Williams, said today that staff members heard from both supporters and opponents of the ban. He added rights groups were welcome to discuss their views with staff members.
While the Pentagon's nuts-and-bolts review is taking place at a second-floor office on Pennsylvania Avenue here, the parallel study is going on more than 3,000 miles away at the Rand Corporation headquarters in Santa Monica, Calif.
"We need Rand's methodological approach and the military's independent judgment," said a senior Defense Department official, explaining why two reviews are needed.
The Pentagon working group is headed by Lieut. Gen. Robert M. Alexander of the Air Force, who is temporarily the Defense Department's chief personnel officer. Assisting General Alexander are Maj. Gen. John P. Otjen of the Army, Rear Adm. John S. Redd of the Navy, Brig. Gen. William B. Davitte of the Air Force, Brig. Gen. Gerald L. Miller of the Marine Corps and Rear Adm. James M. Loy of the Coast Guard.
Heading the Rand study is Bernard D. Rostker, a former head of the Selective Service System. Rand has assigned historians, economists, sociologists, psychologists, anthropologists, doctors and lawyers to the study.
Pentagon officials expect to gather all their information by mid-May, and then consult on various policy options with gay rights groups, veterans organizations and lawmakers through June.

HEADLINE: Tax-Protest Leader to Oppose Florio

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TRENTON, April 15

 BODY:
John Budzash, the mail carrier who organized the huge statewide tax protest that seemed to put the political future of Gov. Jim Florio in serious jeopardy, filed today as a candidate to oppose the Governor in the June 8 primary.
Mr. Budzash, who resigned from the Postal Service earlier this week to run, turned his nominating petitions over to the Secretary of State's Office five minutes after the official filing deadline. But in a hurried telephone call, Attorney General Robert J. Del Tufo directed the office to accept the petitions. 
 Raymond J. Lesniak, the Democratic Party Chairman, said he would review the signatures on the petitions and decide whether to challenge them.
"Here is a guy who was a Republican until a few days ago, and now he decides to run as a Democrat," Mr. Lesniak said.
Mr. Budzash, who delivered the petitions himself, running into the office with his tie askew and his shirttail out at 4:05 P.M., said he was late because he had discovered that 300 of his petitions had been signed on the wrong line.
 
Pledges to Reduce Waste
 Even if Mr. Budzash's petitions survive a challenge, just what impact he will have on the election is uncertain. He conceded today that he has yet to raise any campaign funds, and he acknowledged that he does not have a platform beyond general pledges to reduce waste in government and reduce taxes.
Mr. Budzash, who has never held political office, rose to some prominence in 1990 after he called a radio talk show to complain about the $2.8-billion tax increase Mr. Florio pushed through the Legislature. He and another caller, Pat Ralston, who said she was unemployed and about to lose her home, became the founders of a group called Hands Across New Jersey to work for repeal of the taxes. The group was given credit for igniting the outpouring of voter anger that turned the Democratic majority out of the Legislature in 1990. Mr. Budzash later resigned from the group, which has splintered.

HEADLINE: Immigrant Enrollment Rises In New York City Schools

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Accelerating a trend of recent years, 65,322 immigrant children entered New York City's public schools in the last year, creating new pressures to increase the number of classrooms, expand bilingual education programs and provide other services for foreign-born students.
The increase, reported yesterday by Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, was 45 percent larger than in the 1991-92 school year, when 46,358 immigrant children enrolled in the schools. Since the 1990-91 year, the report said, the public schools have gained 137,796 immigrant children. 
 "It is a phenomenon that harkens back to the waves of immigration at the beginning of the century," said Robin Willner, the executive director for strategic planning for the Board of Education. Instead of increases in native-born students, she added, "It is immigration that is fueling the growth of the schools."
Analysts said the increases, if they continue, are certain to create new difficulties for the nation's largest school system, even though it has been promised a large increase in state financing.
"The pressures are outstripping most people's expectations," said Emanuel Tobier, a professor of economics and urban planning at New York University. The immigrant youngsters may be a "back breaker," for the schools, he added.
The report yesterday was derived from an annual census of school enrollment, conducted last October. It said the immigrant children, from 188 countries, more than accounted for an overall increase in public school enrollment, which rose by 23,319, to 995,465, this year.
 
Dominicans in Lead
 As in recent years, students born in the Dominican Republic, Jamaica and China had the highest increases in enrollment. Dominican-born children now account for more than 20 percent of all immigrants in the public schools.
The influx of immigrant students was spread among all grade levels and experienced by public schools across much of New York City, but the report found three community school districts attracted the largest numbers, each adding more than 6,000 immigrants to its enrollment this year. They are District 30 in Astoria and Corona, Queens; District 24 in Long Island City and Middle Village, Queens, and District 10 in Riverdale and the North Bronx.
New York City public school enrollment declined sharply from the 1971-72 school year, when it reached a peak of 1.15 million, until the 1982-83 year, when it reached a low of 918,384, but it has been climbing back steadily for the last decade.
School officials said yesterday that the latest census made them even more confident of their projections, made repeatedly over the last year, that enrollment would once again exceed 1 million students next year and continue to grow.
"I don't think there is any question we will exceed the previous peak," said Mr. Tobier, who added that he expects continued increases in immigration to combine with a rebound in enrollment by native-born students during the rest of the 1990's.
He said one reason for continued growth will be demographic trends, which resulted in a large increase in birth rates among New York City women in the late 1970's and through much of the 1980's. Their children will enroll in the public schools in growing numbers over the next five years, he said.
The public school census report was released after months of dickering over school financing that resulted in a pledge, contained in the New York State budget proposed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, of $145 million in added state aid for the New York City schools during the next school year, beginning in September.
The increase will follow a year without added financing for the schools, despite their expanding enrollment. Ms. Willner said the public school budget, financed by the Federal, state and city governments, is $7 billion this year and "just about even" with the amount spent during the 1991-92 year.
Anticipating the added state funds, school officials have already announced an aggressive program of opening new schools, largely by leasing space in existing buildings. James S. Vlasto, a spokesman for Mr. Fernandez, said yesterday that seven of the new schools had been opened in recent months, and 43 more would be opening by the beginning of the next school year.
But with more schools and classrooms being prepared, Ms. Willner said yesterday's report underscores the need for more spending on specialized programs. Among them, she said, is bilingual education, an expensive program that costs an average of $650 per student per year, and expanded school services to work with the parents of immigrant children.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Yields End Low After a Wild Day

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The bond market felt the rumble of the roller coaster yesterday as traders and investors bought, then sold and then bought 30-year bonds again, jolting its yield down, up and then down again.
For several brief moments early in the day and near the end of trading, the yield on the long bond dipped below 6.72 percent, the lowest yield since the Treasury began regular auctions of the bond 16 years ago. 
 But by late in the day, the market's wild ride -- which took the yield up to 6.77 percent, down through 6.72, back up to 6.77 and down again -- ended as the yield came to rest at 6.72 percent, matching the low reached on March 8. The price was up 14/32 to 1056/32 and the yield was down from 6.75 percent Wednesday.
 
Hard Day to Explain
 For traders and analysts, it was not an easy day to explain. The data released early in the day, including the decline in initial jobless claims of 38,000 in the latest week, tended to be positive for the economy.
Many traders and investors have been thinking that the March economic statistics have signaled slower growth. But the report on jobless claims provided signs that the economy was actually looking a bit stronger this month. Reinforcing that view was the increase in the business index of the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia, released yesterday, which rose to 24.6 in April from 19.6 in March.
Still, bond prices rose and yields fell early in the day despite this news.
The complete statistics on car sales for the beginning of the month, which were reported yesterday afternoon, also indicated that April might be better than March. Only at the close of trading, when the Federal Reserve reported that money supply growth in the most recent week was much stronger than expected, did the market seem to react normally, as the news seemed to blunt the long bond's last effort to break below 6.72 percent.
The weakness of the money supply all this year is another reason some forecasters are predicting an annual growth rate for the economy of around 2 percent rather than the 3 percent that many forecasters have predicted.
 
Compromise on Stimulus?
 On the other side of the ledger, supporting a rise in prices and a decline in yields, were comments from the White House that President Clinton was willing to compromise with Senate Republicans by making his $16.3 billion economic stimulus program smaller.
"We grudgingly did better for no particular reason," said Paul McCormack, a managing director at Chase Securities Inc., referring to the trading in relation to the news yesterday.
What seems to explain the moves of the day is not the economic news but the abrupt change in the tone of the market in the last week -- from concern about inflation, which had driven yields higher, to expectations of slower growth, a possibility of another cut in interest rates by the Federal Reserve and confidence that inflation is in check.
"In the last week, we have seen a 180-degree turn in the concern of the market," said David H. Resler, chief economist at Nomura Securities International.
Last week's report of two small increases in producer and consumer prices in March have temporarily laid to rest worries about inflation, and Tuesday's report of a sharp 1 percent decline in March retail sales pushed expectations of slower growth to the forefront.
 
Testing the Market
 So, in part, yesterday was a test of how far the market could go in this new environment, and the long bond was doing the probing. The prices of Treasury notes from 2 years to 10 years were unchanged or little changed, while the discount rates on Treasury bills were up a tad.
But for the day, the testing failed, although some traders said a large, unidentified speculator was moving the market. "The market is trying to do better, but it doesn't have the courage of its convictions," said Joseph Liro, chief economist at S.G. Warburg & Company.
Still, Mr. Liro said, the yield on the 30-year bond should eventually fall below 6.72 percent. And he suggested that the report of industrial production today for March could be the catalyst, especially if it is a lot weaker than expected. He is forecasting a two-tenths of 1 percent decline in production.
But Mr. Liro also warned that if the scant data on April that is now available proved to be right, then "in a couple of weeks the slow growth notion could pass."

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines Against Yen As Trade Discussions Begin

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against the German mark yesterday but weakened against the Japanese yen.
After two days of losses, the yen flirted with all-time highs against the dollar on renewed speculation that the Japanese Government favors a stronger currency to help reduce the nation's trade surplus with the United States. 
 The yen began its rise overnight in Tokyo on reports that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa would support a stronger yen in the trade talks with President Clinton that started yesterday. The leading industrialized nations have pressed for a stronger yen, which should help reduce Japan's bulging trade surplus by making its exports more expensive.
 
Jolts from Germany
 Also rocking the market were comments from Helmut Schlesinger, president of the German Bundesbank, that Germany's interest rates were not too high, considering that the nation's inflation rate is more than 4 percent.
"Every time one of his comments came out, the market jerked one way or another," said Ken Gettinger, head of foreign exchange at the Union Bank of Switzerland.
But Mr. Schlesinger's remarks before the Institute for International Economics were overcome by the market's deeper confidence that the central bank would push rates lower, which would raise the value of the dollar.
"The longer-term expectations are still for rates to come down in Germany," said Ronald Holzer, chief dealer at Harris Trust and Savings Bank in Chicago.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 113.43 yen, down 0.04 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 113.25 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was at 113.10 yen, down from late Wednesday's 113.88 yen.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.5425 from $1.5520 late Wednesday. In New York trading, it settled at $1.5415, down from late Wednesday's $1.5515.
Other late dollar quotes in New York, compared with late Wednesday: 1.6055 German marks, up from 1.5935; 1.4683 Swiss francs, up from 1.4590; 5.4275 French francs, up from 5.3885; 1,543.00 Italian lire, down from 1,544.00; and 1.2594 Canadian dollars, down from 1.2630.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Precious Metals Tumble As Rally's Profits Are Taken

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Precious metals futures prices fell back yesterday as a stronger dollar prompted selling that wiped out most of the sharp gains posted a day earlier.
On other commodity markets, copper futures also fell; oil futures retreated; grains and soybeans were mixed, and livestock and meat futures were mixed.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for April delivery fell $2.50, to $337.20 an ounce; May silver tumbled 6.7 cents to $3.878 an ounce.
July platinum fell $1.20 to $368.10 an ounce on the New York Mercantile Exchange. 
 The losses in gold and silver wiped out Wednesday's advances. Platinum, which rose $6.90 on Wednesday, retained most of that gain amid uneasiness about political and racial tensions in South Africa.
Wednesday's surge in prices was a response to violence in South Africa, the world's biggest platinum producer.
 
A Time for Profit Taking
 John O'Connell, metals analyst with the commodities brokerage firm Refco Inc., said the lack of follow-through buying yesterday left the markets vulnerable to profit taking. He said the selling began about two hours after the markets opened, when the dollar rallied on international currency markets.
A stronger dollar makes American goods costlier overseas, which reduces the likelihood of inflation and makes precious metals less attractive to investors.
Copper futures also fell sharply, reflecting a continuing lack of East Asian demand. April copper dropped 1.20 cents, to 87.10 cents, a pound on the Commodity Exchange.
In energy trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, light crude oil for May delivery fell 18 cents, to $20.22 a barrel; May heating oil fell 0.09 cent, to 55.92 cents a gallon; May unleaded gasoline slipped 0.03 cent, to 60.43 cents, a gallon; May natural gas fell 0.7 cent to $2.357 per 1,000 cubic feet.
Wheat for May delivery rose 5 3/4 cents, to $3.55 1/2 a bushel, on the Chicago Board of Trade; May corn rose 3/4 cent, to $2.31 3/4 a bushel; May oats rose 3 cents, to $1.47 3/4 a bushel and May soybeans fell 4 3/4 cents, to $5.90 1/2 a bushel.
Livestock and meat futures ended mostly lower on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.

HEADLINE: City Opera Chairman Is Stepping Down

BYLINE: By ALLAN KOZINN

 BODY:
Robert W. Wilson stepped down as chairman of the New York City Opera yesterday at a meeting of the company's board. Mr. Wilson, who is 66 and has been chairman since 1981, is to remain on the board as chairman emeritus. Irwin Schneiderman, the current president, and Lloyd E. Rigler, the current vice chairman, will succeed him as co-chairmen.
"Mr. Wilson has presided over a turbulent time that included two strikes, a change of artistic leadership and a recession," Christopher Keene, the company's general director, said yesterday, "and he has consistently supported the company's growth." 
 Mr. Wilson, a private investor who has been one of the City Opera's major financial backers during his tenure, said last summer that the company's $2.9 million deficit for the 1992 season might imperil its future. He has also said that the deficit occurred because the company had striven to improve the quality of its performances in the hope of attracting a new audience and more donors, but that the results had not justified the costs. His suggestion that the company therefore scale back its efforts did not meet with general board approval.
"But this is not about being thwarted in any way," Mr. Wilson said yesterday by telephone. "We have not run out of money, so ideally this is a question that the new regime won't have to deal with. There has been no disagreement. I had wanted to step down sooner. I believe that 12 years is long enough, and that it's time for others to have their turn."
Mr. Wilson said he would fulfill his pledge to give the company $2.5 million over six years, ending in 1995, and that he expected to continue to contribute to the company after that. But in stepping down as chairman, he said that he would be less involved in the company's affairs.
Mr. Schneiderman is a senior partner in the law firm Cahill Gordon & Reindel, and has been on the City Opera board since 1986. Mr. Rigler, who lives in Los Angeles, is an investor and philanthropist who has been on the company's board since 1978, when the City Opera and City Ballet established their own boards. Until then, both organizations had been governed by the board of the City Center for Music and Drama. During City Opera's 1982 financial crisis, Mr. Rigler advanced the company $3 million to cover payroll and expenses, and undertook the cost of setting up a development department.

HEADLINE: Why New York's Credit Ratings May Soon Show Improvement

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Stop New York's Shady Borrowing" (editorial, April 2) would lead one to conclude that New York State's dismal credit ratings are based mostly on questionable debt practices. It follows that the state could raise its ratings by reforming those practices. Debt reform is clearly needed, but your view is far too simplistic.
While these practices contribute to the low ratings, the state's poor credit position is more deeply rooted in a weak economy and weak tax revenue growth; in the inordinately long time it took state officials to adjust to this environment; in an inability to end profligate spending; in over-reliance on budget gimmicks; in failure to maintain a balanced budget in four consecutive years, and in too much debt, as opposed to the form it takes. 
 These factors make it clear why the state's rating sank to the bottom. But it is also clear that substantial progress has been made. The state's ratings are likely to rise, possibly as soon as May 1994, even in the absence of debt reform. It will happen because the worst of the state's economic decline is over. Also, the state has adopted a more conservative approach to tax revenue forecasting and has limited spending growth.
Such changes enabled the state to produce a sizable surplus this year, with another likely next year. It will happen because the last two budgets were adopted close enough to the April 1 deadline to eliminate negative credit implications. And it will happen without debt reform, which is fortunate since the state's plan to eliminate its "shady borrowing" practices falls short of true reform.
The new plan codifies the system, giving the Legislature too much power over issuing debt and leaving the voters not enough control over capital spending.
 
MICHAEL BROOKS
Senior Municipal Credit Analyst
Sanford C. Bernstein & Company
New York, April 8, 1993

HEADLINE: CLINTON CONSIDERS A TOUGHER POLICY TO HALT THE SERBS

BYLINE: By MICHAEL R. GORDON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
As Serbian forces moved on the besieged Muslim town of Srebrenica, President Clinton said today that the United States and its allies needed to consider actions that "previously have been unacceptable" to stop the Serbian attacks in Bosnia.
While American officials debated in private whether to seek air strikes against Serbian artillery positions, Mr. Clinton said at a news conference that in the present situation he had not ruled out any military options except the dispatch of American ground troops to the Balkans. 
 At the same time, the United States pressed its efforts to win allied support for arms deliveries to the Bosnian Muslims. The President expressed outrage not only at the Serbian attacks on Srebrenica (pronounced sreh-breh-NEET-sah) but also at the Serbs' refusal to sign a draft peace treaty.
 
A Sense of Confusion
 His comments on the fighting in the Balkans were his most forceful since he took office, recalling his tough campaign statements in which he likened the Serb attacks to the Holocaust.
In New York, the Security Council voted unanimously to declare Srebrenica a United Nations-protected haven, to send in peacekeeping troops and to demand that the Serbian forces retreat from the town.
The vote marked the first time the Council has taken such an action, but it was unclear whether it would have any immediate effect on the Serbian forces just outside the town. Hours after the vote, a United Nations relief convoy left Belgrade for Srebrenica, Reuters reported. [Page 4.]
Mr. Clinton, appearing at the White House with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan, also said Washington would not take any actions that were not approved by its allies. Behind his strong words, the evident ambivalence of the President's position reflected a sense of confusion and struggle as his advisers remained at odds over whether the United States should take military action in the Balkans.
Defense Secretary Les Aspin has argued that air strikes against Serbian positions should be considered, but Secretary of State Warren Christopher on Thursday appeared to rule out the use of military force.
 
What Strikes Could Do
 If air strikes were conducted, they could be used to silence the heavy artillery that is pounding Muslim towns and cities, to cut the supply lines of Serbian forces and, perhaps, to hit targets in and around Belgrade to punish Serbia, which is supporting the Bosnian Serb offensive.
Even though the fall of Srebrenica appears imminent, air strikes could reduce the threat to Muslin civilians in other besieged cities. A team of Administration experts sent to Bosnia by President Clinton recently concluded that the main threat to Bosnian civilians was not starvation but attacks by Bosnian Serbs.
As Mr. Clinton and his aides anxiously watched developments in Bosnia, Administration officials said Washington had stepped up its efforts to persuade its allies to lift the arms embargo, which has locked in the Serbian weapons advantage, so that arms could be provided to the Bosnian Muslims.
 
An Appeal to Moscow
 The Clinton Administration also informed Russia that it would press ahead with a vote in the United Nations Security Council on expanding the trade sanctions on Serbia if Srebrenica were to fall. That vote was supposed to have occurred last Monday but was delayed at Russia's request.
Administration officials said Washington had also asked Moscow to influence the Serbs to halt the fighting.
But there was no indication that Britain, France and Russia had dropped their opposition to arming the Bosnian Muslims. And Western diplomats also said that the Russian Deputy Foreign Minister, Vitali Churkin, appeared to have essentially taken the Serbian side in recent deliberations.
Nor is there any expectation among Administration specialists that the broadening of the trade embargo would have any immediate effect.
As for the use of force, a senior American official said the Clinton Administration had not yet decided whether it was prepared to launch air strikes alone and had therefore not pressed the idea with its allies.
 
'It's on the Table'
 Reflecting the continuing debate within the Administration, a senior Defense official told reporters today that air strikes against Serbian artillery positions were a possibility once it became clear that the talks initiated by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, the mediators for the United Nations and the European Community, could not be revived. The senior Defense official said, however, that it was unlikely that military action would be taken before the Russian referendum on constitutional revisions on April 25.
"It's on the table," the senior Defense official said, referring to air strikes. "There are no good options. There are some that are less bad than others. The one that is less bad is probably the use of air strikes in some way against the artillery."
But on Thursday, Mr. Christopher appeared to rule out military action in an interview with the NBC News program "Today."
"There's no great mystery about the fact that some people have called for the use of force in Bosnia," Mr. Christopher said. "We think that the use of ground troops, the use of American force, is not the solution to that problem at the present time. It's not being contemplated."
After Mr. Clinton indicated today that air strikes were being considered, Administration officials said they would be on a long list of options that the White House would consider to ratchet up the pressure on the Serbs.
 
'Not Just About Bosnia'
 Still, Mr. Clinton's public comments seemed to embody the ambivalence within the Administration over military action.
On the one hand, the President said that stopping Serb aggression in Bosnia was a critical test of the West's ability to deter ethnic aggression after the end of the cold war.
"I think we have an interest in standing up against the principle of ethnic cleansing," the President said. "If you look at the turmoil all through the Balkans, if you look at the other places where this could play itself out in other parts of the world, this is not just about Bosnia.".
"On the other hand there is reason to be humble when dealing with the former Yugoslavia," Mr. Clinton said, referring to the difficulties German invading troops had in Yugoslavia in World War II. "You have only to look at the topography of the country to realize we have a very limited hand to play."
As the Administration debated air strikes, Lord Owen, the European Community mediator, joined the debate, proposing the selective bombing of roads and bridges in Bosnia to interdict Serb supplies lines.
"I think the world community will now have to consider taking direct action to impose sanctions and that is by far the most effective measure," Lord Owen said.
 
3 Urge Military Action
 A group of three Republican lawmakers, returning from a trip to Bosnia, also urged military action. The lawmakers urged the Administration to impose the total diplomatic isolation of Belgrade, end the arms embargo and undertake air strikes.
"Strategic air strikes against Serbian infrastructure is one of the only ways the Serbs will understand that we are serious about them coming to the peace table,' said Representative Susan Molinari, a Republican of Staten Island and one of the lawmakers.
A team of Administration officials, sent to Bosnia in February by President Clinton, also urged that military action be considered, including the creation of a safe haven protected by international forces.
Still, Western officials said there was little support among the Western European allies for lifting the arms embargo or conducting arms strikes.
Britain, for example, appears dead set against lifting the embargo, arguing that such an action would increase the fighting in Bosnia, endangering its peacekeeping troops.
When former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher called for bombing attacks earlier this week, the British Defense Secretary derided the recommendation as an emotional response.
Secretary Christopher also called Mrs. Thatcher's call for military action "a rather emotional response to an emotional problem."
Even if Mr. Clinton rejects the counsel of the State Department and opts for force, the President has made it clear that the Western Europe allies would, in effect, have a veto over any American plans to use force.
"I have operated from the beginning under the assumption that whatever is done must be done within the framework of a multilateral cooperation, that this was not something the United States could effectively do alone," Mr. Clinton said.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Briton Backs Blockade
 LONDON, April 16 (Special to The New York Times) -- The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, took a somewhat harder line on Serbian aggression in Bosnia today, endorsing a full-scale commercial blockade to tighten existing economic and military sanctions, but still stopped short of supporting any direct military action.
Despite growing pressure from Lady Thatcher and even the leadership of the opposition Labor Party to get the Government to support military moves against the Serbs, including air strikes, Mr. Hurd said he remained dubious.
"We are not ruling out air strikes," Mr. Hurd said in response to a question. But he added that the Government "would have to be clear how it would help," and at this point believed such a move would also have to involve a commitment of ground forces to have any real effect.
He also reiterated his opposition to lifting the arms embargo against the Bosnian Muslims, as Lady Thatcher has argued.
Rather, in brief remarks to reporters outside 10 Downing Street, where he had just met with Prime Minister John Major, Mr. Hurd reaffirmed the British policy of international diplomatic and political pressure to get the Serbs to change their policy of "outrage and inhumanity."

HEADLINE: Cuomo Signs Pact With Indians For Casino in Upstate New York

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 16

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed an agreement today allowing the tiny Oneida Indian Nation near Syracuse to open New York State's first high-stakes gambling casino in more than a century.
Mr. Cuomo was considered the last major obstacle to the Oneidas' plan. The compact is subject to approval by the Interior Department, but the Federal agency has a strong record of endorsing such agreements. 
 Bob Walker, a spokesman for Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt, said: "This Secretary has made it clear he supports Indian gaming as a legitimate method of economic development. He's not looking for reasons to reject it."
Opponents and supporters of casino gambling said that Mr. Cuomo's action opens the way for statewide gambling by weakening arguments against casinos in down-at-the-heels tourist areas such as Niagara Falls and the Catskills.
"Whether we like it or not, we'll have it on Indian reservations," said State Senator Nicholas A. Spano, a Republican from Yonkers who has introduced legislation to allow for-profit gambling statewide. "Now we'll be giving great benefits to Indians while our tourism industry is dying and people are out of work."
Though Mr. Cuomo has never publicly expressed a position on casino gambling, his aides said he felt he had little choice but to sign the Oneida compact since a 1988 Federal law allows Indians to have profit-making gambling operations on their land. Under that law, Indians can run the same games of chance the state allows charities to run. Las Vegas nights are commonly run throughout the state by charities.
 
Broad State Regulation
 "People who are for gaming will use this as a reason to push it," said Mary Ann Crotty, Mr. Cuomo's director of policy management. "But I don't have reason to think that the majority of the Legislature wants that right now."
When made final, the compact will open the door to what is probably the state's first legal casino since Saratoga had one in the 1870's. The agreement will allow the Oneidas to operate a variety of games, including blackjack, roulette, craps and keno. It will not allow for slot machines, which are regarded as the most profitable of gambling games, but which are outlawed in New York State.
The Oneidas, who have 1,100 members living on or near a 32-acre reservation in central New York State, would become the second tribe in the Northeast and the 59th in the nation to have for-profit, casino-style gambling. The Mashantucket Pequots opened a casino in Connecticut last year.
The pact will give New York State broad powers to regulate the Oneida's gambling operations. The New York State Police will post officers in the casino and will conduct background checks on potential employees. Inspectors from the state Racing and Wagering Board will also be present to oversee the integrity of the games.
Leaders of the Oneida Nation say the casino, which they hope to open in July near Verona, about 30 miles east of Syracuse, could generate more than $100 million in profits annually. They say it will provide 2,000 jobs for a largely impoverished area and venture capital for a variety of Indian businesses and social services ranging from day care to low-income housing.
"The execution of this compact with the state begins a new era of economic sovereignty for the Oneida Indian Nation," said Ray Halbritter, the nation's representative, an elected tribal position. Mr. Halbritter has said that the casino will not serve alcohol, at least at the outset, because of the high rate of alcoholism among Indians.
The casino will be operated by an outside management company that has not been chosen, he said. Under Federal law, the tribe must receive at least 70 percent of the net gambling profits.
 
Dispute Over Site
 Though gambling on the Oneida reservation seems almost assured, there still could be a dispute concerning the site of the casino. Under Federal law, tribes seeking to open casinos off their federally designated reservations must first ask the Interior Department to incorporate that land into the reservation, Mr. Walker said.
But the tribe plans to open a 68,000-square-foot casino on a 250-acre tract that is not part of their 32-acre reservation. The $10 million, glass-and-metal structure is nearing completion on land just off the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway.
Mr. Halbritter said that courts have recently ruled that the land was historically owned by the Oneidas and therefore is, in essence, part of their reservation. Mr. Walker said it was not clear whether the Interior Department would dispute that.
The casino has received strong support from business groups and elected officials in central New York State, who view it as a valuable economic boost in an otherwise grim period. Griffiss Air Force Base in nearby Rome is one of several local employers where layoffs are threatened or underway.
"This has always been a high unemployment area," said State Senator William A. Sears, Republican of Utica. "The casino is going to be 2,000 jobs and will bring people from all over to spend money locally. It's a great thing."
 
A Reversal by Cuomo
 Still, many Indians have objected to casino gambling on their land, saying it allows unprecedented state involvement in their internal affairs. Others contend that gambling violates traditional Indian values and can become an addiction as bad as alcoholism.
"It's been proven that there is an increase of family breakdown, domestic violence and child abuse when people gamble," said Gerald Thompson, an Oneida who opposes the casino. "Is the money worth the devastation that could happen to our people?"
Mr. Cuomo's office is also negotiating a gambling compact with the St. Regis Mohawk Indians near the Canadian border. Protests against illegal casinos on the Mohawk reservation in 1990 led to the deaths of two Indians.
Today's signing represented something of a reversal by Mr. Cuomo, who had said that the Legislature needed to authorize state regulation of the casino before he could sign a compact. Republican leaders had said Mr. Cuomo was trying to spread political responsibility for gambling, and they refused to debate the issue until Mr. Cuomo signed the compact.
On Monday, Mr. Cuomo plans to introduce legislation giving him the authority to spend $2.5 million for state police officers and inspectors for Indian casinos. Under the compact, that money will be repaid by the Oneidas.
"We'll look at any legislation that he sends," said Chris McKenna, a spokesman for the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino.

HEADLINE: HAITI ARMY SPURNS OFFER OF AMNESTY

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 16

 BODY:
Haiti's military commanders today rejected an offer of amnesty by the country's ousted President that was to have been the cornerstone of a diplomatic settlement of this country's 18-month-old political stalemate.
The rejection was a setback to the efforts by the special United Nations envoy, Dante Caputo, who had set today as a deadline for the military's acceptance of the amnesty offer. In recent weeks, diplomats involved in the mediation efforts said they had been led to believe by the Haitian military leaders that they would accept the proposed settlement if they received a guaranteed amnesty.
 
U.S. Backs Mediation
 Although the details of the rejection were not disclosed, diplomats said the Haitian Army commander, Lieut. Gen. Raoul Cedras, had rejected outright acceptance of a proposed settlement, which calls for the early return of the exiled President, the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. 
 Father Aristide, a populist priest who was the country's first democratically elected leader, was overthrown in a violent army coup on September 30, 1991.
Mr. Caputo, whose mediation efforts have been strongly supported by the United States, said he was flying immediately to New York and Washington for consultations on what diplomats had already warned would be strong new measures aimed at bringing the Haitian military command into compliance.
Diplomats said they would soon announce highly selective sanctions to step up pressure on Haitian military leaders and their supporters among the country's political elite to accept a return to democratic rule. "There are a few things we are going to try right away," said a diplomat close to the negotiations.
After delivering a written summary of the terms of the settlement on Wednesday night, when he met with senior Haitian officers here, Mr. Caputo said he waited throughout the day Thursday and much of the morning today for the army's answer.
"Some very bad things were said," Mr. Caputo said of the army's reply to the proposed settlement, but he declined to give details.
 
'High Price to Pay'
 A diplomat close to the negotiations said: "They have decided to say, 'We are staying,' in effect, 'If you want us, come and get us.' This, however, is not the way things work with this effort, and they may soon find that they have a very high price to pay for their decision."
Asked what kinds of measures might be taken, the diplomat said: "There are many ways to apply pressure. Here, we may be talking about something like microsurgery."
In recent days, diplomats close to the negotiations have used such analogies not to suggest that an early option would be to use force to remove General Cedras and his associates, who presided over the coup against Father Aristide, but to suggest that as opposed to the hemisphere-wide embargo already imposed on the country, new sanctions would be aimed more precisely at recalcitrant military and business leaders.
Although the new measures will probably not be determined until early next week, after Mr. Caputo completes his meetings with the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, and President Clinton's national security advisers, diplomats have alluded to a number of possibilities in recent days.
 
Possibilities Under Study
 Among the measures that would affect military leaders and their supporters most strongly, diplomats said, would be the suspension of commercial air traffic to the United States, the suspension of visas for adults here and the revocation of visas for their children studying in the United States. Other measures reportedly under study include suppression of contraband arriving from the neighboring Dominican Republic, a strict ban on oil shipments and the freezing of financial assets abroad.
Even before any of these measures can take effect, diplomats said, there are likely to be tensions in the army itself, which the diplomats said is divided over the amnesty proposal.
Although he declined to comment on the current round of negotiations, Mr. Clinton's special envoy here, Charles Redman, has reportedly told Haitians with whom he has met in recent days that whether or not the military accepts the amnesty offer, "We're going to arrive at a political settlement here."
In rejecting the settlement offer, an associate of General Cedras said the Haitian commander had cited a speech by Father Aristide on Sunday offering the political amnesty to army leaders. "Our ancestors wish for us to safeguard each other, according to the country's Constitution," Father Aristide said in his broadcast speech. "Toussaint Louverture accorded an amnesty to General Rigaud and his supporters."
 
Veiled Threat Seen
 The military commander's associate said General Cedras, like other conservative commentators here, had read a veiled threat in Father Aristide's remarks about two of Haiti's most prominent independence-era figures. Within months of the amnesty referred to by Father Aristide, Toussaint Louverture supervised the slaughter of thousands of his rival's supporters in one of the most violent incidents of the country's early-19th-century revolutionary struggle with France.
Political experts said that by seizing upon this supposed threat to back out of an amnesty-based settlement, however, General Cedras may lose the protection from prosecution or punishment that Father Aristide reluctantly granted him as part of the settlement. Diplomats said they had repeatedly advised Haitian military leaders that the settlement represented the best deal they could hope for.
In exchange for the amnesty, the negotiated settlement called for the resignation of General Cedras, many of his military associates and the army-backed civilian Government.
After the formation of a new government and the influx of large-scale economic aid to begin the reconstruction of Haiti's shattered economy, diplomats have said, Father Aristide would be allowed to return from exile in Washington within weeks.

HEADLINE: Clinton and the Japanese Premier Scold Each Other on Trade Issues

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan used their first White House meeting today to scold each other bluntly about international trade, as Mr. Clinton insisted on an approach to resolving disputes that the Prime Minister called unacceptable.
Appearing together at an East Room news conference, the two leaders made clear that little progress had been made on their economic disagreement during a private meeting and luncheon, saying only that they would now attempt to work out new definitions of what could constitute a middle ground. 
 "The world needs a strong Japan," Mr. Clinton said. "The world needs a strong United States. The world needs these two countries to cooperate. And it can only happen if we are making real progress on this trade deficit."
Hours before their meeting, the Commerce Department reported that the United States' overall trade deficit rose slightly to $7.2 billion in February. The trade imbalance with the Japanese, Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown said, accounted for two-thirds of the total deficit so far this year. The United States had a $49 billion trade deficit with Japan last year and an overall deficit of $84 billion.
The strain between the two leaders, the result of weeks of barbs thrown back and forth between representatives of both Governments, was evident today. The leaders shook hands politely at the end of their joint appearance but there was little eye contact during the news conference. And there was little of the normal friendly exchange at the podiums that is common to such staged diplomatic events.
Saying that he was "deeply concerned about the inadequate market access for American firms, products and investors," Mr. Clinton said he would like to see Japan increase its purchase of specific American goods by setting goals.
 
Clinton's Approach Criticized
 But Mr. Miyazawa described the President's approach today as an unacceptable foray into "managed trade" that places all of the burden to create greater market access on Japan.
Each leader offered the other standard praise and spoke of his optimism about the potential for agreement on economic and other issues, but neither man pretended to ignore the underlying tensions in the room. Although President Clinton has described America's relationship with Japan as perhaps its most important bilateral link, the disagreements between the two are substantial and enduring.
"Let's not paper this over," Mr. Clinton said as his chief foreign policy and economic aides watched from the sidelines. "There are still differences between the Prime Minister and me about what we should do."
"I recognize that these are complex issues, but the simple fact is that it is harder to sell in Japan's market than in ours," Mr. Clinton said. "America is accepting the challenge of change and so too must Japan."
But American officials said afterward that the President and the Prime Minister never discussed key points of contention such as Japanese imports of American auto parts or American taxes on imported Japanese minivans during a meeting both sides described as "businesslike" rather than warm.
"The President didn't mean to negotiate," said Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, who has angered many in Japan by accusing the nation outright of engaging in unfair trade practices.
Mr. Miyazawa said, "We must nurture this relationship with a cooperative spirit based upon the principle of free trade."
 
'Plus-Sum Relationship'
 "This cannot be realized with managed trade nor under the threat of unilateralism," he said, referring to the possibility of one country imposing tariffs or sanctions, rather than negotiating agreements. "Our relationship must be a plus-sum relationship, not a zero-sum one."
In remarks to reporters here earlier this week, Ambassador Takakazu Kuriyama said that the United States has sought to impose "some artificial government intervention" on trade policy "which would work against fair and healthy competition."
"It really takes two to dance," Mr. Kuriyama said.
Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Clinton said they had agreed that Japan would devise a plan within the next three months aimed at reducing its trade surplus. And the two pledged to meet twice a year, beginning at the economic summit scheduled to be held in Toyko in July.
 
Numerical Targets Opposed
 Officials said they were seeking to establish a different yardstick by which to measure progress on relations between the two countries. The Japanese are wary of specific goals. The Bush Administration was able to reach agreements on the purchase of American semiconductors and auto parts that the Japanese now fear are being used as the benchmark for future agreements.
"We can make improvements without their being any numerical targets," one Japanese official said after the White House meeting ended.
Even though both sides agreed that a new "framework" would be developed to govern trade relations, Mr. Miyazawa made clear that any plan he presented would not necessarily address any of Mr. Clinton's immediate concerns.
 
Influence of the Yen
 "In the area of our bilateral trade and economic relations, I stressed to the President that our economic prosperity is founded on our deep economic interdependence," Mr. Miyazawa said. "It is in this context that I expressed seriously some concern over some trends in the United States. I explained my Government's policy to continue efforts to increase our market access. But this must be done with parallel efforts of the United States to strengthen competitiveness, export promotion under the free trade system."
Mr. Clinton argued that circumstances have now changed between the two nations because of the appreciation of the yen, the new $115 billion Japanese stimulus program and the increased quality of American goods.
"There are some differences still between the Prime Minister and me about what kinds of agreements we should make sector by sector on these structural issues," he said. "But if we focus on them and talk about them specifically, honestly and openly, I believe this is very different from what has happened in the past."
Mr. Clinton, however, backpedaled on his Administration's criticism of the Japanese Government's recently announced $115 billion economic stimulus plan. Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and others had said the plan lacked the heft needed to spur Japanese buyers into increasing their appetite for imported goods that would presumably come largely from the United States.
Calling the plan "a very good first step," Mr. Clinton said he expected it to be part of a beneficial long-term plan.

HEADLINE: Seeking to Lead Group Beyond Abortion Battle

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
In the simple equation of public image, Planned Parenthood equals abortion rights. And Faye Wattleton, the past president of the organization, equals Planned Parenthood.
But the new president, Pamela J. Maraldo, is working hard to change the old equations. When she took over Ms. Wattleton's midtown Manhattan office in February, she hoped to begin reshaping the Planned Parenthood Federation: moving it beyond the abortion-rights crucible that has consumed its budget and energies in recent years, and transforming it into the leading provider of health care for women.
 
Hostage to Abortion Rights
 She and the organization's board reasoned that a White House and Congress less hostile to abortion rights would clear the way for a broader agenda. 
 Instead, Ms. Maraldo has had to devote much of her energy in her first weeks on the job to stepping into the role that her tough, telegenic predecessor played as the nation's leading spokeswoman on abortion rights.
When Dr. David Gunn was shot to death last month by an anti-abortion demonstrator outside a clinic in Pensacola, Fla., where he performed abortions, Ms. Maraldo was deluged with strategy meetings, calls from the news media, television appearances and press releases. Four days after the shooting, Planned Parenthood took out full-page newspaper advertisements seeking donations to its new clinic defense fund.
 
Combat With Catholic Church
 "We obviously had to do all that, and it was very exciting for me to see how fast this organization can move," said Ms. Maraldo, who spent the previous decade as chief executive of an advocacy group for nurses.
Becoming the leading defender of abortion rights was not the most obvious career path for the Catholic daughter of an Italian mushroom grower in Kennett Square, Pa. But Ms. Maraldo does not seem concerned that her views have already made her the target of a homily by John Cardinal O'Connor of New York.
"I didn't take the job to do combat with the Catholic Church," she said. "But the Catholic Church is an institution that has not factored in the development of women -- economic and social -- in American society, and I'm not uncomfortable about saying that."
 
Slightly Camera Shy
 What does make her uncomfortable is television -- the medium in which Ms. Wattleton, fast on her feet and cool in the heat of hostile debate, was a forceful presence.
"Before I got here, I didn't understand the need to be a public person, the need to go on television when a doctor who performs abortions gets killed by an anti-abortion demonstrator in Pensacola," Ms. Maraldo said. "I didn't understand quite what a leap into the public eye this job would be."
Ms. Wattleton, who is six feet tall, possessed a poise and presence that seemed made for television. Indeed, she resigned from Planned Parenthood to become the host of a syndicated talk show, although that plan has fallen through.
Ms. Maraldo finds the medium both alien and a bit alarming, though she is making an effort to accommodate the cameras. While she does not yet paint her fingernails to match her outfits, as Ms. Wattleton did, Ms. Maraldo has begun to use a clear polish. Still, she still seems thoroughly uninterested in the mirrored dressing room that adjoins her office.
"I'm a fairly nice-looking person, so I never gave it a lot of thought," said Ms. Maraldo, who is 45 years old.
 
Stark Contrast in Personalities
 Her personal style could not be more different from that of Ms. Wattleton. Where her predecessor was cool and precise, Ms. Maraldo is warm and informal. Where Ms. Wattleton spoke in careful cadences, Ms. Maraldo is prone to statements like, "It's a the-whole-is-greater-than-the-sum-of-the-parts kind of thing."
Just how to make this work in front of a camera puzzles her.
"The first time I saw myself on television, I thought I looked like Howdy Doody, moving around all the time," she said.
Adding to her difficulties, Ms. Maraldo got braces in November. "My dentist said it was no big deal, but it is," she said. "Even though you can't see them, they feel funny, and I don't feel like I'm talking like my real self."
She sounds a bit wistful about what she gave up when she left her job running the National League for Nursing, an advocacy group that she transformed in 10 years from a nearly moribund organization with a $5 million budget into a powerhouse that spends $20 million a year to improve the lot of nurses.
"A lot of my closest friends are there," said Ms. Maraldo, who is single. "People like me have had a gradual blurring of the line between personal life and vocation. I have the luxury of being friends with people I work with, and having work that's about the same stuff I would be talking about after work anyway."
One thing Ms. Maraldo would be talking about is health-care policy. Although she spent several years as a hospital nurse -- first on the cardiology unit at the New York University Medical Center, then as an oncology nurse at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center -- most of her career has been devoted to policy rather than patient care.
 
'Fire in Her Belly'
 While never achieving the celebrity of Ms. Wattleton, Ms. Maraldo is widely known in the nursing world for advocating, and winning, basic changes in health-care regulations that brought power and status to the nursing profession. Among other things, she got nurses appointed to the commission that accredits hospitals, and she created a new group to accredit home-care services.
Leah Binder, a friend and former colleague of Ms. Maraldo at the nursing league, said: "She has a fire in her belly about empowering women. When the Planned Parenthood job came along, she talked about it with me, because I've been strongly pro-choice for a long time, and she thinks of me as this raging feminist.
"But actually, she's the raging feminist, and the same issues of women controlling their own lives that she cared about at the nursing league carry over into this new job. It's not so different."
 
Fosters One-Stop Clinics
 Ms. Maraldo at first refused to talk to the search firm that was looking for someone to succeed Ms. Wattleton in the $225,000-a-year president's job, because she felt she lacked expertise in reproductive health.
But while she is still learning about the legal and political issues surrounding abortion -- meeting with Dr. Sheldon Segal to discuss RU-486, the French abortion pill, and reading a constitutional analysis of abortion rights by Laurence Tribe, the Harvard Law School professor -- she is fluent and forceful in selling the idea that Planned Parenthood can be a major player in women's overall health care.
"We know that 70 percent of the women who enter the health-care delivery system come in with reproductive health issues, like contraception or Pap smears," she said. "Most patients want one-stop shopping. If they come in for a breast exam or a Pap smear, they'd really like the person who examines them to help them to take care of their flu, too.
"Planned Parenthood is in a good position to do that, with nurses or physician's assistants who will be the Marcus Welbys of the future, doing primary care and really getting to know their patients."
It was that philosophy that made her attractive to the Planned Parenthood board.
"We were terribly impressed with how she articulated the direction in which this organization should be moving as an established network of providers of women's health care," said the the board's chairwoman, Jacqueline S. Jackson, "which was exactly where we had thought we should be going, too."
Ms. Maraldo said that one of her goals would be to help Planned Parenthood clinics persuade clients not to switch to private gynecologists as they grow older and more affluent.
"A lot of women come to us as young adults, and we want to retain them," Ms. Maraldo said. "But we are going to have to convince them we are capable of serving women who are not young and poor."
Planned Parenthood's nearly 1,000 clinics nationwide are run by 168 independent affiliates that control which services they offer. Though only about a third perform abortions, Planned Parenthood is the nation's largest abortion provider, doing 130,000 of the country's approximately 1.5 million procedures each year.
 
Weathering a Money Crunch
 While the Planned Parenthood Federation gets a portion of its money from its affiliates, it also does its own fund raising. But after the Supreme Court's decision last year reaffirming the right to abortion, followed by the election of Bill Clinton to the Presidency, donations to the Planned Parenthood Federation dropped off so drastically that the organization earlier this year reduced its budget by 25 percent, to $27 million from $36 million, and laid off 34 employees.
"Some people apparently think that abortion is no longer an issue," Ms. Maraldo said. "The public has to understand that the battle's not over, that it is a battle for America's soul. Some rights are nonnegotiable. We have to educate people that if you can take away women's rights one day, the next day it's Jews, the next day it's blacks and the next day it's Italians. Pro-choice means a broad social agenda."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Pamela J. Maraldo, the new president of Planned Parenthood, is working hard to alter the image of the organization. Ms. Maraldo hopes to move it beyond the emphasis on abortion rights that has consumed its energies in recent years and transform it into a leading provider of health care for women. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Toyota to Sell G.M.-Made Cars in Japan

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 16

 BODY:
In a deal that would increase American car exports to Japan, the General Motors Corporation has tentatively agreed to make up to 20,000 Toyotas a year in the United States for sale by the Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan.
The "conceptual" accord, which G.M. confirmed today, came as Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan met with President Clinton for the first time in Washington. 
 Japan has been under pressure to take concrete steps to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States, much of it caused by automobiles and automobile parts.
 
 
History of Cooperation
 Exporting American-made Japanese cars to Japan is not new. Some 37,000 American-made cars were imported by Japan last year, about 20,000 of them Hondas. And G.M. and Toyota, the largest auto manufacturers in their respective countries, already have a history of cooperation.
The two companies operate a factory in Fremont, Calif., that makes both G.M. and Toyota vehicles, some of which are exported worldwide. For General Motors, which sold only about 9,000 passenger cars under its various brand names in Japan last year, selling 20,000 to Toyota would represent a big jump.
But compared with the 1.5 million cars Japan exports to the United States, 20,000 "seems like a drop in the bucket," said Peter Boardman, an auto industry analyst for UBS Phillips & Drew International in Tokyo. "It's well-timed news to calm the political pressure," he said.
 
Sales May Begin in 1996
 A G.M. spokesman in Japan, David G. Bodkin, said that the number of cars involved, which will be right-hand drive models, could reach 20,000 a year and that sales were likely to begin in 1996 or 1997.
Mr. Bodkin would not say which factory would be chosen but said G.M. did not plan to use a plant that had been scheduled to be closed in the company's restructuring.
A Japanese economic newspaper, the Nihon Keizai Shimbun, reported today that the cars to be sold would be new versions of G.M.'s J-car line of subcompacts, which include the Chevrolet Cavalier and the Pontiac Sunbird.
