HEADLINE: Clinton Retreats on Jobs Plan, Offering $4 Billion Cut

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
In his first concession on his plan to stimulate the economy, President Clinton today offered to cut $4 billion from the $19.5 billion package. But the overture was immediately spurned by the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole, who said trimming some fat off what he called a pork-barrel bill was no gift to American taxpayers.
Mr. Clinton's new proposal, made in the hope of luring some Senate Republicans who are blocking his package into negotiations, would keep intact the entire list of job and social programs in the bill. 
 But it would cut, by 44 percent, money for some of the most disputed items, including grants to local communities to build parks. Republicans have sought instead to eliminate programs entirely or to cut other spending to pay for Mr. Clinton's package.
 
$200 Million in New Spending
 Mr. Clinton's latest overture adds $200 million in new spending to enable cities to rehire about 10,000 laid-off police officers. This was included to force Republicans into a vote against crime-fighting if they want to oppose the package, or give Republicans the cover of hiring more police officers to justify siding with Mr. Clinton, a senior Administration official said.
"Let's see how long Dole wants to stand out there and say he is voting against more cops," the official added.
White House officials said today that they hope the compromise offer will at least embarrass the Kansas Republican -- by making the President look accommodating and Mr. Dole unreasonable and unsympathetic to the plight of millions of Americans who are out of work. The White House released the contents of the new compromise offer to the press before presenting it to Mr. Dole.
But Mr. Dole and his aides greeted these tactics with amused contempt. Mr. Dole has made clear that he believes he not only has the backing of his own party, but also a lot of support from the public and some Senate Democrats as well.
 
Puns From Dole
 Mr. Dole has been dismissing Mr. Clinton's overtures with a stream of faxes, puns and declarations that do not exactly evince awe for the White House. Mr. Dole's latest statement, faxed to news bureaus in Washington, was headlined: "Gridlock Begins In Oval Office: New Clinton Budget-Buster No Compromise. Once Again Flunks Deficit Test."
Mr. Dole said his party would support the $4 billion in unemployment benefits in the package but would only support new spending measures if the President made offsetting cuts in other programs, instead of engaging in more deficit spending.
White House officials, by contrast, are convinced that a majority of the public wants a stimulus bill that will create more jobs, and are hoping that the President's new offer will be enough to encourage four Republican senators to support the package -- enough to give Mr. Clinton the 60 votes he needs to end the Republican filibuster that has blocked a vote on the bill.
"This is a new offer," Vice President Al Gore said an interview this morning on NBC. "Now Senator Dole has not made any counteroffer. Their position apparently is to just do nothing and wait. The President tracked him down in New Hampshire, where he was out on the campaign trail, and asked: 'What about a counteroffer? Can we get this thing moving?' We'll see."
Win or lose, Mr. Clinton is expending a lot of political capital to see the passage of a bill that most economists say will have only a marginal effect on the economy and unemployment rates. The fight with Mr. Dole and his Republican colleagues has already slowed the Administration's early momentum. Coming on top of several other foreign and domestic challenges, it seems to have left the White House feeling a bit rattled.
Mr. Clinton spelled out the compromise offer in a letter to the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, who has been handling the negotiations with the Republicans and will meet with Mr. Dole on Monday.
The latest offer left intact money proposed for building new highways ($2.9 billion), summer jobs for youth ($1 billion), early childhood immunizations ($300 million), AIDS treatment ($200 million), construction of sewage treatment plants ($845 million), hiring more meat inspectors ($4 million), assisting small businesses ($141 million) and $4 billion in extended unemployment compensation benefits.
The projects that would be cut roughly 44 percent across the board include community development block grants, student loans, mass transit and summer schools. The compromise also adds $200 million for "grants to local governments to hire police as a means of helping to fight crime and to offset layoffs resulting from the fiscal constraints on local government."
The White House spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, said the compromise would result in a reduction of about 18 percent of the job-creating potential of the bill, meaning it would probably create about 250,000 new jobs instead of 300,000.
 
Reluctance and Regret
 "I make this recommendation reluctantly and regret the unwillingness of the minority to let the Senate act on the original legislation," Mr. Clinton said in the letter to Mr. Mitchell. "But our mandate is to achieve change and to move our country forward and to end business as usual in Washington."
Mr. Clinton said the compromise was intended to "achieve a significant portion of our original goals" in the face of what he called "an unrelenting filibuster."
Though Democrats hold a 57-to-43 majority over Republicans in the Senate, it takes 60 votes to break a filibuster and no Republicans have split off from their party so far. It takes only 51 to pass the stimulus bill, which Mr. Clinton would have no problem mustering -- even though several Democrats have come out against it in its present form. These include Russell D. Feingold and Herb Kohl, both of Wisconsin; Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, and Richard C. Shelby of Alabama.
Mr. Clinton has scheduled a trip to Pittsburgh on Saturday to drum up more public support for his plan. The main reason Pittsburgh was chosen was in hopes of swaying Pennsylvania's Republican Senator, Arlen Specter, a moderate who has spoken in favor of many components of the jobs bill, but was upset by the Clinton Administration's tactic of trying to ram the measure through the Senate without negotiating with the Republicans.
Another reason Pittsburgh was chosen was because Senator Spector is traveling in Africa, and Pittsburgh's airport, where Mr. Clinton will be speaking, was slated to benefit from the stimulus bill. The combination of a junketing Senator opposing money that would help the local community was a bit of symbolism the White House could not pass up.

HEADLINE: Treasury Bonds Retreat From Highs

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Treasury bond prices slipped from record highs yesterday, closing lower in choppy but slow trading.
The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond fell 14/32 , with the yield rising to 6.75 percent after sinking to a 16-year low of 6.71 percent on Thursday. 
 Bond prices had established new highs in overseas markets, but traders in the United States saw an opportunity to cash in on the gains when activity shifted to domestic markets, failing to muster the momentum to break through a key psychological level.
 
'Market Is Not Ready'
 "The market is not ready yet to blast through these levels to a lower yield," said Kevin Logan, chief economist in the United States for the Swiss Bank Corporation.
Yesterday's volatility followed a recent trend in which bond prices have moved up and down as much as a point in a session because of thin trading. But prices have been trading within a range, with few signals to modify the market's modestly bullish sentiment.
Some selling yesterday may have been prompted by a Government report showing March industrial production unchanged from February, ending a string of five advances.
The market had expected weaker data, and the report initially seemed to increase the likelihood that the Federal Reserve will maintain its monetary policy, given the relative strength of the economy. The Fed typically lowers interest rates to help stimulate a weak economy, which results in higher bond prices.
The news, however, did little to change the market's tone, said Anthony Karydakis, senior financial economist at First Chicago Capital Markets. He said "two-tenths in either direction is considered in line with expectations."
Mr. Logan said the next big news could come out of Washington as President Clinton's economic program and health care reform package encounter more hurdles.
"A lot of investors are marking time," he said. "They are sidelined, content with their positions."
Short-term Treasuries were unchanged to 4/32 lower, and intermediate maturities were off 2/32 to 5/32 .
The Lehman Brothers Daily Treasury Bond Index, reflecting price movements on bonds with maturities of a year or longer, fell 1.61, to 1,302.95.
Yields on three-month Treasury bills rose to 2.88 percent, with the discount yield rising a basis point, or a hundredth of a percentage point, to 2.83 percent. Six-month yields rose to 3.04 percent, with the discount adding two basis points, to 2.96 percent. One-year yields slipped to 3.18 percent, with the discount off a basis point, to 3.07.
In the tax-exempt market, the Bond Buyer index of 40 actively traded municipal bonds closed at 101 5/8, down 1/8 from Thursday. The average yield to maturity was 5.91 percent, up from 5.90.

HEADLINE: U.S. Reports Its Trade Deficit Has Hit a Three-Month High

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
The United States merchandise trade deficit hit a three-month high of $7.2 billion in February, nearly three-fourths of which was with Japan, the Government reported today.
"The Japanese economy is so weak that they are not importing," said Kermit Baker of Cahners Economics in Newton, Mass. "Until that economy starts to recover, we won't see any improvement." 
 The report came on the same day that President Clinton met for the first time with Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan to discuss trade issues, particularly the American trade deficit with Japan, which reached $49 billion last year, 59 percent of the total for the year.
 
 
Widest Gap Since November
 The Commerce Department said the American gap with its trading partners widened five-tenths of 1 percent in February to the highest level since November, when it was $7.3 billion. It had dipped to $6.9 billion in December before rising to $7.16 billion a month later.
Those figures were adjusted for seasonal variations.
When unadjusted, the deficit totaled $5.7 billion, including $4.1 billion with Japan, 73 percent of the entire shortfall and the highest since a $5.1 billion imbalance last December.
For the year so far, the unadjusted deficit between the two countries was $8 billion, 68 percent of the $11.8 billion American imbalance. The Commerce Department does not make seasonal adjustments by countries.
The Commerce Secretary, Ronald H. Brown, said in a statement that an improvement in the American-Japanese trade situation would be a "driving item" during his visit to Japan next week.
The report said exports, a big source of strength for the American economy for four years, virtually stalled in February, inching up a barely perceptible one-tenth of a percent, to $37.2 billion.
 At the same time, imports increased only two-tenths of a percent, to $44.4 billion. The deficit is the difference between the two.

HEADLINE: March Industrial Output Unchanged

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
Held down by the East Coast blizzard in mid-March, industrial output remained unchanged for the month after posting five straight advances, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
But since most analysts had expected a modest decline, based mainly on employment and workweek data published two weeks ago, the results were considered in line with continued moderate economic expansion. At month's end, the Government is expected to report first-quarter growth in gross domestic product of 2.5 percent to 3 percent. 
 "Production has been chugging along" to replenish inventories depleted by the holiday buying surge, said Robert T. McGee, senior economist for the Tokai Bank.
 
February Output Revised Upward
 Today's report also showed that production climbed six-tenths of a percent in February compared with the gain of four-tenths of a percent initially estimated. January's output, however, was revised downward by two-tenths of a point.
Separately, the University of Michigan told subscribers to its survey of consumer confidence that the preliminary April reading was 84, down slightly from the 85.9 final for March.
While the Fed cited the blizzard as a factor in the flat industrial performance last month, neither it nor other analysts would estimate how much the storm dampened output in March. Most assumed there would have been at least a small overall gain without the storm, but they also noted that it was a positive factor in the utility sector, since it prompted consumers and businesses to turn up the heat.
"Things were a little soft because of the weather," said Darwin L. Beck, a one-time Fed employee who is now an economist for the First Boston Corporation. But, he added, "one never knows" how much of a factor a storm might have been or how much lost production might be regained.
Without adjustment for usual seasonal variations, industrial production fell seven-tenths of a percent last month after jumping 3 percent in February.
 
Capacity Use Is Up
 In addition, the Fed's compilation showed that the nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 79.9 percent of capacity in March, the same pace first reported for February. The upward revision in February output, however, pushed utilization for that month to 80.1 percent, the first time since December 1990 -- when it was in recessionary decline -- that the rate exceeded 80 percent.
The March operating rate for factories was 79.1 percent -- 2.4 points above the year-earlier pace -- while mines operated at 81.8 percent and utilities at 88.3 percent.
Output at factories was up one-tenth of a percent for the month, the Fed reported, with the storm taking its biggest toll on textiles, steel, furniture, tobacco and coal mining. Production from mines and oil and gas wells slumped 1.2 percent, the fourth straight decline, while the gain for utilities was eight-tenths of a percent.
Motor vehicles were assembled at an annual rate of 11 million, down from 11.2 million in February and 11.5 million in January, and production of aircraft and gasoline also declined. Cutbacks in military and space equipment remained a restraint on industry, the Fed said.
 
Appliance Output Rises
 The losses were offset mostly by increases in output of appliances and by residential utilities.
Production of business equipment rose four-tenths of a percent, but this came after gains averaging more than 1 percent a month since October, the Fed also pointed out.
At 112.0, the Index of Industrial Production stands 12 percent higher than its 1987 average and 4.1 percent above its level of March 1992.

HEADLINE: Changing Times: Push-Button Fires

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BETHEL, Vt.

 BODY:
David F. Knowles, secret weapon in hand, stood before a stove with cheery yellow flames dancing over a stack of gnarly logs. The winter just ended was another mediocre one for his industry, wood stoves, but in his palm was his wait-until-next-year weapon, a black plastic box that looked suspiciously like a remote control unit borrowed from a television set.
It was. One click and the flames disappeared. Another and they suddenly came back. And the stove does not burn wood at all; the logs are ceramic, and -- no fuss and no bother -- the merry flames come from natural gas. 
 Remote control? Imitation wood? From Vermont Castings, which made a name for itself in the 1970's and early 1980's with stoves named "Defiant," "Resolute" and "Vigilant?"
 Even in Vermont, whose main exports are maple syrup and New England charm, the 80's took their toll. Oil became cheap and wood expensive; environmental regulators said stoves were big sources of air pollution. People changed, too; the radical back-to-the-land types who once demonstrated to Free Huey and Free the Chicago 7 got more interested in free checking and free parking. So the company, after some corporate misadventures, is trying to catch up with its market.
"We have something for everyone," said Mr. Knowles, the company's research and development director, his face fairly glowing. "There are people who like to dump wood on the stove, and there are people who just like to come home and have a fire," he added.
Vermont Castings recently introduced the gas stove that starts at the touch of a button; full-scale production will begin soon on the remote control model, in time for next winter's heating season. Soon after will come a remote with a temperature dial in the middle; leave it set to the desired level, and the stove will automatically keep the room heated to that temperature. Some models even forsake the macho cast iron in favor of Italian ceramic stove bodies.
 The company won a cult-like following in the 70's and 80's of die-hard, penny-pinching New England Yankees. The owners prospered in the oil price shocks of the 1970's but stayed so folksy that they invited all their customers to an annual "Owners Outing" picnic on a verdant mountainside here, with fiddle music and plant tours; sometimes 10,000 attended.
It was a peculiarly conservative business; the company would not build a stove until the customer put down a deposit, and there was no sales network. Most buyers appeared with pick-up trucks to haul their purchases home.
In 1983, one of the co-founders, Murray Howell, died of cancer. In 1988, the management saddled itself with debt to buy out its largest competitor, Consolidated Dutchwest, and made extensive changes to its foundry in Randolph, just up the road from Bethel, to produce the Consolidated Dutchwest stoves.
The Environmental Protection Agency required that smoke output be cut by more than 80 percent for health reasons. For Vermont Castings, like the rest of the industry, that meant extensive redesign, and in some cases, catalytic converters akin to the ones on cars. The changes promoted fuller combustion, and therefore more heat per log. But the company's owners ran short of capital.
Further, over the course of the 80's, the price of home heating oil fell by nearly half, in inflation-adjusted terms. The old New England adage that wood warms you twice -- once when you chop it and again when you burn it -- began losing its charm. Sales plunged.
 
New Owners
 In May 1990, Vermont Castings' chief creditor, Pacificorp Financial Services of Portland, Ore., stepped in. Now, according to a spokesman, Jeff Wakefield, "the plaid-shirt types are gone." The new owners have brought in a new marketing team, from companies like Mennen and Gillette, and new products.
The gas stoves (or "hearth appliances," as the catalogue calls them), in red, blue, sand, antique brown and midnight black, now account for 15 percent of sales. They, and a stove that burns wood pellets and is controlled by a computer-like circuit board, have restored the company to profitability; 1992 was the first time in 13 years that sales volume grew, according to the firm, with total sales of about $40 million. In North America, it was the company's best year since 1981, when oil prices were at their peak.
For the industry, sales in 1992 were between 150,000 and 160,000 units, roughly the same as the year before, with the market divided among some 50 manufacturers. At the beginning of the 80's there were about 350 manufacturers, turning out more than 500,000 units a year, according to the industry's trade association. Formerly the Wood Heating Alliance, it became the Hearth Products Association in 1991, reflecting the members' search for new products.
Vermont Castings introduced new business practices -- charge accounts, a network of dealers and wholesale pricing that equalizes retail prices around the country. Phoenix, not known for its winters, is a big growth market, said William J. Mathewson, vice president for marketing and sales, and a former vice president of Mennen U.S.A. On the other hand, there will be no more picnics. "Liability problems, things like that," he said.
"The real source of the decline was the bloom coming off the energy crisis," said Carter E. Keithley, president of the Hearth Products Association, which has about 1,500 members. Gas, he said, offers "the convenience factor," and with about 51 million American homes with gas service, a huge market awaits. The industry estimates that nearly two-thirds of those homes have wood fireplaces, ripe for conversion.
Not that efficiency is the goal in the gas-burning models either; they are purposely carbureted badly, to make the flame yellow instead of blue.
The stove industry's turnabout is all the more striking because for a time in the 70's and early 80's, Federal law banned new ornamental gas appliances, because gas was thought to be in short supply. After price controls were lifted, drillers found extensive new reserves and flooded the market.
Vermont Castings is far from alone; the American Gas Association now lists 34 hearth stove manufacturers, up from 5 in 1987.
Wood stove sales still outnumber gas stove sales, especially in places where people cut their own wood. And a replacement market is developing, sometimes aided by local air pollution control officials. In 1991, for example, Crested Butte, Colo., began charging people with uncontrolled wood stoves $30 a month, to encourage them to switch to cleaner models.
 
High Price of Wood
 But in large metropolitan areas, wood is uncompetitive.
"It's probably much more expensive than oil," said Charles G. Ehrens, who has stopped offering wood stoves in his Leisure Unlimited chain of stores in Hartsdale, N.Y., and Danbury, Westport, Orange and West Hartford in Connecticut. And wood was never easy anyway, he said.
"I was not prepared to get up every morning and worry about the damn stove," he said. "I'm not a back woodsman. It doesn't give you fast heat. A stove is meant to burn all day, day in and day out."
Although the stove market may not grow much, Mr. Mathewson thinks Vermont Castings' share of it can. The trick, he said, is to interest homeowners, and especially home buyers, in more than just a wood stove, but a particular brand. "Stoves are the most under-marketed product in the country," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Knowles of Vermont Castings holding a remote control for a gas stove. "We have something for everyone," said Mr. Knowles, who is the research and development director. "There are people who like to dump wood on the stove, and there are people who just like to come home and have a fire." (Jon Gilbert Fox for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Clinton Backs Stronger Yen And Dollar Sinks Against It

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar plunged to a new postwar low against the Japanese yen yesterday as President Clinton, emerging from trade talks with Japan's Prime Minister, stressed support for a stronger yen.
The remarks came after new trade figures showed that Japan's huge trade surplus with the United States swelled further in February. 
 But the dollar advanced against the German mark and other leading European currencies, which were affected more than the dollar was by the yen's surge.
Gold rose in New York but was mixed overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery rose $1.80 an ounce to $339. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $338.50 an ounce, up $1.90.
Reports swept the market this week that Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan would like to see a higher yen as a way to make Japanese products more expensive on world markets, which would help to pare the country's trade surplus.
 
Further Drop in New York
 After falling against the yen in Tokyo and European markets, the dollar retreated further in New York when the Commerce Department reported that the United States merchandise trade deficit hit a three-month high of $7.2 billion in February. Nearly three-fourths of the deficit was with Japan.
The dollar plummeted to 112.15 yen around midafternoon, its lowest point since World War II, after Mr. Clinton told reporters that the trade surplus could be pared by "No. 1, the appreciation of the Japanese yen."
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 112.95 yen, down 0.48 yen from Thursday's close. Later in London, it fell to 112.60 yen. By late afternoon in New York, the dollar settled at 112.30 yen, down from 113.10 yen late Thursday.
Mr. Clinton's remark eased concerns that the seven leading industrial nations would intervene to halt the rise of the yen, which has gained as much as 10 percent this year against the dollar.
The mark, hurt by pervasive weakness in the German economy, was pummeled the most as traders sold it to buy yen. The weaker mark helped the dollar score gains against other European currencies.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Pork and Cattle Prices Fall; Lumber Continues to Surge

BYLINE: By ReutersReuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, April 16

 BODY:
Pork prices fell sharply today after the weekly pace of hog slaughters picked up, resulting in selling that also put pressure on cattle prices.
In other commodity markets, lumber prices jumped the $10 limit for the second consecutive day, most grain prices tumbled and energy prices eased. 
 The hog slaughter jumped to 1.8 million head in the last week, according to Government estimates, lifting the projected supply. The slaughter was below expectations in recent weeks.
 
'Real Jittery'
"The trading is real jittery over this hog slaughter coming in over 1.7 million. We finally penetrated some real key support areas in live hogs," said Dennis Smith, livestock analyst with the Linnco Futures Group.
Traders will take their cue on Monday from hog marketing levels in the Midwest; analysts said a daily run of more than 100,000 head would keep pressure on prices.
Falling hog prices also pushed down already weak live cattle prices for delivery in April, which dropped 0.875 cent, to 81.025 cents a pound. April feeder cattle was unchanged at 85.6 cents.
Lumber prices hit the daily limit of $10 for 1,000 board feet for the second consecutive session, feeding off a cash market for spruce. May lumber closed at $365.30 for 1,000 board feet.
After spending most of the day in the doldrums, corn and soybean futures came to life late in the session as traders representing commodity funds sold. Two meteorologists contradicted the National Weather Service and said warm, dry air would edge into the Midwest next week, drying out the saturated soil.
The commodity funds had held large positions in the soybean complex, betting on a rally tied to inflation fears. But recent data have dispelled those fears.
Crude oil for May fell 8 cents, to $20.14 a barrel; May heating oil eased 0.05 cent, to 55.87 cents a gallon, and May unleaded gasoline dipped 0.09 cent, to 60.34 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
I.R.A.'s Yes, but They're Not Only Kid on Block

BYLINE: By Allen R. Myerson

 BODY:
IN the pamphlets and advertisements pouring forth from banks, brokerage firms and mutual funds, I.R.A.'s are the financial equivalent of vitamin E -- a way to prevent all ills. To scoop up I.R.A. accounts and other retirement savings, Merrill Lynch, for example, has churned out a large-format, 521-page hardcover guide, with a cardboard calculator bound in. Those wanting to guarantee a healthy retirement should buy the book and bench-press it 10 times every morning.
Lately, individual retirement accounts have become an easy sell. I.R.A. investments, off sharply in the late 1980's after Congress restricted their tax deductibility, have come roaring back. 
 Financial advisers strongly recommend that the roughly half of all workers who can still take I.R.A. tax deductions do so. Employees with no corporate retirement plans, as well as joint filers earning less than $50,000 and individuals earning less than $35,000, remain eligible for at least partial deductibility.
For those who cannot take deductions, some advisers show less enthusiasm than many financial merchants. Just the record-keeping to separate deductible and taxable contributions and calculate the taxes decades later causes even some accountants to wince.
Before making nondeductible I.R.A. contributions, investors should set aside all they can through other deductible channels. These include 401(k) plans at many corporations and Keogh and simplified employee pensions (S.E.P.'s) for small businesses and the self-employed.
Then, those saving for retirement should compare the tax-free returns available from municipal bonds and, perhaps, the tax-deferred merits of annuities. Municipals have the advantage of paying interest that remains free of most taxes. I.R.A. earnings are taxed when withdrawn.
Especially for those cautious investors who favor bonds, buying municipals outside their I.R.A.'s can make the most sense, said Lewis J. Altfest, an investment adviser in New York. Corporate and government bonds or bond funds, common I.R.A. vehicles, do pay higher interest rates than municipals. (A point lost on the wretches whose I.R.A.'s hold $51 million in municipal bond funds, sacrificing yield for a redundant tax advantage). Currently, Treasury bonds pay about 6.7 percent, municipal bonds about 5.9 percent.
But eventual taxes on I.R.A. withdrawals could leave the ultimate returns on the corporate and government bonds below those available from municipals. "In the case of the I.R.A., we're getting tax deferral," Mr. Altfest said. "We're not getting tax elimination. In the case of the muni, we never have to pay taxes."
The surge in retirement saving has also washed into annuities. Until recently, annuities were looking rather tired and wan. They offered only narrow investment choices, high fees and other restrictions that largely limited their appeal to older investors. Then their backers took some lessons from the marketers at the brokerage firms and mutual funds.
Now, it's as if annuities have just emerged from an extended stay at the Golden Door health spa. Wood Logan Associates, which sells its Venture annuities through brokerage firms including Paine Webber and Shearson Lehman Brothers, expects to pick up $1 billion this year, up from $632 million last year.
There are fixed annuities, which guarantee steady but relatively low returns without the risk of loss, and variable annuities, which can be invested in stock, bond or money market funds. Investors pay taxes on their contributions, but their earnings accumulate tax-free until withdrawn.
Wood Logan promotes its annuities as P.R.A.'s, or private retirement accounts. "It looks, acts and breathes just like an I.R.A.," said Doug Wood, the firm's chairman.
But they still sometimes quack. For one thing, variable annuities tend to have much higher annual fees and expenses, typically more than 2 percent a year, about twice as much as those of mutual funds available in I.R.A.'s. Although some variable annuity sponsors like to call them no-load, redemption fees often range from about 7 percent for those wanting to cash out within in a year to perhaps 2 percent within 7 years.
Some fixed annuities, however, are paying a percentage point more than risk-averse investors can earn from buying certificates of deposit for their I.R.A.'s. All annuities are free of any ceilings on annual contributions, an attraction for some investors who have already reached their $2,000 annual I.R.A. limits.
The annuities and the I.R.A.'s share a paradoxical advantage over investments that are not shielded from taxes. Any withdrawals before age 59 1/2 suffer a 10 percent penalty in addition to regular income taxes.
"We're not a saving nation, and this forces people to save," said Stuart Kessler, senior tax partner at Goldstein, Golub Kessler & Company, accountants in New York. He recommends nondeductible I.R.A. contributions.
The higher taxes sought by President Clinton would provide an added incentive for tax-deferred savings. And Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen, formerly the chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, sponsored a bill last year to restore the broad deductibility of I.R.A. contributions. Part of a tax bill vetoed by President Bush, the measure is bound to be revived.
Despite all the inducements from Washington and Wall Street, Americans are unlikely to become as thrifty as, say, the Japanese. Even though many younger people -- fearful of losing their jobs, uncertain about pensions or Social Security -- are starting I.R.A.'s, they are unlikely to save at the same rate as their parents.

HEADLINE: Q & A

BYLINE: Leonard Sloane

 BODY:

Your Own 401(k)?
Q. Is it possible for an employee to arrange a 401(k) plan on her own?
 GAIL HARRINGTON, Larchmont, N.Y.
A. No. "The Internal Revenue Code restricts such arrangements to qualified pension, profit-sharing and stock bonus plans maintained by employers," said William J. Arnone, director of financial and retirement planning for Buck Consultants of New York.
Individuals may, of course, set up their own individual retirement plans, which allow tax-deferred investment earnings to accumulate as with a 401(k) savings plan. And self-employed people can establish a simplified employee pension, known as a S.E.P., which operates under the same basic rules as an I.R.A., or a Keogh plan, which operates like a 401(k) plan.
 
 
 
Broker-Held Securities
Q. What are the pros and cons of leaving your securities in the custody of a broker?
 MILDRED D. MAILICK, Forest Hills, Queens
A. A big advantage of keeping securities in the custody of a brokerage firm is that you don't have to worry about safeguarding them or delivering them at the time of sale. There is also generally an automatic deposit of your interest and dividends into some type of interest-bearing money market account at the firm.
"The major disadvantage is that you become tied to the broker who sold the securities to you and whose commissions probably cannot be negotiated," said Kenneth Janke, president of the National Association of Investors Corporation.
In addition, you cannot enter a company's dividend reinvestment plan when your stock is registered in the broker's name. And if the broker has financial difficulties -- even with the insurance protection for customer assets that most firms have -- there may be delays before you can reclaim your securities.
 
 
 
Callable Treasury Bonds
 Q. Why doesn't the Treasury issue bonds with a callable feature?
 WILLIAM H. O'BEIRNE, Brooklyn,
A. Callable debt is redeemable by the issuer before the scheduled maturity date, with calls usually made when the issuer can save money by floating new debt at a lower interest rate. The Federal Government did sell callable bonds in the past and about two dozen issues are still outstanding. But it stopped selling them when it instituted the Strips program in the mid-1980's, a system that led to the separate trading of the principal and interest on its bonds.
"In a system like that, it's pretty inconvenient to have callable bonds," said Deborah Danker, Deputy Assistant Treasury Secretary for Federal Finance. "If the bonds could be called, an investor could never be sure that the interest payments would actually be made in later years."
From a broader perspective, the question relates to the fact that the Government considers itself a large enough entity to self-insure. A call on a bond usually requires a higher interest rate -- in effect, an insurance premium -- that Washington chooses not to pay.

SECTION: Section 1; Page 20; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 452 words

HEADLINE: Lowering the Passions Over Trade

 BODY:
Standing between President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa of Japan during their talks yesterday in Washington was a looming $50 billion trade imbalance. Mr. Clinton labeled the deficit unacceptable and warned that it jeopardized cooperation between the two economic superpowers. Also turning up the heat on the trade dispute are powerful industrialists threatened by Japanese exports; U.S. automobile manufacturers took out a full-page newspaper ad yesterday calling the trade deficit with Japan "priority number one."
Though the two leaders were polite during a press conference following their talks, belligerence was close to the surface. That's too bad, because the trade deficit is a poor reason to drive a wedge between important allies. 
 The U.S. trade deficit reflects a home-grown problem that can be solved with home-grown remedies. Americans buy more goods than they produce; the difference is imported from abroad. If Americans spent less -- saved more -- the trade deficit would disappear. Japan, which saves four times more than the U.S., runs persistent trade surpluses.
Japan does block some U.S. exports. So there is reason for Mr. Clinton to pry open Japanese markets. If Japan imported more supercomputers, medical technology and semiconductors, American workers could concentrate in high-wage jobs -- a marginal but welcome boost to living standards.
But America's economic malaise cannot be cured by bashing Japan. The remedy is to raise savings -- most easily by cutting the Federal budget deficit -- and to raise public and private investment. That, of course, is the core of Mr. Clinton's domestic plan.
The danger is that Mr. Clinton will accept the advice of those urging him to wipe out the trade deficit by fiat: Tell the Japanese how many more U.S. semiconductors and supercomputers they must buy and how many fewer cars they will be allowed to sell. But Tokyo could enforce such edicts only by replacing market decisions with bureaucratic controls -- an odd message from a country that's lecturing Russia to do the opposite.
Besides, trade-by-fiat would prove contagious; Europe, with which the U.S. runs a trade surplus, wouldn't take long to limit U.S. exports. In the end, trade would be stunted and middle-class consumers would face higher prices.
Judging from their remarks, the two leaders tried to turn down the flames heating up trade resentment. They agreed to focus future negotiations on opening up sectors where exports are blocked -- holding each country to rules of fair trade. But if enforcing fair rules slips into enforcing strict quantitative results, the two countries will reignite destructive political and economic passions.

PUB-DATE: April 18, 1993

SECTION: Section 7; Page 14; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1263 words

HEADLINE: King of the Hill, Top of the Heap

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts; Sam Roberts is the urban affairs columnist for The New York Times.

 BODY:

A PHOENIX IN THE ASHES
The Rise and Fall of the Koch Coalition
in New York City Politics.
By John Hull Mollenkopf.
285 pp. Princeton, N.J.:
Princeton University Press. $35.
 
TO BE MAYOR OF NEW YORK
Ethnic Politics in the City.
By Chris McNickle.
Illustrated. 403 pp. New York:
Columbia University Press. $29.95. 
 TWO years ago the chairman of the Budapest City Council's Committee on Human Rights and Minorities spent several weeks surveying the Balkanization of New York City. In Budapest, Dr. Gabor Nagy said, the predominant minority group, the Gypsies, constitutes only about 10 percent of the population. In New York, as he discovered while observing the first campaign for an expanded City Council, political power is more fragmented.
"This is not just a city of ethnic concerns," Dr. Nagy concluded. "It's a city that requires taxation and services. This guy will represent the gays and that one the African-Americans and this one the Hispanic people and that one the Asians.
"But who," he asked, "will represent the majority?"
The answer is simple: it is supposed to be the Mayor. In New York, though, there is a second part to the question that is considerably more challenging: exactly who, in a shifting constellation of fading and rising stars, is the majority? Whoever is elected Mayor this year will preside as his constituents begin to mark the centennial of greater New York. (In 1898, what are now the five boroughs joined together as a single city.) Given the intensity of tribal politics, it seems remarkable that New Yorkers have stuck together so long. Two scholarly analyses illuminate an unsurprising conclusion about New York's current political cohesion: race coupled with ethnicity and religion, more than class, galvanizes and unites the city's shrinking white majority as the century ends.
John H. Mollenkopf's new study, "A Phoenix in the Ashes," is a thorough, if sometimes pedantic, analysis of the changing electorate on which Edward I. Koch capitalized to become New York's 105th Mayor in 1977 and which, having continued to change, discarded him 12 years later. "To Be Mayor of New York," by Chris McNickle, is an encyclopedic overview from the 1880's to the present; it contributes the vital context in which to consider today's events.
Historical perspective is the one ingredient lacking in Mr. Mollenkopf's otherwise instructive account, which amplifies on demographic research he did as a political science professor at the Graduate Center of the City University of New York. Mr. Mollenkopf suggests that Mr. Koch actively exploited middle-class white fears of black and Hispanic encroachment and capitalized on the divisions among his opponents; dispensed "new patronage" to a network of community service providers; struck an accommodation with a rebounding regular Democratic Party organization; and forged a growth-minded coalition with real-estate developers and the corporate elite. "His genius," Mr. Mollenkopf writes, "lay in his ability to construct a new kind of dominant political coalition that made the pursuit of economic growth a politically rational thing to do."
Mr. Koch's successor, David N. Dinkins, benefited from a New York tradition of interracial trust to fashion a "black-led, biracial and multiethnic insurgent coalition," Mr. Mollenkopf writes. But, he continues, except perhaps for the racial card, Mr. Dinkins's agenda as Mayor has seemed strikingly similar to Mr. Koch's. This finely nuanced and sophisticated analysis (supplemented with research by Charles Brecher and Raymond D. Horton of the Citizens Budget Commission) suffers only when it lapses into jargon and seems to infer too much from voting patterns.
Mr. McNickle's history of ethnic succession, and of ethnic secession from changing majorities, is the product of a dangerous exercise: transforming a doctoral dissertation in history into a book. In this case, the author has succeeded. Mr. McNickle, a pension fund consultant, locates the seeds of the Koch coalition in the 1960's, when the city's white majority began to put aside historical ethnic and religious rivalries. "A political alliance emerged in the wake of that decade led by not-so-liberal Jews, supported by Irish Catholics, Italian Catholics and other whites," he writes. "Racial tension held it together."
"To Be Mayor of New York" is a reminder that in a city where ethnic politics is a preoccupation, mayoral campaigns are a continuum punctuated by periodic pauses for governing. Such an overview vividly recalls the era of the balanced ticket, the collapse of the Democratic machine, the depth of dissatisfaction among the many whites who believed the Lindsay administration was favoring blacks, the rise and fall of ethnic hegemonies, and the us-is-them incorporation of the reform movement into the Democratic Party hierarchy. The largely chronological view draws heavily on published accounts and is burdened by some incidental, if enlightening, asides. (Mr. Dinkins, who has been mocked for showering frequently, might be reassured by the reminder that Mayor Vincent R. Impellitteri regularly got rubdowns on a City Hall massage table.)
SPRINKLED through the text are revealing anecdotes gleaned from the author's own interviews, such as a 1969 episode in which Mr. Lindsay's campaign manager, Richard Aurelio, and the Manhattan Republican leader, Vincent F. Albano Jr., browbeat Sanford Garelik, Chief Inspector of the Police Department, to accept the nomination for City Council President on a fusion ticket. "What kind of man are you?" Mr. Aurelio demanded repeatedly of Mr. Garelik, finally prompting Mr. Albano to whisper the cautionary advice: "Christ, Dick, remember he's got a gun."
"To Be Mayor of New York" is an engaging history that is short on analysis but makes a fine introduction to Mr. Mollenkopf's deconstruction of the Koch coalition. Readers for whom time is at a premium might skip Mr. McNickle's account of the Koch administration altogether and go directly to his conclusion: "The various candidates for Mayor in New York have often taken nearly identical positions on local political matters. As a result, citizens cast their votes on the basis of the image the candidates present, not the policies they define. The vote is not a selection of a series of programs. It is a statement of the kind of world the voter would like to see."
That the candidates so often sound alike places a greater premium on how they look. "To be Mayor of New York," Mr. McNickle writes, "requires a leader who can reconcile the competing visions the city's ethnic groups hold of the metropolis, at least in sufficient measure to win the confidence of a majority."
Regardless of how they sound or look while they are running, candidates often tend to act similarly once they win. Getting re-elected requires not only the promise of reconciliation, but the demonstrated leadership and vision that denies rivals a compelling rationale. Mr. Mollenkopf suggests one vehicle for Mr. Dinkins to use to contribute a new dimension to New York City politics: "an alliance between the city workers and community-based organizations who produce public services and the neighborhood residents who use them." But in every potential ash heap, another would-be Phoenix lies in wait. As a consequence of the Mayor's caution, Mr. Mollenkopf concludes, "the Dinkins coalition may founder, as have many of its reform predecessors, on its internal contradictions, opening the way to efforts to restore the Koch coalition in some new form."

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 18, 1993

SECTION: Section 6; Page 18; Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 5330 words

HEADLINE: 24 Candidates in Search of a City

BYLINE: By Jane Fritsch; Jane Fritsch, a former political reporter for The Los Angeles Times, is a reporter for The New York Times.

 BODY:
On the umpteenth wet and dreary day of a peculiar California winter, the drought-resistant plants are drowning in the muck in Ed Begley Jr.'s front yard. Atop his cozy, unpretentious house, solar panels search the sky in vain for sunlight. Inside, the gangly actor pads around in tennis shoes, greeting guests and switching off lights.
Two dozen people who don't have to be anywhere at 9:30 on a weekday morning mill about in Begley's living room, sipping mugs of coffee in the energy-saving gloom. They are middle-aged, liberal and well-to-do, and some are involved in the entertainment industry. The license plate on a new Pontiac van parked out front broadcasts the good fortune of its owner: GOTAGIG. 
 They are the elite of Southern California's environmental movement, a potent political force, and they have paid as much as $5,000 for the privilege of grilling candidates at intimate gatherings about pollution, recycling, conservation and, lately, a novel proposal to turn the concrete-lined Los Angeles River into a freeway on days when it is dry. This morning's guest is Michael Woo, one of the front-runners in the race for Mayor of Los Angeles.
Begley introduces Woo, an old friend, and settles down on the hardwood floor. Woo takes command. In khaki pants and a sport jacket, the 41-year-old City Councilman and student of urban planning sets off on an upscale version of his standard speech.
These balding men with pony tails, these women in earth tones and sensible shoes, are his intellectual equals and philosophical soul mates -- the sort of people a fellow like Woo should be able to count on. He wants to become the first Asian-American mayor of a major American city. What more likely group to embrace that progressive notion? Woo is at ease. The river plan is a "dumb idea" cooked up by one of his opponents. He punches home his points with confidence. Conservation. Electric cars. Coalitions. Big development. Congealed traffic.
In another year, those themes might have galvanized a roomful of environmentalists, but there is something else in the air this morning, and a 40-ish man in an impatient mood gives voice to it. What, he demands, would Woo do to stem the tide of illegal immigrants in Southern California?
Woo, the son of a Chinese immigrant, stiffens. "I will not," he scolds, "support any effort to scapegoat immigrants for our economic problems here."
A no-nonsense voice rises from the couch near the window. This time it's a woman, annoyed that there are just "too many children" in Los Angeles. What, she would like to know, does Woo propose to do about that?
Woo takes a breath, then parries: Family planning is a good idea, but he has no interest in appearing to be anti-child. And besides, there's a limit to what a mayor can do.
It was a strangely hostile exchange, given the liberal bent of the group, but this is an odd time in Los Angeles politics. The citizens of the nation's second-largest city are cranky and out of sorts, having been brought up short nearly a year ago by three enervating days of riots. The old illusion of a glittering polyglot -- the capital of the Pacific Rim for the 21st century, as they liked to predict -- seems childishly optimistic now. The great urban laboratory has exploded, and the best thinkers in town are not certain how to piece it together again.
Like the desert plants drowning in the unexpected rain, the people of Los Angeles are confronting a future they had not prepared for in a city that suddenly seems unfamiliar.
Even the grafitti seems more brazen now. A sleek new traffic sign high above the Hollywood Freeway is unreadable, its electronic messages obscured by the jagged, illegible scrawl of a daredevil.
For all the city's laid-back image, this is an epochal time in its history. The people of Los Angeles mourn the death of a city that never was, that lived largely in the imaginations of the desperate, the bored, the dissatisfied, the seekers of fortune. They had come from Buffalo and Toledo and Kansas City, their notions of aquamarine waters and sparkling lights formed in darkened movie theaters in the dead of winter.
When they arrived, they saw what they wanted to see; the closer the resemblance to the dream, the greater the testament to their cleverness in having chosen it.
At this time of great municipal angst comes what could be one of the most significant mayoral elections in the city's history. In its broadest context, the election is a referendum on whether this city of 3.4 million people wants to take its future in hand with new policies aimed at all its economic and ethnic groups, or continue on the path that has been good for the businessmen who have controlled the public agenda -- and hope that this will somehow be good for the uneasy masses.
Tom Bradley, the placid figure who presided over Los Angeles for two decades of intoxicating growth, decided after the riots not to run again. For most of his tenure, he had been a popular figure, but the city's helplessness in the face of the mayhem last spring took a toll on his image. The son of sharecroppers, Bradley was the city's first black mayor. As a police officer, he went to law school and learned to speak the language of the white businessmen whose support he would assiduously court in his later years.
New construction ran virtually unchecked during the Bradley era. Gleaming downtown office towers seemed to spring up daily, and the last big chunk of untouched land in the far reaches of the San Fernando Valley is now being developed into expensive homes that, inevitably, will be sold to the well-off people -- the white people -- who can afford them.
Embraced by the world of the white and the powerful, Bradley had returned the affection. His quiet style and patrician manner put the city at ease and allowed the better-off to indulge in the fantasy that there were no serious ethnic or racial problems -- among whites, blacks, Asians and the fast-growing Hispanic population -- in their sunny paradise. But the people who had once found comfort in Bradley's quiescence would be looking for a more dynamic leader in 1993, and Bradley sensed that.
The rioting "tore at my heart," he said last fall, conceding that the time for change had come. At 75, he would make his exit as gracefully as possible, under the circumstances, leaving the citizens of Los Angeles to assess what the city was and what it wants to become.
Los Angeles has always been a self-conscious city, acutely so since the widely broadcast beating of Rodney King led it to question its most basic assumptions about its character. The public soul-searching was ratcheted up by the riots that followed the acquittals of the police officers who had beaten King.
No single person can restore the city's self-esteem, but the history of urban America is filled with giant personages -- La Guardia, Daley and even Los Angeles's own rough-hewn Sam Yorty -- who have embodied the essence of their cities and become symbols as much as chief executives. Los Angeles's opportunity to find such a figure is here again.
It is emblematic of the confusion that has engulfed the city that 24 candidates are on the ballot for Tuesday's primary election, each offering the voters a version of the dream. (A list of the candidates appears on page 36.)
There is Richard J. Riordan, the ultra-wealthy, law-and-order conservative who remembers the freewheeling days of a young Los Angeles when he made his fortune, and business was unhampered by City Hall. With some tinkering, he feels, that could happen again.
There is Joel Wachs, who would "empower all the people," as he is fond of saying, so that Los Angeles can be everything to everyone.
There are the fringe candidates, like Julian Nava, the prickly academic who would station as many as 10,000 Federal troops in the city's streets as a prophylactic measure until the people can be trusted to behave themselves.
There is the Greek-born businessman Nick Patsaouras, who has a radical vision of Los Angeles as a great European city, where people get out of their cars to stroll grand boulevards, patronize local shops -- and meet their neighbors.
And there is Woo, who offers the voters a chance to choose as their new public face a seemingly genial young man who fits the stereotype of the new wave of industrious, polite and clean-living Asian immigrants, with a little of Bill Clinton thrown in. Such a candidate may be particularly attractive to white liberals, for whom guilt over the condition of the less-fortunate competes daily with images of hostile minority members rampaging through the city. In its most cynical interpretation, Woo's candidacy enables whites to vote for a minority candidate without voting for someone who is black or Hispanic.
THE WEST BEACH CAFE IS filling up with the evening crowd when Anthony L. Vaughn walks in and is led to a booth near the back, next to the big corner table where Carlos Santana, the musician, is having dinner with friends. It's a trendy place near the ocean in the funky Venice district, and Vaughn, who has a home nearby, is used to seeing celebrities here. But Santana, that's special. He's from a better time -- the 60's -- an era when Los Angeles was a city without limits, when people cared about politics, when Anthony Vaughn cared about politics.
At 41, after a two-decade lapse, Vaughn has become interested in politics again. He thinks he is typical of some young professionals whose fortunes soared during an era of self-involvement. In this land brimming with distractions, it was easy to lose track of humdrum municipal affairs. So many beaches, so much money to be made, so many deals to be done.
Vaughn surveys the menu, and rejects item after item. Salads, pastas, grilled vegetables. Very California. Something catches his eye. "Would anyone be offended if I ordered a steak?" he asks in the most apologetic of tones. Permission is granted.
Vaughn has done a lot of thinking about the state of his city since he saw the smoke rising in the eastern sky a year ago. He and his friends have spent some time talking it over, probably more time in the last year than they had in the last 20. He has come to some conclusions about himself that are not particularly flattering.
"I think I got caught up in the 80's, and a lot of people got caught up," he said. "I made a lot of money, I was very successful, and everybody else's problems were everybody else's problems. What got us into trouble was that everybody just got so selfish."
He is not sure that a mayor can accomplish much now, but he says the next choice Los Angeles makes will be extraordinarily significant.
"I think it's important symbolically, if not effectively, to have minorities in high positions of power," he said. "I think that Woo would be good for Los Angeles."
Like many in Los Angeles, Vaughn knows that Woo was constantly on television denouncing Daryl F. Gates, the rogue police chief, before, during and after the riots. All that was fine, because Vaughn didn't have much use for Gates's bullying either.
Still, Vaughn is uneasy about Woo. Beyond the Gates controversy, he doesn't know much about Woo, or most of the others in the race for that matter. "I don't trust him and I don't know why," Vaughn said.
He wishes that some other candidate would emerge, someone like, say, Bill Clinton, who could inspire the public and raise the city's spirits, but it is difficult for any candidate to catch fire.
The television news producers find the race excruciatingly dull and broadcast little of it. And besides, the television reporters have been preoccupied with the second trial of the officers who beat King -- this time on Federal civil rights charges -- as well as the coming trial of the black youths who attacked Reginald Denny, the white truck driver caught in South-Central Los Angeles when the rioting began.
It is difficult to overstate the effect of the riots on the psyches of the people of Los Angeles.
Vaughn's transformation over the last year has been profound. He has overcome a lifelong distaste for guns and now keeps a .357 Magnum revolver in a locked box near his bed. His friends say they are stunned by this development.
Until the riots, his liberal credentials had been unassailable: he studied law under Bill Clinton at the University of Arkansas, was a labor negotiator for the Screen Actors Guild and was in the kitchen of the old Ambassador Hotel on June 5, 1968, when Robert Kennedy was shot -- so close, he recalls, that he could smell the gunpowder.
He is keenly aware that he has led a charmed life. He has made so much money as a labor negotiator for film studios that he was able to retire two years ago, at the age of 39. He does as he pleases now: a little volunteer work, trips to museums, things that were unimaginable before.
Still, life in Los Angeles is not what he thought it would be, or might have been, if not for the riots.
He remembers feeling "petrified" the day of the King verdict. "Everyone got scared. I found myself walking around the beach with a baseball bat on my shoulder and my little Lhasa apso dog." Some neighbors, pointing to their chests, confided that they were carrying guns.
That night, he gathered up every potential weapon in the house -- the bat, a BB gun and a hunting knife -- and slept with them. Later, after a moratorium on gun sales was lifted, he bought the .357 Magnum and drove over to the Beverly Hills Gun Club to learn how to shoot it. "I'm convinced," he said, "that I'll have to use it."
IT IS A PECULIARITY of California politics that candidates for local office desperately seek to attach themselves to movie stars. Local elections are by law nonpartisan, so there are no Democrats or Republicans to vouch for anybody or get out the vote. In such a system, name recognition is crucial, and anonymity a formidable enemy.
The 24 names on the ballot will lack any party designations, any hints at all, really, to help voters sort things out. The two who get the most votes will compete in a runoff election in June, assuming no one candidate gets more than 50 percent of the vote. Anyone who came up with $300 and the signatures of 500 registered voters is in the race. There is an engineer-composer-songwriter; a writer-musician-activist; a tax preparer-actor; a taxi driver. Half are completely unknown.
But there have been some stunning celebrity coups this election season. The most breathtaking was achieved by J. Stanley Sanders, a black lawyer who persuaded Bill Cosby to preside over the opening of his campaign headquarters and sponsor a fund-raising dinner.
Dana Carvey, the comedian, has been making appearances on behalf of Richard Katz, a white legislator from the San Fernando Valley for whom Carvey's wife used to work. "We had more cameras show up for the event with Dana Carvey than we've had for any other press conference," Katz lamented. He may have put together the most formidable stable of stars: Richard Dreyfuss, Robert Hays, Richard Dysart, Polly Bergen, Shaun Cassidy, Dana Delaney and Mary Steenburgen.
And Katz needs all the help he can get. He has been an influential member of the State Assembly for more than a decade, but only about half of the voters had ever heard of him, according to a Los Angeles Times poll early this year. He is hoping the celebrities will draw some attention to his ideas, like the one about selling a city-owned airport to raise money to put cops on the street.
Woo, who has the highest name recognition of all the candidates, is, nonetheless, taking no chances in the celebrity derby. He represents Hollywood on the City Council and has doggedly pursued legislation to help the entertainment industry. In return, he has obtained major financial support from celebrities and others in show business. In addition to Begley and his environmentalist friends, Woo has the endorsement of Lloyd Bridges, the television and movie actor, notwithstanding the fact that Bridges lives in Beverly Hills, beyond the Los Angeles city limits.
And Woo has entered an unlikely alliance with the actor Charlton Heston, a highly visible backer of conservative interests, including the National Rifle Association and William F. Buckley Jr.'s publication, National Review. It is the sort of thing that makes people uneasy about Woo.
Heston was host of a fund-raising dinner for Woo, but Garry South, Woo's campaign spokesman, plays down its significance. "It's based, apparently, on an old friendship," South said. "And celebrities are not as big a deal here as they are in other places. People see them at the grocery store."
Woo has been a high-profile member of the City Council almost since the day he was elected in 1985. He came to prominence as the chief sponsor of a sweeping ethics and campaign financing law. Shortly after the King beating, with an eye on the 1993 mayoral race, he thrust himself into the spotlight again by demanding the resignation of Chief Gates. He was the first city official to do so -- others were waffling, worried that their constituents cared more about law and order than civil rights.
A year later, when Gates's police force failed utterly to either prevent rioting or bring it under control once it started, Woo seemed prescient. And he got the added benefit of countering a perception that he was indecisive and lacked deeply held convictions.
There is a grudging consensus among the city's political leaders and Woo's fellow candidates that his stand on Gates two years ago is responsible for his position as the front-runner now.
By virtue of his standing in the polls, Woo is the enemy. Some of his opponents have taken particular glee in seeing him twist and turn in the face of stinging disclosures about his personal affairs. First, there was the report that Woo was vastly enlarging his hillside home at the same time he was pushing legislation that would all but ban such projects. Then there were the stories raising questions about his handling of campaign funds. These were especially delicious because Woo had taken so much credit for the ethics law.
Still, Woo plods on, pushing his Clintonesque ideas, like the Urban Peace Corps, an organization that would put young people to work on community projects. And he goes out to South-Central Los Angeles as often as he can, to hunt for the black and ethnic-minority votes he knows he will need.
Since the King beating, Woo has been making weekend pilgrimages to black churches. Sometimes the pastors let him take the microphone and talk to the faithful.
But two years of practice have done little to lessen the awkwardness of the scene: a slightly built, bespectacled Asian man sits stiffly off to the side, tapping his delicate fingers on the back of the pew, sometimes clapping tentatively in rhythm with the foot-stomping music.
All patience and graciousness, he waited his turn at the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal Church one Sunday in February. The payoff was a kind introduction by the bombastic pastor, the Rev. Cheviene Jones, who took note that President Clinton was in town -- somewhere nearby, he had heard -- but would not be bothering with this church today. "But this young man thought enough of us to come." Even so, Woo would be allotted only 2.6 minutes, Jones ruled, so he had better get to it. Woo crammed it all in: crime, unity, economic rebirth, a new generation of leadership. A breath. Applause. Some did not clap, but the reception was respectable. On to another stop.
NOT ALL THE VOICES OF post-riot Los Angeles are despairing. Perhaps those who saw the city for what it was, those who had only small dreams, are the happiest now.
Ivon Allen has lived in South-Central, the area hardest-hit by the riots, since she moved there from Arkansas with her husband, John, in 1946. He died in 1975, but his picture has a prominent place on a table in her living room. Her neighbors can see the stone facade he applied to the front of their neat little house two decades ago. It was the envy of the neighborhood. And, if she looks past the big palm tree in the yard, she can keep up with the comings and goings of her neighbors. She is satisfied with what she sees.
Allen, who is black, has seen a wave of Mexican immigrants move in, and Korean immigrants have bought up most of the little grocery stores.
The neighborhood is organized, she said, and if a problem arises, if a "bad element" moves in, they "nip it in the bud." A small government-sponsored loan program has helped many in the area get money to rehabilitate their houses, she said. And she thinks it has made all the difference.
"So far as I know, people get along," Allen said on a recent afternoon.
"We're different races, but whenever the opportunity presents itself I get acquainted." Sometimes they exchange small gifts.
During the riots, she watched some television reports, but the trouble seemed remote. "I really was not afraid."
On the second morning, she decided to go for a walk. A year earlier she had had a hip replacement and she wanted to keep up with her exercise. "My neighbor next door saw me walking and told me that I'd better go back in my house," she said. It hadn't occurred to her that she might be in danger. "I feel very good about remaining here," she said. "I do like Los Angeles."
Ivon Allen has taken the measure of Michael Woo, and she will consider voting for him. She happened to catch his speech a few months ago at a gathering in her neighborhood. When she got the moderator's attention, she tried to ask a question. Her words got all twisted around and the moderator tried to interrupt her, but Woo said, wait a minute, I understand what she's saying. She wanted to know why sometimes rich people conclude that poor people are ignorant. She doesn't remember precisely what his answer was, but he made a good impression.
IT'S POWER BREAKFAST time at the Pacific Dining Car, and Richard Riordan, considered a front-runner, is running late. His driver didn't show, so he piloted his Ford Explorer into downtown Los Angeles on his own, through rush-hour traffic all the way from his home in Brentwood, where the lawns look like fairways at Pebble Beach and the cool ocean breeze picks up the sweet scent of the bougainvilleas and the lavender jacaranda trees.
Riordan is out of breath when he arrives. He gives a nod, a wave, a shake of the hand as he passes tables crammed with the lobbyists, lawyers and political aides who meet here each morning to share secrets and work out deals.
For years now, Riordan has been one of them, a lawyer working the levers of politics in relative obscurity. Now he is out in the open. His vast fortune -- more than $100 million -- no longer satisfies. He wants something more. He wants to be in charge. He is a man of majestic appetites.
This morning, he orders the eggs Benedict, a serving of pancakes, a big glass of orange juice and coffee. He demolishes the feast in astonishing time, particularly given the fact that he has been answering questions nonstop. It is a skill perhaps picked up in these long months on the campaign trail.
Despite his millions, he is plagued by anonymity. He has put $3 million of his own into the campaign to pay for television commercials, but that may not be enough.
Does he have any celebrities?
"I've got Billy Barty," he offers.
The name hangs in the air for a moment or two. He tries again.
"And Tom Poston."
Largely because of his money and his willingness to spend it on the race, Riordan is viewed as one of the leading contenders. If Woo is the Bill Clinton of the race, then Riordan is the Ross Perot. Riordan does not mind the comparison, but he wants it made perfectly clear that he is not an autocrat. He believes in making deals, thrives on it, in fact. Woo's preachments about unity and harmony are all very nice, but it's a disaster out there.
Richard Riordan's Los Angeles is a frightening place, viewed around the world as a "war zone." Audiences respond well to this theme. His campaign brochure features a sinister picture of the barrel of a revolver pointing at the reader dead on from the gloved hand of an anonymous assailant. The brochure demands 3,000 more police officers -- "even more firepower in the war against crime."
His best hope is the vast San Fernando Valley, beyond the mountain range that runs through the center of the city, a suburban world where lots are still zoned for the keeping of horses and people still want to dream that they can be the masters of their little urban ranches. If the fences are high enough, you can pretend that there is no city around you at all.
Riordan's apocalyptic message may play well there, but he may have a hard time persuading the less fortunate around the city that he speaks for them. He portrays himself as an outsider, but over the years, his law firm has received millions of dollars in business from local government. And he was, and still is, a friend of Michael Milken, the ultimate insider who, from his office in Beverly Hills, ran the junk bond department of the defunct Drexel Burnham Lambert investment firm.
Riordan gets nervous when you ask about Milken. Riordan has made some of his millions through deals handled by Milken's department.
"I personally never had any involvement with Mike Milken whatsoever on business," Riordan snaps. "The people who work with me dealt with Milken."
BKUWON KIM, A Korean immigrant, knows little of Richard Riordan, or for that matter any of the people who are running for Mayor of Los Angeles. He and his family work 12-hour days to keep up with the demands of their grocery store in far South-Central Los Angeles, where sullen young men stand at the roadside with sacks of oranges, or peanuts or some other fragment of a crop that has made its way into the city from a distant farm.
The Kim family has been in the grocery business for 12 years now, drawn to California by the same celluloid images that have lured millions. Buwon's parents wanted a better life for their children and good educations, so they followed their version of the dream.
Buwon's mother, Kumhee, summons her son and returns to the darkened corner of the store where she sits for hours and watches. Often, her eyes brim with tears. In February, her husband, Hyung Soo, Buwon's father, was bludgeoned to death by a black teen-ager and a 26-year-old accomplice who had lured him out of the store and robbed him. Kumhee was inside, at the counter, but she had heard nothing. Now, she is of little use to the business, but she comes in anyhow, to watch over her sons.
At 28, Buwon has abruptly taken over the store and his younger brother, Hyowon, has dropped out of school to help. He was studying theology at a seminary in Chicago.
From what the Kims have been able to glean from the police, their father was killed for the cash in his pocket. It happened at the beginning of February, a time of the month when people knew that he carried money to cash small checks for his customers. He was found in a pool of blood outside the store.
Now Buwon feels the great weight of family responsibility as he strides around the store in his baseball cap and blue jeans, stocking shelves and directing customers. He had wanted to be an architect, but it is all confusion now. "My dad came to another country, another land and spilled his blood here. I don't want to just turn my back and go my own way." Buwon has not come up with a solution. He will give the matter some thought.
He has thought a great deal about what happened to his father and has found a certain peace about it. He does not think it was a hate crime, although he knows there has been so much trouble between the black residents of South-Central and the Korean merchants who seem to run all the shops.
"I really feel bad about the people here," he says. "I feel sad. Most of them are very decent people. They're the victim as well as we are."
Their store survived the riots last year because the people in the neighborhood liked his father. He respected them, called them by name and gave them credit.
Whoever did this was just a bad element, Buwon has concluded. "Everybody's hungry here. It's an economic thing mainly. That's why I think this happened."
He has been casting about for some help from a government official and wants to know who one calls about such a tragedy. He has gotten little response from the City Hall offices he has tried to call, but he knows he is over his head in all this bureaucracy and has not made himself clear. His family, his people, have stayed at a distance from American politics. But now, when they help, there must be someone who can do something about his father's death. He is not quite sure who that might be.
 

 
A 24-CANDIDATE FIELD OF DREAMS
Ernani Bernardi: white city councilman for 30 years.; the city's blunt-spoken institutional memory; at 81 running so that he can show up at debates and keep the other candidates honest.

Linda Griego: only woman among the major candidates; deputy mayor for economic development and a Latina; wants to streamline byzantine permit process that she believes is strangling the city's small businesses.

Ted Hayes Jr.: advocate for the homeless; pushing his agenda at a time when concern for the homeless has taken a back seat to law-and-order issues.

Nate Holden: black city council member with a law-and-order message; began an appeal to white conservatives two years ago by supporting Daryl Gates, the former police chief, in aftermath of Rodney King beating.

Richard Katz: white state legislator; the something-for-everyone candidate; envisions a Los Angeles where small businesses thrive along with the environment and transportation, mass or otherwise; has proposed turning the Los Angeles River into a freeway on days when it is dry.

Thomas Kingsley Houston: white lawyer and former deputy mayor; wants to free Los Angeles of illegal aliens by having city police go after them.

Julian Nava: Latino; prickly academic and former ambassador to Mexico; wants to station up to 12,000 Federal troops in the city's streets until people learn to behave themselves.

Nick Patsaouras: Greek-born businessman; envisions Los Angeles as great European city, where people get out of their cars to stroll grand boulevards, patronize local shops -- and meet their neighbors.

Richard J. Riordan: wealthy, white, law-and-order conservative; wants to return Los Angeles to its free-wheeling days of TK years ago, when he made his fortune, and business was unhampered by City Hall.

J. Stanley Sanders: black lawyer and Rhodes Scholar; wants to revitalize South Central Los Angeles, the area hit hardest by last year's riots, and press the needs of the underclass.

Joel Wachs: city councilman and nostalgic white liberal who wants to "empower all the people," as he is fond of saying, so that Los Angeles can be everything to everyone.

Michael Woo: Clintonesque liberal of Chinese descent; envisions a Los Angeles where ethnic groups get along with each other, prodded by programs like his Urban Peace Corps.

--------------

Some of the candidates have little or no money, no political base, and names that are recognized by fewer than 1 percent of the voters. Undaunted, they signed up to run. Following are their names and the self-descriptions they have given to the City Clerk's office:
 
Kim Delynn Allen: railroad worker.

Eileen Anderson: singer-dancer-candidate.

Philip Ashamallah: engineer-composer-song writer.

John Z. Borunda: businessman-retired policeman.

Adam Bregman: writer-musician-activist.

Douglas Carlton: no occupation stated.

"Melrose" Larry Green: tax preparer-actor.

Michael Adam Leptuch: no occupation stated.

Randy Mark Pavelko: taxi driver.

Leonard Shapiro: publisher.

Frank Teran: property investor-retired.

Oscar C. Valdes: medical doctor.
