HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Playing It Safe With Payment

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE

 BODY:
A GROUP of 16 students and teachers at Mattituck High School on Long Island paid $17,000 to a travel agent in Florida for a class trip to England and Ireland earlier this month. But when Alan Lawrence, the social studies teacher who organized the group, had not received travel documents and was unable to reach the agent the day before the group was to leave, he began to make inquiries. He learned, he says, that none of the money had been remitted to the airline, the hotel or the company providing the land tour. Then he called the Martin County Sheriff, who issued a warrant for the agent's arrest on charges of grand larceny.
A week after the group's original departure date, with travel donations from Trafalgar Tours, which volunteered to help, and Virgin Atlantic Airways, the airline Mr. Lawrence was told would be used, plus cash from a number of Mattituck community groups, the students and their teachers took off for their 10-day trip. 
 Mr. Lawrence and the other organizers, as well as a similar group in another Long Island town, were not flinging their carwash earnings at a stranger. The travel agent, originally from Long Island, had provided "excellent tours, everything you could ask" in two earlier years, according to Mr. Lawrence.
Unknown to the Long Islanders, in May 1992 the agent had left the Smart Traveller of Miami, where she had been an outside sales agent, according to the agency's manager, and set up in business north of Miami with a name so similar that the original agency obtained a court order in August to stop her from using it. The checks, made out to the original agency, were endorsed for deposit with the new agency name. Then the account was emptied and the agent disappeared, the sheriff said.
 
In Case of Default
 No organization insures against the failure of a travel agency, so how can people arranging a tour protect themselves?
First, it seems clear that last year's reference may not be good enough. Agents and operators may have a record of good performance for several years and still default.
Bands and high school groups save for a year for the class trip, using the same agent as earlier classes, then the agent decamps or the operator strands the group. "I've heard the story a hundred times," said Dick Knodt, executive vice president of the American Society of Travel Agents. Deposits given to a travel agent should be acknowledged in specific ways. Mr. Knodt said that when large amounts of money were involved over a long time, the organizer of a tour could ask for a joint account so that he or she would countersign all checks, verifying that the checks are made out to the airlines and other providers.
Anyone acting on behalf of a big group should demand proof from the agent or directly from the travel companies within 24 hours that arrangements have been paid for, according to Robert E. Whitley, president of the United States Tour Operators Association. That way, if the agency folds, he said, the supplier can provide the tour. He said the amount of the travel agency's commission need not be disclosed; the receipt need only say "received full payment for land arrangements" or words to that effect.
Travelers should get receipts with reservation numbers and copies of acknowledgments from suppliers. "When no vouchers and no tickets appear," Mr. Knodt said, "call the suppliers and find out why."
Mr. Knodt said that one check is to call the association at (703) 739-2782 to find out if the travel agency is a member. If an agency does belong, the group may help in resolving disputes. One can also ask the Better Business Bureau how many unresolved complaints are listed for a particular agency.
Travel agencies, because they have virtually no assets that can be seized and because their only inventory is ticket forms, may be more susceptible than some other businesses to larcenous schemes. But if honest agencies have sent a customer's money to a tour operator or even an airline and that supplier ceases operations, the travel agency may be forced to make refunds from its own funds, and it becomes a victim too.
 
Setting Up Insurance Pool
 The United States Tour Operators Association, the American Society of Travel Agents and the National Tour Association, which is made up primarily of bus tour operators, have created insurance pools to meet this possibility. The recession has put heavy pressure on these plans. Mr. Whitley estimated 25 tour operators' failures in the last five years.
The tour operators' association plan, which in 1990 increased its coverage to $5 million, protects all 38 tour-operator members, which are large companies like Abercrombie & Kent, American Express Vacations and Maupintour. If any member company becomes insolvent, the plan refunds customers' payments. At one point, the plan was coping with $6 million in losses, but the drain was spread over two fiscal years, so the plan remained solvent.
Tour companies that belong to this organization usually advertise it, but the organization, (212) 944-5727, will comfirm an operator's membership.
The American Society of Travel Agents has had two plans fall victim to bad times. The Tour Protection Plan provided coverage of $250,000 for tour-operator members who signed up. Customers got refunds if a bankrupt operator was a participant and if their travel agent belonged to the society. As of February, 26 companies were participating.
In the light of recent defaults, the organization's board felt that $250,000 was inadequate coverage; Mr. Knodt said that refunding 10 cents on the dollar in a big failure would do the society more harm than good. But he said that the participants who were polled did not want to pay for $1 million in coverage, which was expected to cost a premium of $1 for each client in addition to the $250,000 letter of credit that the agencies were already maintaining. So the organization's board voted to terminate the plan, effective at the end of 1993. Until then, operators that display the plan's logotype are covered.
To replace the coverage, the society is encouraging its tour-operator members to hold customer payments in an escrow bank account until the travel takes place, but this requires tying up their cash flow. The program is just getting started; one tour operator, Future Tours, is signed up.
The travel agents' organization's second plan to unravel, the Travel Reimbursement Insurance Protection Plan, underwritten by Lloyd's, began in August 1992 and was sold to 600 agencies for $600 a year. If any supplier defaults, it repays the agency whatever it lost, including clients' deposits. In October, Lloyd's stopped providing the insurance, so the coverage will end when all the one-year policies have expired. Another underwriter is being sought.
The National Tour Association's Consumer Protection Plan, begun in 1988, covers its 560 members, operators of escorted bus tours in the United States and Canada, for $100,000 each in customer deposits, but this plan is facing increased demands because of recent failures. A consumer guide is available from the organization, 546 East Main Street, Lexington, Ky. 40508; (800) 755-8687.
These organizations act to protect public confidence in travel sellers, but the climate is harsh and protection costly. Keep a careful watch on how your checks are deposited, and get confirmation at each step. Use of a credit card provides further protection.

HEADLINE: Q and A

 BODY:

Rent-Controlled Increase
 
Question: My mother-in-law, age 85, lives in a large rent-controlled apartment in Manhattan. A few months ago she arranged for a 17-year-old music student from Bulgaria to move in with her so she would not be alone at night. The student, however, pays her no money. 
 When the landlord learned that the young woman was living there he raised my mother-in-law's rent by approximately $30 a month. He told her that the increase was justified by the city's rent control and stabilization law.
Is this legal? . . . A.W. Hopkins, Manhattan
 
Answer: Yes. According to Bruce D. Friedberg, a Manhattan lawyer, the owner can increase the rent based on Sec. 2202.6 of the city's Unconsoldiated Rent and Eviction Regulations, which says that where there is an increase in the number of residents who are not members of the immediate family of the tenant, the landlord can apply to the Department of Housing and Community Renewal for an increase of no more than 10 percent of the maximum rent.
 
Living in a Loft
 
Question: Please tell me why it is illegal to live in a so-called commercial loft? Also is a J-51 absolutely necessary for someone to live in a loft? . . . C. Harris, Manhattan
 
Answer: No. According to Arthur Rhine, a Manhattan lawyer, the J-51 tax abatement program is irrelevant to whether you can live in a loft. The program, essentially, was a deal struck between apartment and loft owners and the city to encourage landlords to fix up buildings, regardless of whether they are lofts, brownstones or apartments.
"Basically, the city lent money to the owners in exchange for keeping the rents low, usually for 10 years," Mr. Rhine said. "You can live in a loft with or without a J-51."
As for moving into a commercial loft, you can't do it, Mr. Rhine said, unless the building was legalized into a residence. Under the city's loft law, the unit had to be used as a residence on both April 1, 1980, and Dec. 1, 1981, the beginning and end of the so-called window period for legalization.
Mr. Rhine added that there also had to be at least three separate lofts being used as residences in the building on those days.
 
Patrolling Private Streets
 
Question: We inadvertently parked our car on what turned out to be the private streets of Forest Hills Gardens Corp. Within a half-hour, the tire was booted and we had to pay $150 in cash immediately for the boot to be removed or else the car would be towed with an additional fine. What made this all the more astonishing was that this was also during a time that parking regulations were suspended in New York City because of weather conditions.
Can a co-op have this much power to control what were once city streets? . . . Karen Louise, Kew Gardens, Queens
 
Answer: Yes. According to Stuart Saft, chairman of the Council of New York Co-Operatives, the streets of such a corporation are basically privately maintained.
He added that the quid pro quo for the community for having the obligation to maintain and secure the streets was having some control over their use.
 
Why 'the Bronx'?
 
Question: Is it necessary to put the word "the" before the word "Bronx" when referring to that borough? . . . Hymie Kindler, Brooklyn
 
Answer: Yes -- but nobody knows why. It has been speculated, though, that the name derives from Jonas Bronck, a Scandinavian who in 1639 became the first European to settle there. It could it be that people going to visit the Bronck family kept saying they were going to see the Broncks and that this later became the Bronx.

HEADLINE: At Work;
Worthy Child-Care Pay Scales

BYLINE: Barbara Presley Noble

 BODY:
IF wages are any indication of the esteem in which a person's labor is held, consider the following fact, culled from the pages of the Federal Government's Occupational Outlook Handbook: People who take care of zoo animals make on average nearly $2,500 a year more than most of the people who take care of human animals in child-care centers.
Should it gall a child-care worker that a python is thought to require more skillful handling than a toddler? No? Then try on these figures from an about-to-be-released survey and see how they fit your budget: In 1988, the lowest-paid workers in child care, assistant teachers in preschool centers, made $5.16 an hour; in 1992, they made $5.08, a figure that works out to about $8,890 a year. The highest-paid teachers at the centers, most of whom have college-level training in early childhood education, were doing slightly better: in 1992 they made $8.85 an hour, up from $8.19 in 1988, for an annual salary of $15,488. That's about twice as much as the burgermeisters at McDonald's make. The bad news is that, even as the number of centers has grown to accommodate the demands of working parents since the mid-1970's, salaries in real dollars are off by 20 percent. About a fifth of the 10 million American children in child care are in certified, regulated centers. 
 These figures come from the Child Care Employee Project, a research and advocacy project in Oakland, Calif., which has updated a survey of child-care centers it released in 1989. On Thursday, the project will release its new report in Washington as children, teachers and child-care providers call attention to its findings by observing Worthy Wage Day, a program sponsored by a group known as the Worthy Wage Coalition.
In locations across the country, from Pacific Grove College in California to the Jelly Bean Child Care Center in Stamford, Conn., child-care advocates will take time off to march, rally and wear buttons in the service of a quest for higher -- or "worthy" -- wages and wild-and-crazy amenities like paid health benefits, which are now offered to less than a third of teachers.
The original study may be remembered for the chill it sent up many a working parent's spine: the high turnover of child-care workers, the survey concluded, hurt the children's language and social development. Between 1988 and 1991, 70 percent of the teaching staff interviewed had left their jobs. Turnover stabilized somewhat last year at about 26 percent. But, as the study notes, the turnover at all United States companies in 1992 was an average 9.6 percent.
WHY are child-care workers badly paid? One clue comes from the survey's sample, which was drawn from centers in Atlanta, Boston, Detroit, Phoenix and Seattle: 98 percent of the workers were female and about a third were women of color. "We don't think women's work is valuable," said Marcy Whitebook, executive director of the Child Care Employee Project. "This is the quintessential women's work."
But there are other, more complicated reasons as well. "Child care is something families have not traditionally paid for," Ms. Whitebook said. "We don't think of it as skilled work that we want to pay for." And in many places an underground economy in child care allows consumers to opt for cheaper alternatives to regulated care. Workers in regulated centers subsidize the underground option with depressed wages.
The Worthy Wage Coalition is calling for a minimum average wage of $10 an hour and comprehensive health care. Few experts in the area think the market will take care of workers' concerns. "The main way to increase wages in child care is through public subsidy," said Heidi Hartmann, an economist who directs the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. "We want children to have a higher level of care than parents can afford. It's like public education, it's a social good."
Such a program requires what Ms. Whitebook and others say the country lacks: a national policy on child care. "We have a nonsystem system," she said. "We've never said to ourselves, 'Parents of young children are going to be in the labor force. What shall we do about it?' "
Perhaps Hillary Rodham Clinton will need another project after she whips the health-care system into shape.
Information on Worthy Wage Day is available from the Child Care Employee Project at 510-653-9889.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1521 words

HEADLINE: Business Diary/April 11-15

BYLINE: By Hubert B. Herring

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL
 
Helping Russia: What's in It for the Rest of Us? 

How much is generosity, how much just self-interest, when hands are extended to an ailing neighbor? As soon as the world's richest nations announced a $28 billion aid package for Russia last week, each country rushed to point out how it could help folks back home. Secretary of State Warren Christopher was quick to mention the national-security angle -- "The world will be a considerably more dangerous place if Mr. Yeltsin does not prevail" -- and stressed the risk of losing "large potential markets for our businesses." And Norman Lamont, Chancellor of the Exchequer, said, "Russia could be one of the biggest export markets for British firms." True, each nation must sell the aid package to legislators back home, who must come up with the money out of already-tight budgets. But do the world's emissaries really have so little faith in voters' altruism?
 
A Shot in the Arm for Japan
 
As President Clinton struggled to get his stimulus plan through Congress, Japan announced a far larger effort to get its economy moving -- to the tune of $116 billion. And even though some said the plan would not help much, investors took it quite seriously. Stocks in Tokyo, which had already been rallying for two months as the nation sensed a possible end to recession, took another leap to their highest level in more than a year.
 
A.T.& T. Wants Equal Access
 
Multinationals don't worry much about borders. They're more interested in things like sending data around the globe fast -- and in one-stop shopping for fancy phone services. But providers of those services, often bound by borders but hungry for that vast business, often snipe at foreign rivals. So when British Telecom sought permission to provide an array of trans-Atlantic services, A.T.& T. cried foul. It moved last week to block its rival until it's allowed to compete in Britain.
 
Oil for Sale in Argentina
 
Argentina's President, Carlos Saul Menem, apparently wants to sell half the state oil company for $3 billion to buy another term. It works like this: If the privatization -- possibly Latin America's largest ever -- goes through by July, Mr. Menem can pay off a million pensioners. Then, the reasoning goes, he'll have enough backing for a constitutional amendment to allow him a second term.
 
 
 
COMPANIES

 
Is It a Toyota? Don't Ask
 
The day is surely coming when the same car gets shipped back and forth across the Pacific, over and over, a stateless orphan, because people keep forgetting whether it's an American car, a Japanese car or one dressed up as the other. Here's the latest (try to keep it straight): General Motors has tentatively agreed to make up to 20,000 cars a year in the United States, and Toyota will sell them in Japan as Toyotas. Yes, it will lift our exports a bit, and ease some political pressure, but isn't this getting, well, rather confusing?
 
Sega Lands a Body Blow
 
The battle is fierce, each warrior lashing out with deadly jabs and kicks. Tension mounts, pulses quicken. But just as giant Nintendo seems to have Sega in a corner and is going for the kill, Sega unleashes a mighty surprise attack. Last week Sega said it would team up with two cable giants, Time Warner and Tele-Communications, to transmit its games directly into homes. Yes, there are 25 million or so Nintendo machines out there, dwarfing Sega's 8 million, but Sega may suddenly have battered down the door of 17 million homes with the cable deal. As one analyst said, "Nintendo seems to be getting left in the dust."
 
Don't Let Sales Dry Up
 
Consumers are catching on: If you want to buy something, you don't have to buy all the marketing hoopla, too -- you can buy a no-name product for a few dollars less. And more companies, their precious market share in peril, are getting the message and cutting prices for brand names. But investors' reactions vary. When Philip Morris cut Marlboro's price recently, its stock plummeted, but when Procter & Gamble lowered prices last week for its disposable diapers, Pampers and Luvs, its stock rose slightly. Investors must figure that babies' bottoms, being far more appealing than cigarettes, have a plumper future.
 
Mighty Wal-Mart Takes a Spill
 
Wal-Mart has for years been larger than life. Sales at the nation's largest retailer have grown more than 30 percent a year, and when it rides into town with its rock-bottom prices and vast stores, terrified rivals often throw down their guns without a fight. But the Arkansas tough guy may be slowing down. The stock has taken some nasty falls lately -- as it did last week when the company said recent sales growth fell below the kind of outsize performance investors have come to expect. Also creeping in are health care worries: More than half of Wal-Mart employees work less than 28 hours a week, with no health benefits; if benefits for part-timers are ever mandated, costs could soar.
 
A Tidy Profit in Citicorp Stock
 
It's always been simple to make a fortune on Wall Street -- just buy low, sell high. Leave it to a Saudi prince to apply that rule on a royal scale. A little over two years ago Prince al-Waleed bin Talal invested hundreds of millions in Citicorp, when its shares were in the dumps. It was a smart move. Citicorp stock has soared to its highest point in three years, and last week Prince Waleed raked in some profits, selling nearly nine million of his shares for $268 million -- two and a half times what he'd paid. Not that he's bailing out: He still owns a good chunk of the company. But the question is: What's he investing in now?
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Will 1 Electric Car Beat 3?
 
Here's a challenge: Take a popular product, make it far less useful, charge a hefty premium for it and get people to buy it. Under a California law that's spreading to other states, 2 percent of 1998 cars have to be "zero-emission" (unless Captain Kirk provides some dilithium crystals, that means electric). But current electric models have a range of 100 miles or less, and their prices give new meaning to "sticker shock": An electric Dodge van costs $120,000. Facing this deadline, Detroit is doing something drastic: Last week the Big Three said they were discussing building the car jointly.
 
A Tax to Pay the Doctor
 
The Administration doesn't like to say "tax" -- it scares people. And, wanting to keep the focus on the jobs bill, it doesn't want to talk just yet about how it's going to pay $50 billion or more to fix the health care mess. But a bulky tax idea is hard to keep under the rug, and last week it came out: The White House admitted that it's considering a value-added tax. ("Sin taxes," apparently, will fall short.) The advantage of such a tax, imposed on goods at every step of production, is that -- as Europe has found -- it is hard to evade. One disadvantage: It falls heavily on lower-income people, but that could be eased if items like food and housing are excluded.
 
A Place to Peck
 
Critics of recent Republican Administrations (older readers will remember those days) have said the only species protected then were timber companies and property owners -- not exactly high on any endangered list. The main goal, critics assert, was to weaken the Endangered Species Act by encouraging conflict. But these days, deals seem more likely. Last week Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt announced a deal with Georgia Pacific to protect the red cockaded woodpecker, which was one of the first species listed under the 1973 act, and whose habitat in the South is being chain-sawed away. Georgia Pacific gets more freedom to cut logs elsewhere in the South, and the bird gets a good deal, too: 10 acres of trees for each colony to peck at.
 
S.& L. Property, Up for Grabs
 
The Bush Administration did not want it around -- all that property seized from failed savings and loans. Too painful a reminder, perhaps, of all those wild, Government-backed spending sprees. So it sold it off quickly in huge bundles -- over $300 billion worth so far. But complaints abounded -- that local investors were frozen out, that the Government wasn't getting the best price. So the Clinton team shifted gears last week, making it far easier for smaller investors to take part. It brings the process "to Main Street, where it should be," a Treasury official said.
 
Retail Sales Dip, Analysis Soars
 
Politicians can't seem to leave statistics alone. Before the ink is dry, they litter them with partisan footnotes. When word came that retail sales fell 1 percent in March, the Administration seized on the figure as proof of a dire need for its stimulus package -- which Republicans are holding hostage. But others were quick to say the East Coast blizzard kept people out of stores. Senator Bob Dole, who as No. 1 Clinton needler is putting cute wordplays ever higher on his list of job duties, called it a "snow job" to overplay a weather-related sales dip -- that the real consumer worry is a "blizzard of new taxes."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 496 words

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Inflation: Not Dying, Just Changing

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to inflation and share prices, the most important question is not how big the inflation is, but where it is. When the market allows companies to raise prices almost at will, Wall Street comes to love them.
What is going on now is a reshuffling of inflationary pressures. With the dollar down -- and the Clinton Administration evidently quite happy to keep it there -- the pressures are receding on those American companies that sell goods subject to international competition. Mr. Clinton's tendency toward managed trade and quotas -- illustrated last week in his talks with Japanese Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa -- also bodes well for those companies. 
 But in this country, the price pressures are on, whether it is in diapers, drugs, cigarettes or corn flakes. Throughout the 1980's, brand name products raised prices regularly. Now, with real incomes down, "they have priced themselves out of a lot of markets," says Robert Barbera, the chief economist at Lehman Brothers. As companies fight for market share, prices are falling for many products.
But the opposite may be true in the internationally traded manufactured goods that were the subject of the most intense competition in the past decade. "Protectionism and the decline of the dollar are creating a price umbrella for the auto industry," says David Shulman, chief equity strategist at Salomon Brothers. Adds Mr. Barbera: "The price of cars could go up faster than the price of Cheerios."
If so, it will be a radical change. The consumer price index for cereals (yes, the Government really does compute that figure) is up 156 percent since the beginning of 1980, three times as much as the C.P.I. for new cars. It should come as no surprise that Kellogg's share price is 12 times as high as it was then, while G.M.'s is up just 62 percent.
The stock market is beginning to adjust to the new reality, buying American industries that are gaining in international markets and avoiding domestic businesses that have relied on price increases that no longer can be sustained. In 1993, Kellogg stock has fallen 15 percent, while G.M.'s is up 25 percent.
The prospect of price flexibility is good for Detroit, but it has less comforting implications for the overall inflation rate. The optimism that swept Wall Street last week, in the wake of a good report on March consumer prices, may prove to have been overdone. Mr. Shulman argues that investors are now confident that consumer prices will rise only 3 percent or less, and says that indications it might be more like 4 percent could alarm both the stock and bond markets.
It is amusing to see Wall Street happily watch the decline of the dollar -- it is down 9 percent against the yen since Mr. Clinton was elected -- while talking about the end of inflation. Americans can afford less of what the world produces, which is the real meaning of inflation, even if some American companies can expect to make more (devalued) dollars.

And So Did Kellog's Stock," tracks stock prices for Kellog's and General Motors, Jan. 1980-Apr. 16, 1993.

HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Short Memories for the Bad Times

BYLINE: By Susan Antilla

 BODY:
WALL STREET'S executives are at heart a cheerful bunch, and nothing proves that better than their speedy ability to forget the bad times and revel in the good.
Merrill Lynch said last week that it had enjoyed record earnings in the first quarter, and the giddy Wednesday morning headlines set just the right tone for an annual gathering of securities executives in New York. 
 The Securities Industry Association, trade group for the brokerage industry, packed 200 people into a Hilton conference room to ogle a slide show of bar charts that only a short seller could hate: initial public offerings, mutual fund sales, municipal bond offerings and total industry revenues gaining year after year, to a sizzling finale in the first quarter of 1993.
The introductory cheerleading session was followed by a workshop in which purveyors of financial products from brokerage firms, banks and mutual funds each told why theirs was a business that would continue to prosper. Phrases like "baby boomers," "scared savers" and "outliving assets" come to mind. How could anything go wrong with all those investors panting for the good advice of financial services firms? How, indeed.
By Thursday afternoon, holders of brokerage industry stocks were reminded that parties can end abruptly on Wall Street. A surprisingly strong 19 percent surge in first-quarter earnings at Charles Schwab & Company, the discount brokerage firm, was met with a heavy selloff of Schwab shares, which lost $3.125, to close the day at $35.125. The glass is half full to brokerage industry executives who assume that individual investors will be lining up for their services for years to come. But increasingly skeptical brokerage stock shareholders are starting to wonder if all the hoopla is deserved.
And at the Wednesday confab, some outsiders to the industry were wondering too.
Though Stephen Friedman, chairman of Goldman Sachs, warned his colleagues that the 1990's would be ruthless with any brokerage firms whose managements didn't begin to take tough measures, most industry representatives had a happier message. John S. Chalsty, chief executive officer of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, applauded "a great improvement in management on Wall Street." James F. Getz, president of the mutual fund outfit Federated Securities Corporation, cheered the fact that only 30 percent of American households own mutual funds, which presumably means the other 70 percent will come around. The bullish Mr. Getz even made the optimistic prediction that assets would continue to flood into funds at a rate of 15 percent to 20 percent a year.
Reality check time came, though, when a politician, a securities industry analyst and a publishing executive imparted their thoughts on what was ahead. Warren B. Rudman, the retired Senator from New Hampshire who co-authored the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings deficit reduction law, pretty much spoiled the raspberry sundae dessert with his prediction of higher long-term interest rates. That, he said, would come as a result of President Clinton's reluctance to take tougher measures to reduce the Federal deficit.
John Keefe, a brokerage industry analyst who gave an afternoon talk, splashed a little more cold water in the crowd's faces when he began his talk with a reminder that "the financial weather" can change quickly and completely. Even worse, he included a slide in his presentation that showed a more complete history on mutual fund sales than had an earlier speaker. Fund sales started to drop months before the 1987 stock market crash, he documented. That means even the indestructible asset management business "isn't all that free from cycles," he said.
So who asked him?
The audience perhaps can easily ignore Mr. Keefe, but they may not be able to hide from the last industry critic of the day, who could well wind up as the top cop of the securities industry. Arthur Levitt Jr., the former American Stock Exchange chairman who currently runs a media firm, gave a closing speech that warned against several evils that have troubled him since he left the brokerage business five years ago.
For one thing, said Mr. Levitt, there is the prickly issue of brokerage firms purchasing other firms' order flows -- something that potentially could harm investors who might not get the best price. For another, there is the troubling use of custom-made derivatives products, which "remain unregulated and misunderstood except by small groups of professionals." Mr. Levitt had other problem areas on his mind, too, including the institutionalization of the financial markets. Then there are the matters of corporate structures "in turmoil," excessive rewards for those who act as principal as opposed to agent, and health insurance.
Health insurance?
Of course health insurance. Mr. Levitt's name may be on top of every list of would-be S.E.C. chairmen, but he said last week that the White House hadn't even called yet. So why not curry a little favor by supporting the President's goals. We are "not covering enough people" right now, he said.
Mr. Keefe said Friday that while he happens to agree with Mr. Levitt on the health care issue, "it was somewhat out of place" at a conference of securities executives. As for the bullishness of the group of securities executives generally, he admitted sheepishly, "My speech wasn't too well received," in light of those irritating reminders of how cyclical the brokerage business is.
But the industry hasn't become overly bullish, said Mr. Keefe. Baby boomers may disappoint Wall Street if they fail to save as much as the firms hope, but at least wooing these investors isn't that expensive. "It's not the kind of thing where Acme Brokerage goes out and rents the most expensive real estate in Tokyo to implement expansion plans," he said. "They haven't built a temple of individual investor services or done other unnecessary spending in the name of the small investor." At least not yet.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Arthur Levitt Jr. sees trouble. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
A Gabelli Guarantee to Ponder

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
MARIO GABELLI, the mutual fund manager well regarded for his investing acumen, is introducing a new fund with a difference -- a guaranteed investment return. Sounds good, but it is a difference that the investor would be wise to study well.
The new Gabelli ABC Fund is of a type created by mutual fund companies in the last few years to lure bank-account and certificate-of-deposit savers -- those used to insured investments but distressed by tumbling interest rates. One new product puts the stress on less volatile share prices while others, like the Gabelli fund, provide some sort of investment guarantee. 
 One of the first moves came from Shearson Lehman Brothers. Shearson Principal Return 1996, set up in 1989, combines stocks with enough zero-coupon bonds to insure that investors will get back in 1996 at least the amount they invested. Shearson started a second fund two years later. And Kemper Retirement I, II and III, a series of similar funds, started coming out in 1990.
Gabelli ABC, which can invest in virtually any type of stock or bond, goes much farther: it promises a minimum investment return. However, the promise is only good for one year, only on a limited amount and likely to be expensive, prompting Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo, to conclude that, overall, "The fund promises too much and delivers too little to the investor."
The promise is a guaranteed total return of at least 6 percent for the first year on the first $2,000 invested during the fund's initial offering period, which began March 15 and runs through April 29. As of last week, the fund had about $1.2 million, at an average of $2,000 an account, according to Bruce Alpert, chief financial officer of the Gabelli funds.
No sales charge is levied on the first $2,000 invested but, in an unusual twist, a load (of 2 percent) is applied to additional investments.
In another twist, Mr. Gabelli promises, backed by a letter of credit he set up with the State Street Bank and Trust Company, to use his own money to make good on any shortfall in the 6 percent return at the end of one year.
While the Gabelli fund breaks new ground, analysts do not expect to see similar ones soon because of the risk to the fund manager. "It's innovative," said John Rekenthaler, editor of Morningstar Mutual Funds, in Chicago, "but it's dangerous."
In addition, fund companies that have been trying to educate people to the risks and rewards of the financial markets may regard this fund as hiding the risk and thus a setback to their efforts. To this, Mr. Alpert replies that the one-year guarantee program is intended to serve as "an introduction to the securities markets."
Only a select group can invest in Gabelli ABC. First dibs (up to 60 percent of the shares) go to individual retirement account investors who do not already own shares in the other seven Gabelli funds. Up to 30 percent more is reserved for investors in the Gabelli Convertible Securities Fund (for whom the guaranteed return is on investments of up to $10,000), plus other Gabelli shareholders. Others can buy any leftovers.
The $2,000 limit on the guarantee and the large allocation to I.R.A.'s are intended to attract long-term pension assets, as Fund Action, an industry newsletter pointed out. Those are assets that are likely, because of investor inertia, to remain in the fund after the guarantee has expired. "The preference for non-Gabelli shareholders," the newsletter continued, "is a marketing ploy to expand the adviser's shareholder base."
Shareholders will find the fund is not cheap. Besides the sales load above $2,000, there are steep annual expenses: a 1 percent management fee, generous by industry standards, and a one-quarter of 1 percent 12b-1 fee, used to defray marketing expenses. These fees, plus the fund's other annual expenses are projected to equal 2 percent of assets, nearly double the average stock fund's, which Mr. Alpert attributed to the expectation that the fund would be relatively small, at $30 million.
And the guarantee can actually backfire. In the prospectus, Mr. Gabelli says he intends to manage the ABC fund more conservatively than his other funds to avoid having to reimburse the State Street Bank for any payments. He adds that he will "seek to manage the Fund without regard to this potential conflict of interest" that could prompt him to shun a possibly high-return investment for fear it could prove a big loser.
But what happens if the fund's net asset value falls significantly? If it drops 15 percent or more and Mr. Gabelli fails to put up additional collateral, the bank can terminate the letter of credit and pay the entire shortfall at that time, forcing the investor to rely on Mr. Gabelli's largesse to cover any balance over the full year.
And who believes the stock market will drop that far? Mr. Gabelli, for one. In the 1992 annual report mailed to Gabelli Asset Fund shareholders earlier this year, he wrote: "All in all, we think the Dow could decline as much as 20 percent during the year from current levels."
Said Mr. Alpert of that possibility: "If the market will fall 20 percent, this is the fund to be in."

HEADLINE: Raising the Roof As the Economy Lifts

BYLINE: By THOMAS C. HAYES

 BODY:
HOME builders usually are hard at work when a teetering economy has begun to recover, and that is happening now in many parts of the nation. Wood frames for single-family homes are going up at what analysts estimate is the fastest yearly pace since 1986.
But this is not a typical home-building resurgence. The industry recovery, which took its first, small steps as the Persian Gulf war ended two years ago, has hit its stride in the last year only for the big companies that generally build 1,000 or more homes a year in a business where most competitors build fewer than 20. 
 Among the winners are the Centex Corporation, Toll Brothers Inc., Ryland Homes, the Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, Hovnanian Enterprises and the PHM Corporation, parent of Pulte Homes.
Even some fallen giants have revived. The U.S. Home Corporation, for example, was cleared April 1 by a Federal judge to complete a two-year bankruptcy reorganization. New-home sales at the Houston-based company increased 39 percent last year, to 5,000.
But medium-sized and smaller builders have had a tougher time. Many have been shut off from traditional lending sources at banks and savings institutions, narrowing their opportunities to acquire lots that are ready for building.
By contrast, the big builders have been using Wall Street more often to raise money, through stock issues, debt offerings and borrowing from institutional investors. Profits growing out of big land purchases made from banks and government agencies at fire-sale prices in the last three years should begin to show up in earnings reports by this summer, said James Meyer, housing analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. Stock prices of many big builders have already risen by more than 50 percent from their low points in the last 12 months and are expected by many analysts to go higher.
In short, a consolidation trend that thousands of builders thought could never happen in an intensely-local business is under way.
"It's my view that eventually there will be nothing between the big builders and the very small builders, virtually nothing," said Barbara Allen, the housing analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.
The Clinton Administration acted last week to help smaller builders and developers when it ordered the Resolution Trust Corporation to alter procedures for auctioning raw and developed land and other assets that had favored larger bidders.
But the small builders are still facing a credit crunch. "The land development loan is still far and few between," said Lewis Ranieri, chairman of Hyperion Partners, a New York investment group that owns a large Texas savings institution, Bank United.
The trends favoring large builders should make houses, particularly starter homes, more affordable in many markets, courtesy of the big builders' economies of scale and management savvy. But in Dallas and other cities where big builders have been very active, buyers have complained about fewer choices in architecture and floor plans.
Home builders capitalized on low mortgage rates and improved consumer confidence in the last 18 months to play a leading part in the recovery, and most analysts expect the industry to be a steady, but not rousing, element for the nation's economy through most of the 1990's.
According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis, investments in single-family construction rose by 16.7 percent last year in an economy that grew overall by 3.1 percent. Sales of new furniture, appliances and other household goods often acquired for new homes rose by 12 percent.
The chief economist at the National Association of Home Builders in Washington, David Seiders, estimated that housing construction will rise by 9 percent this year, to 1.32 million units, representing 1.15 million single-family homes and the rest apartments. He anticipates no increase in the overbuilt apartment market, with nearly all gains coming in home construction.
Ms. Allen, the Donaldson, Lufkin analyst, said the nation needs to add an average of 1.5 million housing units a year through the decade, and that construction should reach that level by 1995. Builders lament that soaring lumber prices, which have added $3,000 to the price of a typical new home in less than a year, have pinched back demand, but Ms. Allen says prospects are good for healthy, moderate growth lasting several years.
"If inflation remains low, and therefore mortgage rates, you could have a very, very long upward cycle," she said. "Frankly, it's a wonderful environment."
What follows are profiles of three of the more successful builders. Each has profited by adapting well to local markets with widely varying economic conditions.
 
Centex
 The nation's largest home builder, Centex, was a pioneer among home builders in raising money from Wall Street during the early 1980's. It also was a major buyer in recent years of bargain-priced raw land in north Texas from the R.T.C.
"We were one of the few people in this market that had cash, and they were all cash deals," said Laurence E. Hirsch, chairman and chief executive.
Centex occasionally expands into new areas by buying existing builders, but more often brings in people trained in other Centex markets.
"Home building is becoming a more sophisticated and management-intensive industry," Mr. Hirsch said. "There certainly are the mom-and-pops, but to really be successful, you're going to have to use traditional management tools."
He said Centex spends $2 million a year training employees in everything from land acquisition to holding the hands of anxious buyers. The company also has computerized information systems that keep managers on top of lumber, labor and land costs, among other things.
Centex built about 10,000 homes in the fiscal year ended March 31, 29 percent more than the average of its last three years. The Dallas-based company, operating in 41 markets in 20 states, plans to build as many as 14,000 homes by 1995.
Centex still gets most financing through large debt offerings, and also has the option of issuing more common shares when its stock price rises, as it has in the last two years. "We look at the credit crunch as a significant advantage for Centex," Mr. Hirsch said.
Land bargains of recent vintage are showing up in rising profits. Net income increased 81.7 percent, to $45.8 million, in the nine months ended Dec. 31, with revenues up 12.5 percent, to $1.8 billion.
Home-building and mortgage banking generated most of the profit and revenue. The company also operates the nation's fifth- largest general contracting company, cement and wallboard companies and a Texas savings institution.
 
Kaufman & Broad Homes
 California's economy has been sliding for three years, but Kaufman & Broad's focus on new homes for first-time buyers has paid off. Its orders in the state last year increased 49 percent, with three of every four customers buying a home for the first time.
The company, based in Los Angeles, reported a 28 percent gain in first-quarter profits last month, to $4.4 million. Sales increased by 22 percent, to $224.9 million.
Bruce Karatz, president and chief executive, said Kaufman & Broad pared the size of its typical starter home in California in the last four years by 200 square feet, to 1,500 square feet, as one way to reduce the price for first-time buyers.
The company also established a central purchasing department to lower costs for lumber and other materials. Financing costs have also dropped. Managers of its 12 divisions are sharing information, and when costs are noticeably lower in one region, other managers are expected to get their costs down, too.
"You show people this in an honest, straightforward way, and they get the message real quickly," Mr. Karatz said. "People really want to succeed."
The changes reduced the average price of Kaufman & Broad's homes in California to $169,000, from $200,000 in 1989. The company also builds homes in France and Canada, and recently opened a subdivision in Las Vegas for the first time.
Analysts estimate that Kaufman & Broad will build more than 5,000 homes this year in California and Nevada. The company had its biggest year ever last year in California, building 3,900 homes, or 200 more than in its previous best year, 1989.
"Many analysts said 10 to 15 years ago that the big would get bigger and the medium-sized builders would get squeezed, but it never happened," Mr. Karatz said. "Now it's happening."
 
Toll Brothers
 The suburbs of cities along the Atlantic coast are filled with land bargains, and Toll Brothers, which builds from Washington to Boston, has been snapping up building lots as fast and sensibly as it can.
Of the 5,600 lots that it put under option to buy in the last 24 months, more than 5,100 were parcels other developers or builders had once owned at higher prices. The land was acquired either from financial institutions or Federal agencies liquidating failed banks and savings institutions.
"You could make great land buys in the '81-'82 recession, but maybe one a quarter, not one a week," said an enthusiastic Robert I. Toll, chairman and chief executive. The company is based near Philadelphia in Huntingdon Valley, Pa.
The recent history of Southport Chase, a wooded setting on a former estate of 105 acres wedged between Bridgeport and Westport, Conn., near Long Island Sound, provides a case study of how Toll Brothers spotted opportunities in troubled properties.
The company won a sealed-bid auction last May for 47 vacant lots remaining in the 79-lot development. Roads, sewers and water lines had already been completed by the original developer-builder of Southport Chase.
The property was auctioned by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, which had acquired a huge portfolio of problem loans as a result of the biggest bank failure in the Northeast, the Bank of New England. The agency foreclosed on the original developer, who had been behind on payments since 1990.
Toll Brothers' bid of $5.6 million, an average of $119,000 a lot, was well-timed. The company now has 27 contracts for four home models that range in size from 3,000 to 3,500 square feet. Three of the homes are completed and occupied, with another 20 under construction.
The company has increased prices five times since last July, a reflection of strong buyer demand even in the face of rising lumber costs. The homes now sell for between $470,000 and $550,000, up from the original $447,000 to $505,000.
In the quarter ended Jan. 31, Toll Brothers recorded $88.2 million in contracts on new homes, an increase of 55 percent from the comparable quarter a year ago. Net income soared to $4.9 million, from $2.3 million, a record high for the eighth quarter in a row. Revenues rose 47 percent, to $51.8 million.
Like executives at Centex, Kaufman & Broad and other big builders, Mr. Toll said he is prepared to retreat after the land bargains have waned and smaller builders drive up material and labor costs, as they typically do late in a housing boom.
For now, though, the land bargains are too ripe to ignore. "These tremendous buys have not existed since the end of the Depression," he said, "and they probably will not be available for more than another year."

HEADLINE: Profile;
Soros's Alter Ego: Low Profile, Very High Returns

BYLINE: By Stanley F. Druckenmiller By BARRY REHFELD; Barry Rehfeld is a freelance writer based in New York.

 BODY:
WHEN the Tokyo stock market began rallying last month, a big buyer was the Quantum Group, the investment funds run by George Soros. Indeed, once word got around that Mr. Soros had bet big and fast on a range of Japanese securities, the rush into the market accelerated.
Yet Mr. Soros could not have been farther from the action. He was in Eastern Europe and Russia, tending to his numerous philanthropic projects. The Soros lieutenant who masterminded the Japan investment was Stanley F. Druckenmiller. 
 When Quantum bet $10 billion on the German mark and against the British pound and the Italian lira last September, it was Stanley F. Druckenmiller who created the investment strategy, which made $2 billion in profits in a matter of weeks.
For four years, the 39-year-old Mr. Druckenmiller has quietly served as Mr. Soros's alter ego, deciding on the complicated mix of investments by Quantum, while also handling his own large and highly profitable fund, Pittsburgh-based Duquesne Capital Management.
Mr. Druckenmiller's strategy goes far beyond buying stocks and bonds, into the esoteric world of derivatives like options and futures on a variety of products worldwide, including foreign currencies, bonds and stock indexes. His success has contributed mightily to the perception that, while the 1980's was the decade of the dealmakers, the 1990's is the decade of derivatives.
Since Mr. Druckenmiller took over, Quantum's funds have been averaging an annual gain of 40 percent in net asset value -- higher even than Mr. Soros's own outstanding record of 30 percent annually since 1969. Last year was his best yet -- a 60 percent jump.
"Of all the people in the business, he is just the best, both at the macro level and with individual stocks," said Julian Robertson, who runs the Tiger Management funds, which are among Quantum's biggest competitors.
So formidable is the Soros-Druckenmiller investment hand that many on Wall Street have discussed its ability to undermine a major foreign currency. In January, Mr. Druckenmiller traveled to London with all the credibility of a financial head of state. He met privately with officials of the British Treasury and the Bank of England. In an interview with The Financial Times, he denied reports that Quantum was angling for a repeat of last September's killing shorting European currencies, this time wagering against the franc.
But Quantum may be at a crossroads. It has grown so enormous that its sheer size might work against its funds' chances of finding enough investment opportunities to continue the spectacular gains. Moreover, Quantum's management has been subpoenaed in connection with the Justice Department investigation of the 1991 Treasury auction scandal involving Salomon Brothers. The Government is thought to be looking into whether big investment houses and their customers participated in a squeeze play, driving up the price of the Treasury issue by cornering the market.
Mr. Druckenmiller has kept a low profile. Technically he's one of 12 managing directors at Soros Fund Management, which runs the Quantum Group. And, guarded by Quantum's newly hired public relations firm, Kekst & Company, he has refused to be interviewed for this article. (So have Mr. Soros and anyone else at his firm.)
Those who know him -- friends, in-laws and people in the money-management business -- say he prefers staying out of the limelight, is loyal to Mr. Soros and is consumed by investing.
A magna cum laude graduate of Bowdoin College in Maine with degrees in economics and English, the tall, lanky Philadelphia native was the head of equity research at Pittsburgh National Bank by the time he was 25. When a securities-firm executive offered him $10,000 a month just for the chance to talk with him about investments, he decided to open his own money management firm, Duquesne Capital, in 1981.
His numbers in the first five years attracted Howard Stein, head of the Dreyfus Fund, and the 32-year-old boy wonder was soon dividing his time between New York and Pittsburgh. Mr. Stein built up funds around him -- seven in all -- offering investors variations on Mr. Druckenmiller's technique. Mr. Soros landed him in autumn 1988.
The union got off to a rocky start; Mr. Soros second-guessed his protege, and they clashed over the sale of bonds that Mr. Druckenmiller had wanted to keep. Mr. Druckenmiller was able to take charge, he told Jack D. Schwager for the book "The New Market Wizards," only after the collapse of Communism in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union allowed Mr. Soros to devote himself more to philanthropy in his Hungarian homeland and throughout the region.
But the changeover brought little real difference in Quantum's investment approach. Like his mentor, Mr. Druckenmiller concentrates on "macro" issues, the proverbial big picture. How corporate leaders perform is less important than what the Federal Reserve chairman does. When the Persian Gulf war started in January 1991, he switched his American investments from short to long.
He is disciplined yet flexible, just as comfortable shorting securities as buying them, and borrows readily to make investments.
Mr. Druckenmiller also favors "technical" over "fundamental" analysis. That is, he concentrates on market factors like price and volume trends rather than on particular corporate revenues and earnings -- Wall Street's methodology -- in determining which way securities are heading.
FOR example, he predicted the October 1987 crash because he thought the market rally preceding it was being driven by a few strong companies, while the vast majority were trailing weakly and were headed for a fall; unfortunately for him, after the market began to fall just before the crash, he started to buy -- the worst case of timing in his life.
The Soros-Druckenmiller team produced spectacular results last summer when the pound looked shaky despite British determination to prop it up. In August, Mr. Druckenmiller built up a position shorting the pound and the lira, and buying the German mark, on the assumption that the British and Italian economies were took weak to support the value of their currencies against the mark. He bought British stocks, betting on a boost from lower interest rates intended to stimulate the economy, and sold German and French stocks because the lack of a similar drop in interest rates and increases in prices relative to British prices would be bad for business. By the same token, he bought French and German bonds because they would look good by comparison to stocks in those countries.
Mr. Soros's role in this investing coup? He endorsed the strategy and in fact encouraged Mr. Druckenmiller to bet more and faster.
As of the end of last year, the original Quantum Fund had assets of $3.7 billion and, by borrowing on them, had built a portfolio weighted heavily in currencies and fixed-income investments like Treasury securities that was worth more than $30 billion.
Quantum has grown so quickly that four new funds -- Quota, Quasar International, Quantum Emerging Growth and now Quantum Realty -- have been spun off in the last two years from the original Quantum Fund. Taken together the five funds held a portfolio of more than $50 billion at the beginning of the year. Mr. Druckenmiller directly controls the original Quantum Fund and oversees Mr. Soros's other funds.
"He's the master chef," said James Marquez, the portfolio manager at Quantum Fund in the early 1980's, who now runs his own money management company.
Not everything has come out well done. Last January an outside portfolio manager at the Quantum Fund was a defendant in one of the largest insider trading cases. The Securities and Exchange Commission charged that a tip from the manager, Purnendu Chatterjee, had enabled his brother-in-law and a friend to profit from a takeover of the Foxboro Company, in which Quantum had a large stake and Mr. Chatterjee held a board seat. The three defendants settled the case with the S.E.C., without admitting or denying guilt, for $2.1 million. Meanwhile, Mr. Chatterjee is still managing the same slice of Mr. Druckenmiller's Quantum Fund as he did before.
WHILE his investment record is formidable, Mr. Druckenmiller has a manner that does not always impress. E. Lee Hennessee, a hedge-fund consultant at Shearson who met Mr. Druckenmiller when he came to New York, said his dry style turned off the investment manager of an Ivy League university to whom she introduced him. "Stanley's a very intense, serious man with a very quick mind. He'll go through something very fast, not seeming to notice that he's leaving some people behind. When he's said what he has to say, that's it."
At work or away from it, he had little interest in small talk or in revealing much of himself. "He's very hard to read," Ms. Hennessee concluded.
Mr. Druckenmiller maintains something of a spartan regimen in the midst of luxury at the penthouse on 72d Street off Park Avenue and the weekend home in Southampton that he shares with his wife (Fiona Biggs, another Dreyfus money manager and a niece of Barton Biggs, the Morgan Stanley managing director) and three daughters. Mr. Druckenmiller works out in his apartment gym, jogs in Southampton and has been known to be in bed at 8:30 P.M. on weekends.
He has hunted at the Maryland barony of Paul Tudor Jones, who runs Tudor Investment; he socializes with Stanley Shopkorn, a former vice chairman at Salomon, and he plays an exceptional game of golf.
Even admirers of Mr. Druckenmiller suggest that it will be hard for him to extend his sensational streak. Barton Biggs thinks that the markets might be overwhelmed by imitators. Mr. Marquez added: "They're almost too big. It's tough to move $7 billion. It's tough to maintain those returns."
Mr. Marquez suggested that Quantum may effectively be limited in every market except for trading currencies, which at a daily volume of $1 trillion dwarfs all the others.
And even then, it may be tough finding the right plays.
 
 
 
NOT FOR WIDOWS AND ORPHANS
 TOO bad, America. The funds managed by Stanley F. Druckenmiller are closed to United States citizens or residents. The principal reason: Their managers want access to more than 99 investors, the maximum United States securities law allows for such "hedge funds."
The law limits the number of investors as a means of limiting exposure to risk.
Hedge funds also register outside the United States so they can operate with a lot more flexibility than if they were governed by the Securities and Exchange Commission.
That can translate into a lot more risk. Hedge funds may short securities as often as they buy. But shorting has far greater potential for loss than gain. Their longs (purchases) or some other opposing strategy may cover them, which is where the term hedging comes from, but the buys could also go down as the shorts go up.
Also, investing in futures and options currencies, commodities and stocks forces managers to deal with volatile variables not found when buying "vanilla" stocks and bonds. Finally, the funds may leverage up to 20 times their assets. All and all, not for widows and orphans.
Few funds are as successful as the Quantum Group and those that are can't produce simply "good" returns for investors to make money. The funds generally charge a management fee of 1 percent and take 15 percent to 20 percent of the profits, and the best of them might charge a premium of some 30 percent on the purchase of their shares.

HEADLINE: THE SEXES;
This Proposal Is for Status Quo

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Kaye

 BODY:
POPULAR entertainments being what they are, attempts to analyze a movie these days may produce the uneasy sense that you are critiquing a cartoon. Still, Hollywood cartoons can impinge on a nerve, activating reservoirs of shame and secret longing, tapping into inadmissible impulses, in the process providing a release for moral and sexual anxiety in much the way that horror movies are said to release other types of tension. Consider "Fatal Attraction," "Pretty Woman," "Basic Instinct" and, with an opening-week gross of $25 million, the current leading box-office attraction, "Indecent Proposal," a film that begins in the soft focus of a Kotex ad, and goes on to prove that nothing is sacred.
The picture's evocative title instantly telegraphs the link it draws between sex and money, the two issues that even the most sanguine individuals are least sanguine about. This combination is examined through a premise that is as bogus as it is intriguing: can a middle-class marriage survive after a devoted wife sells herself for an evening to a stunning-but-lonely billionaire winsomely played by a guarded-yet-tender Robert Redford? Or, to recycle the question Erich Segal posited more than 25 years ago, does being in love really mean never having to say you're sorry? 
 Yet, because the other leading characters are numbingly bland, as portrayed by Demi Moore and Woody Harrelson, and because the potentially explosive subject matter is dealt with so fancifully, the most astonishing aspect of this picture is that it has made so many people of such varying views so apoplectic.
Last week, a local Manhattan news show interviewed Dr. Ruth Westheimer, who categorically stated that the picture cheapens love. Newspaper reporters interviewed Patricia Ireland and Susan Faludi, who categorically stated that the picture demeans women. One station conducted man-on-the-street interviews with men who stated categorically that the picture demeans them.
In The New York Post, society columnist William Norwich reported that the English author Barbara Cartland, "has gone ballistic."
"The whole idea is absolutely disgusting, degrading and vulgar," Mr. Norwich quoted Ms. Cartland as saying, "and no woman with any pretensions to being decent would do it."
"This movie," said a woman I know, "is a man's fantasy of a woman's fantasy."
The proliferation of that fantasy is more widespread than you might suspect, as can be gleaned from results of a poll aired on the Oprah Winfrey show on which the film's premise was discussed. "If you were offered a million dollars," women were asked, "would you break your marriage vows and sleep with a stranger?" Fifty-five percent said yes.
To men, the delicate matter of whether to relinquish their wife to raise money they cannot earn seemingly provoked such overwhelming feelings that most retreated into the cliches that mask real emotion.
"I'd do it in a minute," one man told Ms. Winfrey, "they can touch her physically, but they can't touch her spiritually."
"I would have to say yes," agreed another man. "I love her, but afterwards I could still love her, and we'd have the money."
In case you were wondering how its theme plays out, the film's main characters, Diana and David (Miss Moore and Mr. Harrelson) are avatars from an equally bromide-ridden America, a smug and comfortable world where there is an answer for every question and no one questions any answers. In this world, David believes "a life without risk is like no life at all."
Displaying her habit for being bowled over by shopworn verities, Diana dreamily intones, "Someone once said, 'If you want something very badly, set it free, if it comes back to you, it's yours forever.' "
In Diana and David's sturdy, no-frills America, pocketbooks are eschewed for knapsacks, underwear is white cotton and shirts are well-worn denim. David snacks on the good-old-American peanut butter and banana sandwiches that fattened Elvis Presley. Yet, Diana and David are not squares. Their sex life is heated and virtually incessant. Their intimacy permits Diana to engage David in earnest talks about their finances while she sits on the toilet.
David is an architect. Diana is a real estate agent who finds the property on which David can build the dream house that will establish his reputation, though it turns out that, unlike Mr. Blandings, he can't afford it. The recession has inhibited their grasping the American dream through the hard work and vision that traditionally help obtain it. They borrow $5,000 and go to Las Vegas, Nev., to parlay it into the $50,000 they desperately need, thus partaking in the ultimate American dream, which is to get something for nothing.
In Las Vegas, Diana beguiles the billionaire John Gage by surreptitiously helping herself to a large handful of free Godiva chocolates, (read: innocent) and then trying on a $5,000 black dress that is elegant with just a hint of bondage (read: sexy). Still, Diana evinces her stubborn Calvinist streak when John tries to buy her the dress.
"You've earned it," he tells her.
"No, I haven't," she replies. "The dress is for sale. I'm not."
Sadly, like most of what Diana claims, this is not the case.
And when John offers David a million dollars for one night with Diana, she replies with characteristic originality, "You can't buy people."
"That's naive, Diana," John says, in the best line of the picture, "I buy people every day."
John is curiously self-effacing for a man able to amass a billion dollars. "The night would come and go," he tells the couple when they initially and emphatically refuse his offer, "but the money would last a lifetime."
In any case, you see what is upsetting about this picture: it nudges you to reassess cherished illusions that the vows you make cannot be broken, that the principles you adopt cannot be compromised, that you cannot be bought for a million dollars. And the audience giggles and twitters nervously when the next scene reveals David in bed, sleeplessly staring at the ceiling, eyes as round, blue and blank as newly laid robin's eggs. They laugh because it is obvious that he is thinking that the deal might be worth it.
Just like people in real life, movie characters want it both ways, although, unlike in real life, getting it both ways does not seem to pose much of an obstacle.
"Fatal Attraction" hedged its bets by dividing the classic madonna/ whore into two people. The particular cleverness of a movie like "Pretty Woman" or "Indecent Proposal" is that they contain the tension of madonna and whore in a single individual. Not that there is much tension, this being Hollywood. In "Pretty Woman," the madonna was barely a whore, while "Indecent Proposal's" whore is a tad too earthy to really be a madonna. Nonetheless, this fusion enabled the pretty woman to be both a prostitute and an innocent, while enabling Diana to be both a bad girl and a self-sacrificing martyr.
But sacrifice, or so women are always told, is meant to be its own reward. So perhaps what ultimately upsets people about "Indecent Proposal" is not that Diana spends the night with John, but that she enjoys it. The idea that a woman can enjoy sex without love makes people nervous.
In the Chinese film "Raise the Red Lantern," the most likable woman is the one who least likes being a concubine. But now, we have Diana, dressed by John for their rendezvous in a Mandarin-style sheath, after he has already pleased her with a sexy dress in a big red box tied with bright red ribbon, like a child's vision of a really good present. You don't have to be pre-pubescent to harbor the fantasy of being Daddy's little girl.
The future of the woman's movement depends on women disliking their current position, which means that nothing subverts feminism more than the possibility that there are perks in being infantalized and in victimization. The secret appeal of the victimized status is precisely what Adrian Lyne, the director of "Indecent Proposal," has capitalized on since he made "Nine-and-a-Half Weeks" and "Fatal Attraction." The degree to which women enjoy being victims is the degree to which their progress is impeded, which means that progress depends on denying that this enjoyment is possible.
"I hate you," Diana later tells John.
"No," he says, "you want to hate me."
By the end of the movie, David and Diana have ventured far from the good, predictable America where children of all ages eat peanut butter and banana sandwiches, only to arrive there once again, ready to embark on the life they planned initially. Which brings us to the most disturbing aspect of this picture: it's strange ability to demonstrate that nothing is more difficult to become than the person you always claimed to be.

HEADLINE: Fixing Blast Damage Isn't an Economic Lift

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report April 8 that economists of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey estimate the World Trade Center blast is providing an economic benefit. You have fallen prey to an old economic fallacy often called the "broken window fallacy." 
 This is the notion that wanton destruction, whether by vandals, terrorists or even full-scale war, is somehow a net benefit to the economy by creating work and funneling funds in a concentrated manner toward repairing damage and replacing destroyed goods.
But real wealth, as opposed to money wealth, has been destroyed in the bombing; spending money in the effort to recreate it funnels that money from the effort to create new wealth.
The thinking of the Port Authority economists overlooks all the other jobs that would have been created or sustained and the products that would have been purchased if people could spend their money as they preferred to spend it before they had to spend money on replacing what has been destroyed.
Whether or not most of the money came from outside the New York area, if the logic of the broken window fallacy were followed, New York City could get the most bang for the buck (so to speak) economically by employing terrorists, since a simple and cheap explosion is the quick ticket toward economic growth. Obviously, this is nonsense.
So is the Port Authority analysis, which you have presented so unquestioningly.
 
BRIAN DOHERTY
Asst. Editor, Regulation: The Cato
Review of Business & Government
Washington, April 9, 1993

HEADLINE: APRIL 11-17: Failure in Bosnia;
Srebrenica: A Symbol Of Serbian Brutality And the World's Impotence

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN

 BODY:
Serbian forces in Bosnia last week launched a final assault on the eastern town of Srebrenica after a siege emblematic of the horrors of the Balkan war and the outside world's inability to stop it. The United Nations, having failed to organize action that might have saved the Muslim-held enclave, was reduced to efforts to minimize the carnage of its evacuation.
The town's plight seems to illustrate conclusively, if there were any doubt, that the Bosnian Serbs intend to use force to consolidate their position while the world dithers. Negotiating, if necessary, comes later, from a vantage of strength. 
 Hope is fading for the peace plan for the former Yugoslavia devised by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen of Britain. The Muslim-led Bosnian Government said Srebrenica's fall would render its signing of the peace plan void. Even Lord Owen last week said bombing raids on the Serbs' supply routes were now probably needed to bring the Serbs in line.
President Clinton may have been hinting the same thing when he said the West needed to consider actions that "previously have been unacceptable" to stop Serbian attacks. He said he had not ruled out any military option except sending American ground troops to the Balkans.
Also under consideration are tightened economic sanctions and, perhaps, a decision to allow the Bosnian Government to import arms.
The Serbs are evidently calculating that they can live with anything short of major Western military intervention (the NATO air patrols that began last week over Bosnia are largely inconsequential). Still, tough action may not materialize for many reasons, ranging from American fear of a quagmire to Russian opposition.
