HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Head to Head With the Japanese

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
IF there was any doubt in the minds of the Japanese that the rules have permanently changed in their dealings with Washington, it ended last week when Secretary of State Warren G. Christopher flew into town for an emergency meeting about aiding Russia and stopped by to meet Japan's new Foreign Minister, Kabun Muto.
In years past there would have been lots of reassuring talk at such a first meeting about how crucial the Japan-America relationship was, as the linchpin of stability and democracy in East Asia. Instead, the two men started talking about personal computers. Halfway through Mr. Muto's explanation of the wonders of Japan's new $116 billion economic stimulus package, which includes the purchase of more high-tech equipment for Japanese schools and universities, Mr. Christopher cut to the heart of the matter: Would the program result in more opportunities for the likes of I.B.M., Compaq and Apple, whose share of the Japanese personal computer market, while growing, is nothing to celebrate? 
 "It wasn't so subtle, but the message had to get across," said an American diplomat who helped inspire the exchange. "The central element in this relationship is now, more clearly than ever, the economic relationship. And for the Japanese, that is taking some getting used to."
Indeed, for two countries as obsessed with each other as these, it is remarkable how out of sync they seem to be. When Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa arrived in Washington on Friday, President Clinton and his Cabinet members wasted little time with get-to-know-you niceties, and moved right into talk about the primacy of the trade surplus to the relationship -- and the need for immediate results before protectionist movements mushroom.
They did nod to the continued need for a deep security relationship, especially in light of North Korea's nuclear program. There was the usual vague talk about global cooperation on the environment and energy. But Mr. Clinton made it clear that the shift in priorities that has been seeping through the relationship for years must now be acknowledged. "The cold war partnership between our two countries is outdated," he said at a joint press conference with Mr. Miyazawa. He talked at length about "the rebalancing of our relationship" to put economics at the forefront. "America is accepting the challenge of change, and so, too, must Japan."
 
Different Timetables
 But it is clear that the pace of change the two countries have in mind is quite different. Mr. Clinton is talking about a quick reversal of the trade gap, which was $49 billion in 1992. But Mr. Miyazawa, in a contemplative conversation on Monday with American reporters, said that "we should be patient."
"Since we have been trying to cooperate for a decade," he said, "there is no reason we should solve it overnight." He even mused about the continued need for "gaiatsu" -- the well-rehearsed cycle of American pressure and Japanese concessions that, while effective, breeds resentments here. Mr. Miyazawa likened it to a "mother telling her child to do this or not to do this, otherwise your neighbor may laugh at you; that is the way of education in this country." And it would go on for some time, he predicted, because gaiatsu is "just perhaps a part of our culture," Japan's mechanism for adjusting itself to "the modern world."
In the Clinton Administration's view, it is a bit late for hand-wringing about how Japan needs more time to make cultural adjustments. Mr. Clinton's leaked comment to Russia's President, Boris Yeltsin, that "when the Japanese say yes to us, they often mean no" seemed tinged with impatience about talks that drag on endlessly. Mr. Miyazawa laughed the comment off, saying it reminded him of the song, "Yes, We Have No Bananas." But in the end, his trip to Washington amounted to another no-bananas meeting. Apart from the economic stimulus program -- which at best will increase imports by a few billion dollars -- he brought little fruit to feed the new occupant of White House.
For the Japanese, this is the worst moment to talk about new concessions, much less a new basis for the relationship. At few times in its 37-year rule has the Liberal Democratic Party been in greater turmoil or fear that its monopoly on power may be threatened. The result is a virtual vacuum of political leadership at the top -- where leadership has never been in huge supply -- to get done what Mr. Clinton says he needs.
Over the past two months most of the elderly men who quietly executed the political fixes with the United States have suddenly found themselves in jail, in the hospital or out of power, leaving it less clear than ever who is really running the place. And this has left a swirl of rumors about the growing strength of some new parties and the possibility of large-scale defections from the Liberal Democrats later this year.
The absence of political leadership was evident in the weeks leading up to the two-day emergency meeting here last week of the seven leading industrialized democracies, an event Japan was unenthusiastic about. Everyone in Tokyo knew that as the host of the meeting, and of the G-7 summit meeting in July, Japan would have to come up with serious aid for Mr. Yeltsin. It did: $1.8 billion (most of it in credits and trade insurance) as its share of a $28 billion aid package largely contingent on Russian austerity. Along the way, though, Japanese leaders left their Russia policy in a tangle of contradictions, with Cabinet ministers changing their descriptions daily about whether Japan is now willing to set aside a territorial dispute over four islands held by the Soviet Union and Russia since the end of World War II.
The Russia conference proved that gaiatsu lives on as the driving force behind Japanese policy. But top officials here say they fear that the Clinton Administration is beginning to push too hard, announcing "investigations" of compliance with trade agreements and tempting the Japanese bureaucracy to retaliate in kind.
Mr. Miyazawa made it clear during his visit that Japan would not stand for new American efforts to guarantee a specific market share for American products, or tolerate trade sanctions if Washington plays judge and jury on issues of trade.
"You want to solve everything quickly," one of Mr. Miyazawa's closest foreign policy advisers said the other day. "From our point of view it will take time." In short, we have no bananas today. Maybe tomorrow.

HEADLINE: Verdict in Los Angeles;
Calm Relief Where Rage Once Ruled

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 17

 BODY:
After two years of convulsions, racial turmoil and fear, a great cloud of gloom lifted from Los Angeles today.
The battered city seemed to open and brighten just after 7 A.M., when it was announced that two of four white officers had been found guilty of violating Rodney G. King's civil rights. Shopkeepers who had boarded up their stores opened for business. Children went to Saturday arts classes. Traffic moved smoothly amid a general feeling that the split verdict had brought at least a measure of justice, if not a solution to all this city's social ills. 
 "It's like I've got cotton under my feet," Jimmy Simon, a black retired mechanic, said as he flashed a toothy smile on a street in South-Central Los Angeles. "Everybody can go home -- nothing will happen now."
 
Divisions Remain
 It was much the same throughout this polyglot region's patchwork quilt of suburbs and city, and the calm that lasted through the day appeared to be holding well into the evening.
But there were also pointed reminders that much work remained, that more than equal justice in the courts was at issue.
"There has to be some economic and educational justice," said Connier J. Nero, a black woman who helps the elderly get medical care. "We can't talk about holding hands and being friends when you have a job and I don't."
 
Nightmare May Be Over
 Since Friday evening, 6,500 police officers, backed by National Guard troops, have been at full mobilization in case of a repeat of the devastating riots that left 52 dead and $1 billion in property damage last year. But they had little to do apart from keeping a wary eye.
"All the information we are getting is that the streets are quiet and peaceful," said Deputy Police Chief Matthew V. Hunt at the police command post at the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. "Hopefully, this long nightmare that has gone on for the last two years is finally behind us."
At City Hall, Mayor Tom Bradley, nearing the end of his 20-year tenure, breathed a sigh of relief. "Today a jury representing the diversity of our city found the truth," he said. "Today a measure of simple justice has been delivered to our community."
He added, "Today, Los Angeles has turned the corner."
The verdicts were praised around the city and the nation. Gov. Pete Wilson said, "Justice has been done." In Washington, Attorney General Janet Reno said, "The jury has spoken and justice has prevailed."
There was also great relief 40 miles away in Simi Valley, the suburban community in Ventura County where a state jury with no black members acquitted the four officials on state charges last year, in a verdict that touched off days of rioting. "I think we are very pleased that it is over, so we can get on with life," said Mayor Gregory Stratton. "The prosecution this time did a much better job."
At the corner of Florence and Normandie Avenues, the South-Central Los Angeles flash point for last April's riots, all was calm apart from the commotion caused by dozens of reporters and photographers. Drivers passed, honked their horns and flashed peace signs at the cameras.
"I don't understand why everybody is here," said Joseph Thomas, a black stock worker at the Price Club who had stopped for gas at the Unocal station at the still-battered intersection. "This area has been pretty quiet until today."
 
Business as Usual
 In Koreatown, which suffered the worst of the damage to shops last year, merchants warily began to open for business starting about 9 A.M., when it appeared that all was calm. "When I heard the verdict, I thought, There's not that much to get excited about," Charles Yoon said at his small key-copying shack in the minimall at Vermont Avenue and West Eighth Street. His shack was looted and burned last year.
At Cosmos, a Koreatown appliance store that had been cleaned out last year, Lawrence Ha, the manager, was open for business as usual. "The city is so quiet now," he said. "We've already started making deliveries across town, downtown, and in black neighborhoods. There is nobody on the streets."
Probably nowhere was the reaction more emotional than at the First African Methodist Episcopal Church, a predominantly black congregation where a large crowed gathered to watch the verdict on big-screen televisions.
One year ago, just after the acquittal in the state trial, Mayor Bradley stood at the church's pulpit and pleaded for calm as violence broke out around the city.
Today, the Rev. Cecil Murray bowed his head in prayer and held hands with the Rev. Jesse Jackson as the clerk read the verdict in Federal court.
 
Eruption of Cheers
 The word "guilty" twice brought an eruption of cheers when the verdicts for Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officer Laurence M. Powell were read. When it was over, the group burst into the hymn "My Faith Looks Up to Thee," their hands reaching to touch a Bible held aloft.
Later, Mr. Murray, a leader in attempts to calm the city's minority areas, expressed joy at the verdict but warned that "justice means jobs."
There were still fears of trouble because of the upcoming trial of three young black men in the beating of a truck driver, Reginald O. Denny, during last year's unrest. But John Mack, president of the local chapter of the Urban League, said he believed that the groundwork for peace had been laid during months of preparations.
"I believe that the verdict in this case is going to help," he said. "We have begun to restore the lost credibility in the criminal justice system, which was just about zero before in the African-American community."
 
'Justice Has Spoken'
 The church hall rang with calls for the local and Federal governments to intensify efforts to create jobs and training, and to improve schooling in Los Angeles's poorer neighborhoods.
The reaction among police officers was more equivocal. Deputy Chief Hunt watched the verdict with other officers at the Coliseum. "It was a very dramatic moment with very little reaction," he said later. "Justice has spoken."
On the streets, most police officers refused to comment on the record. One who did was Sgt. Gene McCloskey, who said: "We've been turned upside down for two years. Maybe we can get on with policing now."
Another white officer, who would not give his name, said the convicted officers "were scapegoats."
At the Los Angeles Police Department's Southeast Division headquarters, officers clustered around television sets. Officer John J. Clark said, "For the people who work in the street, it makes their job a lot tougher to do, because we'll be second guessed every time we do something.
"This is what a majority of the community wanted. This gives the criminal a lot more power in the streets."
At City Hall, the Chief of Police, Willie L. Williams, urged Angelenos to go about their normal business today, saying the police would remain on high alert.
"Right now, the City of Los Angeles is very calm, perhaps even more calm than this time last Saturday," he said. "It's very important to point out that the deployment plans put in place last night, complemented with full deployment beginning at 6 A.M. this morning, will stay in place for the time being."
The previous police chief, Daryl F. Gates, who was forced from his job by controversies over the King beating, spoke on KFI, a radio station on which he has a talk show. "It's amazing to see the jubilation on the part of some people over this verdict and that fact that so many are saying what a great verdict it is and what a great job this jury has done," Mr. Gates said. "Those are the same people who trashed the system on the last occasion."
"I think they were under incredible pressure," Mr. Gates said of the jury. "Clearly in the back of their minds they had to have the pressure of the rioting, the vilification of the last jury."
Asked about Mr. Gates's comments, Mayor Bradley -- long at odds with the former chief -- said, "Daryl Gates is irrelevant to the issues of this city."
Civil rights groups voiced satisfaction with the verdict but cautioned that the case was merely a symptom of basic issues of unequal justice, racial bias and police brutality that must still be addressed.
In a statement, the NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund said, "These convictions send a message to all of America: It is unacceptable under the laws of our nation to brutalize any person on the basis of race."
The group called on the nation "to look beyond the drama of this trial, to the criminal justice system that produced this horrible event," and to the economic plight of urban minority communities.

HEADLINE: Verdict in Los Angeles;
CLINTON SATISFIED BY JURY'S DECISION

BYLINE: By JEFF GERTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
President Clinton expressed satisfaction today with the verdict in the police beating trial in Los Angeles and then used the decision as a platform to promote spiritual and economic revitalization.
In an interview at the airport in Pittsburgh with radio station KDKA shortly after the verdict, Mr. Clinton said of the jury, "No one knows exactly why they did what they did, but it appears that they really tried to do justice here." 
The President, a former prosecutor and lawyer, gave his own analysis of the split verdict, saying that the two men who were convicted, Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officer Laurence M. Powell, seemed to bear more responsibility in the March 1991 beating of a motorist, Rodney G. King. One of the acquitted officers, Theodore J. Briseno, tried to shield Mr. King from more blows, Mr. Clinton said, and the other officer, Timothy E. Wind, was a rookie.
 
Federal Efforts Praised
 The President also praised the efforts of the Federal Government in developing the case. The case was begun by the Bush Administration's Justice Department in the heat of last year's election campaign several months after the acquittal of the four officers in a state trial precipitated rioting in Los Angeles.
The new Attorney General, Janet Reno, said today at a press conference in Washington that the "Department of Justice is going to do everything it can to continue to bring prosecutions to insure that the civil rights of all citizens across the country are protected."
The department will recommend sentences for the two convicted officers to the Federal judge in the case, but Ms. Reno declined to discuss the matter further, saying, "That should be done in court."
The President, at the beginning of a rally at the Pittsburgh International Airport, relayed news of the verdict to the crowd, who cheered and applauded at the announcement of the two guilty verdicts. Mr. Clinton said he found a deeper message in the jury's decision, calling for reconciliation and harmony despite the racial, religious and ethnic differences in the country.
 
'Our Common Humanity'
 "Surely the lasting legacy of the Rodney King trial ought to be a determination to reaffirm our common humanity and to make a strength of our diversity. And if we can do that, then we get on about the business of this great land," he told the airport crowd.
The President, in his radio interview a few minutes later, said that the verdict reinforced the importance of "not violating the civil rights of any American." He also used the case to highlight two priorities of his Administration, renewing the fight against crime and revitalizing the cities and economically distressed areas.
President Clinton was in Pennsylvania to push his spending program.

HEADLINE: 2 Gay Adoption Cases Go to Appeals Courts

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BURLINGTON, Vt., April 17

 BODY:
Appellate courts in two states are to decide whether a person in a long-term homosexual relationship can adopt the children of the partner.
The Vermont Supreme Court and the Commonwealth of Massachusetts Appeals Court each have before them a case in which a lesbian has asked to become the adoptive parent of her partner's children. The rulings later this year will be the nation's first appellate-level decisions on the issue. 
 Some advocates of such adoptions say they welcome the prospect of rulings with more weight than the decisions of trial court judges.
"Not only will this provide uniformity throughout one state, but it may also have a persuasive effect on other states," said Paula Ettelbrick, a lawyer with the Lambda Legal Defense and Education Fund, a gay-rights group based in New York.
But other people see a peril for those who favor such adoptions.
"At least 100 -- and probably hundreds -- of these cases have succeeded at the trial court level, most of them on the West Coast," said Ruth Harlow, a lawyer with the Lesbian and Gay Rights Project of the American Civil Liberties Union. "At the trial court level, the judge gets to see the interaction between the parents and the children. The danger at the appellate level is that judges will deal with the legal issues in a vacuum."
There was no legal opposition to the adoptions in either of the New England cases. The lawyers for the people involved say they simply want an interpretation of the laws.
The catalyst for the Vermont case was a health insurance claim involving Deborah Lashman and Jane Van Buren. Ms. Van Buren, who was unemployed at the time, was the biological mother of two boys, 18 months old and 4 years old, who were conceived by artificial insemination.
Ms. Lashman's insurer would not include them under her policy.
"We had been thinking about adoption for some time," Ms. Van Buren said in an interview, "but when I was unemployed, we felt very vulnerable. We were living off Deb's income. What if something happened to her? The boys couldn't even collect her Social Security benefits."
 
Rare Adoption Rejection
 Judge George Belcher of Burlington Probate Court turned down their adoption request in June 1992 in what Ms. Ettelbrick and Ms. Harlow said was the first case they were aware of nationally in which a trial judge disallowed such an adoption.
Judge Belcher declined to comment on his decision, but Ms. Ettelbrick, who took part in the case, said he apparently relied on language in the Vermont adoption statutes that requires a spouse to consent to an adoption. She said Judge Belcher interpreted the wording to mean that couples must be married in order to adopt.
Ms. Lashman and Ms. Van Buren appealed.
In the Massachusetts case, known as "the adoption of Katherine Mary," Ms. Harlow said the trial judge allowed the adoption but then sent the case to the appeals court to test the validity of her interpretation of the statute. Briefs in that case were filed in mid-February.
Only two states, Florida and New Hampshire, have specifically prohibited adoptions by partners of the same sex, and the Florida statute is being tested in several lawsuits there.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%);

HEADLINE: Audit Faults Market for Ills of Blue Cross

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, April 17

 BODY:
A long-awaited independent audit of Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield concludes that the management of New York State's largest health-insurance company has been slow to react to accelerating changes in the insurance marketplace. Among other findings, the audit maintains that Empire trailed the rest of the industry in expanding its managed-care programs and in developing modern computer systems, both of which contributed to heavy losses in recent years.
But the executive summary of a draft of the report, based on an audit ordered by the State Legislature last year and performed by Arthur Andersen & Company, maintains that Empire's poor financial performance has resulted primarily from economic forces beyond the control of management. 
 "Empire's current financial straits are the result of the inevitable conflict between the historic social mission of Blue Cross Blue Shield and the modern reality of spiraling health-care costs and heightened market competition for low-risk customers," according to the draft report.
The final report is due on May 1, but officials with Empire and the state began receiving copies of the draft on Thursday night. The Daily News reported some of the audit's findings today.
 
Empire Officials Find Support
 Empire officials said today that they were gratified by the audit's support for their contention that the company's losses of $250 million over the last two years were largely unavoidable. But the audit stops far short of giving Empire's management a clean bill of health.
"In a dynamic, volatile health care market, Empire has been an autocratic, functionally organized, hierarchical organization that has been slow to react to the pace of change," the report states. "In an earlier era -- when the pace of change was slower and competition less intense -- Empire's culture and operating environment may have served it well. Today Empire is neither organized nor managed to become a market leader in innovation or quality improvement."
The audit criticized the dual managerial role played by Albert A. Cardone, who serves both as Empire's board chairman and its chief executive officer. That arrangement has been questioned by the State Insurance Superintendent, Salvatore R. Curiale, who told Empire board members on Friday that they should either take more responsibility for the company or resign.
The audit concludes that "companies like Empire, which operate in the public trust, can more effectively address issues such as governance and strategic mission by separating the lead roles in the company."
Michael Blumenfeld, Empire's vice president for public and governmental affairs, said the board would seriously examine all of the audit's recommendations, including the division of Mr. Cardone's responsibilities.
The larger issue may be whether the board ultimately will lose confidence in Mr. Cardone, who has become a lightning rod for criticism of the company. Some Republican legislators have called for the resignations of both Mr. Cardone and Mr. Curiale.
The audit may help Mr. Cardone to some extent. It dismisses as unjustified the recurring criticism of the company's salary levels and administrative expenses.
 
$600,000 Salary
 Last month, The New York Times reported that Empire lost tens of millions of dollars over the last decade through a series of management mistakes, offered lucrative contracts to insiders and spent freely on management perquisites. Mr. Cardone receives $600,000 a year, travels first class and is provided with a chauffeur-driven Lincoln Town Car.
But the audit concludes that "based on comparisons to various insurance executive compensation surveys, Empire's officer-compensation levels are reasonable."
And with regard to travel and entertainment expenses, if found that "Empire's policies are stringent when compared to comparable private corporations and in fact may impair the ability of Empire's marketing and sales organization to compete in the larger group market."
Empire is a nonprofit corporation that must insure all those who can afford to pay, regardless of their health or age. In return, it gets a discount on hospital charges and pays no state or city taxes. The company serves 8.5 million people in 28 counties in eastern New York, from the New York City area to Albany.
With the company's reserves dwindling in recent years, the Legislature and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo have taken a number of extraordinary measures to keep Empire afloat.
In January, under a deal negotiated by Mr. Cuomo and the Legislature, Mr. Curiale granted Empire a rate increase that averaged 20 percent per customer. The increase came on the heels of legislation approved last year that was aimed at making Empire more competitive with commercial insurance companies.
Under the new law, which took effect on April 1, commercial insurers have to accept all applicants and must base rates on the risks posed by groups of customers rather than individuals. The law also authorized Arthur Andersen to conduct the audit to determine whether the company's problems resulted from its management practices or its competitive disadvantage in the marketplace.

HEADLINE: Verdict in Los Angeles;
NEW YORK GREETS VERDICTS QUIETLY

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. McFADDEN

 BODY:
Calm prevailed across the New York metropolitan area after the verdicts in the Los Angeles beating case yesterday, but emotions were sharply mixed as public officials, spiritual and civil-rights leaders and many ordinary people voiced relief, praise, anger and disappointment over the mosaic outcome.
The verdict -- two white officers guilty and two acquitted of Federal civil-rights charges in the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King in 1991 -- was the topic of the day for people across the region, as it was for millions of Americans a year after straight acquittals in a state trial that led to deadly riots in Los Angeles and other cities. 
 But after days of apprehension and low-key preparations for trouble, there were no reports of violence in the metropolitan area yesterday -- not even an echo of last year's sporadic and relatively moderate incidents of disorder in New York City, New Rochelle and a few other areas.
"It's as quiet as any normal April Saturday," said Deputy Inspector John Laffey, commanding officer of New York's police operations, whose hundreds of officers had little to do but patrol a soft spring day remarkable mainly for the yellow daffodils and sprays of forsythia out in the parks and for a warm golden sun that prowled for openings in a puffy meringue of clouds.
 
Hopes for Harmony
 And while hundreds of people in the New York area attended vigils, rallies or gatherings in houses of worship and expressed anger and sorrow over what many felt was an imperfect verdict, the predominant themes were those of peace and hope for harmony in a nation too often dealing with racial hatreds.
"It was half of what I wanted, but twice as much as I expected," said the Rev. Al Sharpton, who attended a morning vigil with 150 people at Public School 175 in Harlem and later led a rally of 50 chanting demonstrators protesting the verdict outside Police Headquarters in Manhattan.
"I think it vindicates those of us who have for years said that the state trials were unfair," Mr. Sharpton said of the verdict. "In many ways it validates the marchings and groanings and protests that many of us have done for years." He also called for a review of a half dozen local cases involving allegations of excessive force by police officers.
Another civil-rights advocate, the Rev. Herbert Daughtry, said he was sorry that all four officers in Los Angeles were not convicted but relieved that at least two were found guilty. And he contended that last year's riots, while sparked by the King verdict, were a result of more profound grievances.
"The eruptions which created such havoc in cities across America last year were due in large part to the urban decay, impoverishment, neglect, unfairness and injustice," he said. He called for a new urban policy to save the cities with aid comparable to the Marshall Plan for Europe after World War II.
 
Mayor Asks for Calm
 At City Hall, Mayor David N. Dinkins, who had appealed for calm in recent days while quietly mustering support from leaders of civic and other groups and ordering a wide range of security precautions, met with his top advisers, including Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly and Fire Commissioner Carlos M. Rivera.
"I thought all four were guilty," the Mayor said after the announcement in Los Angeles, echoing a view expressed by many New Yorkers. He said the four had "crossed the thin blue line between appropriate response and excessive force." But he added, "We must accept the verdict -- that doesn't mean I have to like it."
In Newark, a largely black and poor city of 275,000 that experienced devastating riots in 1967, the verdict was met with a mixture of disappointment and relief.
"It's something," said Malik Al-Salaam, who was selling T-shirts with red, black and green flags of Africa. "After the first verdict, when the proof was so obvious with the videotape, I thought there was nothing that could give a black man justice."
But Thelma Nickerson, a lifelong Newark resident, said she believed that accusations of police brutality were still largely unheeded. And Allan Siegal, director of a downtown art gallery, said: "I've become more depressed than before. It points out the horrible state of urban disintegration."
 
Compromise Is Seen
 In Harlem, on Malcolm X Boulevard, many called the verdict a compromise, perhaps intended to pacify Americans, and that left some angry. "I think all of them should have been found guilty -- and that's not because I'm black, it's because I'm a human being," said Junior Smith, a street vendor.
But Kevin McGill, a shoe-store owner, called the verdicts just. "The next time a black man gets stopped by the police, he won't have fear in his heart," Mr. McGill said.
In Brooklyn, Luis Garden Acosta, chief executive of El Puente, a Hispanic community organization, called the verdict a step in the right direction for the nation.
"This trial was not just about those four individuals, but about this country's values and about our history and who we are as a people," he said. "I believe the two individuals found not guilty represented the millions of Americans who in the face of injustice turn the other way."

HEADLINE: Turgut Ozal, 66, Dies in Ankara; Pugnacious President of Turkey

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL

 BODY:
President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, who was combative, pugnacious and provocative to the last, died in his Ankara home yesterday. He was 66 years old.
Officials said the cause of death was heart failure and suggested that it might have been hastened by a grueling 12-day tour of Central Asia that ended two days earlier. 
 The five-country tour was designed to show support for neighboring Azerbaijan, which is ethnically close to Turkey, in its conflict with Armenia.
Mr. Ozal had undergone triple-bypass heart surgery in the United States in 1987 and survived an assassination attempt a year later. He had been free of known heart problems since then.
Reporters traveling with him in Central Asia said he had seemed very fatigued.
 
Joined Anti-Iraq Coalition
 A squat, bespectacled and irascible figure, President Ozal left a deep mark on Turkey's modern history.
In 1990, he showed no hesitation in committing his predominantly Muslim country, a member of the NATO alliance, to the United States-led coalition against Iraq in the Persian Gulf war. That was crucial to the coalition's planning because it meant the severing of Iraq's principle oil-export routes, which remain closed by United Nations sanctions, and gave allied warplanes access to tactically important air bases.
In a statement yesterday, President Clinton said: "On behalf of all Americans, Mrs. Clinton and I extend our heartfelt sympathies to the people of Turkey and to the family and friends of President Ozal. President Ozal devoted his life to public service, and Turkey is a stronger country because of his dedicated and visionary leadership."
At home, many Turks remembered Mr. Ozal as the leader who thrust his land into an export-led drive toward free enterprise that revolutionized its moribund economy and turned the 1980's into free-wheeling boom years as the nation emerged in 1983 from three years of military rule.
Mr. Ozal's career betrayed a liking for power played out in devil-may-care style on the stage of international renown. But at home, his political life displayed other attributes. He engaged publicly in what seemed petty personal vendettas.
In his later years, his provocative comments often seemed deliberately at odds with official policy. And he was often accused of permitting his family to misuse his office to lead lives of lavish ostentation.
 
Was World Bank Economist
 Mr. Ozal was born in the central Anatolian town of Malatya. His father was a bank clerk and his mother a schoolteacher. He studied electrical engineering at Istanbul Technical University and joined the World Bank as an economist. Suleyman Demirel, Turkey's most durable political survivor and current prime minister, appointed him head of the State Planning Office in the 1970's.
His political career took shape during Turkey's period of military rule, from Mr. Demirel's overthrow in 1980 to the return of civilian rule in 1983.
His Motherland Party was one of the few the army allowed to operate, and Mr. Ozal became Prime Minister from 1983 to 1989. By then, the high inflationary cost of the 1980's boom and complaints about the autocratic behavior of Mr. Ozal and his family had weakened his public following.
Sensing his party's imminent political decline, he had himself elected President, a post traditionally above politics, so as to be able to retain high office after his party's 1991 election defeat by Mr. Demirel and his allies.
 
Running Battle With Demirel
 From then on, Mr. Ozal fought a running battle with Mr. Demirel, the one-time patron whose political rehabilitation he had opposed in the 1980's.
Such was Mr. Ozal's objection to the apolitical nature of the presidency that he once spent most of an hourlong interview with a reporter reading aloud clauses from the Constitution permitting presidential political intervention.
Those interventions were often controversial.
Claiming some Kurdish ancestry, he spoke out far more openly for limited rights for Turkey's large and restive Kurdish minority than did Mr. Demirel or most other mainstream politicians.
He also seemed to delight in abandoning Ankara's cautious diplomacy to champion the cause of Turkey's Muslim allies in regional disputes from the Caucasus to the Balkans.
 
'Turkey Must Show Its Teeth'
 "Turkey must show its teeth to Armenia," he said two weeks ago in discussing the conflict between Armenia and Azerbaijan. "What harm would it do if a few bombs were dropped on the Armenian side by Turkish troops holding maneuvers on the border?"
His five-nation Central Asian tour itself seemed a display of his refusal to play only ceremonial roles.
According to a medical report issued in Ankara yesterday, Mr. Ozal suffered blood pressure fluctuations overnight, and doctors implanted a pacemaker in the early hours of the day. By the time he arrived at Hacettepe University Hospital in Ankara in the early afternoon, however, he had no pulse and his breathing had stopped. Efforts to revive him failed.
Mr. Ozal is survived by his wife, Semra; two sons, Ahmet and Efe, and a daughter, Zeynep.
Under Turkish law, the Speaker of Parliament, Husamettin Cindoruk, will be acting President until Parliament elects a successor within 30 days. The new president needs the support of two-thirds of the 450 legislators.

HEADLINE: Revival of Tax Credit Is Sought to Spur Low-Income Housing

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Perhaps Thurgood Marshall or Cab Calloway slept in what is now Anita Winston's apartment back when the Whitelaw Hotel was the place to stay for black notables visiting segregated Washington. But after the 1950's, the hotel decayed into an abandoned, drug-infested hulk.
A lot of forces had to come together to revive the historic hotel into a home for 35 low-income families. Among them was an unusual alliance of big corporations looking at their tax bills and a network of housing groups hoping to rebuild inner cities. 
 But most of all, the transformation of the Whitelaw rests on a tax provision that has become the primary resource for such housing nationwide and that is a major element of the Clinton Administration's policy on housing: the low-income housing tax credit.
 
Tax Credit Has 2 Advantages
 The credit was responsible for 94 percent of the low-income housing constructed from 1986, when it was enacted as part of the Tax Reform Act, and last year, when its temporary authorization expired. By calling for the provision to be made permanent as part of his economic package, Mr. Clinton has picked up on an idea endorsed by housing advocates well before he came to the White House.
Though some advocates assert that changes are needed in the provision to insure that it benefits those who are most in need, the majority of them agree that its permanent extension is essential. And housing experts in and out of Government agree that the credit has two important advantages over more traditional housing programs: it puts development into private hands, which is considered more efficient, and tax credits are often easier to support politically than direct Government spending.
In a recent speech, Housing Secretary Henry G. Cisneros said permanent extension of the tax credit would "stimulate the construction and rehabilitation of 120,000 low-income homes annually, support 67,000 jobs and generate $1.7 billion in wages every year."
Although the tax credit has enjoyed widespread support in Congress and the White House, under Presidents Ronald Reagan and George Bush, Congress balked at writing its foregone revenues into the budget permanently. The credit, which would cost the Government $5 billion over a five years, is one of several tax incentives in a Democratic urban aid and tax bill.
Even as a temporary measure, the tax credit is responsible for the creation of more than 600,000 housing units in the last six years and one-third of all new housing starts, said Paul S. Grogan, president of the New York-based Local Initiatives Support Corporation, whose subsidiary, the National Equity Fund, organizes tax-credit financing. Housing has been built through the credit in all 50 states, with the cities of Los Angeles, New York and Philadelphia among the biggest beneficiaries.
 
Community and Private Groups
 Under the law, the Federal Government issues tax credits to state housing agencies, with the most populous states receiving the most credits. Developers can apply to the state for credits that are then sold to investors, usually corporations that enjoy credits against their Federal corporate income tax.
The provision has resulted in partnerships between community-based organizations and private investors. And several groups have grown up as intermediaries, raising money for corporations that are then packaged as financing for specific projects proposed by the grass-roots groups. The National Equity Fund and the Enterprise Social Investment Corporation, a subsidiary of the low-income housing group Enterprise Foundation, are the two largest national funds set up to manage this money.
In 1992, Local Initiatives and Enterprise together raised $403 million from more than 100 corporate investors. Of that amount, $83 million is earmarked for projects in New York and held in the New York Equity Fund, a joint venture of the two groups.
Community developers point to the Whitelaw, which reopened in late 1992, as an example of the tax credits' success. The building, which suffered a near-fatal blow in 1981 when a fire gutted its interior, was bought in 1991 by a local not-for-profit housing developer, Manna Inc.. The $4 million renovation included more than $1.6 million in capital provided by Local Initiatives.
The tax law requires that all of the units in the Whitelaw be rented to people who make 60 percent or less of Washington's median income. Nine of the units must be occupied by people who make 50 percent of the median or less. A family of four, like that of Sidney Johnson, a printer at the State Department and his wife, Olivia, who live in a three-bedroom apartment with their two daughters, must have an income of $18,000 to $36,000 a year.
The units are considered affordable by many people because tenants pay no more than 30 percent of their income. The Whitelaw must maintain these income requirements for at least 15 years, at which time renters will be given the option to buy their units.
"I've got a baby 12 months old so I could be one of the ones that stays around," said Anita Winston, 40, who lives in a three-bedroom apartment with four of her children. Standing in the building's refurbished lobby after a recent tenants' meeting, Ms. Winston said her new apartment was a "step up" from her old place in a run-down building.

HEADLINE: POLITICAL NOTES;
Peek at Whitman Wealth Puts a Foe on the Attack

BYLINE: By JERRY GRAY

 BODY:
Christine Todd Whitman, a candidate for the New Jersey Republican Party's gubernatorial nomination, gave a cursory peek at her personal finances last week, and it was enough to make her political opponents gasp.
Mrs. Whitman's campaign reported that she and her husband, John, had an estimated 1992 income of $3.7 million and had paid $1,028,568 in Federal taxes and $255,000 in state income taxes. They also paid real-estate taxes of $39,551. 
 Mrs. Whitman came under immediate attack from James H. Wallwork, a former State Senator who entered the Republican race after both Mrs. Whitman and another candidate, Cary Edwards, admitted that they had hired illegal aliens.
"In light of the Whitmans' extraordinary 1992 income of $3.7 million, her hiring of illegal aliens off the books and her failing to pay Social Security, withholding, unemployment, worker compensation and other taxes demonstrate arrogance and insensitivity to tax-paying New Jersey families," Mr. Wallwork said.
Earlier this year, Mr. Edwards and Mrs. Whitman paid the back taxes and other fees associated with the hirings.
The one-page statement released last week by the Whitman camp did not say how she and Mr. Whitman, a financial consultant who currently works for the Agency for International Development, made their money.
The Whitmans have asked for a four-month extension of the April 15 filing deadline, and Mrs. Whitman said her full tax returns would be made public after she officially files. That prompted complaints from Mr. Edwards and Mr. Wallwork that Mrs. Whitman was trying to wait until after the June 8 primary.
Gov. Jim Florio and his wife, Lucinda, paid $30,160 in Federal taxes and $8,237 in state taxes on an income of $171,106. The bulk of their income came from Mr. Florio's $85,000-a-year salary as Governor and his official expense account of $75,000.
Mr. Wallwork, a businessman, and his wife, Lark, had an income of $210,047 and paid $50,188 in Federal taxes and $10,431 in state taxes. They also paid $10,405 in property taxes.
Mr. Edwards, a lawyer, has said he will release his tax information this week.
 
The Matalin Factor in Albany
 Mary Matalin, the sharp-witted and acid-tongued deputy campaign manager for George Bush in 1992, has agreed to serve as a political strategist for Jon S. Fossel, a former Assemblyman who plans to run for Governor of New York in 1994.
The agreement between Ms. Matalin and Mr. Fossel is a loose one, with neither a signed contract nor an agreement on compensation. That has led to some confusion over just what Ms. Matalin's role will be.
Mr. Fossel, a Westchester resident who served in the Assembly from 1978 to 1982 and is chairman of Oppenheimer Mutual Funds, described Ms. Matalin alternately as his "C.E.O." and his campaign manager.
But Ms. Matalin said that for the time being she considers herself more an informal adviser and overseer than a day-to-day manager. But she said that she had no plans to work for other candidates and that her role in Mr. Fossel's campaign could become active next year.

HEADLINE: $20 Million Given to Harvard Medical School

BYLINE: By KATHLEEN TELTSCH

 BODY:
Warren Alpert, a poor boy who made a fortune in the petroleum and food-products business, has given $20 million to Harvard Medical School, the largest gift in its 200-year history.
The Alpert gift is for the school's research building, opened last year, which houses the laboratories of the departments of genetics, neurobiology and pathology and the Center for Blood Research. The building will be named for him. 
 "I want cures, cures for Alzheimer's disease, cancer, AIDS," said Mr. Alpert, 71, who added that he chose Harvard Medical School in Boston because he thought it the most likely to be successful in fighting the diseases.
Sentiment also played a role: He likes to recall that he grew up across the harbor in a working-class neighborhood in Chelsea, Mass., and lived at 90 Orange Street in a frame house that has since been razed.
 
Always in a Hurry
 Mr. Alpert's mother had Alzheimer's and her last years were spent in a nursing home. Her photograph hangs in a place of honor in his New York office, a picture of a dignified, and somewhat stern woman with a firm chin and a no-nonsense look about her. The family resemblance is marked.
At 13, Mr. Alpert became an entrepreneur, helping his father to peddle sheets and towels from a truck. He tried to induce his father to open a store and sell on credit. "Even then, I was in a hurry to succeed," he recalled.
He put himself through Boston University, earning money as a hat salesman and by tutoring students. After Army combat service in France in World War II, he went to the Harvard Business School with the help of the G.I. Bill of Rights. It was the first time he had set foot on the Harvard campus.
In 1950, he started his own business, a dry-goods store, with $1,000 in savings and $9,000 borrowed from his older brother, which was repaid promptly.
 
On the Forbes List
 Today, Warren Equities and the Warren Companies market petroleum and food products through 300 service stations and convenience stores, operate a wholesale petroleum business along the Atlantic Seaboard and employ 1,600 people in 11 states. The enterprises have a $600 million annual volume and are listed by Forbes as one of America's 400 largest privately held companies.
Unlike many big-business ventures, the company has no long-term debt and a single owner: Mr. Alpert. He never married, and there are no children to share the fortune.
Over the years, he has made gifts to the Harvard Business School, Boston University, Albert Einstein College of Medicine and the Sutton Place Synagogue in Manhattan, for which he helped to build a new home. Along the way, he also served in the Agency for International Development in the Kennedy Administration.
 
'Let Them Give Money'
 Mr. Alpert says he plans to urge other business leaders to endow the Harvard Medical School, pointing to buildings near the Warren Alpert Research Building known simply as A, B, C and D. Mr. Alpert deplores this anonymity as "a wasted opportunity."
"Let them give money," he said, "and have a building in their name."
He also intends to prod scientists at the research institute to pursue cures in much the same way he has pushed his own staff to promote business.
Dr. Bernard Fields, chairman of the school's department of microbiology, said medical progress was more likely to be incremental than dramatic. Still, he added: "Some people will be ruffled by his questions, but most will not. Whatever his style, most people will appreciate what he has done for this institution."
The largest gift to a college or university is believed to have been the $105 million donated in 1979 to Emory University in Atlanta by Robert W. Woodruff, former chairman of Coca-Cola. In 1992, the entrepreneur Henry M. Rowan and his wife, Betty, donated $100 million to Glassboro State College in New Jersey, which was renamed Rowan College. The gift is believed to have been the largest to a public college or university.

HEADLINE: Old M.I.A. Theory Is Given a New Life

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
A document recently unearthed in Moscow has breathed new life into one of this city's most enduring conspiracy theories: that the Reagan and Bush Administrations covered up attempts by Vietnam to trade American prisoners of war for cash.
The theory, which remains unproved, holds that Vietnam held back hundreds of P.O.W.s to make sure Washington paid war reparations, and then kept them as bargaining chips when no aid was forthcoming. 
 Proponents of this view see two new pieces of supporting evidence in the Sept. 15, 1972, document, whose authenticity is still in dispute. In it, a high-ranking Vietnamese military officer, identified as Gen. Tran Van Quang, wrote that Hanoi was holding 1,205 American prisoners, 837 more than it publicly acknowledged.
The officer explicitly linked the captives' release to economic aid and other concessions from the United States, saying, "Nixon must compensate North Vietnam for those enormous losses which the destructive war caused." Hanoi denies the authenticity of the document.
 
Only 591 Released
 Eleven days later, at the Paris peace talks, Le Duc Tho, the Vietnamese negotiator, told American negotiators that the issue of prisoners was tied to "the question of reparations," according to transcripts since made public.
When the war ended, Hanoi released only 591 prisoners. That was 400 to 600 fewer than American military officials had estimated were still alive. Eugene Tighe, a retired lieutenant general who once headed the Defense Intelligence Agency, said in an interview this week that he had helped draw up a list of 900 to 1,000 names of men presumed to be prisoners in 1973.
Relatively little was done to resolve this discrepancy in the Nixon, Ford and Carter Administrations. A Senate report released in January said that from 1975 to 1983, intelligence agencies had assigned a very low priority to collecting data on troops missing in action.
Congress repeatedly refused to authorize any money for rebuilding Vietnam and by the 1980's rumors were circulating in Washington and Asia that Vietnam was seeking discreetly to trade live P.O.W.'s for cash.
 
No Conclusive Proof Found
 Those reports were repeatedly denied by officials in both the Reagan and Bush Administrations, and a recent inquiry by a Senate select committee failed to find conclusive proof either of such offers or a conspiracy to conceal them.
But the suspicions of Government wrongdoing persist, fueled by a stream of first-hand accounts from refugees and others that Americans are imprisoned in Southeast Asia. Those who believe the Vietnamese are holding Americans point to Vietnam's record in its war with France.
An expert formerly involved in investigations of Americans missing in Vietnam said that when the French withdrew in 1954, the Government agreed to pay an annual fee to Vietnam to maintain graves and continue resolution of casualties.
In 1986, rather than pay a yearly charge, France agreed to an unspecified lump sum, which was said by some to be about $360 million worth of grants and credits to buy French goods. Whatever the sum, Vietnam suddenly released 25,000 French remains in six months in 1986.
After that, some Vietnamese working on that program were transferred to American searches.
"This is our country's greatest state secret," insisted J. Thomas Burch Jr., chairman of the National Vietnam Veterans Coalition. "They've known these men were there and they've covered it up."
Mr. Burch is a lawyer for the source of one of the most tantalizing stories, an account by a Secret Service agent of a 1981 conversation he says he overheard between President Reagan and his senior aides. According to the agent, the Government of Vietnam was offering to sell live P.O.W.s for $4.5 billion.
Senator Robert C. Smith, the New Hampshire Republican who was vice chairman of the Senate select committee, said in an interview that he learned of the agent's story in the mid-1980's. Mr. Smith, a member of the House of Representatives at the time, demanded a meeting with President Reagan and Vice President Bush and confronted them with the allegation in the Oval Office. Both denied it.
In 1992, when the Senate committee was investigating the matter further, the Secret Service agent refused to testify unless he was subpoenaed, saying he feared losing his job. The Treasury Department said Congressional testimony by a Secret Service agent would set a bad precedent, and a majority of the committee agreed.
When Richard Allen, Mr. Reagan's national security adviser at the time of the supposed offer, was questioned by the committee in 1992, he initially recalled an offer of $4 billion. Later, he said he had been mistaken, and that his recollection was of being asked about the issue years later. In an interview, Mr. Allen said that if the question had arisen during his tenure, he would have supported looking into it further.
Senator Smith said that Max Hugel, who was head of operations for the Central Intelligence Agency at the time, told him recently that the offer was well known to senior intelligence officials, and that the P.O.W.'s were to come out through Laos on Jan. 26, 1981. During his deposition to the committee, however, Mr. Hugel denied any knowledge of the issue or of having said anything about it to the Senator.
Senator Smith himself says he no longer believes the story told by the Secret Service agent. "If I sit in the Oval Office and ask a straightforward question -- and they tell me the answer is "No" -- and then we have a guy that won't come forward, where does that leave you?" he asked. "I'm siding with the President."
Proponents of the conspiracy theory suggest that the Reagan Administration was ignoring reports about the P.O.W.'s because it was afraid of being trapped into the sort of hostage crisis that crippled the Carter Presidency.
The Reagan Administration's actions cast doubt on that hypothesis. In early 1981, when it received intelligence reports on a possible prison camp in Laos, the Administration sent Laotian operatives into the jungle to search for confirmation. The search proved inconclusive; the team was permitted to look into the compound's buildings only from a distance.
Another opportunity arose in 1984, when a person with contacts in Southeast Asia, identified in the Senate report as I. Irving Davidson, was told by a general in Indonesia that the Vietnamese were willing to discuss with Washington the sale of both remains and live P.O.W.s. In this instance, a Government paper trail exists. Paul Wolfowitz, at the time a senior State Department official, wrote a memo to Secretary of State George P. Shultz that referred to the offer of "possible live P.O.W.s."
Richard Childress, the National Security Council's senior expert on Asia, traveled to Hanoi, met with a member of the Politburo and was told that the only thing the Vietnamese were ready to discuss was the return of remains.
The committee sent investigators to Indonesia to try to trace the report further, and even that led to conflicting testimony. The general said his original offer mentioned only remains; the general's brother, who was also involved, said the Vietnamese had included live P.O.W.s.
A final incident that has fueled speculation in Washington surrounds a February 1977 C.I.A. report. In it, Senator Smith said an Indonesian diplomat quoted the Vietnamese Vice Foreign Minister, Min Phan Hien, as saying that his country was holding P.O.W.s who would be released only if the United States provided aid.
A declassified version of the document, which does not identify the name of the Vietnamese official who is speaking, says that data on M.I.A.s were "a trump card" for Vietnam in coming talks with the United States.
William Hendon, a former Republican Congressman from North Carolina who is one of the most vocal advocates of the conspiracy theory, said he saw the complete version of the document while working for the Pentagon in 1983 as a consultant on P.O.W. issues. Although the document does not specifically identify a source, Mr. Hendon said he believed the Indonesian diplomat's account of the conversation had been picked up by a listening device secretly planted in Indonesia by the C.I.A.
A C.I.A. spokesman said Friday the agency now views the report as a "fabrication."
In 1986, a Pentagon panel headed by General Tighe reviewed the existing intelligence files and concluded that there was a "strong possibility" that Americans were still being held in Vietnam.
According to Mr. Hendon, William J. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence at the time, told several members of Congress in October 1986 that he had the same opinion, but could not take any action unless the Americans were seen by "two of my men." Mr. Hendon later prepared a sworn affidavit that quoted Mr. Casey as telling the group, "What do you want, another hostage crisis?" Mr. Casey died in 1987.
In its 585-page report, in January, the Senate Committee quoted sworn testimony from most of the major figures in American policy that a conspiracy of silence would have been impossible to carry out. Several noted that such an effort would require the support of thousands of people scattered through the military and intelligence agencies for a period of 20 years.
"The isolated bits of information out of which some have constructed whole labyrinths of intrigue and deception have not withostood the tests of objective investigation," the report said. "The vast archives of secret U.S. documents that some felt contained incriminating evidence have been thoroughly examined by the committee only to find that the conspiracy cupboard is bare."

HEADLINE: Sanitation Cutbacks Hit Poorer Districts Hardest

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD J. LEVY

 BODY:
The sharp cuts in New York City's sanitation budget during the fiscal crises of 1990-91 have hit poor, minority residents far harder than wealthier ones, scarring once-orderly blocks in neighborhoods like Harlem, Bedford-Stuyvesant and the South Bronx.
With garbage collection, sweeping and enforcement steadily scaled back, the number of the city's 59 sanitation districts rated dirty by the Mayor's Office has jumped from 1 to 12 since 1987. The dirty districts are all economically depressed areas with mostly black and Hispanic populations. 
 In West Harlem, the percentage of streets rated acceptably clean by the city dropped from 58.8 in 1987 to 39.4 this year. In the South Bronx, the percentage decreased from 59.8 to 38. The rating in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, declined from 55.3 to 46.4.
A district is considered dirty if fewer than 50 percent of its streets are rated acceptably clean during monthly surveys by inspectors who assign grades based on visual examinations.
 
Poor Areas More Vulnerable
 The drops in poor neighborhoods have occurred even as the city overall has weathered the sanitation cuts fairly well. The citywide average for all 59 sanitation districts has remained steady in recent years; about 70 to 75 percent of the city's streets are rated acceptably clean.
Sanitation Department officials maintain that they have spread service reductions evenly around the city. But they acknowledge that poor neighborhoods have suffered more because overcrowding, shoddy apartment maintenance and a surfeit of vacant lots and abandoned buildings make them more vulnerable to sanitation problems.
"There are a lot of conditions in these districts that are tough to correct," said John J. Doherty, the deputy sanitation commissioner for operations.
But community leaders in these areas scoff at those explanations, contending that the city has long devoted proportionally fewer resources to the sanitation needs of poor residents. The budget cuts, they say, have merely dealt another blow to fragile neighborhoods already reeling from decades of indifference.
 
'There Has Never Been a Will'
 "There has never been a will to keep Harlem clean," said Stephen Roberson, an organizer at Harlem Initiatives Together, a citizens' lobbying group. "You're asking me to differentiate between a time when they didn't want to keep this area clean and now, when they don't want to keep it clean even more."
The Sanitation Department received some of the most severe cuts of any city agency in 1990-91. Its budget in fiscal year 1988 was $563.8 million; the projected budget for fiscal year 1994 is $598.6 million, which actually represents a decline of about 16 percent from 1988 when inflation is factored in. The latter figure also includes money for the city's recycling program, which was not in place in the 1980's.
Perhaps the harshest service reduction was the elimination of the Clean Teams -- crews that roamed the city on foot with trash cans and brooms, picking up refuse from streets and sidewalks. In 1987, there were 1,400 such workers. Now, there are none.
"Many of our cleaners were in these poorer districts, so we were able to keep these districts out of the filthy category," Mr. Doherty said. "But when the Clean Teams left, that had a big impact."
That is readily apparent during a morning stroll around West Harlem with Peggy Shepard, co-founder of a citizens' group called West Harlem Environmental Action. At the corner of Broadway and West 152d Street, Ms. Shepard gingerly circled a gutter clogged with so many fast-food wrappings, newspapers, beer bottles and chicken bones that it looked like a roadside waste pit.
"Think about the children in this area," she said. "When they walk through a trash-strewn neighborhood every day, sooner or later they are going to wonder, 'Why is there so much trash? Maybe I'm trash, too.' "
And then, turning away as if she could no longer bear the sight of so much decay, she added defiantly: "You wouldn't see this on Columbus Avenue downtown."
 
Private Crews
 Community leaders like Ms. Shepard maintain that the service reductions are not only ravaging their streets and sidewalks, but are also giving rise to a kind of sanitation segregation.
In some prosperous neighborhoods, business improvement districts -- private groups financed by surtaxes on businesses -- are hiring their own sanitation workers to cushion the blow from the cuts. In midtown Manhattan, for example, these crews have reclaimed streets that were once considered among the city's filthiest.
But poor areas have become dirtier because residents cannot afford to turn to the private sector to keep their streets clean. They also have less political influence, so they have trouble lobbying for and obtaining scarce city services, the community leaders say.
"This is basically the message now from the city: Those who have the money and power can expect certain services," said Luis Garden Acosta, executive director of El Puente, a community development group in Williamsburg, a heavily Hispanic section of Brooklyn.
 
Widening Gap
 The city's studies point to the widening gap between rich and poor neighborhoods. The stability in citywide cleanliness levels in recent years seems to suggest that as neighborhoods like Harlem or the South Bronx have become dirtier because of service cuts, others have become cleaner.
That contrasts starkly with the ratings after the last municipal cuts in 1975, when the city almost went bankrupt. By 1980, only 53 percent of the city's streets were acceptably clean and 38 of the 59 districts were rated dirty, indicating that the effects were felt more evenly.
Mr. Doherty of the Sanitation Department emphasized that despite the cuts, the department has taken steps in recent years that have helped prevent the citywide cleanliness rating from dropping. It has stepped up cleaning of vacant lots, which are often used as illegal dumps, and removed more abandoned vehicles from streets.
The department is also coordinating its efforts with the business improvement districts, whose cleaning crews are having a striking effect on sanitation around Times Square, Grand Central Terminal and 34th Street in Manhattan and the Metro-Tech complex in Brooklyn.
 
7,500 Pounds a Day
 Around Times Square, one of the most heavily trafficked areas of the city, the percentage of streets rated acceptably clean has jumped from 28.9 in 1991 to 74.4 now, the city says. That increase largely reflects the work of the 45 or so street sweepers hired by the Times Square Business Improvement District, who pick up about 7,500 pounds of trash a day.
Executives of the business improvement districts are sensitive to charges that they are Balkanizing New York City by fostering an every-neighborhood-for-itself attitude, and they emphasize that their areas are vital to the city's economy.
"If Times Square is economically healthy, that benefits far more people than the 250,000 who work in Times Square," said Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District. "That benefits the entire city. There's got to be a ripple effect."
 
'It's a Little Unbearable'
 In any case, many poor neighborhoods, without the private resources of business to step into the breach, have seen their streets continue to deteriorate.
There is an abandoned brownstone at 535 West 152d Street in Harlem whose courtyard has been turned into a makeshift dump. On many mornings, Olu Rowland, 30, a nurse, passes that building when she brings her daughter, Mandisa Bryant, 4, to the Modern School, a private school a few doors down.
"I've always seen trash there," Ms. Rowland said the other morning. "It's a little unbearable. You explain to your child that there are bad people, that this is what they do. But I'm moving out. I can't take making the explanations to her anymore."

HEADLINE: With Oilfields as Battleground, Colombia Adopts New Tactics in Rebel War

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: YOPAL, Colombia

 BODY:
With guerrillas waging war on Colombia's vital oil industry, the authorities are fighting back with a new strategy that relies on economic tools like setting bounty for rebels and freezing assets of extortion targets.
Much the way American businesses use cost-benefit analysis to evaluate pollution, Colombian officials now weigh counterinsurgency plans in terms of economic loss and gain. Here in the eastern foothills of the Andes, the benefit of protecting the oil industry is obvious: a newly discovered underground sea of two billion barrels of light crude. 
 "This is Latin America's only low sulfur crude -- it is going to be very attractive to U.S. Gulf coast refineries," said Nicholas P. Connolly, general commercial manager for the exploration arm of British Petroleum PLC. BP is a production partner in a consortium that includes Triton Energy Corp. of Dallas, Total S.A. of France, and Ecopetrol, Colombia's state oil company.
With oil having displaced coffee in 1991 as Colombia's largest export product, the oil sector attracted $328 million, half of the total, in foreign investment last year. Oil flowing from these rich fields 100 miles east of Bogota is expected to allow Colombia to supplant Ecuador as South America's second-largest oil exporter, after Venezuela.
 
The Cost of Bombings
 The costs of bombings by Colombia's three guerrilla armies are equally clear. In 86 dynamite attacks on Colombia's two oil-exporting pipelines in 1992, the guerrillas cost Ecopetrol $100 million in lost sales. Pipeline repairs and cleanup of 230,000 spilled barrels cost the company an additional $4 million. In December, pipeline attacks were so severe that Colombia suspended exports and had to import oil for the first time since 1985.
In this cost-benefit equation, a $30,000 reward paid last month for the capture of a National Liberation Army explosives expert nicknamed "Molotov" was a bargain.
"It is proving to make economic sense," Defense Minister Rafael Pardo said of the new bounty program, which offers up to $1.4 million for the capture of top guerrilla leaders.
Bounties for guerrilla leaders, freezing the assets of kidnapping victims' families, sanctions against banks caught handling guerrilla accounts, and cancellation of state oil and mining contracts with foreign companies caught paying protection money to guerrillas are all part of an arsenal of economic weapons adopted over the last six months to thwart rebel attacks.
 
Auditors Battle Guerrillas
 In another move, teams of Government auditors are now inspecting state and municipal finances to insure that governors and mayors do not pay protection money to local front groups for guerrillas.
The tough measures were adopted mainly in response to an attack on an oil field in southern Colombia that left 26 policemen dead last November. "We are going to attack with decision and firmness the sources of subversion's financing," Colombia's President, Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, said at the time.
With the collapse of Cuba's economy and the disintegration of the Soviet Union, Colombia's guerrillas now raise virtually all their money locally. Last year, Semana, Colombia's largest-selling weekly news magazine, calculated that the nation's 8,000 guerrillas earned $200 million a year through extortion, kidnapping, and ties to cocaine and heroin traffickers.
The nominally Marxist groups have gained such notoriety as extortionists that 56 percent of the respondents to a recent poll by Semana judged that the guerrillas were motivated by personal enrichment rather than politics.
For the first time in more than a decade, a majority of respondents -- 53 percent -- said they supported a military solution to the guerrilla threat. Only 38 percent said that peace could be obtained through negotiations with the three groups: the National Liberation Army, the Popular Liberation Army and the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. [Peace talks between the Government and a faction that claims to represent one-third of the National Liberation Army's 2,000 guerrillas began in April.]
 
Leftists Turn Against Rebels
 "Your war lost its historic validity some time ago," read an open letter to the guerrillas signed last November by 47 leading left-wing intellectuals, including Gabriel Garcia Marquez. "The corruption that you reject has contaminated your own ranks through your business with drug traffickers."
Capitalizing on the public's supportive mood, the Government has levied a series of taxes on companies and local government revenue in recent months. Oil companies now pay 78 cents for every barrel produced. Since January, oil-producing states have been placing 20 percent of their oil revenue into a national defense fund.
The Governor of Casanare state, Oscar Leonides Wilches Carreno, complained in February during a visit here by President Gaviria that the new levy "means that we have to suspend the execution of social investment projects that are fundamental for guaranteeing the very same peace." But with billions of dollars in future oil revenue at stake, Government officials argue that a cost-benefit analysis justifies an increase of 15 percent, or $190 million, this year in its military budget.
The budget increase includes money for nine new counterinsurgency battalions, 44 military intelligence units, and the stationing of 18,000 police and soldiers around oil installations. Colombia's state agency for land reform received money to expropriate thousands of acres of ranchland around oil fields to create security zones patrolled by the military.
"Attacks on pipelines have already dropped," said Juan Maria Rendon Gutierrez, president of Ecopetrol, which has 86 contracts with foreign oil exploration companies.
 
Stepped Up Army Patrols
 Army patrols and expanded use of military intelligence have also held off an expected guerrilla infiltration of this area, Colombia's richest oil-producing region. "We always have a helicopter fueled and ready and soldiers standing by," said Col. Jaime Uscategui, chief of staff of the 16th Brigade, a new army unit stationed here in December.
In the only two fatal incidents over the last four months, a car packed with dynamite exploded prematurely in December, killing seven people here, including the guerrilla squad. In January, two guerrillas were blown up as they prepared to dynamite a pipeline.
Oil companies and their subcontractors appear to be heeding the Government's orders not to pay extortion money, which are reinforced at monthly meetings between business officials and army commanders.
"It seems that the foreign companies are not paying to be 'vaccinated,' " said Col. Miguel Angel Meza Lara of the police, using local slang for guerrilla protection demands. In one exception, an American seismic company apparently paid a ransom to win the release last December of a kidnapped employee.
To win support from residents of oil-producing areas, a consortium of state and private interests called the Oil Pipeline Foundation has lined up the financing for social projects in 112 towns and villages along Colombia's pipelines.
 
'Wanted' Posters on TV
 For most Colombians, the most visible aspect of the Government's economic war on the guerrillas are televised "Wanted" posters that flash nightly before news programs. By paying for information, a practice still considered a novelty here, the Government has captured the second in command of the People's Liberation Army, the fourth-ranking leader of the National Liberation Army, and several commanders of the Revolutionary Armed Forces since December.
The National Liberation Army began a revenge bombing campaign against urban targets last December, including luxury hotels in Bogota and traffic control towers in provincial airports.
Accustomed to maintaining economic growth during 30 years of guerrilla warfare, many Colombians believe that attacks on oil installations can be limited to such a manageable level that security will come to be viewed simply as another cost of production.
"Repairing the pipeline now takes about 36 hours," said Mr. Rendon of Ecopetrol. "It's become routine."
