HEADLINE: Many in Litchfield Want to Keep the Little Jail on the Common

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LITCHFIELD, Conn., April 17

 BODY:
Benjamin Rodriguez shakes his head in frustration when he thinks about the Governor's proposal to close the jail he has called home for six months.
It's not just that the window across from his cell looks out on one of the prettiest town greens in New England, or even that he is allowed to have a day job outside the jail. Mr. Rodriguez, who began his four-year sentence on a drug-related crime at the state prison in Enfield and has 14 months remaining to serve, says the Litchfield jail simply gives him hope. 
 "To come from a place like Enfield to a place like this is like turning off an endless highway onto a side street and finding someplace where you belong," he said. "There are a lot of guys who would do so well in a place like this. The place should stay open for them."
Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s 1994 budget calls for closing six small Corrections Department sites by next year. If adopted, the jail here, the state's oldest and smallest, would be among the first to shut down. The others are in Brooklyn, New Haven, Windsor Locks and Hartford, where two would be closed. The Legislature is to vote on the proposal in June.
The decision to close the correctional sites was based on economics, said a Corrections Department spokesman, Bill Flowers. The six are to be replaced by three new ones, which are ready to open, he said. Just one of the new centers can absorb the inmates and operations now spread among the six to be closed.
While mothballing the smaller, antiquated centers makes economic sense, opponents of the Litchfield closing -- including many residents who volunteer at the jail -- say they hope it is blocked.
That's a far cry from the mood less than a year ago when most people would have been glad to see it close forever.
 
Clearly Antiquated
 Until last year, the jail, which enjoys a quirky notoriety for sharing a wall with the Farmer's Savings Bank, was almost as primitive as it was when it was built in 1812. Cots hung from chains. The old gallows yard had filled with debris over the years, but it still looked much as it had when public hangings were commonplace.
Until the mid-1980's, inmates used to squeeze through a broken screen in a third-floor window, jump to the ground and run across the street to the liquor store. Hiding the stash in their shirts, they would rescale the jail's brick wall, using the warden's office window frame as a foothold. The inmates' booze-buying days came to an end, however, when a prisoner's foot slipped one day and smashed the warden's window.
Then, last summer, two inmates, one charged with the murder of his grandfather, escaped and went on a crime spree for more than a week before being recaptured. Angry residents called for an immediate shutdown of the jail.
The Corrections Department, however, had another idea. Within a matter of weeks, the jail went from a maximum security site with 150 inmates to a minimum security drug- and alcohol-treatment center with room for only 28 "clients." An airier cellblock with plumbing was opened. Qualified prisoners could work in the community and be granted weekend furloughs. Today, the jail houses 22 inmates whose crimes were primarily drug and alcohol related, though nonviolent. To qualify, they must be within two years of finishing their sentences, and they must attend a substance-abuse program at least three times a day, seven days a week.
 
A New Approach
 Robie Irizarry, a former parole officer who is now the counselor-supervisor in Litchfield, is credited by inmates and many in the community with turning the jail into a place where hope and self-confidence can be restored.
Mr. Irizarry ordered the open-cell policy and the removal of heavy iron doors between rooms. He set up an informal lounge with soft-drink and candy machines and a phone.
"One of our goals is to give back to the community as much as we can," Mr. Irizarry said. Inmates volunteer their services to the town, including to the Litchfield Performing Arts Center. They recently spent a day cleaning the banks of the Naugatuck River, and soon will be helping to build a community playground.
Supporters of the jail say it offers inmates a chance at rehabilitation they would never find in a larger prison. In the long run, they maintain, successful rehabilitation will reduce the number of repeat offenders. Mr. Irizarry says the recidivism rate is hard to measure because the program is so young, but already, three former inmates are working in the community.
Those who favor the closing, however, argue that the Corrections Department does not have the expertise to operate a drug- and alcohol-treatment program. Even many of the local volunteers who want to see the jail stay open say they would prefer it to be run by a group specializing in substance-abuse treatment.
For now, the correctional center is operating as if it will go on for another 181 years. And if it is closed, "We're thinking of turning it into a halfway house-restaurant," said Mr. Flowers. "The warden already has a name: Litchfield Bars and Grills."

GRAPHIC: Photo: If Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr.'s plan to close six Corrections Department sites is adopted, the jail in Litchfield, Conn., would be among the first to be shut down. Benjamin Rodriguez, who is serving a four-year sentence on a drug-related crime, says that the Litchfield jail simply gives him hope. (Steve Miller for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hospitals Plan Strategies To Counter Competition

BYLINE: By LISA BELKIN

 BODY:
New York City's hospitals are scrambling to prepare for a new era of competition -- not even defined yet, but almost surely on its way.
New York Hospital has taken control of nearly a dozen other hospitals, clinics and nursing homes, so it will eventually have beds available in every borough. About a dozen other major hospitals are spending $5 million to create their own health maintenance organization. 
 The municipal Health and Hospitals Corporation has begun sending employees to two-day training sessions where they are taught to be nice to patients, for fear that public hospitals will not be able to compete once everyone has health insurance.
The level of activity being created by the Clinton Administration's efforts to overhaul health care is particularly acute in New York, administrators and experts say, because the history and structure of the New York health care system mean the city and state are ill-prepared for the looming changes.
 
Worries About Change
 "I've never seen the hospital community more anxious, worried or frustrated," said Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents the city's private hospitals and nursing homes. "The thinking is extremely hyperactive all over town. They're all trying to figure out how to best position themselves for an enormous amount of change in a short period of time."
In the past, New York State in general, and the New York City area in particular, have been extremely resistant to the concept known as managed care, under which patients receive all their health care from groups like health maintenance organizations.
According to the most recent figures from the Group Health Association of America, a trade association for H.M.O.'s, 11 percent of people in the New York City metropolitan were enrolled in the plans in 1989, compared with 46 percent in San Francisco, 32 percent in Los Angeles, 28 percent in Boston and 16 percent in Chicago.
Much of the reason, Mr. Raske said, is that state regulation of hospital rates in New York is among the strictest in the country, meaning that there is little room for H.M.O.'s to negotiate lower rates with hospitals. At the same time, hospital occupancy rates in New York are higher than anyplace else in the country, meaning there is little incentive for hospitals to give lower rates.
 
Alliances Across Geography
 Competition and negotiation, however, are expected to be the mainstays of the Clinton plan. If the advance word from Washington is correct, large collectives in need of care will search out large providers of care and settle on the cost. Should that change come to pass, health experts and hospital administrators say, New York is not ready.
"If it were to happen tomorrow, it would overwhelm us," said Dr. Spencer Foreman, president of Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. "If you're in California or Minnesota, or areas where managed care has been developed extensively, then this is simply the next step in a progression that has been going on for the past five years. But for New York the transformation will be more dramatic."
Hospitals are taking different approaches in positioning themselves for the transformation. Perhaps the most ambitious plan, and the one that has been the longest in the making, is that of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan.
Four years ago, anticipating a changing marketplace, the hospital's trustees decided to form the New York Hospital Care Network, under which New York Hospital will effectively take over smaller institutions.
Eventually, administrators hope, the large consumer collectives expected under the Clinton plan will find such regional diversity appealing. "If you work in the city and live in the other boroughs we can be there for you," said Dr. David B. Skinner, president of New York Hospital.
 
The Search for Economies
 So far, the network includes: the Amsterdam Nursing Home, Gracie Square Hospital, New York Downtown Hospital, the Stanley Isaacs Healthcare Center for Senior Citizens and the Rogosin Institute, all in Manhattan; Community Hospital and the Methodist Hospital, in Brooklyn; and Booth Memorial Medical Center, Booth Silvercrest Extended Care Facility, The Healthcare Center of Western Queens and the Rogosin Institute Dialysis Center, all in Queens.
New York Hospital paid to acquire only one of these institutions, Booth Memorial, said Dr. Skinner, who declined to give the purchase amount. In every other case, he said, New York Hospital gained control by contracting the right to select the institution's board.
"The boards of the several institutions have done their own strategic planning," Dr. Skinner said. "They looked to the future and they saw they could not survive on their own. They need to be part of a network."
Dr. Tracey E. Strevey, president of Booth Memorial, the most recent addition to the network, said the only way that his hospital could weather the Clinton plan was to ally itself with a larger organization that could help it reduce costs. "Hospitals that are not prepared to maximize their economies of scale and cannot be competitive will not survive," he said. "There's only one place all these billions in spending cuts can come from, and that's from reduced revenues to those providing services."
The network, he said, plans to use a single billing and bookkeeping system and a central laundry center and warehouse.
 
Hospitals Form H.M.O.'s
 Mount Sinai Medical Center is attempting to form a similar network. Last year Mount Sinai affiliated with the Queens Hospital Center and, several months later, with the Jewish Home and Hospital for the Aged in Manhattan. Earlier this year, Phelps Memorial Hospital in Westchester County was added to the list.
"We want to position ourselves," said John W. Rowe, president of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and Mount Sinai Hospital.
Not every hospital can expand with the force of New York Hospital or Mount Sinai, and many say they do not want to.
"Our strategy has not been to acquire additional facilities simply for the sake of growth," said Dr. Robert E. Newman, president of Beth Israel Medical Center, which consists of hospitals in two locations, a private practice building in Manhattan and a nursing home in Westchester. "Our strategy has been to focus on quality in the facilities we already have."
Beth Israel is one of about a dozen hospitals that have spent the past year creating a H.M.O., called HealthFirst, under the auspices of the Greater New York Hospital Association. The $5 million start-up costs are being paid by the hospitals, Mr. Raske said, although the list of participants is growing and is not yet official.
 
Patients to Get Choice
 The program could be in operation by June, Mr. Raske said. It is intended to provide care to Medicaid patients under the state's new plan to improve health care for the poor, and its founders hope to enroll 180,000 Medicaid patients within its first year. When in need of hospitalization, those patients would be sent to the hospitals that created the plan.
The Health and Hospitals Corporation, which runs the city's 11 municipal hospitals, is also forming an H.M.O. Currently a pilot project at Metropolitan Hospital in Manhattan, the Metropolitan Health Plan will be expanded to include all the municipal hospitals, said Dr. Billy E. Jones, the corporation's president.
The Clinton plan would lift some of the burden from public hospitals by providing insurance for people whose care is currently underwritten by the hospitals. But with insurance, patients will feel freer to go to any hospital they choose. Public hospitals, where the level of care and the physical plants are often not competitive with private hospitals, could be at a disadvantage.
Last month the municipal corporation attempted to address that problem, with the first of a series of intensive staff training seminars. Eventually everyone who works in the public hospitals -- from doctors to custodians -- will attend.
"In public facilities there is the notion that you can treat people any kind of way," Dr. Jones said. Under the Clinton plan, he predicts, "that won't be the case."
"Everybody can vote with their feet as to where they want to go," he said. "We have to get ready for that. I think everyone has to get ready for that. We have a lot of getting ready to do."

HEADLINE: SERVICE JOBS FALL AS BUSINESS GAINS

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH

 BODY:
Scores of New York City employers -- from New York Telephone and Arthur Andersen to Merrill Lynch and Grey Advertising -- are making quantum leaps in learning how to produce ever more work with ever fewer people, according to economic data and a large amount of anecdotal evidence.
Ultimately, this remarkable innovation could help rejuvenate New York's ailing economy, by increasing its competitiveness in the intensifying battle for global markets. 
 But in terms of producing jobs today for New Yorkers, it is a disaster. Indeed, the city's jobs performance at this point in the national recovery is the worst of any comparable period since records began to be kept in 1950.
 
Recession Over, but Not Plunge
 From March 1991, when the national recession officially ended, through last February, the number of jobs nationally grew by eight tenths of one percent -- hardly a stellar performance. But jobs in New York City plunged by 145,900, or 4.3 percent, according to the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Since April 1989, New York has lost more than 350,000 jobs, nearly 1 in 10.
The steady growth in the output per worker -- productivity gains, in economists' terms -- helps explain why government and private economists expect virtually no job growth in the city this year even though its economy has been expanding since last June.
"You're probably talking the end of the decade before we put all the jobs back lost during the recession," said James P. Brown, an analyst at the New York State Labor Department.
What is happening here reflects something happening throughout the country. Companies that provide services -- from banks and insurers to accounting and law firms to phone companies, airlines, retailers and hotels -- are finally following the lead of manufacturers in making great strides in getting work done with fewer employees, mainly because of advances in technology.
These gains, however important, are inflicting anxiety, pain and, in many cases, a plunging standard of living on hundreds of thousands of people, from clerks to middle managers and professionals. They are out of work or bounce from one temporary or part-time job to another in a professional limbo that pays no benefits like health insurance and pensions.
Consider Elizabeth E. Brager, a talented professional who seems to be making a go of freelance work.
At the moment, Ms. Brager, 40, has her hands full with assignments from three major investment firms. A specialist in creating promotional materials for selling financial services products, she has been freelancing for 14 months, since losing her job as a vice president at Citibank when it eliminated her department.
At this moment, she is receiving two to three times her Citibank salary, she said, radiating confidence and pride as she talked about how her clients really depend on her expertise. But only a month ago, she was in an emotional valley -- between jobs and anxiously waiting for some response to her dozens of calls and letters in search of work.
"It's a juggling act -- working and lining up future jobs at the same time," she said. "It's an emotional roller coaster. But right now, I love the ride."
 
Better Paying, but Fewer
 Skilled professionals like Ms. Brager may be the lucky ones.
The city's economy appears to be creating fewer, though better-paying, full-time jobs. From 1987 through 1991, clerical jobs in the city plummeted by 80,000 or 12 percent. That is an ominous development for a city with more than one million people receiving public assistance.
"What we may be moving towards here is a tale of two cities: growth in higher-paying jobs and a shrinking in lower-paying jobs," said City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman. A failure to create lower-skilled jobs "will create turmoil -- more social dislocation, more crime, more poverty," she warned.
At Grey Advertising, the "reconfiguring" of the work force, as Edward H. Meyer, the company's chairman put it, is a case in point.
While the advertising industry has slumped, Grey Advertising has prospered. But Grey's New York employment has remained flat for two years at nearly 2,000, and lower-level jobs are vanishing.
 
Computerized Advertising
 In Grey's media-buying operation, for example, the number of clerical workers, trainees and junior professionals have fallen to 154 from 178 since 1989. By contrast, Grey's cadre of senior professionals and executives has doubled to 115.
The main reason is computerization. A dearth of software had long prevented ad agencies from exploiting the plunging cost of computing power. But that problem is now being overcome since the advent of personal-computer networks and the proliferation of easy-to-use software that can be customized.
Stagnant throughout the 1980's, productivity in private, or nongovernment, services in the United States grew 2.75 percent in the last year, estimates Stephen S. Roach, an economist at Morgan Stanley & Company.
"That's a significant turnaround," he said. "And the productivity story is here to stay."
That matters a lot for New York, where services account for 9 of 10 jobs, versus 8 of 10 nationally. "Regions like New York, which clearly do have a disproportionate share of their activity tied up in the services sector, will be increasingly hard pressed on the job front in the years ahead," Mr. Roach said.
 
New York Industries Hit
 The productivity revolution is in full swing in industries that fueled the 1980's boom in New York City: financial, business and professional services like banking, insurance, accounting, advertising, consulting and law.
From March 1991 through last February, jobs in financial, business and professional support services shrank by 49,200. Moreover, virtually everyone expects employment in these areas to grow much more slowly relative to their profits and sales over the next decade than it has historically.
"It's difficult to envision a scenario of job growth for New York City without a strong job recovery in these key sectors," said Samuel M. Ehrenhalt, regional commissioner at the Bureau of Labor Statistics. "It's like trying to do Hamlet without the prince."
In many cases, services companies are simply doing much better at tapping the labor-saving potential of computers -- ever cheaper and easier to use -- high-speed telecommunications lines, and voice-mail systems that render secretaries obsolete.
 
People Less Necessary
 Doing the tax returns for a client who worked in, say, five states, accountants at Arthur Andersen & Company used to enter the information into the computer six times: once for each state and once for the Federal return. Thanks to software perfected two years ago, the numbers are now entered once. The computer then produces all six returns and the supporting documents required.
At the New York Telephone Company, "expert" computer systems are increasingly making people unnecessary. Executives at its parent company, the Nynex Corporation, say some programs can spot problems on phone lines, diagnose the causes and then dispatch repair crews.
In the mid-80's, when a corporate customer had a problem with a circuit that carried large amounts of data between its computers, seven New York Telephone employees were required to take the call, test the circuit, make a diagnosis and send out a repair order.
Now some customers can contact New York Telephone's electronic doctors themselves. Sometimes even that is unnecessary because of a new system that continuously monitors special circuits.
 
No More Form Fillers
 "People who know how to look up things in a book and fill out forms are not going to be the people we are going to hire," said Edmond J. Thomas, vice president of Nynex's science and technology division.
But computers are not the only reason for the rise in productivity in services. Many companies are finally getting serious about identifying and getting rid of superfluous jobs.
Traditionally, companies laid off people in tough times and rehired them once business improved. A new approach dubbed "process re-engineering" aims to avoid such surges. It examines whether each function -- purchasing or customer billing or public relations -- is necessary or "adding value" and whether it is being done most effectively.
Gone are all the lower-level people in customer accounts at Grey Advertising, the people who generated reams of reports, detailing product sales and ad expenditures by clients and their competitors. It turned out clients did not want this work.
 
Time and Motion Studies
 Andersen conducted time and motion studies of hundreds of audits. "We were able to wring out anywhere between 10 and 25 percent of the hours in a typical audit," said Louis P. Salvatore, head of audit, tax and business-advisory services in the firm's metropolitan New York operation.
Nynex was able to cut by more than half the 100-plus steps once involved in designing and installing high-capacity circuits that corporate customers use to transmit computer data or to connect their phone systems directly to long-distance carriers. It can now provide the service within a day versus the 30-day average before.
Companies are also asking whether a task can be done by hiring another company or freelancers in the huge talent pool produced by the recession and the re-engineering binge. Because freelancers are not employees of the company, it is usually not responsible for paying fringe benefits and can let them go at will.
 
Adapt or Move On
 "It is not as necessary to add people to the payroll as business improves because of all the freelance art directors, copywriters and the like out there," said Mr. Meyer, Grey's chairman. "When a freelancer we highly regard says, 'I have a job offer from Young & Rubicam,' that's the day I have to sit down and say, 'Wait a minute.' "
With this attitude the rule, freelancers like Sarah Anne Peckham, a producer of television commercials, know they must adapt or move on.
"I love television production," said Ms. Peckham, who is 54. "Now I'm going to find out if I'm temperamentally suited to the freelance life style." She has had two jobs and worked a total of five weeks since January, when she was dismissed by Young & Rubicam, where she had been a senior producer for 12 years. She is now working freelance at Chapman Direct Advertising, a Young & Rubicam subsidiary.

HEADLINE: What Small Business Really Wants

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The small-business men and women I know would give up all the "little apple seeds" of tax incentives the Administration is promising in exchange for the elimination of two of the rotten apples in his plan -- the tax increase on individuals and the energy tax. ("Clinton Plan -- Small Businesses Smile," March 28.) 
 President Clinton's quest to raise taxes on the so-called "wealthy" actually falls flat on the backs of small businesses and family farms. He is asking small businesses that are organized as Subchapter S corporations, sole-proprietorships and partnerships to pay higher marginal tax rates than I.B.M. or General Motors. Small businesses also are the least likely to be able to absorb the additional costs of the energy tax.
And yet, the President still is expecting small businesses to continue creating the majority of the new jobs in our country!
 
SENATOR LARRY PRESSLER
Washington, April 1
 
The author, a Republican of South Dakota, is ranking member of the Senate's Small Business Committee

HEADLINE: Moving Ahead on Head Start

 BODY:
President Clinton wants to increase funding for Head Start by $1.3 billion, a whopping 46 percent increase. It's a big vote of confidence for a program that's weathered a lot of criticism recently. But, Mr. Clinton has made the right decision. Continued careful expansion of Head Start, addressing its problems along the way, is desirable.
Probably the best known and most successful of the Great Society efforts, Head Start is a comprehensive early childhood development program that aims to give low-income children educational and social skills needed to succeed in school. Beyond that, the program gives its 3- to 5-year-old participants health and nutrition services and offers a range of social services to their families. It also places heavy emphasis on parent involvement. 
 How well does it work? Several studies indicate that the immediate intellectual gains made by Head Start children fade after a few years and that the program fails to permanently raise scores on intelligence tests. But the program never claimed to have these everlasting effects.
Other studies have shown that by the end of the program Head Start participants are further along in terms of mental, social and emotional development and self-esteem than non-participants. And the provision of social services strengthens the family's ability to help the child.
There is evidence outside Head Start that an enriched preschool experience can have lasting effects. In the most famous study, children in the Perry Preschool Project in Ypsilanti, Mich., are still,two decades later, more likely to have finished high school, held a job, and avoided teen-age pregnancy and trouble with the law than children from similar backgrounds who did not participate.
The key issue is the quality of the program. Dr. Edward Zigler, one of Head Start's original planners, estimates that 50 percent of the Head Start programs are "excellent," 25 percent are "marginal" and 25 percent are "poor." Internal reports from the Department of Health and Human Services, which has responsibility for Head Start, found that many of the programs were not properly managed and others failed to provide needed health services, like immunizations. The reports also suggested that expanding the program to serve 100 percent of eligible children, instead of 35 percent, could be thwarted by a lack of qualified teachers and adequate buildings.
Some of Head Start's problems stem from efforts by the Reagan Administration to spread resources too thinly; enrollments increased, but staff training and oversight suffered severe cutbacks.
Now the Clinton Administration aims to do better. The economic stimulus package includes $500 million for a summer extension of Head Start. An additional $874 million is being requested for the program next year. And Mr. Clinton wants to come as close as possible to enrolling all eligible 3- to 5-year-olds in the next five years. Beyond adding dollars, the Clinton Administration has promised to address some of the concerns about quality, although specific proposals are still being developed.
Clearly, Head Start is not a panacea for the years a disadvantaged child spends in poor health and housing, with little or no intellectual stimulation and only the prospect of advancing to poor public schools. But, with careful monitoring and adequate safeguards, it can give poor children a boost to success in school and community.

HEADLINE: Public & Private;
What You See

BYLINE: By ANNA QUINDLEN

 BODY:
I remember visiting an apartment in Brooklyn several years ago that had almost no furniture except for two televisions. There were two of them because one was broken but was used as a stand for the working one. The TV provided background music to fractious family life and copacetic child care, little eyes glassy in the reflected glare.
But it also brought the world into a place where most people were afraid to go out after nightfall. Or at least the slice of the world that television shows, which had about as much to do with the life of this family as an Amy Fisher mini-series has to do with "Masterpiece Theater." The image of the two televisions stayed with me, a symbol of how powerful TV is in the lives of so many families just like that one. 
 "They show all the happy white people on TV," Tara Dalley said the other day, hanging with her friends outside Washington Irving High School, and when I considered her words I thought about that power all over again. "Black people are shown as bad people, the reason for a bad situation."
As we digest the verdicts in the second Rodney King case, as we talk about the negative effects of seeing images of police preparing for rioting as though it were as inevitable as rainfall, as we see once again the videotape in which Rodney King is beaten by the white police officers, it's worth talking to a few of the kids about what television shows them.
Not about what it has shown them about the treatment of one black man. But about what they think it has been telling them for years about where they fit into the world, a message that has surely laid the groundwork for anger.
They grow up, so many of our children, with TV the single most potent force of myth and image in their lives. And if they are struggling and black they see, almost close enough to touch, a world of well-dressed white people with perfect homes and families. For some of them, the only things that seem true to life are the shoot-'em-ups on cop shows.
They don't know how much better it is than it used to be, how short a time ago there were virtually no people of color on the tube at all. But even when they see black people in television programs, the situations often have an air of unreality. "On 'Cosby,' " said a 16-year-old named Jasmine Roscoe, "excuse me, but where they finding families like that, where the father is a doctor and the mother is a lawyer?"
It's interesting that the show random groups of kids mentioned positively most often was "Roseanne," the sitcom about a family living close to the economic bone, tussling and cussing, led by a strong, smart-mouthed woman. It's a class thing, not just a black thing.
Their complaints about television news range from being ignored to being reviled. A white person is shot, they say, and it leads the newscast; a black person is shot and it is ignored. "Maybe they don't think it's important," said Jasmine. "Another dead black body, just pick em up. It's usual."
"Black people are shut out," said Tara, as the girls around her nodded.
Yesterday, if they were watching our regularly scheduled verdict, they saw people who looked like them all over the television news, black citizens triumphant, feeling they'd seen some measure of justice when two of four police officers were found guilty of violating Rodney King's civil rights.
But that's not what they see most of the time. For most of their young lives this box in their living rooms, the thing around which so often all the other furniture is arranged, has told them, they say, either that they are insignificant or that they are bad. I know television doesn't seem to reflect any of our lives, but it has a whole lot more to do with a comfortable white existence than a struggling black one.
Seeds of anger in the black community are sown in many ways, from the contempt of law enforcement to the grinding poverty of many neighborhoods to a case like that of Rodney King. But maybe for some of our kids the anger grows just hanging around the house, watching a soap opera. "Everybody rich, everybody always wearing fancy clothes," said Yesenia Evans outside the high school. The world comes into your home every day, and it's a world that much of the time seems to exclude or revile you. Life's a party, almost close enough to touch, and you're not invited.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Pretending About Bosnia

BYLINE: By LESLIE H. GELB

 BODY:
After some legitimate dallying and weighing of options, the Clinton Administration has adopted the European approach to Bosnia: Let nature take its course toward a Serb victory over the Muslims -- while pretending to do otherwise. Today, watching Srebrenica fall; tomorrow, Sarajevo.
This policy is very "realistic." It avoids all the political and military risks of getting trapped in a place hardly anyone cares about, especially when nations must tend to their own domestic woes. It is also devastatingly cynical. And for that reason alone, President Clinton should reconsider it. 
 Cynicism feeds on itself and spreads like a cancer. In time, little matters. Not Boris Yeltsin, not a tiny country like Haiti, not Kosovo, not injustice abroad, not injustice at home. Cynicism also corrodes democratic leadership, since it's hard to debate what's not acknowledged.
No Clinton Administration official openly admits to such a cynical policy, although some have come close in private. Perhaps they can't admit what they're really doing, even to themselves. But their policy has been quite clear for weeks.
In the current phase: Go along with Europe's funneling only minimal relief supplies to dying Muslims, pretend to be trying hard to reach a "peace" settlement, stay clear of direct military intervention and assume the Serbs will effectively win the war in the next three to six months.
After the Serbs triumph: Don't formally recognize or in any way legitimize the victory, maintain economic sanctions against Serbia and try to stop the Serbs from using force against Kosovo and Macedonia.
Since the outbreak of the war, the Serbs have allowed only the bare minimum of U.N.-provided food, fuel and medicine to reach Muslims; often less. Worse, last week U.N. relief workers howled that their warehouses were near empty, with little new Western aid in sight. Why let this happen, when it will only weaken the Muslims and lead them to surrender?
The U.S. and its European cohorts say they favor a Vance-Owen-type peace, dividing Bosnia into ethnic enclaves. But they've ruled out using force, or even the threat of force, to make the Serbs accept it. So the Serbs openly laugh at their timidity. Mr. Clinton's only comeback is to say he's "keeping all options open." The Serbs laugh at that, too. Why give the Serbs this kind of free ride, when they can only take it as a wink?
Western leaders now speak of tightening the economic embargo against Serbia as a way of getting Bosnian Serbs to accept the Vance-Owen plan. But why weren't these tougher measures imposed long ago? Was it simply because Moscow threatened to veto the effort? Are the Russians any likelier to go along now? And why such emphasis on economic sanctions when Western leaders know well that sanctions have never worked? Why, if not mainly for show?
Still, world leaders continue to protest their devotion to the Vance-Owen "plan" or "process" and their willingness to put it into action. Yet not one of them has firmly pledged a single peacekeeper to keep the peace.
NATO experts estimate upward of 100,000 peacekeepers, including 40,000 Americans, will be required to do the job. Where will they come from, and who will put up the $5 billion to $10 billion annually to keep them in the field? Why the total failure to commit this money and manpower? Why, indeed, unless Western leaders are simply playing a very cynical game?
In what passes for candor among Western officials, some will privately say that Bosnia is just too far gone, that they will make their stand against Serbia in Kosovo and Macedonia. But it's hard to imagine that Belgrade will move against Macedonia, or that Westerners will protect Kosovo since they all recognize it as a province of Serbia. In any event, why should the Serbs fear Western military power in these places when the West did nothing to stop genocide in Bosnia?
And now what was suspected is confirmed. Regular Serb forces are part of this war. Isn't this enough for the West to end its charade?
At some level, everyone understands these games. "Realist" pundits even praise Mr. Clinton for his pretense; anything to them seems better than the risks of military involvement. But the cynicism will eat away at the Clinton Presidency and at U.S. foreign policy. Bosnian Muslims will pay with their lives, and Americans with their faith.

HEADLINE: Republicans Hold Clinton Accountable;
Senate Childishness

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Our Government should not be run by filibuster. As a responsible Republican who cares more for country than for party, I deplore the power games being played by the Republicans in the Senate (news article, April 13). Their stall and obfuscation tactics lead to the conclusion that, like spoiled children, if they can't set the rules they won't play the game. 
 Bill Clinton won the election. He deserves the chance to put his jobs programs in place. For 12 years my party did nothing, and now we have more unemployed people than ever in recent history. The Republican Senators should start being responsible legislators.
 
ALLENE G. HATCH

HEADLINE: Republicans Hold Clinton Accountable

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Dances of the Cranes" (editorial, April 7), you castigate Senate Republicans for stymieing President Clinton's $16.3 billion economic stimulus plan. According to your analysis, the Republicans are thwarting the will of the voters by preventing the Democratic President and Democratic Congress from enacting the program they were elected to enact. Such reasoning is seriously flawed since 43 percent of the voters who supported candidate Clinton never endorsed a program that would tax the middle class and increase Government spending by $202 billion from 1993 to 1997. 
 During the Presidential campaign, candidate Clinton's economic plan promised a middle-class tax cut and an increase in the marginal tax rate to 36 percent for families earning more than $200,000 a year. During the last Presidential debate Mr. Clinton promised he would not raise taxes on the middle class to pay for his programs and that spending programs would be scaled back before such a tax increase would be contemplated.
President Bush charged that Mr. Clinton could finance his campaign promises only by raising taxes on every family earning more than $36,000. Candidate Clinton responded: "It is a disgrace to the American people that the President of the United States would make a claim that is so baseless, that is so without foundation, so shameless, in an attempt to get votes under false pretenses."
When President Clinton announced his economic plan, he shamelessly raised taxes on families earning more than $30,000, violating his campaign promises, as Mr. Bush charged.
Fortunately, the Senate Republicans are holding President Clinton accountable for his violated campaign promises by preventing enactment of a wasteful Government spending program that we simply cannot afford. Instead of excoriating Republicans for such actions, perhaps you would consider analyzing why President Clinton should be allowed to enact a spending program that he misrepresented to the voters.
William Jefferson Clinton might better heed the words of Thomas Jefferson: "A wise and frugal government . . . shall restrain men from injuring one another, shall leave them otherwise free to regulate their own pursuits . . . and shall not take from the mouth of labor the bread it has earned."
 
DAVID P. SIMONETTI
New York, April 9, 1993

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Fans Out to Condemn Jobs Bill

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MERRIMACK, N.H., April 17

 BODY:
Taking a page from the Clinton and Perot playbooks, Congressional Republicans held town meetings today in 13 states to condemn the President's budget plan, especially his package to stimulate the economy, as a collection of special favors for constituents.
In this heavily Republican New Hampshire town, 90 people gathered at the American Legion hall to hear their Representative, Bill Zeliff, and Senator Phil Gramm of Texas speak against the President's plans and vent their own frustrations about rising local unemployment, health-care costs and welfare. 
 And in New Jersey, about 40 people turned out to hear Representative Dick Zimmer, Republican of Middlesex County, N.J., attack the President's jobs bill as more deficit spending.
 
Appealing to Perot Backers
 The Clinton package, now reduced to $15.5 billion, is stalled by a Republican filibuster in the Senate, and Republicans hoped the publicity they would attract from today's events might help them challenge larger parts of the President's program as well. The Republicans said they also wanted the meetings to mark the beginning of their effort to win back middle-class voters who abandoned President George Bush to vote for Ross Perot last November.
"There's no question there are a lot of Perot people out there looking for a vehicle by which they can express their feelings," Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, said on Friday. "We want to get back to the grass roots."
President Clinton insists his stimulus proposals are popular because they include financing for summer jobs, AIDS research, highway construction and money to rehire police officers laid off by local governments. In an effort to rescue the package, which initially cost $19.5 billion, he offered on Friday to cut $4 billion from it, but that gesture has been rebuffed by Republican Senate leaders so far.
In the meeting here, Mr. Gramm pushed the Republican argument that Mr. Clinton's stimulus package was nothing more than a pork-barrel payoff to Democratic constituencies. Giving examples of what he said were the kinds of programs the President's plan would support, he said, "How do you stimulate the economy by building an ice-skating rink warming hut in Connecticut or an Alpine slide in Puerto Rico so the people in Puerto Rico can pretend they're in Switzerland?"
 
Quips and Punch Lines
 Mr. Gramm, who has an eye on the 1996 Presidential race, and Mr. Zeliff worked the audience in tandem like two performers exchanging quips and punch lines.
When Mr. Gramm said, "The problem is the money doesn't come from heaven, it comes from the pockets of working Americans," Mr. Zeliff slid next to the Texas Senator and displayed the plastic cover of his checkbook. "Are you telling me," Mr. Zeliff asked with a mock smile, "we can't write a check with an empty check book?"
For the most part, the two lawmakers were preaching to a choir of conservatives who have no fondness for more spending and borrowing. When Mr. Zeliff asked for a show of hands of those who favored the stimulus package, only six went up.
"When you talk about swimming pools and bike paths, I want to remind the people here that we built a beautiful playground," Shelly Uscinski, a 35-year-old housewife, told the lawmakers in a question-and-answer period. "If other communities want such things, they can go out and do that themselves."
Claira P. Monier, executive director of the New Hampshire Housing Finance Authority, spoke up to say that the Community Development Block Grant portion of the Clinton plan would be wasted by poor planning in bureaus like hers because the money needed to be spent before Dec. 31. "We have needs in New Hampshire, but we need time to develop good projects," she added.
 
Why the Meetings?
 Three weeks ago, House Republican leaders came up with the idea of the town meetings in opposition to the stimulus package, but only 24 out of the 175 Republicans in the House agreed to participate. "If we had more time, it could have been more broadly based," Mr. Michel said.
In addition to New Hampshire and New Jersey, town meetings were also held today in Arizona, Arkansas, California, Georgia, Illinois, Louisiana, Michigan, Missouri, Pennsylvania, Texas and Wyoming.
In East Brunswick, N.J., Representative Zimmer said he sponsored the town meeting today "to try to explain to the American public that there is another way to eliminate the deficit and that's the old-fashioned way that every family and business understands."
He added, "If your revenues aren't sufficient to meet your expenses, then cut your expenses."
In Joplin, Mo., Representative Mel Hancock criticized President Clinton's budget plan and bill to stimulate the economy, saying they would add to the budget deficit.
"The people in this room understand you can't spend yourself wealthy," Mr. Hancock said.
When the Missouri Republican asked for a show of hands to see how many in the audience of about 250 were willing to pay more taxes, only two people raised their hands.
One was Bennett Wilson of Carthage, Mo. He said that while he was not excited about paying more taxes, it was a necessary evil to begin reducing the Federal debt.
 
Where Was the Party?
 "I'd like to know where the Republican Party was the last 12 years when they had control of the dialogue in the country and they didn't deal with the budget deficit," said Mr. Wilson, a Democrat who voted for Mr. Clinton.
Mr. Gramm used the occasion here in New Hampshire to increase his visibility in the nation's first Presidential primary state. At the event in Merrimack, he arrived early and left late, then spent time giving interviews to local reporters, dutifully posing for pictures with children. He even wore a red, white and blue tie that Mrs. Zeliff gave him last October when he attended a fund-raising event she put on for him.
Peyton Hinkle, a 55-year-old commercial real estate appraiser and volunteer in Mr. Perot's organization, United We Stand America, got up to challenge Mr. Gramm's support for the free trade agreement with Mexico.
Mr. Gramm was careful to point out that he was working closely with Mr. Perot to enact a constitutional amendment to require a balanced Federal budget, but explained his disagreement with Mr. Perot on trade in no uncertain terms. "We can't hide under a rock," the Texas Republican said.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 20, 1993, Tuesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a Republican town meeting in New Hampshire misstated the purpose of a political fund-raising event last October. It raised money for Representative Bill Zeliff of New Hampshire, not Senator Phil Gramm of Texas.

HEADLINE: As Building Slows, So Does Demolition

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER

 BODY:
WHATEVER goes up must come down, the old saw goes. But the saw-maker wasn't thinking of buildings, and certainly not those that have gone up so recently that they have never even been occupied.
It has fallen to Big Apple Wrecking and Construction Corporation, a 14-year-old Bronx contractor, to take down the top 12 floors of the never-occupied but largely completed 32-story residential building at 108 East 96th Street, condemned as in violation of the height restrictions in New York City's zoning code. Big Apple believes it is making demolition history by taking down so large a piece of newly built space that is both structurally sound and economically viable. It is happening at a time when demolition for its more accustomed purpose -- site clearance in preparation for something new -- is at a low ebb. The lack of work underscores the low state of expectations for new private commercial or residential construction. 
 "What we're doing has never been done before," said a wind-blown Peter Kowalevich, the 67-year-old site foreman at the $1 million job, as he stood amid a scene of incipient wreckage on the building's roof last month. "I enjoy this because it's a challenge, but it's ridiculous."
It is not ridiculous, of course, to East Siders upset by what many consider a blatant and perhaps purposeful code violation. "If the law cannot be enforced when people are fairly active and have a following, what can happen in other parts of the city?" asked Genie Rice, president of Civitas, the Upper East Side community organization that brought the violation to the attention of city officials and opposed possible remedies less drastic that demolition.
But to the demolition people it's work, and they will take it. The Buildings Department, accustomed to monitoring construction of 65 to 75 major buildings simultaneously in the 80's, is now monitoring only one of more than 15 stories -- 1992 Broadway, Millennium Partners' 47-story mixed-use condominium at Broadway and Columbus Avenue between 67th and 68th Streets.
Filings for new-building construction permits last year covered only 13 million square feet of buildings. About a quarter of the space is in public-sector projects. The number of applications filed was 3,000, down from 3,900 in 1991; 4,500 in 1990, and 5,700 in 1989.
Most of the current major demolition work is at airports, hospitals and utility-company facilities. There is little work in progress for private builders. Even the public and institutional work is reduced from the level of the 80's, contractors say. But it is almost all that is left with the collapse of new residential and commercial construction.
In Harlem, Crossbay Contracting Corporation of Brooklyn is taking down the San Juan theater on Broadway at 165th Street and part of the Audubon Ballroom, in preparation for the construction of a Columbia University research building. At the same time, the facade on Broadway is being restored and preserved, as is the portion of the ballroom where Malcolm X was assassinated in 1965.
In Corona, Queens, the School Construction Authority reports, the old and vacated P.S. 92 will be demolished in May by the West Coast Construction Corporation of Queens to create a park in front of the new P.S. 92 behind it, at 34th Avenue and 99th Street.
A FEW miles away, Big Apple has laid low three contiguous buildings on the property of Jamaica Hospital, at Van Wyck Expressway and 89th Avenue, to make room for a five-story ambulatory surgery and mental-health facility. In Manhattan, it is demolishing the old Hospital for Joint Diseases at Madison Avenue and 123d Street, following the completion of the new North General Hospital last year.
Big Apple is also busy at La Guardia Airport. The customer is Morse Diesel International, construction manager for USAir. Drivers on Grand Central Parkway whose glance falls on a Continental sign on a hangar next to the USAir Terminal may be surprised to learn that there is no longer a structure behind the facade, which will also come down. Continental bowed out of a venture involving the hangar, and now USAir wants to provide more maneuvering space for planes as it adds boarding capacity to its adjacent terminal.
Stephen Chasin, co-owner of Big Apple, which has done 5,000 demolitions in the last 14 years, said he had never encountered a demolition of newly built usable space like the one the company is doing on 96th Street. "I don't think that anywhere in the world they would make an owner do something like this," he said.
Many demolitions are of small scale, often involving unusable or unsafe old buildings in locations where no new construction is planned. The bigger jobs are handled by perhaps half a dozen contractors in the city. In a good year the total business might generate $40 million in work, the contractors say. Now, they say, the total is perhaps a third to a half of that.
One of the larger jobs in prospect this year is a demolition planned by the Federal Bureau of Prisons for a 10-story, 1,000-cell detention center. It will occupy a portion of a three-acre site at Bush Terminal in Brooklyn, between Second and Third Avenues and 29th and 30th Streets. The construction would be the final stage of a project that will start with the renovation of 200,000 square feet of old warehouse space at the eastern end of the property.
The western portion is to be demolished by Blanford Land Clearing Corporation of Brooklyn using the implosion method. Dynamite demolitions are unusual in New York, but Federal and state demolitions are not subject to New York City rules.
"We haven't permitted explosives or swinging balls in at least 25 years," said Vahe Tiryakian, spokesman for the Buildings Department. Much demolition work is still handwork in New York City, with strong men wielding hammers, crowbars and chipping tools.
But the big jobs, about 5 percent of the total number of demolitions, use mechanical means, with the permission of the borough building superintendents. The machines of choice include the Brokk 250 from Sweden, whose mean-looking steel claw is operated by remote control from a cab on a wheeled platform. It drills and chips and hammers and pulls the debris to the deck, from which a laborer dumps it into a chute.
Also useful is a Melroe Bobcat 743, a small front-end loader that removes material once it has been smashed to bits by the Brokk 250. Sometimes a huge Caterpillar front-end loader sits on the ground and loads debris passed down a chute into bins on the ground, to be carted away by truck.
All this equipment is on view at the 96th Street demolition, where VJB Construction Corporation of Manhattan, construction manager for the Parkview Associates, the owner, is overseeing the demolition. The reinforced steel columns are to be burned away with acetylene torches, said Vincent J. Bagnoli Jr., president of VJB Construction.
FROM the 20th floor to the top the building has been wrapped for safety with steel screening, wired to outside scaffolding sitting on steel beams. "Nothing bigger than a pea can get out," said Richard Morano, VJB's construction supervisor.
The Buildings Department has an inspector, a member of the Building Enforcement Safety Team, on duty all day. The contractor has a professional engineer on hand to be sure the demolition won't affect the integrity of the structure below the demolition area.
The task began in February and is expected to take four or five months. Already the main roof is out and the walls betwen the 31st floor and the roof are mostly out.
In densely populated areas, demolition work never creates friends among people living in the vicinity. Besides safety, the problems are noise and dust. ("You can never control dust enough," said Mr. D'Agostino of Crossbay Contracting.)
The cost of demolition for new construction has been greatly increased in recent years when there has been a need to first remove asbestos from the building coming down. With no asbestos involved, a typical major demolition costs between 25 cents and $1 a cubic foot in a standard building. The old Jamaica Hospital buildings, for example, cost about 50 cents a cubic foot to demolish.
However, when there is a question of removing asbestros from the building, the cost can double. For example, at the site of the old North General Hospital there was over $1.5 million in asbestos removal to be done before the $2.5 million demolition could begin.
At the former Gimbels building on 86th Street and Lexington Avenue, gutted in the 80's for a new mixed-use condominium, the razing cost about $10 million, of which $5 million was for asbestos removal, a highly regulated procedure, said Mr. Chasin of Big Apple. The gutting of a Gimbels on 33d Street for another mixed-use building, including a new A & S store, cost more than $20 million, but asbestos removal was only $1.5 million. The difference was a result of the type of asbestos to be removed. On 86th Street, beams, columns and ceilings had been sprayed with asbestos. On 33d Street, only the pipes and boiler plant had been covered with asbestos.
The regulatory process is complex and the penalties for disobeying it potentially extremely severe. Officials have not forgotten the 1985 demolition of several buildings on West 44th Street done for the Macklowe Organization without a permit before utilities had been turned off. A lawsuit brought by the city was settled when Macklowe agreed to pay $2 million to assist single-room-occupancy housing.
Contractors need to supply original documentation that utilities have been cut off. They also have to pay the fines due on building violations on old properties, long ignored by earlier owners. That sometimes raises costs as much as $100,000, Mr. Chasin said. And they must get an asbestos-free certification from the Department of Environmental Protection.
"THE activity is slow now," Mr. Chasin said. "Until you see demolition pick up, you won't see construction pick up."
As for the 96th Street project, Laurence T. Ginsberg, principal in Parkview Associates and also in the Algin Management Company of Forest Hills, Queens, a family-owned investment owner-builder, described himself as "resigned" to these losses and eager to put the whole situation behind him. Mr. Ginsberg and his father, Albert, bought the land for the 96th Street project from Mount Sinai Hospital in the late 70's. Algin Management owns and manages about 35 properties in Manhattan and Queens, with about 3,500 apartments.
The demolition is the first stage of new construction on the site that zoning does permit. The shortened building plus new construction on what was to have been a plaza beside it will provide 112 apartments (more than the 97 of the original tower) in structures 19 stories high. The footprint for the new building will be in the plaza that was to have been created on the eastern side of the original tower. The architect remains Peter Claman, of Schuman Lichtenstein & Claman, whom Mr. Ginsberg says he considers blameless in the costly error in design.
"The experience has been enormously frustrating," Mr. Ginsberg said. "Now we want to put it behind us."

HEADLINE: Many Gay and Lesbian Groups Want Big March to Back Clinton

BYLINE: By JEFFREY SCHMALZ

 BODY:
Just a week away from a huge gay march on Washington, leaders of gay and lesbian organizations are rallying behind President Clinton, trying to prevent the demonstration from becoming a protest against him. But some other homosexuals and AIDS organizers, disappointed in the President, are threatening anti-Clinton outbursts at the march next Sunday.
"Clinton talks a good game," said Adam Mailor, a 24-year-old Seattle teacher. "But what's he doing? We need to put the heat on him." Mr. Mailor plans to carry a sign that asks: "Bill, Where's the Beef?" 
 Asked if the march should be a protest against the President, David B. Mixner, a longtime gay friend of Mr. Clinton, said: "We have spent all our lives hidden and quiet. If people feel concern and anger, they should express it."
 
'Experience of a Lifetime'
 On Friday, after an hourlong meeting with the President in the Oval Office, leaders of gay and lesbian organizations were starry-eyed. "It was the experience of a lifetime," said Billy Hileman, a co-chairman of the march.
Tim McFeeley, the executive director of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, summarized the meeting this way: "It's not just what the President said, but how he said it. It's a feeling you got by looking into his eyes."
Participants described the President as committing himself to signing an executive order to end the ban on homosexuals in the military, an issue that they said he was confident of winning. They said he urged the leaders to get out the stories of discrimination in the military against real people.
"On the military issue," Mr. McFeeley said, "he talked in terms of 'we' and 'our.' "
The leaders of the gay and lesbian organizations said Mr. Clinton embraced their struggle as a civil rights one. When it was suggested that some White House staff members seemed uncomfortable addressing homosexuality, the President countered by pointing to three gay and lesbian White House staff members who were present: Bob Hattoy, Keith Boykin and Alexis Herman. Mr. Hattoy spoke of how movingly symbolic it was that he, as a gay man with AIDS, was serving in the White House.
The issue of AIDS was raised by Mr. Clinton, not the gay organizations' leaders, who said it had not been on their agenda because it had been discussed at another White House meeting earlier in the day. That meeting was not attended by the President.
Mr. Clinton, those who met with him said, committed himself to naming a director of the Government's fight against AIDS in about a week and to preserving AIDS allocations in his package to stimulate the economy. He also renewed his support for legislation that would allow the spending of the full amount previously authorized for AIDS programs but never spent.
"He didn't waver at all in his commitment on our issues," William Waybourn, the executive director of the Victory Fund, which gives money to gay candidates, said of the meeting's overall tone.
But looking from outside the glow of the Oval Office, some homosexuals argued that the organizations' leaders had been used. With gay and lesbian Americans about to march on the capital in numbers they say could reach one million, their political leverage is considerable, the dissenters point out. Yet, they say, the leaders of the gay organizations came out of the meeting with no more than they had going in.
Mr. Clinton turned down their request that he appear in person at the march, saying that he had several commitments, including a Senate Democratic retreat in Jamestown, Va., on April 24, and a speech the next day to the newspaper publishers in Boston.
 
Meetings' Results Assailed
 "We fell for his pitch hook, line and sinker," said the playwright Larry Kramer, a critic of Federal efforts to combat AIDS, who was not at the meeting. "It's an indication of how desperate we are. The man has welshed on all his AIDS promises, every one, and the caliber of the names coming up for AIDS czar are all fourth-rate."
A leading advocate of homosexual rights who was not at the meeting, Urvashi Vaid, disagreed with the dissenters. "I understand the frustration of people like Larry who have been dealing with H.I.V. every day for 10 years," she said. "And Clinton has not shown extraordinary leadership on AIDS. But the meeting was historic, the first of its kind in the Oval Office, an important nod of recognition from the President of the United States at a crucial time in our movement."
Thomas B. Stoddard, coordinator of the campaign to allow homosexuals in the military, who was at the meeting, said, "I had a sense that we were being welcomed into the family that had scorned us for so long."
Leaders of the gay organizations said Mr. Clinton recalled a college friend's telling him that his Administration would be remembered for two things -- overhauling the health-care system and gay rights. They said Mr. Clinton smiled as he recalled telling the friend, "You're probably right."
The White House meeting came as gay and lesbian Americans throughout the country were preparing for the march. For months, march posters and notices have dotted gay enclaves from Manhattan to Seattle.
In New York City, bars and clubs and restaurants are organizing their own buses. Organizers are hoping for 300,000 from the metropolitan area.
Many are making a fancy day of it. For $37, Florent Morellet, who owns the Manhattan restaurant Florent, is offering round trip on a bus, breakfast and a lunch bag, as well as cocktails in the parking lot of the Pentagon. He has filled 10 buses.
The enthusiasm is not just on the East and West Coasts. In Omaha, for example, leaders of gay and lesbian groups say the 200 airline seats they booked are all taken. They estimate 100 more people have either booked seats separately or are making the trip by automobile.
"One hundred more is a conservative figure," said Amy Meek, a 26-year-old lesbian. "People are getting together in vans or however they can make it. The word is out: 'Get to Washington.' "
By comparison, in 1987, Omaha sent only 57 people to a similar march, which drew about a half-million people. The enthusiasm for this march is greater because of the battle to lift the ban on homosexuals in the military and their opponents' depiction of homosexuals as sexual predators.
In addition, throughout the country, there is a fervor among gay and lesbian Americans that their time has come, that they need to show Congress and the President their numbers.
Most of them laugh at a recent survey that found only 1 percent of men identifying themselves as homosexual.
"I like Clinton," said Alan Wolk, a San Francisco painter. "But I'm wary of him. I think we need to say, 'Hey, Bill, look at us. We won't let you forget us.' "

CORRECTION-DATE: April 18, 1993, Sunday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about plans for a gay march on Washington next Sunday described a White House meeting last Friday between President Clinton and leaders of gay and lesbian groups. The article said the President pointed "to three gay and lesbian White House staff members" at the meeting, and it gave three names.
The description of Mr. Clinton's action was not attributed in the article, and was based on a misunderstanding of a report by someone at the meeting. Two of the three named staff members had publicly discussed their sexuality. But the third, Alexis Herman, had not, and she said yesterday that she was not homosexual.
The Times erred in failing to ask Ms. Herman about the report, and in naming her in this list.

HEADLINE: Struggle in the Balkans;
U.N., With Abstention by Russia, Tightens Its Sanctions on Belgrade

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 17

 BODY:
After a day of tense negotiations, the United Nations Security Council brushed aside a new cease-fire agreement in the battered Bosnian Muslim town of Srebrenica and voted late tonight to impose Draconian new sanctions on the rump Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro.
 Russia had fought hard to delay the vote until after the April 25 referendum on President Boris N. Yeltsin and his economic reforms because his nationalist opponents sympathize with the Serbs. But after hours of brinkmanship, Russia finally accepted defeat and abstained instead of using its Security Council veto to block the new sanctions. China also abstained. 

 
Total Isolation'
 But all 13 other Security Council members voted in favor of the punishing new sanctions, which France's representative, Jean Bernard Merimee, described as "the total economic and financial isolation of Serbia."
 The tightening of the noose around Yugoslavia indicated that the anger of many of the world's nations was not lessened when Bosnian Serbian commanders agreed in Sarajevo to call a cease-fire in Srebrenica and permit limited United Nations evacuations. The cease-fire, in effect, was a victory for the Bosnian Serbs in their drive to occupy Muslim-held lands. [Page 16.]
 The final vote was a victory for France and five of the Council's developing nations -- Venezuela, Cape Verde, Morocco, Djibouti and Pakistan -- which insisted on bringing the new resolution to a vote. They were convinced that Russia was bluffing when it repeatedly threatened to veto the measure or warned that it would only encourage the Serbian forces to massacre the tens of thousands of Muslims in and around Srebrenica.
 But to win Russia's abstention, France and its five allies agreed that the new sanctions would not take effect for nine days, or just after the Russian referendum.
 
Patience Exhausted
 Diplomats said all Council members except Russia wanted to vote on the new sanctions now, despite today's cease-fire in Srebrenica, because they had lost patience with the Serbs and their relentless "ethnic cleansing," which has continued unabated despite numerous cease-fires and repeated claims that the Serbs really want peace.
 The Council thus ignored a new letter from the Bosnian Serbian leader, Radovan Karadzic, in which he promised to cooperate fully with the United Nations in carrying out the resolution that the Security Council passed on Friday night declaring Srebrenica a "safe area."
 It also ignored a suggestion by Under Secretary General Chinmaya Gharekan that a vote be postponed for 72 hours to see whether the new cease-fire in Srebrenica would hold.
 Instead Council members argued that the Serbs had lost all credibility by refusing to sign an overall peace agreement the Croats and Muslims accepted last month and by their continuing brutal campaign of "ethnic cleansing." Compared with this record, they argued, the Srebrenica cease-fire was irrelevant.
 
An Incomplete Accord
 Many also criticized several provisions of the agreement hammered out at the Sarajevo airport. Mr. Merimee, of France, pointed out that Serb forces are not required to pull back from around Srebrenica, as the Security Council ordered Friday, and can continue to occupy surrounding villages.
 Diplomats also complained that the Sarajevo agreement provided for the United Nations to "demilitarize" Srebrenica, which appears to mean that it will help disarm the town's Muslim defenders without disarming the aggressors who surround them. Only "seriously wounded" and "seriously ill" people are to be evacuated, in United Nations helicopters, suggesting that the Serbs will retain control over the less badly injured.
 The new sanctions are intended to isolate Yugoslavia in the hope that the suffering this will inflict on its people will force Belgrade to compel its Bosnian Serbian allies to make peace.
 The new measures are intended to end violations of current sanctions by banning even the transshipment of goods through Yugoslavia to other countries and tightening controls on barges moving along its stretch of the Danube. They ban all ships from entering Yugoslavia's territorial waters. And they require countries to impound any Yugoslav trucks, ships, aircraft or rolling stock within their jurisdiction.
 They also freeze all foreign Yugoslav financial assets, a move that is expected to put the overseas branches of Yugoslav banks and companies out of business, and penalize private foreign companies in which Yugoslavia's leaders are believed to have hidden assets.
 
Surprised by an Accord
 The debate on sanctions began earlier today in an atmosphere of farce and confusion as journalists in Bosnia began reporting on the new cease-fire agreement, which United Nations officials in New York said they knew nothing about.
 One embarrassed official said he admitted that his commander on the spot, Lieut. Gen. Lars-Eric Wahlgren of Sweden, had inexplicably failed to report the cease-fire to headquarters before his spokeswomen had briefed the press in Sarajevo.
 The agreement clearly met some of the demands the Security Council sought on Friday, including a cease-fire, helicopter evacuation of the sick and wounded, the opening of land corridors so relief supplies can enter the town, and the deployment of a Canadian peacekeeping force to monitor conditions in Srebrenica.
 
A Serb Is Adamant
 But Dr. Karadzic said his forces would continue to occupy the villages surrounding Srebrenica, even if they promised not to enter the town. And the plan to disarm Muslim troops in Srebrenica leaves the town's inhabitants at the mercy of the Serbs.
 Earlier in Paris, Foreign Minister Alain Juppe had demanded that the Security Council action cut Yugoslavia off from the rest of the world "at the earliest possible moment," adding that "the fall of Srebrenica can come from one moment to the next. It is truly a turning point in this drama."


GRAPHIC: Chart: "A Tighter Noose"
Photo: United Nations Security Council ambassadors voting for new sanctions on Serbia and Montenegro included Juan Antonio Yanez-Barnuevo of Spain, Sir David Hannay of the United Kingdom and Madeleine K. Albright of the United States. Yuri M. Vorontsov, left, of Russia, abstained. (Steve Berman for The New York Times) (pg. 16)
The United Nations Security Council voted last night to tighten sanctions against the Yugoslav republics of Serbia and Montenegro. These are the main points covered by the resolution:
 FINANCIAL ASSETS Freezes funds overseas held by the Yugoslav authorities, including funds derived from property, commerical, industrial or public utilities. ADRIATIC TRAFFIC Allows NATO to guard a 12-mile martime exclusion zone barring all ships from entering the territorial waters of Yugoslavia except in emergencies and with special permission of the Council's sanctions committee. CONVEYANCES Empowers countries to impound all Yugoslav vessels, trucks, rolling stock and aircraft found abroad, which can be forfeited if found violating sanctions. If ships, trains, trucks, aircraft from other countries are suspected of violating sanctions, they must be detained. If they are guilty, they must be impounded and can be forfeited.
 PEACE PLAN Calls on Bosnian Serbs to sign a peace plan devised by Cyrus R. Vance and Lord Owen, and for Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali to present detailed military plans on its implementation. OVERLAND TRAFFIC Prohibits goods shipped to or through Yugoslavia except for relief supplies, which have to be approved on a case-by-case basis by the Council's sanctions committee. Freight transport can pass only at a limited number of road and rail crossings approved by the Council. Supplies going to the United Nations and other relief agencies in Bosnia and Croatia need agreement from those countries. DANUBE TRAFFIC Bars Yugoslav traffic on the Danube outside of its own borders. Other vessels passing through Serbia must carry a monitor and get approval from the council. OTHER SERVICES Prohibits all services, financial and others to anyone in Yugoslavia except for telecommunications, postal and legal. Services necessary for humanitarian aid or "other exceptional purposes" have to be approved by the Council.
(Source: Reuters) (pg. 16)
