SECTION: Section 13WC; Page 16; Column 5; Westchester Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1603 words

HEADLINE: At the Coachman Hotel De Facto Permanence

BYLINE: By MERRI ROSENBERG

DATELINE: WHITE PLAINS

 BODY:
IT takes imagination to see a playground's swings and slides where there is nothing but a parking lot strewn with broken glass and garbage or to hear the sounds of hammers and saws in the familiar spring symphony of renovation, instead of the frustrated shouts of tired mothers trying to shepherd their children back to their rooms.
Under a plan first proposed last year by County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke, those are the sights and sounds that the homeless families living in the Coachman Hotel might have expected by now. 
 But when Mr. O'Rourke's proposal to lease the hotel from its owners, Universal Hotels, for $8.9 million, and bring in Westhab, a nonprofit housing agency that provides counseling and other services to homeless families, was put on hold by the New York State Division of the Budget, the families who remain in the Coachman, a temporary shelter that for many has become de facto permanent housing, ended up in a limbo of red tape.
When it had initially appeared that the Coachman was going to be renovated and that Westhab would be providing all the necessary services, the Urban League's Project Move, which had provided on-site case management and support services to the Coachman's residents, decided to pull out. With Project Move gone, the financial support that had come from International Business Machines and the United Way also disappeared. With the loss of those services, many social work experts said, an already difficult situation for the Coachman's families became worse.
Since August, Westhab, although it has not been able to provide the full services outlined in Mr. O'Rourke's proposal, has been offering educational support services. Moreover, a spokesman for the County Department of Social Services said that there is a caseworker at the Coachman daily.
 
'An Unmanaged Situation'
 "It is common knowledge that most people would rather not be at the Coachman," said a social worker who agreed to be interviewed only on condition of anonymity. "It has been a bad situation for a long time. Unless it is going to be turned over to a real facility with a real delivery of services, it is just a joke."
Added Eloise Kates Julius, a family therapist from White Plains who volunteers at the Coachman's Learning Center, an after-school tutoring program: "You have unmanaged people in an unmanaged situation, and it is a rough environment. The sorrowful part is that initially the Coachman was considered one of the safer havens for the homeless, and now it has become a travesty. There had been a hopefulness that people would receive case-management support and get the skills to cope with the world. We have seen it get worse."
White Plains residents who were frustrated by local and state government inaction on the Coachman recently formed an ad hoc coalition called Citizens Concerned About the Coachman, which held a protest rally in front of the hotel on March 18. The coalition -- which has representatives from the Westchester Coalition of Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens, Grace Episcopal Church and the Jewish Community Center, all in White Plains, as well as some local business owners -- wants to close the hotel or compel government agencies to renovate it.
"When everyone was feeling optimistic about the Coachman, everyone pulled out," said Stanley Schear, director of a nonprofit agency, the Bridge Fund, which offers temporary loans to people so they won't be evicted. "The county is paying $115 a day for each family to the Coachman's owners to house people there. That's a rent roll of $4 million a year, but we are wasting lives and money."
 
Problems in the Area
 Edward Majonis, owner of Esy's Cafe and a former social worker, added, "Without social services or a supportive system for the people who live there, you are just breeding problems for society."
Merchants in the retail area surrounding the Coachman have reported seeing youngsters 5 and 7 years old on the streets at 11 P.M., and in front of their stores they have found used crack vials, which they said come from hotel residents. Several have complained about break-ins or shoplifting by teen-agers from the Coachman. Still others are concerned about the 319 police calls involving the Coachman last year and 422 fire department calls.
"Our fire inspectors are in there every day," said White Plains Mayor Alfred Del Vecchio. "That building is not wired for hot plates, and yet the young mothers need to heat up baby food. God forbid we have a fire in there."
Julian Di Donato, owner of Dakota Dry Goods and president of the White Plains Merchants' Association, said: "A lot of stores are moving away from that area. There are lots of vacancies down there, and the stores that come in are lower-caliber stores. It has definitely hurt Upper Post Road."
In response, Charles Goldberger, a lawyer for Universal Hotels, said: "There are certainly some problems there, but there's not a lot the hotel can do without running afoul of the residents' civil rights. We cooperate with the police and we cooperate with the county. They're the ones charged with the conduct of those in the hotel."
 
'An Ominous Quality'
 A major concern for those who volunteer at the Coachman, either as tutors in the Learning Center or as meal providers, is the decline in the building's physical condition as well as the pervasive harassment that affects them and the residents. "It gets enough cleaning to not be in violation," said Dorothy Fox, a volunteer tutor at the Learning Center and former director of the program. "But there is an ominous quality when you come in. This is not a happy atmosphere. A 5-year-old child came in one day and said, 'This is a dump." Walls are drab and have holes in them. Carpets are frayed, and the lighting is harsh.
"A lot of families were moved out during the last week," Ms. Fox added, "and we are at a point of deciding whether to recruit more volunteers."
As of last Tuesday there were 52 homeless families at the Coachman. At times, however, there can be as many as 120 families. A spokesman at the County Executive's office said that some families had recently been placed in permanent housing while others had left for full-service shelters.
Harley Lewis, director of the Westchester Coalition of Food Pantries and Soup Kitchens, observed: "After the march, there was hell to be paid for the residents. They were in absolute fear of being dispossessed. The children were scared and asked the volunteers where they would go if they couldn't live there anymore. And the volunteers were told they couldn't park in the parking lot anymore." Residents refused to be interviewed for fear of repercussions.
 
Effects on the Children
 Margarita Rivera, director of the Daily Bread program, which provides breakfast at the Coachman on weekdays and an early dinner on three weekdays, is worried about the effects of the deteriorating environment on the children. "The children are exposed to drugs, drinking and fighting," Ms. Rivera said. "They see people selling drugs to their mothers just outside the building. I've seen young kids walking around with knives, and that really scared me."
While the Coachman remains in transition, possibilities are bleak for the youngsters who live there. "It's a situation where obviously the children are caught in the middle," said Daniel Owens, program associate with the Plan for Social Excellence in Mount Kisco, a private foundation that finances and reports on innovative educational programs and recently published a report called "Slipping Through the Cracks," which looked at the educational needs of homeless children in the county.
"There is no safety net for these kids," Mr. Owens added. "One person could not serve the needs of hundreds of people or know how many students are falling through the cracks."
Without sufficient services, said Evan Jeske, director of community relations and development at Grace Church Community Center, "there's a problem of unsupervised youngsters." Ms. Jeske added: "Before, people could go somewhere. When there was a service coordinator, there was a person in charge on the premises."
Derrick Byrd, coordinator of children's services at Westhab, who works at the Coachman, said: "I have a caseworker who delivers educational case management. We're responsible for making sure that the youngsters are tracked through a school district and that parents know about their options. Our priority is seeing that the youngsters get to school."
As part of their services, Westhab informs parents at the hotel about the services provided by the Learning Center as well as those offered by the Head Start program at St. Bernard's Roman Catholic Church. Mr. Byrd also works with a Girl Scout troop, the Hudson Valley Writing Center and Greenburgh's Open Door program, a drug-prevention and -treatment program, representatives of which come once a week to work with youngsters. Mr. Byrd conceded: "It's not anywhere near where we would like to see it. There is no after-school recreational program."
Many observers are still skeptical about progress at the Coachman. "I think the Coachman is an abomination," said Mayor Del Vecchio. "I don't believe we're doing these homeless people any favor by keeping them there -- warehousing them with a minimum of services."
The Mayor continued: "There have been some valiant efforts by volunteer groups, who do the best they can, but the solution won't be taken care of by volunteers. The solution needs government intervention and government money. I'm not convinced anything is going to happen."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 3562 words

HEADLINE: A Reader's Guide to the Balkans

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a contributing editor of The Atlantic, is the author of "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History."

 BODY:
HISTORY, like hate, is the product of memory, and memory is composed of unforgettable detail -- sights, smells, sounds, exalted emotions, grim statistics and cruel ironies. A memory is not subject to condensation. Made to fit inside the narrow strictures of a television sound bite or a newspaper column, it loses all meaning. It becomes just another lifeless fact that can never convey how people have come to think and behave as they do.
The Balkans are a region of pure memory: a Bosch-like tapestry of interlocking ethnic rivalries where medieval and modern history thread into each other. More complicated and less visually exotic than the Middle East, the Balkans are unsuited to the reductions of the television camera. (A recent ABC News special, "Land of the Demons," showed footage from Bosnia, but even with rock music playing in the background the effect was flat.) Whereas the Middle East is a game of checkers -- Arabs versus Israelis, with a modern history that began only in 1918 -- the Balkans are three-dimensional chess. 
 So in a sense the ascendancy of the Balkans as a news story in the 1990's means a victory for print over television. Yet it is not only the television correspondents who can't do much with the Balkans. Neither can the newspaper pundits, since the region is not an extension of America's own ethnic and racial obsessions, the way the Middle East and South Africa are. The Balkans are truly foreign. They require pure intellectual curiosity, nuance, not op-ed polemics. There is no getting around it. To understand the Balkans, you have to read books.
The key word for understanding the Balkans is process: the process of history and the process of memory, processes that Communism kept on hold for 45 years, thereby creating a kind of multiplier effect for violence. Balkan violence is not a phenomenon of "modern hate," like that in Algeria and the West Bank, fed by rising economic expectations and demographic stress. Southeastern Europe is a caldron of history -- of unresolved border disputes and nationality questions created by the collapse of the multinational Hapsburg and Ottoman empires.
By "process," I mean the fact that in the Balkans each individual sensation and memory affects the grand movement of clashing peoples. For today's events are nothing but the sum total of everything that has gone before. Process is something that is more emotional, physical even, than rational. It often has no direction: the asides and footnotes can be more meaningful than the main story line. You have to feel. You have to be able to imagine all the details of the past. That is why the best books about the Balkans are old and frequently eccentric -- granting access to a psychological universe that no television camera will ever penetrate.
Here is my own Balkan reading list, consisting mainly of books that, although written long ago, explain the essentials of today's violence:
Dame Rebecca West's "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon," first published in 1941, is the perfect literary metaphor for the Balkans. Dame Rebecca takes nearly 1,200 pages of small print to describe Yugoslavia. Her book is filled with the most subtle of tangents, which go on for thousands of words. By concentrating on the minutiae of memory, she illuminates how people who basically look the same, speak the same language and have virtually indistinguishable names can hate one another with primitive ferocity.
Because Dame Rebecca experienced Yugoslavia in the late 1930's, during the buildup to fascism in Croatia, she is more critical of the Croats than of the Serbs. This serves a useful purpose for the modern reader, however: it shows that the present civil war is merely the second half of one that began in the midst of World War II, only to be interrupted by 45 years of Communist rule. The Croats were responsible for much of the brutality in the first half; the Serbs are guilty now.
Dame Rebecca's clairvoyance is demonstrated by Slovenia's absence from her travelogue. As the current war shows, Slovenia has always been a sideshow to the Yugoslav drama, owing to its lack of ethnic Serb and Croat minorities and its position in the extreme northwest of the federation. Wisely, Dame Rebecca concentrated on Bosnia, and she pointed to Macedonia as the pre-eminent Balkan problem, since it is the region where territorial and linguistic disputes dissolve into an anarchy of formlessness.
Like all good books about the Balkans, "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon" is politically incorrect, because it recognizes national character as historical destiny. Culturally, the Balkans may be the world's most intractable area. People are born equal there, but what happens to them afterwards -- the lies they are fed, the truths they are fed, the way they drink and the way they worship -- makes them profoundly different from one another by adulthood. For example, Roman Catholic Slovenia has experienced decades of Communism, even as Eastern Orthodox Greece has been a member of the Western alliance. Yet Slovenia's economic future appears to be brighter than Greece's. This is geography, character and history speaking, not policy.
Because the national character in question today is mainly that of the Serbs, I recommend several books, each profoundly incorrect, that take you inside the minds of some of the world's best haters.
"The Mountain Wreath," by Petar Petrovich Njegos, first published in 1847, is the great epic poem of the Serbian language. Njegos, the Bishop of Montenegro, was an unreconstructed Serb nationalist who justified the 17th-century mass murder of Albanian converts to Islam as part of a larger struggle against the Muslim Turks. The reader can experience a hundred pages of fiery verse like this:
 
 Our struggle won't come to an end until
 we or the Turks are exterminated. . . .
 we . . . set their houses ablaze.
 Out of their mosque and of a small building
 we made a pile of accursed rubble there. . . .
"The War in Eastern Europe," by John Reed, with drawings by Boardman Robinson, is the author's 1916 account of his Balkan travels during World War I. Beneath a sketch of a Serb soldier at the book's beginning, a caption reads, "Half-savage giants dressed in the ancient panoply of that curious Slavic people whose main business is war." When Reed asked a Serb soldier if he was afraid of foreign intervention, the soldier replied: "Let them all come! Serbia can whip the world!"
Reed, best known today for "Ten Days That Shook the World," his account of the Bolshevik Revolution, reflected in "The War in Eastern Europe": "I thought with wonder of these Serbians, their origin and their destiny. They alone of all the Balkan peoples have been one unmixed race. . . . They held their narrow passes against the Tartars of Bulgaria, the Dacians of Rumania, the Huns and Tcheks of the North. . . . When Europe imposed foreign dynasties on Bulgaria, Romania and Greece, Serbia was ruled by her own house. With such a stock, with such a history, with the imperialistic impulse growing daily, hourly, in the hearts of her peasant soldiers, into what tremendous conflicts will Serbia's ambition lead her!"
ANOTHER book that conveys just how little this far-off corner of Europe has changed is C. L. Sulzberger's "Long Row of Candles: Memoirs and Diaries (1934-1954)." In 1939, Mr. Sulzberger, who was later to become a foreign affairs columnist for The New York Times, met a Slavic Macedonian who was forced to Bulgarize his name after the Bulgarians invaded his homeland, and then to Serbicize his name after the Serbs invaded. This caused the fellow to say: "No wonder the rest of the world calls stew a macedoine. . . . When will we smash our fetters and gather round our capital in Solun?" Solun is the city of Salonika -- in Greece. It is such irredentist attitudes over the decades that fuel the seemingly irrational attempt by Greece to prevent the recognition of Macedonia as an independent state.
The mother lode of Serbian culture and national aspirations is its Orthodox monasteries in "old Serbia," a region where the medieval Serbian kingdom was born and grew to greatness in the 13th and 14th centuries, but which is now inhabited by Albanian Moslems and is known as Kosovo. In "The Saga of Kosovo" (1984), Alex N. Dragnich and Slavko Todorovich chronicled the history of this region in delicious and convoluted depth. They did it from an ardently pro-Serbian standpoint, allowing the reader to see how even well-educated ethnic Serbs can sneer at Muslim Albanians and, by implication, the Muslims in Bosnia.
According to Mr. Dragnich and Mr. Todorovich, Serbia is a modern nation that has grown organically from a well-developed medieval civilization, while Albania is "culturally not ready" for nationhood, owing to its "total involvement in the passing Turkish civilization." Notice how both Njegos in the 1840's and Mr. Dragnich and Mr. Todorovich in the 1980's see Balkan Muslims as the historical appendage of the hated Ottoman sultanate that ruled in Serbia from the late 14th century through the 19th century.
For an Albanian view, turn to "The Albanians: Europe's Forgotten Survivors" (1977), by Anton Logoreci. While the Serbs see their defeat by the Turks in Kosovo in 1389 as the end of Christian enlightenment and the beginning of Muslim barbarism in the Balkans, Mr. Logoreci sees the medieval Serbian army as a feudal rabble that was defeated by "the more disciplined and better trained" Turkish troops. His theme is that the Albanians have always been victims of aggressive neighbors, especially the Greeks and the Serbs, forcing his people to turn to Hapsburg monarchs and Ottoman sultans for help.
In their age-old battles with the Albanians, the Muslims and the Croats, the Serbs have drawn psychological sustenance from Russia, their big, Slavic Orthodox neighbor to the north. In the first section of Milovan Djilas's "Conversations With Stalin" (1962), appropriately called "Raptures," the former Yugoslav Vice President under Tito described his first visit to Russia, in 1944, as being like "returning to a primeval homeland, unknown but mine." Mr. Djilas wondered: "Was this not the homeland of our ancestors, whom some unknown avalanche had deposited in the windswept Balkans?" As he writes about how the "limitless gray steppes" of Russia released "unknown inner urges," Mr. Djilas suggests the irrational but real impulses that have brought the Serbs and the Russians together through the centuries.
Blood ties and hatred can be tricky. On a recent television talk show, a Croatian American and a Bosnian Muslim both attacked me for failing to note that in Sarajevo, at least, Muslims, Croats, Serbs and Jews had usually got along. I recommend that they and others read "The Damned Yard: And Other Stories" by Ivo Andric. A Bosnian Croat, Andric won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1961, mainly for his novel "The Bridge on the Drina." In one of his stories, "A Letter From 1920," first published 73 years ago, Andric explained:
"Yes, Bosnia is a country of hatred. That is Bosnia. And by a strange contrast . . . there are a few countries with such firm belief . . . so much tenderness and loving passion . . . or with such a thirst for justice. But in secret depths underneath all this hide burning hatreds, entire hurricanes of tethered and compressed hatreds. . . . Thus you are condemned to live on deep layers of explosive, which are lit from time to time by the very sparks of your loves and your fiery and violent emotion."
Andric said that the people of the region denied this hatred, and consequently hated outsiders who mentioned it to them. The often invisible border between hate and love, and unity and disunity, is further explored in Andric's novel "The Days of the Consuls" (1945), about the small Bosnian town of Travnik in the early 19th century, and the political atmosphere found there by the French and Austrian consuls.
Sorting out all these passions in a clinically objective fashion is what Misha Glenny, a BBC correspondent, has done in "The Fall of Yugoslavia: The Third Balkan War" (1992). He describes how an awful history is now made worse by morally corrupt and incompetent regimes in Serbia and Croatia that are the legacy of Titoism. In addition to "Conversations With Stalin," Milovan Djilas has written a number of books exposing Tito, who imprisoned Mr. Djilas for the crime of advocating glasnost three decades before Mikhail S. Gorbachev did. Particularly readable is Mr. Djilas's "Rise and Fall" (1985), about the author's own tragic career in the Yugoslav Communist Party and how it mirrored the fall of Titoism, the rotten system in which economic war between the regionally based ethnic groups substituted for a shooting war -- until 1991, that is.
THE Yugoslav conflict impinges on neighboring Balkan countries, which in this decade will face dangerous historical reckonings following the collapse of Communism and the false division of Europe. Since national character will write the script in these places, too, look again to history -- and therefore to good books -- as a guide. The best survey of the historical personalities of the region's peoples, in my opinion, was originally published in 1915. "The Balkans: A History," by Nevill Forbes, Arnold J. Toynbee, D. Mitrany and D. G. Hogarth, is particularly good on Yugoslavia. Forbes explained that the Serbs and the Croats were one people, divided by religion and history, not by race and language -- whatever Croats and Serbs today may tell you. The book was written before the collapse of Ottoman Turkey, and its advantage is its emphasis on earlier history in the development of ethnic identity.
Greeks may be the best known and least understood of the Balkan peoples. They are a nation whose political personality flows from two millenniums of Byzantine rule and Ottoman despotism, rather than from Periclean Athens five centuries before Christ -- or, for that matter, from the superficial and contentious period of American tutelage following World War II. The finest book I know about the Greek political character is the British journalist David Holden's "Greece Without Columns: The Making of the Modern Greeks." Holden painstakingly stripped away the fantasies of the university classicists, enamored of the ancient Greeks, and described an authentic Greece, one built on Eastern Orthodox ritual and political intrigue. Published 21 years ago, the book is more relevant now than ever.
In one of many telling observations, Holden noted that "fashionable Greeks . . . still unconsciously acknowledge their Eastern heritage by saying they are off to 'Europe' when they visit Rome, Paris or London." Holden's unstated premise was one I share: that the 20th century has been a disappointing one for Greece, owing to the loss of Greek colonies in Asia Minor in the 1920's, the civil war in the 40's, the disastrous right-wing dictatorship in the 60's and 70's, and massively corrupt left-wing populist rule in the 80's. Greece is still struggling to rejoin the very world it once invented -- that of the West. Its obsession with Macedonia may further complicate this pursuit.
The false image of Greece entertained in the West is a principal theme of modern Greek poetry. "What I Love," by Odysseas Elytis (translated by Olga Broumas), the "Collected Poems" of George Seferis (translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard) and the "Greek Poems" of C. P. Cavafy (translated by Memas Kolaitis) all provide poignant references to what it means to be a modern Greek. Cavafy in particular saw the Greek Orthodox Church -- not the Parthenon -- as the Greek symbol, one that recalls "the greatness of our old Byzantine days."
The most intractable -- and to me, the most fascinating -- culture in the Balkans is not Greek but Romanian: a blend of Latin sexuality and flair, Eastern Orthodox mysticism and superstition, and Byzantine intrigue. Not surprisingly, Romania has been responsible for some of the most inspired writing on the Balkans.
"Athene Palace" (1942), by R. G. Waldeck, a German-Jewish magazine writer, is a textured miniature painting in words of Romanian manners, as seen from the lobby of the Athene Palace Hotel in Bucharest during the fascist revolution of 1940-41. Had correspondents who covered the revolution of 1989 that deposed President Nicolae Ceausescu read Waldeck's book, they would have realized that far from being unique, the 1989 revolution was a natural extension of what had occurred in the same streets almost half a century earlier: a fascist-style monarch was being overthrown by a usually docile population, which every few decades explodes in a bout of orgiastic fury.
Yet things in Romania are never as bad as they seem. Conquered and abused throughout history, Romanians, Waldeck noted, have learned to "fall artfully, soft and loose in every joint and muscle as only those trained in falling can be." That is, they know how to corrupt each successive fascist and Communist regime in order to soften its effects.
"The Prodigals" (1962), by Petru Dumitriu, is a sweeping novel that brilliantly satirized how the author's fellow Romanians could corrupt a ruling order to such a degree that the whole house crashed down on them. Mr. Dumitriu wrote about the period leading up to World War II. But his book is relevant for today, as brothels proliferate and mafias once again come out of the shadows in Bucharest. One shouldn't forget Bram Stoker's "Dracula," first published in 1897, whose early chapters provide a wonderfully evocative description of the geography, customs and ethnic complexities of what Stoker called "one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe."
For more fun, and not a little insight into the chaos and anarchy now being unleashed in the Balkans, turn to Eric Ambler's "Coffin for Dimitrios" (1939). Here is a tale of drug smuggling, assassination and political intrigue, set in the early part of the century, that perfectly captures the atmosphere at the end of the century, as political crime networks make their return not just to Bucharest, but even more so to Belgrade and other former Communist capitals.
This is a world far removed from the calmer realities of London and Paris. In the television special about Bosnia, "Land of the Demons," Peter Jennings kept repeating how Yugoslavia is "in the heart of Europe" -- making it sound as if it is a scandal that Western Europe hasn't done anything about the war there. But Western Europeans have never thought of the Balkans as Europe, and their inaction only expresses their deep psychological desire, based on historical precedent, to formalize the division they perceive. For Western Europeans, Europe has always ended where the Ottoman Empire begins -- in Yugoslavia. Mr. Jennings, and others as well, would be wise to read "Eothen" (Greek for "from the East"), by Alexander Kinglake, a mid-19th-century British traveler, who began his account this way:
"At Semlin I still was encompassed by the scenes and the sounds of familiar life. . . . Yet, whenever I chose to look southward, I saw the Ottoman's fortress -- austere, and darkly impending high over the vale of the Danube -- historic Belgrade. I had come, as it were, to the end of this wheel-going Europe, and now my eyes would see the Splendour and Havoc of The East."
 
 
 
A BALKAN BOOKSHELF

 All the books listed here, except for Mr. Kaplan's, are discussed in the accompanying essay.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 1; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 3562 words

HEADLINE: A Reader's Guide to the Balkans

BYLINE: By Robert D. Kaplan; Robert D. Kaplan, a contributing editor of The Atlantic, is the author of "Balkan Ghosts: A Journey Through History."

 BODY:
HISTORY, like hate, is the product of memory, and memory is composed of unforgettable detail -- sights, smells, sounds, exalted emotions, grim statistics and cruel ironies. A memory is not subject to condensation. Made to fit inside the narrow strictures of a television sound bite or a newspaper column, it loses all meaning. It becomes just another lifeless fact that can never convey how people have come to think and behave as they do.
The Balkans are a region of pure memory: a Bosch-like tapestry of interlocking ethnic rivalries where medieval and modern history thread into each other. More complicated and less visually exotic than the Middle East, the Balkans are unsuited to the reductions of the television camera. (A recent ABC News special, "Land of the Demons," showed footage from Bosnia, but even with rock music playing in the background the effect was flat.) Whereas the Middle East is a game of checkers -- Arabs versus Israelis, with a modern history that began only in 1918 -- the Balkans are three-dimensional chess. 
 So in a sense the ascendancy of the Balkans as a news story in the 1990's means a victory for print over television. Yet it is not only the television correspondents who can't do much with the Balkans. Neither can the newspaper pundits, since the region is not an extension of America's own ethnic and racial obsessions, the way the Middle East and South Africa are. The Balkans are truly foreign. They require pure intellectual curiosity, nuance, not op-ed polemics. There is no getting around it. To understand the Balkans, you have to read books.
The key word for understanding the Balkans is process: the process of history and the process of memory, processes that Communism kept on hold for 45 years, thereby creating a kind of multiplier effect for violence. Balkan violence is not a phenomenon of "modern hate," like that in Algeria and the West Bank, fed by rising economic expectations and demographic stress. Southeastern Europe is a caldron of history -- of unresolved border disputes and nationality questions created by the collapse of the multinational Hapsburg and Ottoman empires.
By "process," I mean the fact that in the Balkans each individual sensation and memory affects the grand movement of clashing peoples. For today's events are nothing but the sum total of everything that has gone before. Process is something that is more emotional, physical even, than rational. It often has no direction: the asides and footnotes can be more meaningful than the main story line. You have to feel. You have to be able to imagine all the details of the past. That is why the best books about the Balkans are old and frequently eccentric -- granting access to a psychological universe that no television camera will ever penetrate.
Here is my own Balkan reading list, consisting mainly of books that, although written long ago, explain the essentials of today's violence:
Dame Rebecca West's "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon," first published in 1941, is the perfect literary metaphor for the Balkans. Dame Rebecca takes nearly 1,200 pages of small print to describe Yugoslavia. Her book is filled with the most subtle of tangents, which go on for thousands of words. By concentrating on the minutiae of memory, she illuminates how people who basically look the same, speak the same language and have virtually indistinguishable names can hate one another with primitive ferocity.
Because Dame Rebecca experienced Yugoslavia in the late 1930's, during the buildup to fascism in Croatia, she is more critical of the Croats than of the Serbs. This serves a useful purpose for the modern reader, however: it shows that the present civil war is merely the second half of one that began in the midst of World War II, only to be interrupted by 45 years of Communist rule. The Croats were responsible for much of the brutality in the first half; the Serbs are guilty now.
Dame Rebecca's clairvoyance is demonstrated by Slovenia's absence from her travelogue. As the current war shows, Slovenia has always been a sideshow to the Yugoslav drama, owing to its lack of ethnic Serb and Croat minorities and its position in the extreme northwest of the federation. Wisely, Dame Rebecca concentrated on Bosnia, and she pointed to Macedonia as the pre-eminent Balkan problem, since it is the region where territorial and linguistic disputes dissolve into an anarchy of formlessness.
Like all good books about the Balkans, "Black Lamb and Grey Falcon" is politically incorrect, because it recognizes national character as historical destiny. Culturally, the Balkans may be the world's most intractable area. People are born equal there, but what happens to them afterwards -- the lies they are fed, the truths they are fed, the way they drink and the way they worship -- makes them profoundly different from one another by adulthood. For example, Roman Catholic Slovenia has experienced decades of Communism, even as Eastern Orthodox Greece has been a member of the Western alliance. Yet Slovenia's economic future appears to be brighter than Greece's. This is geography, character and history speaking, not policy.
Because the national character in question today is mainly that of the Serbs, I recommend several books, each profoundly incorrect, that take you inside the minds of some of the world's best haters.
"The Mountain Wreath," by Petar Petrovich Njegos, first published in 1847, is the great epic poem of the Serbian language. Njegos, the Bishop of Montenegro, was an unreconstructed Serb nationalist who justified the 17th-century mass murder of Albanian converts to Islam as part of a larger struggle against the Muslim Turks. The reader can experience a hundred pages of fiery verse like this:
 
 Our struggle won't come to an end until
 we or the Turks are exterminated. . . .
 we . . . set their houses ablaze.
 Out of their mosque and of a small building
 we made a pile of accursed rubble there. . . .
"The War in Eastern Europe," by John Reed, with drawings by Boardman Robinson, is the author's 1916 account of his Balkan travels during World War I. Beneath a sketch of a Serb soldier at the book's beginning, a caption reads, "Half-savage giants dressed in the ancient panoply of that curious Slavic people whose main business is war." When Reed asked a Serb soldier if he was afraid of foreign intervention, the soldier replied: "Let them all come! Serbia can whip the world!"
Reed, best known today for "Ten Days That Shook the World," his account of the Bolshevik Revolution, reflected in "The War in Eastern Europe": "I thought with wonder of these Serbians, their origin and their destiny. They alone of all the Balkan peoples have been one unmixed race. . . . They held their narrow passes against the Tartars of Bulgaria, the Dacians of Rumania, the Huns and Tcheks of the North. . . . When Europe imposed foreign dynasties on Bulgaria, Romania and Greece, Serbia was ruled by her own house. With such a stock, with such a history, with the imperialistic impulse growing daily, hourly, in the hearts of her peasant soldiers, into what tremendous conflicts will Serbia's ambition lead her!"
ANOTHER book that conveys just how little this far-off corner of Europe has changed is C. L. Sulzberger's "Long Row of Candles: Memoirs and Diaries (1934-1954)." In 1939, Mr. Sulzberger, who was later to become a foreign affairs columnist for The New York Times, met a Slavic Macedonian who was forced to Bulgarize his name after the Bulgarians invaded his homeland, and then to Serbicize his name after the Serbs invaded. This caused the fellow to say: "No wonder the rest of the world calls stew a macedoine. . . . When will we smash our fetters and gather round our capital in Solun?" Solun is the city of Salonika -- in Greece. It is such irredentist attitudes over the decades that fuel the seemingly irrational attempt by Greece to prevent the recognition of Macedonia as an independent state.
The mother lode of Serbian culture and national aspirations is its Orthodox monasteries in "old Serbia," a region where the medieval Serbian kingdom was born and grew to greatness in the 13th and 14th centuries, but which is now inhabited by Albanian Moslems and is known as Kosovo. In "The Saga of Kosovo" (1984), Alex N. Dragnich and Slavko Todorovich chronicled the history of this region in delicious and convoluted depth. They did it from an ardently pro-Serbian standpoint, allowing the reader to see how even well-educated ethnic Serbs can sneer at Muslim Albanians and, by implication, the Muslims in Bosnia.
According to Mr. Dragnich and Mr. Todorovich, Serbia is a modern nation that has grown organically from a well-developed medieval civilization, while Albania is "culturally not ready" for nationhood, owing to its "total involvement in the passing Turkish civilization." Notice how both Njegos in the 1840's and Mr. Dragnich and Mr. Todorovich in the 1980's see Balkan Muslims as the historical appendage of the hated Ottoman sultanate that ruled in Serbia from the late 14th century through the 19th century.
For an Albanian view, turn to "The Albanians: Europe's Forgotten Survivors" (1977), by Anton Logoreci. While the Serbs see their defeat by the Turks in Kosovo in 1389 as the end of Christian enlightenment and the beginning of Muslim barbarism in the Balkans, Mr. Logoreci sees the medieval Serbian army as a feudal rabble that was defeated by "the more disciplined and better trained" Turkish troops. His theme is that the Albanians have always been victims of aggressive neighbors, especially the Greeks and the Serbs, forcing his people to turn to Hapsburg monarchs and Ottoman sultans for help.
In their age-old battles with the Albanians, the Muslims and the Croats, the Serbs have drawn psychological sustenance from Russia, their big, Slavic Orthodox neighbor to the north. In the first section of Milovan Djilas's "Conversations With Stalin" (1962), appropriately called "Raptures," the former Yugoslav Vice President under Tito described his first visit to Russia, in 1944, as being like "returning to a primeval homeland, unknown but mine." Mr. Djilas wondered: "Was this not the homeland of our ancestors, whom some unknown avalanche had deposited in the windswept Balkans?" As he writes about how the "limitless gray steppes" of Russia released "unknown inner urges," Mr. Djilas suggests the irrational but real impulses that have brought the Serbs and the Russians together through the centuries.
Blood ties and hatred can be tricky. On a recent television talk show, a Croatian American and a Bosnian Muslim both attacked me for failing to note that in Sarajevo, at least, Muslims, Croats, Serbs and Jews had usually got along. I recommend that they and others read "The Damned Yard: And Other Stories" by Ivo Andric. A Bosnian Croat, Andric won the Nobel Prize in Literature in 1961, mainly for his novel "The Bridge on the Drina." In one of his stories, "A Letter From 1920," first published 73 years ago, Andric explained:
"Yes, Bosnia is a country of hatred. That is Bosnia. And by a strange contrast . . . there are a few countries with such firm belief . . . so much tenderness and loving passion . . . or with such a thirst for justice. But in secret depths underneath all this hide burning hatreds, entire hurricanes of tethered and compressed hatreds. . . . Thus you are condemned to live on deep layers of explosive, which are lit from time to time by the very sparks of your loves and your fiery and violent emotion."
Andric said that the people of the region denied this hatred, and consequently hated outsiders who mentioned it to them. The often invisible border between hate and love, and unity and disunity, is further explored in Andric's novel "The Days of the Consuls" (1945), about the small Bosnian town of Travnik in the early 19th century, and the political atmosphere found there by the French and Austrian consuls.
Sorting out all these passions in a clinically objective fashion is what Misha Glenny, a BBC correspondent, has done in "The Fall of Yugoslavia: The Third Balkan War" (1992). He describes how an awful history is now made worse by morally corrupt and incompetent regimes in Serbia and Croatia that are the legacy of Titoism. In addition to "Conversations With Stalin," Milovan Djilas has written a number of books exposing Tito, who imprisoned Mr. Djilas for the crime of advocating glasnost three decades before Mikhail S. Gorbachev did. Particularly readable is Mr. Djilas's "Rise and Fall" (1985), about the author's own tragic career in the Yugoslav Communist Party and how it mirrored the fall of Titoism, the rotten system in which economic war between the regionally based ethnic groups substituted for a shooting war -- until 1991, that is.
THE Yugoslav conflict impinges on neighboring Balkan countries, which in this decade will face dangerous historical reckonings following the collapse of Communism and the false division of Europe. Since national character will write the script in these places, too, look again to history -- and therefore to good books -- as a guide. The best survey of the historical personalities of the region's peoples, in my opinion, was originally published in 1915. "The Balkans: A History," by Nevill Forbes, Arnold J. Toynbee, D. Mitrany and D. G. Hogarth, is particularly good on Yugoslavia. Forbes explained that the Serbs and the Croats were one people, divided by religion and history, not by race and language -- whatever Croats and Serbs today may tell you. The book was written before the collapse of Ottoman Turkey, and its advantage is its emphasis on earlier history in the development of ethnic identity.
Greeks may be the best known and least understood of the Balkan peoples. They are a nation whose political personality flows from two millenniums of Byzantine rule and Ottoman despotism, rather than from Periclean Athens five centuries before Christ -- or, for that matter, from the superficial and contentious period of American tutelage following World War II. The finest book I know about the Greek political character is the British journalist David Holden's "Greece Without Columns: The Making of the Modern Greeks." Holden painstakingly stripped away the fantasies of the university classicists, enamored of the ancient Greeks, and described an authentic Greece, one built on Eastern Orthodox ritual and political intrigue. Published 21 years ago, the book is more relevant now than ever.
In one of many telling observations, Holden noted that "fashionable Greeks . . . still unconsciously acknowledge their Eastern heritage by saying they are off to 'Europe' when they visit Rome, Paris or London." Holden's unstated premise was one I share: that the 20th century has been a disappointing one for Greece, owing to the loss of Greek colonies in Asia Minor in the 1920's, the civil war in the 40's, the disastrous right-wing dictatorship in the 60's and 70's, and massively corrupt left-wing populist rule in the 80's. Greece is still struggling to rejoin the very world it once invented -- that of the West. Its obsession with Macedonia may further complicate this pursuit.
The false image of Greece entertained in the West is a principal theme of modern Greek poetry. "What I Love," by Odysseas Elytis (translated by Olga Broumas), the "Collected Poems" of George Seferis (translated by Edmund Keeley and Philip Sherrard) and the "Greek Poems" of C. P. Cavafy (translated by Memas Kolaitis) all provide poignant references to what it means to be a modern Greek. Cavafy in particular saw the Greek Orthodox Church -- not the Parthenon -- as the Greek symbol, one that recalls "the greatness of our old Byzantine days."
The most intractable -- and to me, the most fascinating -- culture in the Balkans is not Greek but Romanian: a blend of Latin sexuality and flair, Eastern Orthodox mysticism and superstition, and Byzantine intrigue. Not surprisingly, Romania has been responsible for some of the most inspired writing on the Balkans.
"Athene Palace" (1942), by R. G. Waldeck, a German-Jewish magazine writer, is a textured miniature painting in words of Romanian manners, as seen from the lobby of the Athene Palace Hotel in Bucharest during the fascist revolution of 1940-41. Had correspondents who covered the revolution of 1989 that deposed President Nicolae Ceausescu read Waldeck's book, they would have realized that far from being unique, the 1989 revolution was a natural extension of what had occurred in the same streets almost half a century earlier: a fascist-style monarch was being overthrown by a usually docile population, which every few decades explodes in a bout of orgiastic fury.
Yet things in Romania are never as bad as they seem. Conquered and abused throughout history, Romanians, Waldeck noted, have learned to "fall artfully, soft and loose in every joint and muscle as only those trained in falling can be." That is, they know how to corrupt each successive fascist and Communist regime in order to soften its effects.
"The Prodigals" (1962), by Petru Dumitriu, is a sweeping novel that brilliantly satirized how the author's fellow Romanians could corrupt a ruling order to such a degree that the whole house crashed down on them. Mr. Dumitriu wrote about the period leading up to World War II. But his book is relevant for today, as brothels proliferate and mafias once again come out of the shadows in Bucharest. One shouldn't forget Bram Stoker's "Dracula," first published in 1897, whose early chapters provide a wonderfully evocative description of the geography, customs and ethnic complexities of what Stoker called "one of the wildest and least known portions of Europe."
For more fun, and not a little insight into the chaos and anarchy now being unleashed in the Balkans, turn to Eric Ambler's "Coffin for Dimitrios" (1939). Here is a tale of drug smuggling, assassination and political intrigue, set in the early part of the century, that perfectly captures the atmosphere at the end of the century, as political crime networks make their return not just to Bucharest, but even more so to Belgrade and other former Communist capitals.
This is a world far removed from the calmer realities of London and Paris. In the television special about Bosnia, "Land of the Demons," Peter Jennings kept repeating how Yugoslavia is "in the heart of Europe" -- making it sound as if it is a scandal that Western Europe hasn't done anything about the war there. But Western Europeans have never thought of the Balkans as Europe, and their inaction only expresses their deep psychological desire, based on historical precedent, to formalize the division they perceive. For Western Europeans, Europe has always ended where the Ottoman Empire begins -- in Yugoslavia. Mr. Jennings, and others as well, would be wise to read "Eothen" (Greek for "from the East"), by Alexander Kinglake, a mid-19th-century British traveler, who began his account this way:
"At Semlin I still was encompassed by the scenes and the sounds of familiar life. . . . Yet, whenever I chose to look southward, I saw the Ottoman's fortress -- austere, and darkly impending high over the vale of the Danube -- historic Belgrade. I had come, as it were, to the end of this wheel-going Europe, and now my eyes would see the Splendour and Havoc of The East."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 5; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 284 words

HEADLINE: Making a Difference;
Letting the Good Times Roll

BYLINE: By SUSAN KARLIN

 BODY:
HUMAN bowling, Velcro wall jumping, tricycle races and TV theme singalongs aren't exactly by-the-books business strategies. But they've helped two brothers turn one restaurant/bar into a multi-million-dollar franchise during both a recession and an era of drinking less.
In six years, the two brothers, John and Jim Ressler, who've yet to turn 30, have opened six successful places in Manhattan and Long Island under their umbrella company, Global Enterprises, with themes from the Wild West to a fraternity basement. Their current venture is the Aces & 8's bar in the East Village. 
 Three more are planned for this summer: Caddyshack in Manhattan, and North Carolina Cattle Company and a new Delta House, both in Wilmington, N.C.
Wilmington? "It's the 14th fastest-growing city in the U.S. and the No. 1 for relocation," said John Ressler. "It's going to be the new Greenwich Village in the next six months," he added, with a trace of hyperbole.
The Resslers were not always so confident about operating several establishments. They pretty much went into the business blind. "We opened a restaurant because everyone wants to be in the restaurant business," John said. As it turned out, he added, just about everyone is already in the restaurant business.
"As the booze market got weaker," Mr. Ressler said, "we had to do things beyond installing a couple of pinball machines." Now, drawing gimmicks from pop culture and college bulletins, the Resslers attract a carefree twentysomething crowd by throwing toga and beach parties and donning pig and gorilla suits as promotions.
"We were looking to have people do something other than just drink. So we decided to sell fun," said John.

GRAPHIC: Photo: That's entertainment? Human bowling ball at Aces & 8's. (Brian Palmer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Corporate Vows to Aid Poor Produce Little in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 18

 BODY:
Almost daily a group of well-dressed business executives announces with great fanfare a financial commitment to revitalize this city's poor neighborhoods in the aftermath of last year's riots. At last tally, 200 corporations had pledged more than $500 million in aid.
But these pledges have so far done little to change the bleak economic conditions of the inner city. Most of the corporate money will come in the form of donated equipment, buildings and services and support for educational and job training programs -- not for the factories, distribution centers, outlets and other operations that would create jobs in low-income areas. 
 "We've heard a lot of companies announcing what they plan to do for South-Central in the past year, but it's mainly been a bandwagon for large businesses to jump on for their own promotional purposes," said Eric Mann, director of the Labor Community Strategy Center in Los Angeles, an advocacy group that deals with labor and environmental issues.
 
City Is Quiet
 Los Angeles was quiet today after the convictions on Saturday of two police officers on Federal charges of violating the civil rights of Rodney G. King. But public figures ruffled the peaceful atmosphere by pointing out that the court case did not solve the city's underlying problems. One called the verdict "both epochal and irrelevant." Another said, "All the root causes of what happened a year ago are still there." [Page B11.]
Efforts to persuade companies to invest in the inner city have been hampered by a stubborn recession that has brought enormous layoffs as well as by California's stringent environmental and labor regulations, which add to the cost of doing business. And promises of Federal and state aid have not materialized so far.
While some corporations have pledged to increase the number of contracts that go to minority-owned businesses and to invest in healthy inner-city businesses and banks as a means of creating jobs, few residents have found work because of these efforts.
The results in the 11 months since the riots that followed the acquittal of four police officers on state charges in the beating of Mr. King have come as a major disappointment to many government officials, community leaders and economists here who have been looking to the business community to help solve the economic and social problems of troubled areas.
"If you are looking for shiny new factories and thousands of new jobs, you won't find them," said Jack Kyser, chief economist for the Economic Development Corporation of Los Angeles County. "The economic situation in these areas is about the same as it was a year ago, and it would be naive to think that within a year you could plop down a huge new plant in that area and put thousands of people to work."
 
Transferring Workers In
 As a result of the recession, companies say they are extremely limited in the type of assistance they can provide. For example, the Hughes Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of General Motors, has promised to give $18 million to the South-Central area and to move one of its business divisions there.
But $15 million of the Hughes money represents contracts that the company plans to set aside for minority-owned businesses. And the military contractor does not plan to hire local residents to work in the division it relocates; the workers will be transferred from other locations.
Richard Dore, a Hughes spokesman, said it would be unrealistic to expect the company to build a factory in South-Central Los Angeles at a time when the company was likely to eliminate 15,000 jobs in the metropolitan area and move many operations to other states.
The International Business Machines Corporation, which posted losses of $5 billion last year and announced its first layoffs in a half century, has pledged $31 million over the next five years to improve economic conditions in poor Los Angeles areas.
But none of that money will go directly toward new jobs or operations. About $19 million will be contracts given to businesses owned by members of minority groups; $5 million will go to support job-training centers that the company has sponsored with the Los Angeles Urban League and the Bank of America since 1968, and the remainder will be used to provide computer equipment and services to the centers and to Rebuild L.A., the public-private consortium charged with reviving the economy of the city's poor areas.
"When we first sat down with Peter Ueberroth he asked us if we could build a computer plant in South-Central and create jobs," said William E. Brown Jr., project director for I.B.M.'s rebuild program. "But with I.B.M. eliminating 100,000 jobs and phasing out plants around the country, his idea was clearly not feasible." Mr. Ueberroth, the former Baseball Commissioner best known for organizing the highly successful 1984 Summer Olympics here, heads Rebuild L.A.
The group faces a gargantuan task: A management consultant has estimated that an investment of about $6 billion and the creation of 75,000 to 94,000 jobs are needed to heal the inner city.
In recent months, Rebuild L.A. has come under fire for what critics say has been its failure to attract enough corporate support to create meaningful jobs.
 
Rebuild L.A. Sees Progress
 Mr. Ueberroth, who declined to be interviewed for this article, has said that the pace of revitalization in the inner city has been slower than he expected, mainly because of the economy and the lack of government incentives for corporate investment.
But other officials of Rebuild L.A. say that the consortium has made significant progress in the 11 months since its formation, and that about 5,000 jobs have been created directly and indirectly.
"You don't have $500 million invested and not have jobs," said Barry A. Sanders, a co-chairman of Rebuild L.A. "Unfortunately people are looking for a quick fix, but we cannot correct decades-old problems overnight."
He cites a vocational automotive training center built by Toyota Motor Sales Inc. and the Los Angeles Urban League. The center trains about 100 people a year as entry-level automotive technicians and assists them in finding employment.
Mr. Sanders said that real job growth in the inner city would come mainly from the expansion of small and medium-sized businesses and that Rebuild L.A. would soon announce a program to provide capital for such growth.
Officials of Rebuild L.A. say they are being asked to fulfill a role that the Federal and state governments have not been willing to assume. While Federal and state officials have promised increased financing for troubled areas like the South-Central neighborhood, little has been forthcoming so far. Nor have there been regulatory revisions and financial incentives that government officials acknowledge are necessary to encourage investment.
Community advocates here say the main barriers to economic development in areas like South-Central Los Angeles are negative stereotypes that Corporate America harbors.
"There's a general assumption by large corporations that investments in these areas will not be recouped and that there are only marginal profits to be made," said Denise Fairchild, director of the Los Angeles office of the Local Initiative Support Corporation, an economic development group.
 
Supermarket Chains Expand
 Ms. Fairchild said the expansion of major supermarket chains into the inner city was starting to debunk these assumptions. She points to plans by Vons supermarkets to spend $50 million to build five stores in low-income areas of Los Angeles. The stores, scheduled to be completed by next year, will generate 500 to 1,000 jobs.
While Vons had planned to expand into the inner city before the riots, the company says it has accelerated those plans, which include an additional $50 million investment in other disadvantaged areas. "We are doing this because we know that we can be profitable in these areas that have long been underserved and also because we feel some social responsibility," said Mary McAboy, a Vons spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: As Health Plan Comes Together, Big Price Tag Comes Into Focus

SERIES: Health Agenda: Tallying the Costs -- A special report.

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR with DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Just one month before President Clinton is scheduled to send Congress an ambitious proposal to guarantee comprehensive health care for all Americans, Administration officials are beginning to realize that it may involve huge costs and tax increases bigger than any previously proposed.
The White House has spent 12 weeks developing ideas for guaranteeing all Americans a rich package of health benefits. But only recently has the task force sorting through the ideas begun to focus on the costs. 
 President Clinton would probably finance his health plan by asking Congress to impose new taxes, amounting to hundreds of dollars a year even for middle-income families, including millions who already get health insurance coverage through their employers. In return, the Administration says, the health plan would provide peace of mind for all Americans because people would be assured of coverage if they moved, changed jobs or became sick.
 
How Many Billions?
 Officials say they cannot yet estimate totals because Mr. Clinton has not decided what the precise ingredients of his package will be and because even the members of the health-policy team cannot agree on reliable figures for individual elements of the plan.
But if the plan included guaranteed insurance coverage for prescription drugs, mental health care and long-term care, benefits recommended by the staff, these items alone could easily reach more than $50 billion a year, say health-policy experts and actuaries in and out of the Government. Parts of the health program might be put into effect gradually, so that the tax increase would be less abrupt, and perhaps more politically palatable.
In February, Ira C. Magaziner, manager of the President's Task Force on National Health Care Reform, said in a memorandum that "universal access could mean $30 billion or $90 billion of additional annual expenditure by the Government by 1997." The ultimate cost may be toward the upper end of that range if Mr. Clinton's proposal includes many items under discussion.
 
Surprised by an Uproar
 As attention turns to the costs of new health benefits, the options for raising revenue also come into focus, as do the political risks that may accompany such proposals.
Aides to Mr. Magaziner, a business consultant from Rhode Island with limited experience in government and politics, say he was surprised by the political uproar last week over the disclosure that the Administration was considering an indirect form of national sales tax known as a value-added tax to pay for the health program.
Government actuaries and statisticians told the White House that if all the benefits recommended by the staff of the task force were included, a 14 percent value-added tax might be needed, a rate much higher than politicians have ever contemplated.
Two senior Administration officials said recently that Cabinet officers had pressed Mr. Magaziner for more detailed cost estimates and had been frustrated at his not factoring cost into the deliberations earlier.
Robert D. Reischauer, the director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, said these matters were "so complex and the data so limited" that reliable estimates were probably impossible.
What follows is a description of the potential costs of individual elements of the President's plan that are under discussion and the possible sources of revenue to finance them.
 
The Costs
Many Needs Mean Huge Expenses
 Lack of health insurance inhibits the use of health care. Providing coverage for the uninsured would increase their use of care and improve their health, but would also contribute to an increase in spending.
"If you give people an insurance card, they will go to the doctor more often," said John F. Sheils, a vice president of Lewin-VHI, a consulting concern that specializes in medical economics. "The uninsured use about 60 percent as much care as insured people with similar characteristics."
Mr. Sheils said health-care spending for people now uninsured would rise by $30 billion a year if they all became insured. The uninsured now get $41 billion a year in medical services, including what they pay for themselves as well as what they receive from public hospitals and programs, and they would get $71 billion worth if they were insured, he estimates. To prevent overuse of services, Administration officials would encourage patients to see general practitioners or family doctors before specialists.
One unresolved question is whether to upgrade Medicare, the Federal health insurance program for 35 million elderly and disabled people, to include all the benefits now offered by private health-maintenance organizations. Such enhancements could cost $15 billion to $20 billion a year.
These other elements are under consideration:
Prescription drugs It would cost the Government perhaps $10 billion a year to provide insurance covering the cost of prescription drugs to people who do not have such coverage.
The Federal Health Care Financing Administration, which runs Medicare and Medicaid, estimates that $44 billion, most of it private money, will be spent on prescription drugs for people outside hospitals this year. The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association says 72 million Americans have no insurance coverage for prescription drugs. One-fourth of these people are 65 years old or over.
If the Government required employers to cover prescription drugs as part of the standard package of employee health benefits, it would, for political reasons, almost certainly have to provide drug coverage under Medicare.
Elderly people account for 13 percent of the population, but they are responsible for 34 percent of all spending for outpatient prescription drugs. Medicare generally does not cover the cost outside a hospital.
Long-term care Standard health insurance policies do not cover the cost of nursing homes or medical and social services provided to people in their own homes over a prolonged time. Medicaid, the Federal-state program, finances a substantial amount of such long-term care for low-income people, at a cost to the Federal Government of $35 billion a year.
But many other people need such care. Donald N. Muse, a statistician who has worked for the Congressional Budget Office and for the Medicare actuary, estimates that "a medium-size package of long-term care would cost the Federal Government $50 billion a year," beyond what it already spends.
Generous, comprehensive coverage under a public program could cost $100 billion a year, Mr. Muse said. By contrast, he said, the cost to the Government might be $20 billion a year under a program of the type favored by the nursing-home industry, which relies heavily on private insurance.
But Mr. Sheils said: "There's a lot of unmet need for nursing homes and home health care. If you had full coverage for long-term care and eliminated supply constraints, you would probably see a 30 percent increase in utilization of nursing homes, and the use of home health services could double."
Mental health President Clinton's proposal holds out the prospect of mental health care for millions of people who need such services but do not get them. His plan, at a minimum, would guarantee coverage for people with severe mental illnesses. But it would probably cover little psychotherapy for people who function reasonably well at work and at home.
In a report to Congress last month, the National Institute of Mental Health said it would cost $6.5 billion a year to provide coverage for treatment of severe mental illnesses like schizophrenia, major depression and manic-depressive disorder.
"Currently," the agency said, "60 percent of people with severe mental disorders use services during a given year. This number would probably increase to about 80 percent with full coverage." The Government says that 5.1 million adults and nearly 1 million children have severe mental disorders.
Mr. Clinton's plan could also help some people whose illnesses were less than severe.
Confidential work papers from the task force say people will be eligible for mental health care if they have disorders that meet criteria in the diagnostic manual of the American Psychiatric Association and if these disorders "create a serious risk for functional impairment."
Subsidies Mr. Clinton wants to require employers to provide health benefits to employees; workers would bear some of the cost. But Mr. Clinton will propose subsidies to reduce the burden on poor people and on companies with many low-wage employees.
Such subsidies could quickly become expensive for the Government. Under one option favored by senior members of Mr. Clinton's health team, the Government would subsidize premiums so that a private employer's contribution would not exceed a specified proportion of payroll -- say, 7 percent. Such a guarantee, Mr. Sheils says, would cost the Government $20 billion a year in premium-subsidy payments.
But he points out that health costs are growing faster than wages. To cover such costs, insurance premiums must also rise rapidly. As a result, Mr. Sheils said, more employers will find their health costs exceeding 7 percent of payroll. More employers will thus qualify for the Federal subsidies, and employers will need bigger subsidies.
 
The Taxes
A Few Proposals, None Painless
 Politicians, scholars and others at the center of the debate disagree over how to pay for universal health care, but a consensus exists on one point: some new form of tax with which Americans have no experience will almost certainly be needed.
More than 90 percent of Federal revenue is now raised through individual and corporate income taxes and through payroll taxes from employers and workers for Social Security and Medicare. No one is seriously proposing higher income or payroll taxes to meet the cost of the health program.
Mr. Clinton has already asked for a steep increase in income tax rates to reduce the Federal budget deficit, and another increase is out of the question politically. He can hardly ask employers to pay a further tax, since they would already bear much of the cost of universal coverage.
The financing problem is worsened by the fact that the Government will lose billions of dollars in tax revenue if additional workers are covered by their employers. That is because either companies or workers will owe less in income taxes: If companies swallow the additional cost of covering workers, they will get a new tax deduction. If, instead, companies offset their cost by lowering employees' pay, the workers would owe less in income taxes.
Administration officials have said that more than a dozen potential sources of new revenue are under consideration. As a practical matter, only a handful seem plausible. These are the most widely discussed:
Sin taxes The President has said he favors new taxes on tobacco and alcohol products, and opinion polls show that the public would favor such a step. But these taxes would not raise nearly enough money to cover all the Government's new costs.
According to the Congressional Budget Office, an increase in the Federal cigarette tax, now 24 cents a pack, to $1 would raise an additional $10 billion a year. An increase to $2 would raise nearly $20 billion.
The most commonly discussed proposal on alcoholic beverages would, for example, increase the tax on a six-pack of beer to 81 cents from 33 cents. Such a tax on alcoholic beverages would raise nearly $5 billion a year, according to the budget office.
These taxes have the advantage of taxing behavior that leads to poor health, Administration officials say. But if people cut back on drinking and smoking, the tax base would erode, and officials believe the revenues from those taxes would not keep pace with the rising cost of health care.
Value-added tax Such a tax, called a VAT, would be imposed at each level of production and would ultimately be paid by consumers, meaning it would essentially be a sales tax. Food, housing and medical care would probably be exempt, but most other products and services would be covered.
The main advantage of a value-added tax is that it would raise large sums of money. The Congressional Budget Office calculates that a 5 percent VAT would generate nearly $60 billion the first year it was fully in force, and the amount would rise annually as the economy grew and prices of goods and services rose.
Theoretically, value-added taxes also encourage saving, since no tax is paid until money is spent. Psychologically, consumers can feel a small degree of control over what they pay, since they can avoid taxes by keeping their wallets shut.
The biggest disadvantage is that this is what economists call a regressive tax, meaning that the poorer people are, the heavier their tax burden.
Middle-income families could pay more than $1,000 a year in additional taxes with a VAT as low as 4 percent, even with exclusions for food, shelter and medical care. Politically, this would be an extraordinary proposal for a Democratic President who campaigned on the theme that the tax system was unfair to the poor and middle class.
Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, seized that theme today on the NBC News program "Meet the Press." Calling a value-added tax one that "hits low-income people the hardest," the Kansas Republican said he would not support a VAT "unless it replaces maybe the corporate income tax or part of the income tax."
States and local governments would also complain, because they see sales taxes as their province.
Tax on Insurance Employers can take a tax deduction for the entire cost of paying medical insurance premiums for workers, and no matter how generous this fringe benefit, employees get it tax-free. Most experts believe that overly generous insurance coverage encourages overuse of medical services and raises the overall cost of care.
The Congressional Budget Office reviewed a proposal to place a tax on employer-paid premiums of more than $165 a month for individuals and $400 for a family, approximately the cost of the average policy.
The tax could be imposed either by disallowing the employers' deductions for the additional amount or by requiring employees to pay taxes on the excess as if it were income. Limiting the deduction is probably more attractive politically. Either way, according to the budget office, $20 billion to $30 billion a year could be raised.
This proposal is a favorite of economists and health-policy specialists. But it is vigorously opposed by labor unions that have forgone large wage increases in favor of medical benefits.
Payroll Tax for Part-time Workers This tax is nearly a sure bet. Employers would not have to provide medical insurance for employees who worked fewer than a certain number of hours, but they would have to pay a tax to cover the Government's cost of buying insurance for such workers.
Lewin-VHI, the consulting group, calculated that if companies had to pay a tax of 8 percent of part-time workers' wages, it would raise about $4 billion a year for the Government.
Tax on Hospitals and Doctors In theory, hospitals and doctors would get a windfall from universal coverage because they would be paid for care in charity cases that now go unreimbursed. Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems and a lobbyist for private hospitals, estimates that on average hospitals spend 5 percent of their budgets on charity patients.
By one estimate, a 3 percent windfall tax on the hospital revenues and doctors' incomes could raise $10 billion to $12 billion a year. But without price controls, this could become a tax on the sick, since doctors and hospitals would pass it along to their patients.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
Consumers are flocking back to the nation's stores as the weather improves, and business executives and economists are breathing easier. Early April cars sales werealso up, and mortgage applications remain at a high level. [Page D1.]
Business pledges to help revitalize poor neighborhoods in Los Angeles have so far done little to change the bleak economic conditions of the inner city. [A1.] 
 A dispute has erupted in the Clinton Administration over Vice President Gore's efforts to persuade the President to announce specific steps to reduce the threat from global warming. Because of its potential cost, such a move has met resistance from several Cabinet members, principally Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary. [A17.]
The costs of health-care reform may be huge and involve tax increases bigger than any previously proposed. [A1.]
 
International
Fiat's chairman, Gianni Agnelli, admitted to corporate corruption in Italy's vast kickback scandal. [D1] Italians headed to the polls in elections that could restrict the power of the nation's political parties. [A8.]
Peru has embarked on a privatization program that is the most radical in Latin America. The nation plans to auction off virtually all its state-owned companies over the next two years. [D1.]
 
Companies
Tandy's chief, John V. Roach, is tightening his grasp on operations at the company's flagship, the nationwide chain of Radio Shack consumer electronics stores. The company disclosed Friday that Bernard S. Appel, a Tandy senior vice president and the chairman of Radio Shack for the last year, would retire June 30 and become a consultant to the company. [D1.]
Three corporations were ordered to pay $48.3 million in punitive damages in a civil lawsuit over leaky plastic plumbing that flooded some homes. The three are the Shell Oil Company, the United States Brass unit of Eljer Industries and the Hoechst Celanese Corporation. [D2.]
 
The Media Business
ABC was the only network to gain ground as the official 1992-93 television season ended last night. It moved to second place behind CBS. NBC slid deeply into third place. [D1.]
Radio stations are consolidating in the wake of the F.C.C.'s easing of regulations to allow a single owner to buy up to four stations in one metropolitan area; 730 radio stations, or nearly 7 percent of the industry, have signed deals that will lead to ownership changes. [D1.]
Town & Country has appointed Pamela Fiori, a longtime American Express Publishing executive, as editor in chief to shore up the faltering magazine. [D11.]
Newspapers get some advice on how to compete with television. William Glaberson: Press Notes. [D11.]
America West Airlines tries to show respect for it customers. Advertising. [D12.]
 
Today's Columns
An economist has come up with a new method for predicting trends in the bond market that uses data provided by the Journal of Commerce index of commodity prices. Jonathan Fuerbringer: Credit Markets. [D5.]
A more effective way to protect endangered reptiles has been developed by two professors. Patents. [D2.]
Apple's report of quarterly performance has divided analysts over whether it is good news or bad news. Market Place. [D4.]
