HEADLINE: Scallopers See a Livelihood Imperiled

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW BEDFORD, Mass., April 18

 BODY:
Like the 19th-century whalers who lived and labored here before them, scallopers say they fear they may become the next fallen icons of New England, remembered only in museums, books and the tall barroom tales of fishermen.
Dwindling stocks of sea scallops, foreign competition and increased enforcement of Federal fishing regulations have turned their once-pleasant trade into an ordeal that threatens their way of life, say the men and women who work the seas. 
 Situated on Buzzard's Bay, New Bedford and the neighboring town of Fairhaven share a port that brings in a $200 million catch each year, the largest in the nation. Memorialized by Herman Melville as a whaling port in "Moby Dick," the Buzzard Bay area has long attracted fishing families from Portugal and Norway.
An estimated 300 vessels, 120 of them scallopers, compose the commercial fishing fleet, which in large part fuels the economy of this poor, working-class community. Unemployment here was 15.2 percent in February, compared with 7.7 percent nationally.
 
Raids Spark Tension
 Tensions soared last month when Federal agents raided 22 scalloping vessels in the Port of New Bedford, seizing $126,220 worth of scallops. The agents, armed and wearing bulletproof vests, charged six boat owners with catching undersized, or baby, scallops and a seventh with unloading a catch outside the 5 A.M.-to-5 P.M. "window" set by Federal officials.
Scallopers, their families and many others in this closely intertwined community of about 116,000 said they were outraged by what they considered overzealous enforcement of rules they say are complex and leave scant room for error in judging the maturity of scallops. Fines for such violations can be as much as $100,000.
"We're not drug runners; we're not murderers; we're not rapists," said Bobby Bruno, a 52-year-old scalloper who started as a deckhand 33 years ago and now owns the Alpha & Omega II, a 96-foot scalloping ship. "We're just fishermen, and we go out and we work hard so we can come home and be with our families and be happy."
Federal agents acknowledged that tensions were high during the seizures, but they said that part of the tension had been caused by numerous death threats against agents and their families. A Federal investigation of the threats is under way, said John McCarthy, special agent in charge of the Northeast region for the National Marine Fisheries Service, a branch of the Commerce Department that regulates the fishing industry.
Representative Barney Frank, the Massachusetts Democrat who inherited the New Bedford area in last year's Congressional redistricting, said of the fishermen: "They get hammered by huge fines. Some of these guys feel like they're the last guys shot in the war before the truce. They're not hurting anyone. They are guilty sometimes of working too hard."
 
Regulations at Issue
 At issue are two Government regulations that scallopers say have made them feel, and sometimes behave, like criminals, while forcing them to work harder for smaller catches.
One involves the Hague line, a boundary set by the World Court in 1984 to delineate the fishing waters of the United States and those of Canada. Fishing on the Canadian side of the line, patrolled by the Coast Guard and Canadian submarines, can bring penalties of up to $100,000, the forfeiture of boats and the loss of fishing permits.
In January, 12 boats, most of them scallopers, were cited by the Coast Guard for crossing the line. Eight of the catches were seized and sold, the proceeds held in an escrow account without interest pending appeals.
The second regulation is one devised by Federal officials in 1982 to protect baby scallops and thus future stocks. The rule, known as the meat count, limits the number of small scallops in an average pound. A catch is considered in violation if a random count shows that a pound contains more than 36.3 scallop meats per pound.
The biggest problem with the system, scallopers say, is that the maturity of a scallop cannot be accurately judged until the shell has been pried open to reveal the meat size, a process that kills the scallop, making it impractical to throw the undersized scallops back into the sea to reseed.
At sea, scallopers open the shells and weigh the meat in one-pound cranberry juice cans. The meats are then put in cloth bags and stored in the ship's hold on ice until they return to shore, where Federal inspectors often meet the boats to do random counts of the meats in the cloth bags. Scallopers complain that the system is ineffective and inaccurate and that counting meats at sea is difficult and time consuming.
 
Scallopers Rally
 After the recent Federal raids, the scallopers held a series of rallies demanding that the Government abolish the meat count. On Thursday, six scallopers tied their vessels to the pier, the fishing equivalent of a strike.
The scallopers want the meat count replaced with a "gross catch quota," which would simply limit the number of pounds per trip a vessel could harvest. They also want a moratorium on new commercial fishing permits.
On Monday, about two dozen fishermen, family members and fishing industry representatives are to go to Washington to lobby Commerce Department officials.
While the scallopers will fight on, Mr. Bruno said, their way of life seems to have been changed forever. Trips that once took 10 days at sea have been averaging 12 days since the meat count went into effect, and even the joy of returning home is gone.
"It used to be the nicest part of the trip," Mr. Bruno said of sighting the port. "Now it's hell day.
With all the tensions of the meat count, he said, "You're not looking forward to seeing your family after 12 days. You're worrying about whether your trip's going to get seized. You're worrying that you counted wrong. You're worrying about the fines."

HEADLINE: Gore Meets Resistance in Effort for Steps on Global Warming

BYLINE: By KEITH SCHNEIDER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
As President Clinton prepares to commemorate Earth Day with a speech on the environment, a dispute has broken out in the Administration over efforts by Vice President Al Gore to persuade Mr. Clinton to fulfill a campaign promise on specific steps to reduce the threat of global warming.
Mr. Gore, say aides in the White House and in several Cabinet agencies, has urged the President to commit the United States to freezing at 1990 levels the amount of global-warming pollutants pouring from cars, trucks and factories, a standard that would be reached by the year 2000. 
 Mr. Gore, the aides said, is arguing that such a commitment, promised during the 1992 campaign, would send an unmistakable message that the Clinton Administration is taking the lead in battling global environmental threats. Last year, Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore criticized President George Bush for rejecting an identical commitment proposed by the European Community.
 
Secretaries' Reservations
 But Mr. Gore's proposal has met resistance from several Cabinet members, principally Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary. Senior aides said both Secretaries contended that the Administration had not clearly studied how limiting air pollution from carbon dioxide, the principal source of scientific concern about global warming, would affect American industry.
The aides said such a commitment could also further endanger the energy tax Mr. Clinton has proposed. Opponents in Congress, the aides say, would seize on the commitment as proof that the Administration would seek to cut consumption of fossil fuels by drastically increasing the tax.
The aides, who spoke about the dispute only on the condition of anonymity, said that by the year 2000 the United States will be pouring 100 million metric tons more carbon dioxide into the atmosphere than it did in 1990. If Congress approves the energy tax, the Administration estimates that the amount of carbon dioxide would be reduced by 25 million metric tons by the end of the decade.
But the Administration has not yet figured out how to eliminate the rest, the aides said, and until it does officials in the Energy and Treasury Departments have urged the President not to make a commitment on global warming.
 
Balancing Earth and Economy
 Although the aides differed about the intensity of the dispute, they agreed that it has provided the most revealing look yet at the enormous political pressures involved as the Administration tries to make environmental and economic goals compatible.
The struggle also is crucial for Mr. Gore, who has made a political reputation and a best-selling literary debut by discussing ecological problems and how to solve them. Last month the White House overruled Mr. Gore, who had promised to shut down a hazardous waste incinerator in Ohio after the White House overruled him. And he has been virtually silent on environmental issues since his inauguration.
Marla Romash, the spokeswoman for Mr. Gore, said nothing had been decided about the proposal and that the President's speech, which he is to deliver on Wednesday, a day before Earth Day, was not yet written. "The President plans to commemorate Earth Day and to make clear this Administration's commitment to growing the economy and protecting the environment," she said. "There are no disagreements that I know of at all."
But aides at several other agencies who have been involved in the discussions at the White House about the speech contradicted Ms. Romash.
"We all want to get to the same goal but we are not in agreement on what is the most cost-effective way to benefit the global environment and the American economy," said a top aide at the Department of Energy. "It may take more time to work this out than we have before the President's speech. We support the commitment made during the campaign. The issue is how to get there."
Just as he did during the 1992 campaign, when he used Earth Day to deliver an important environmental policy address in Philadelphia, Mr. Clinton is apparently ready to make a splash again.
Aides in the White House and in other agencies say Mr. Clinton is considering announcing that he will reverse the Bush Administration's position and sign an international treaty to protect endangered plants and animals. Mr. Bush was widely criticized for his decision at the Earth Summit last year in Rio de Janeiro.
Mr. Clinton could also announce that he has approved Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt's plan to reorganize the scientific divisions in his department and establish a better scientific basis for managing the Department's more than 500 million acres of land.
But none of the ideas the White House is considering for inclusion in Mr. Clinton's speech have caused as much disagreement as the global-warming proposal. A commitment to reduce the levels of carbon dioxide that the United States puts into the atmosphere would affect every American, and put even more pressure on American industry to compete with Japanese and German manufacturers who already use energy more efficiently.
Carbon dioxide is a byproduct of burning oil, coal, natural gas and other fossil fuels and the only way to control it is to be much more judicious in using energy. The United States poured 1,381 million metric tons of carbon dioxide into the atmosphere in 1990 and is expected to increase that amount to 1,475 million metric tons by the year 2000, the Department of Energy says.
Carbon dioxide traps infrared radiation from the sun in the atmosphere, which raises the temperature on the ground. Concentrations of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere have been rising steadily over the last century but there is considerable dispute among scientists about whether that will present a significant ecological threat.

HEADLINE: Market Place

BYLINE: By Lawrence M. Fisher

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
AFTER Apple Computer Inc. announced a decline in earnings for its second fiscal quarter, analysts rushed to revise their estimates for the year. Some revised them downward, as one might expect, but some raised their estimates and others even issued new buy recommendations. Apple shares closed up 87.5 cents, at $48.125, when trading ended on Friday.
Analysts at Bear, Stearns; S. G. Warburg; Salomon and Sanford C. Bernstein upgraded their investment ratings. Lehman Brothers and First Boston maintained buy ratings, while analysts at Hambrecht & Quist; Merrill Lynch and Goldman, Sachs were negative. 
The Apple bulls contend that the pricing pressures on the company will abate in the second half of the year as new products become more available, and sales will continue to grow. The bears say that Apple has been promising earnings growth for some time now, and that maintaining margins will get harder, not easier, in the face of continuing price wars and shaky consumer confidence.
Even before Apple released its second-quarter results on Thursday, the analysts were pretty much split. For the quarter ended March 26, Apple reported earnings of 92 cents a share, below the $1 average of analysts' projections. But among individual analysts, the estimates had been as high as $1.15, while others were as little as 85 cents. So, the quarter was a big disappointment to some but a pleasant surprise to others.
"There was no consensus," said Doug van Dorsten, an analyst with Lehman Brothers in San Francisco. "There was an arithmetic mean of $1 a share, but there were no analysts at $1." He said any weakness in Apple's stock price represented a buying opportunity. Many of the new products introduced in the March quarter are only beginning to be shipped in quantity, he said, and they will contribute to sales growth.
Charles R. Wolf, an analyst with First Boston, also maintained his buy rating. Apple's managers, he noted, "are very bullish on the second half of the year."
"They expect to start cutting into their backlog," he said. "Gross margins might continue to deteriorate, but not nearly at the same rate as in the first and second quarters when they really slashed prices."
In anticipation of the new models, Apple sold older Macintosh models at deep discounts, which contributed to the erosion of its profit margins. Many of the products Apple introduced were "supply constrained," Apple-speak for not immediately available, and have added to its backlog. Bearish analysts say Apple may have missed the opportunity to sell these machines if consumer buying slows.
"The overall climate for PC sales is softening," because of changes in the tax code and a weakening of consumer confidence, said Bruce Lupatkin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist. "About the time Apple is ready to meet demand, there may be a lessening of demand."
While Apple has been saying it would show earnings growth in the second half, he added, "there doesn't seem to be much possibility of earnings growth before the fourth quarter."
Michelle Preston of Merrill Lynch also had a negative outlook. "We still expect an acceleration in revenue growth, but we now expect margin pressures to offset this improvement, resulting in a negative earnings comparison for the third quarter," she said. "While Apple's market-share gains and accelerating revenue momentum are positive, until we see the potential for positive earnings growth, we are remaining neutral on the stock."
Still other analysts said there was too much emphasis on the negative. "There is an excessive amount of concern about the quarter they just reported," as well as "an excessive amount of fear about the summer," said Andrew Neff of Bear Stearns, who raised his recommendation to "strong buy."
At Friday's closing price, Mr. Neff said, Apple has "a valuation of 10 times calendar-year earnings for what is probably one of the most profitable computer companies in the world."

HEADLINE: STRICTLY BUSINESS;
For Those Who Deliver, a Good Take

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN

 BODY:
Five years ago, Lois O'Neill found herself at a dead end. Her life had come down to a divorce, an unrewarding office job and three children to put through college.
So she took a small inheritance and bought a bread delivery route in Bergen County, N.J., for $18,000. She began going to work at 1 A.M. seven days a week, wearing a sweat suit rather than the high heels to which she was accustomed. 
 It paid off. By dint of hard work, she increased her number of stops to 45 from 20, thereby raising her annual income to $80,000 a year. She is now trying to sell the route for $110,000 so she can move to Arizona.
There has been just one drawback, the social one. "You don't meet the president of I.B.M. delivering bread at night," Ms. O'Neill says.
 
Big Business in Routes
 Truth to tell, she may have made some wiser economic decisions than I.B.M., considering how fast things are changing in this crazy economy. Some of the most unlikely folks are popping up in this arcane precinct of entrepreneurship -- the delivery of much of the merchandise you find on the shelves of grocery stores, delicatessens and even auto body shops.
"With so many people laid off and so few new job opportunities, men and women are now clamoring for routes," says Kenneth Sussman, president of The Route Brokers, a Great Neck, L.I.-based company that has made a business of matching buyers and sellers of routes.
Route Brokers, which employs nine agents in three metropolitan area offices, sells about 150 routes a year at an average price of $89,000, for which it earns a 10 percent commission paid by the seller. A buyer can expect to make $800 to $1,200 a week before taxes, and considerably more if he hustles to sign up more stops or more sales at existing stops.
In the last five years, Mr. Sussman says, more than 40 percent of the routes have been bought by people who previously had white-collar jobs. Women, who rarely used to be in the business, now account for one-tenth of route purchases.
"If you're a sales-oriented person, you can make a fortune," Mr. Sussman declares. Routes can sell for as little as $25,000, or as much as $500,000, he says.
He cites the success of a Long Island man whose brothers owned profitable Pepperidge Farm routes. Instead of following suit, the man took a chance on a Martin's Potato Rolls route in his native Brooklyn. He paid $39,000 for the route, then built its income to more than $1,200 a week through aggressive salesmanship. He sold the route in five pieces for a total of more than $200,000.
 
A List, a Territory and a Truck
 What you get when you buy a route is a list of customers, often a protected territory, usually a small truck of some sort and the right to pick up merchandise from a company like Coca-Cola, Ben & Jerry's Ice Cream or Wise's Potato Chips. But what you can almost never get is bank financing: sellers usually take a sizable downpayment, with the remainder in a personal note.
There are an estimated 7,500 independently owned routes, mostly in the food business, in the New York metropolitan area. Each month, Mr. Sussman or his staff hears from 250 owners interested in selling. About 125 turn out to be serious.
Companies began selling routes to independent drivers in this region in the mid-1960's, Mr. Sussman says, prompted partly by desires to escape vehicle maintenance and insurance. More important, a route owner has considerably more incentive to increase sales than an employee who is drawing a salary.
"If you have a personal stake in what you're doing, you'll do it a lot better than somebody who doesn't have that stake," says Neil Churchill, director of the Center for Entrepreneurial Studies at Babson College in Wellesley, Mass. "You can build a business with low capital, some ingenuity and a lot of perseverance."
Daniel J. Feld, the owner of the Saratoga Potato Chip Company, a five-year-old maker of gourmet snacks, studied a number of distribution systems before deciding on owner-operated routes. Initially, his approach was to give the routes away. Since then, some original owners have made profits by selling parts of their ever-more-profitable routes.
"This is the only way to make these routes work," Mr. Feld says. "It's a funny kind of arms-length, but very close, relationship."
Some see another aspect to the decision by some companies to sell routes. Audrey Freedman, an independent labor economist in Manhattan, says the practice is driven by companies' desires to shun unions, avoid wage and hour laws, and save on benefits. "Anything at all they can do to avoid having a permanent employee on the payroll, they'll do," she says.
 
'You Can Hustle'
 There are many roads to the route business. Frederick Berryhill of Freeport, L.I., worked for 11 years in sales support for the Xerox Corporation. He left Xerox in October to buy an auto tool route for $30,000, and began operating it in December. He enjoys not wearing suits, but even more, he relishes being his own boss.
"You can hustle," he says. "That's the whole idea."
Yamira Lopez, a 22-year-old mother of two who lives in Sunset Park in Brooklyn, used $39,000 from a jury award after an automobile accident to buy an Italian bread delivery route. She makes a pretax income of $1,000 a week, of which $200 goes to a part-time helper.
Her work days start at 3 A.M. and end around 11 A.M., when she returns home to ride herd over two preschool children. She hopes to sell the route in a year or so and buy a bigger one.
"I love having my own money in my hands," she says.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Lois O'Neill has made a bread delivery route in Bergen County, N.J., that she bought for $18,000 into a route that has raised her annual income to $80,000 a year. She prepared to begin her early morning route. (Norman Y. Lono for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Apartment Owners as Both Tenant and Landlord

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY

 BODY:
It is a bizarre New York City game, a real-estate version of musical chairs. To participate one only needs to own a co-op or condominium that cannot be sold and have a need or desire to live somewhere else.
While there are no hard figures on how many people have been thrust into this sometimes costly game, where apartment owners are landlords and tenants at the same time, anecdotal information suggests that the number of co-op owners who are subletting their apartments while they rent other places is growing. 
 The result is a convoluted spiral that can look like this:
Jerry Harmyk, who was moving his antiques dealership from the Upper East Side to Greenwich Village, wanted to live near his business. But with nary a nibble close to his asking price for his one-bedroom co-op on York Avenue in the 80's, he found a tenant instead, then signed a lease for a smaller apartment in the Village.
Now he is renting from a couple who also could not sell their apartment. And they in turn are renting from a family who were unable to sell their co-op near Columbia University.
 
Facing a Sure Loss
 "I started trying to sell my apartment just as the market started to drop," Mr. Harmyk said. "And because I took a second mortgage, if I sold now it would surely be at a loss. In fact I don't think I would even get the value of my mortgage out of the deal."
Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, one the largest rental agencies in the city, said situations like that of Mr. Harmyk and the other couples involved in his rental circle are becoming more common. Two-thirds of the 4,000 apartments Feathered Nest currently lists are in co-op or condominium buildings, she said, and the majority of them are being offered by people who either live or lived in them.
"When we first started listing condominiums more than 10 years ago, most were owned by investors who never occupied them," Ms. Packes said. "But as the co-op sales market worsened, we began seeing more apartments offered for rent by owners who could not sell but who wanted to move on."
The problems co-op and condominium owners have in selling their units can be traced to a four-year housing slump that has left many apartment owners reeling in the wake of declining prices. So severe has been the slide in prices -- 30 percent since the market's peak in 1988 -- that subletting apartments offers the owners the only palatable alternative to a financial bath.
While the phenomenon does not stop at New York city's borders, renting as an alternative to selling is more common in the city than in the suburbs because the city has more apartments and its rental tradition is stronger.
 
Subletting No Panacea
 The trend toward subletting is by no means a panacea. In some cases, co-op boards have refused to allow sublets. In others, the boards have added monthly fees for owners who sublet their apartments. At the same time, a soft rental market has meant sometimes accepting tenants who pay less than what is needed to meet mortgage and maintenance payments.
And for many people, the unaccustomed role of landlord is fraught with the usual perils of deadbeat, demanding or destructive tenants and the cost of having to make repairs. Some co-op and condominium owners admit to being squeamish at playing the roll of the hard-nosed landlord.
For their part, some tenants contend that subletting in co-ops and condominiums offers some of the nicest living spaces in the city, but the arrangement has its down side. What some apartment owners know about their responsibilities as landlords, some tenants say, leaves a lot to be desired. Other subletting tenants said they have been caught in the crossfire when apartment owners and their co-op boards battle over matters like subletting rights and apartment repairs.
"You are at the mercy of the quality of your owner's relationship with the board," said Leslie Deamer, who is renting a one-bedroom co-op in Brooklyn. "If the relationship is not good it can be a real burden."
Many owners with apartments they cannot sell bought them at the crest in the wave of co-op and condominium conversions that moved across the city in the 1980's, when prices seemed to escalate by the week and there was no end in sight to the dizzying rise in value.
 
Home Plan Fizzles

But starting with the stock market crash in 1987, prices for co-ops and condominiums started to tumble and a regional economy that refuses to be revived has kept a recovery at bay.
Susan Walsh, a secretary at a New York law firm, is one of those who bought just as the market was beginning to turn sour. Now she finds that trying to sell is harder than she ever imagined. After her divorce, Mrs. Walsh paid $165,000 for a studio apartment in the 70's on the Upper East Side. The plan was for her to live in the apartment for a year or two before selling, possibly at a profit. She expected to use the money from the sale for a home in the suburbs.
It did not work that way. Not realizing that the market was unraveling, Mrs. Walsh passed up an offer that would have allowed her to break even. Soon it became apparent that any sale would result in a loss.
Mrs. Walsh does live in the suburbs now -- in an apartment she rents on Long Island.
"I just signed a lease with my third tenant," said Mrs. Walsh, who moved out of her Manhattan apartment five years ago. "I am relieved to have someone in the apartment but it is frustrating that I can't get my money out so we can buy a house."
 
Subletting 2 Studios
 Marlene Lee and her husband, Paulo Bolivar, are also frustrated owners who cannot sell. They recently bought a two-bedroom apartment on the Upper West Side. But each has a tenant in studio apartments they owned and occupied before they married. Mr. Bolivar, a New York-based news producer for a Brazilian television network, admits that his first effort at subletting was a disaster.
"I was not tough enough with the first tenant and he really took advantage of that," Mr. Bolivar said.
The tenant dodged Mr. Bolivar's efforts to collect the rent and eventually moved without notice, taking with him an Oriental rug and other furnishings.
"The apartment was a mess when he left," said Mr. Bolivar who has turned the couple's property-management chores over to his wife.
Even though they have found responsible tenants for both apartments, Ms. Lee said, their subletting headaches h have not ended. The co-op board of the building where she owns recently introduced a policy requiring a $105 monthly fee for sublets.
"There is only so much you can charge these days for a studio apartment," said Ms. Lee, who works in the design department at Donna Karan in Manhattan. "I do not see how I can pass this on to my tenant."
She has heard that other owners in the building are angry about the fee and plan to fight it. If the policy is not rescinded, she will have a monthly shortfall between what her tenant pays and her own expenses.
Mary Ann Rothman, executive director of the Council of New York Cooperatives, a nonprofit support organization for co-ops and condominiums, said that some co-op boards use the fees as a way of discouraging subletting without banning it.
"The subletting issue is one of the most difficult that boards now face," said Ms. Rothman, adding that many boards are trying to extend relief to apartment owners facing financial hardship while at the same time addressing the concerns of other shareholders about sublets.
One of those concerns, Ms. Rothman said, is how subletting might affect other units. Some banks have tightened their requirements for issuing mortgages, often requiring that at least 50 to 60 percent of the units be occupied by the owners.
Permission to sublet is not what is keeping Dr. Edward Soufer's apartment vacant. Dr. Soufer bought two condominiums during the boom years with the intent of making them into one large unit. He later decided instead to rent one of the units, a two-bedroom with spectacular views of downtown Manhattan and the East River. Though he does not need any approval to put in a tenant, he has not been able to replace the family that moved out last August.
"First I could not find a buyer," said Dr. Soufer, who is asking $3,500 a month for the apartment. "And now I can't find a tenant. How far do values have to drop before we see an end to this?"

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Confronting Urban Ills, 2 Senators Face Reality

BYLINE: By Sam Roberts

 BODY:
THERE he goes again.
This time, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan did not single out blacks. But the searing lecture he delivered last week on the social consequences of family disintegration managed to offend, among others, Mayor David N. Dinkins and Representative Charles B. Rangel by waxing nostalgic about the good old days when more families may have been intact, but neglecting to mention that the old days were not so good for blacks still subject to legal segregation. 
 In some respects, though, many blacks face even tougher hurdles today because of the very social conditions that Mr. Moynihan had the courage to acknowledge. And critics who also faulted him for being short on solutions forget that no elected official has been hectoring the Clinton Administration more to make meaningful changes in the welfare system.
Mr. Moynihan was expanding on a theme he sounded earlier this year in The American Scholar, when he wrote that "we have been redefining deviancy so as to exempt much conduct previously stigmatized." He offered three categories of redefinition: "The altruistic, may be illustrated by the deinstitutionalization movement within the mental health profession that appeared in the 1950's. The second category, the opportunistic, is seen in the interest group rewards derived from the acceptance of 'alternative' family structures. The third category, the normalizing, is to be observed in the growing acceptance of unprecedented levels of violent crime."
While New York's senior senator was delivering his stern warning to civic leaders in Manhattan last week, Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey was in Paterson gauging the depth of despair and the grounds for hope that inspired him to introduce a six-point "urban community-building initiative."
"I've gotten a lot of personal stories that confirm the basic three problems of violence, joblessness and family disintegration," said Mr. Bradley, who last year qualified, like Mr. Moynihan before him, as a profile in candor for articulating America's unspoken obsession with race.
One elderly couple who had lived in Paterson for three decades said their neighbors were pretty nice except for the occupants of one house on the block. Drug dealers? Mr. Bradley asked.
"I'm afraid to say anything," the woman replied.
"But the premise of my urban package was also confirmed," Mr. Bradley said. "A Hispanic couple was waiting at the teller's window in one of the few bank branches in the area. They said they were putting in only $100. I asked how much they made and saved a year and they said they have five kids, made less than $20,000 and still managed to save $3,000. There are the people who need to be given a better chance."
Mr. Bradley's modest $1.44 billion-a-year package seeks to replicate what works. His Assets for Independence Act would allow anyone with an income of up to twice the poverty line to contribute up to $2,000 to an "individual development account" to buy a first home, pay for college education or for retirement or to start a small business. Government would provide money to community-based nonprofit groups to match the savings.
His package also includes a Neighborhood Reconstruction Corps to train youths and match private investment in public works; money to keep schools open after normal hours to provide students with a safe haven and a mentor; support for community development financial institutions that re-invest deposits in the community; grants to community colleges and community development corporations to train people for self-employment; Federal subsidies to expand community policing; investment in van services and other means of connecting jobless city dwellers with suburban jobs; and a network of "Fifteen-Month Houses" that offer poor and young mothers a place to live, health care and counseling during the third trimester of pregnancy and the first year of life.
He echoes the Kerner Commission report -- and a follow-up this year sponsored by the Milton S. Eisenhower Foundation -- that American cities are suffering from "not just the failure of spending, but the failure of imagination." In contrast to President Clinton's stalled jobs bill, the Senator said, "These are all new, innovative, grass-roots-up programs -- not Federal bureaucrats putting a pot of money out there and attracting people who want the money. These provide resources at points of leverage.
"The eight bills in this initiative are based on creative programs that have already worked on the local level, supported by communities and undertaken without government assistance," he said. "This initiative gives these local programs a national test, so we can see what works and what doesn't. The cost of the program is $1.44 billion per year -- slightly more than the cost of four days of rioting in South Central Los Angeles last April."
Even after the rioting last year, Mr. Bradley said, "I was astounded at how few people stood up and said, 'Let's confront our reality.' " Will the quiet riot that consumes America's cities every day inspire public officials to confront reality as boldly as Senators Bradley and Moynihan have? Will Congress compromise on the President's jobs bill, much less seriously consider Mr. Bradley's urban agenda?
"If Los Angeles were to erupt again, there's usually a paroxysm throughout the nation that lasts about a month and that says we have to do something about the cities," Representative Charles E. Schumer of Brooklyn said last week. "The timing, in a perverse way, is that may be the month when the jobs compromise has to be negotiated."
So no blood, no guts?
"Strange world we live in," Mr. Schumer said.

HEADLINE: Privatization To Reshape Peru Market

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LIMA, Peru

 BODY:
In Latin America's most radical privatization program, Peru has embarked on a plan to auction off virtually all its state-owned companies over the next two years -- including oil, electric, telephone, and mining companies and the railroad that takes tourists to the Incan ruins at Machu Picchu.
With investors already poring over company prospectuses, the privatizations are expected to reshape Peru's economy in a free-market mold, tripling foreign investment and dismantling a socialist legacy left by a leftwing military Government of the 1970's. 
 "There are no sacred cows," said Carlos Montoya, a Stanford-trained economist who is overseeing the drive to sell 70 state companies by 1995.
 
Investment Missions Overseas
 When the dust settles, it is unclear whether the United States will retain its traditional rank as Peru's largest foreign investor. Investment missions are promoting Peru in China and Japan, and to encourage Asian investment, the Government is adopting a program of granting Peruvian passports to foreigners who pay $25,000 to Peru's treasury. Latin American neighbors are also being courted.
"Now is the precise time to invest in Peru, since it is just opening to foreign capital," Miguel Bauzar, a Chilean businessman, told reporters after leading a delegation of Chilean investors here for a meeting with President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru. "Now is when we Latin American businessmen have the chance, because later on the multinationals will arrive and we will not have so many opportunities."
In recent months, investor confidence has soared in Peru. Police have captured leaders of the nation's two guerrilla groups. And the inauguration in January of a new Congress has softened international criticism of Mr. Fujimori's authoritarian rule.
By the end of 1992, Lima's stock index had risen in real terms by 138 percent, ranking it second only to Jamaica's in terms of growth among world markets. With an eye on the coming privatizations, investors had bid up stock prices on companies scheduled for full privatization this year. Last month saw the debut of the first internationally traded mutual fund for Peru.
"We have doubled our staff, from 33 last year to 60 today, and have added a stock brokerage," said Ivan Carrillo Chavez, a vice president here for Citibank del Peru, the only United States bank operating in Peru.
In December, the United States Overseas Private Investment Corporation signed an agreement with Peru to extend insurance protection and investment credits to American investors here. The last agreement was suspended by Peru's military rulers in 1968.
 
Negotiating Loan Repayments
 In March, with the United States providing financial and political support, Peru repaid debts to the World Bank and to the International Monetary Fund and re-entered the international financial community after a six-year absence. Low-interest loans from multilateral banks are expected to amount to $1 billion this year. In May, talks are to start to negotiate repayment terms for Peru's $8 billion debt to private foreign banks.
Further increasing Peru's attractiveness has been the adoption of an investment code described by one American economist here as "the most open foreign investment regime on the continent." The code allows free repatriation of capital, erases legal distinctions between national and foreign capital, and allows international arbitration of disputes.
"Peru is offering a friendly economic and political environment -- and we are encouraged by that," said D. Michael Rounds, a spokesman for the Cyprus Minerals Company of Englewood, Colo. The company, a major copper producer, has been inspecting state mining properties that are to be sold. Mining accounts for half of Peru's export revenues.
"American mining companies seem to be showing interest through their Chilean subsidiaries," Daniel Hokama, Minister of Mines and Energy, said. Chileans, who share an Andean geology similar to Peru's, endured terrorism and political turmoil during the 1970s.
 
Foreign Investment in Mining
 Reflecting growing American interest, the Newmont Mining Corporation, which is based in Denver, is starting a $36 million investment to develop a gold mine in northern Peru. In projects bound to reverse Peru's declining minerals production, five foreign companies have drawn up plans to invest almost $1 billion in Peruvian mining operations through 1995.
Given Peru's reputation as a high-risk nation, properties here are considered to be among the cheapest in the world.
"Because of the situation that Peru has endured for the last 10 years, values are well below their real value," President Fujimori said in an interview in early April. Last year, Mr. Fujimori succeeded in lowering inflation to 57 percent, its lowest level in 15 years. But economic activity has continued to fall, dropping 20 percent since 1980.
Last fall, Mantos Blancos, a Chilean subsidiary of the Anglo-American Corporation of South Africa, paid $12 million for a copper deposit owned by Minero Peru, a state company. In Chile, Mantos Blancos paid $190 million for a deposit of similar size.
With $500 million in oil-related investments planned for Peru over the next two years, 12 of the 20 private oil companies operating here are American, including the Petrotech International Corporation, which won the bidding to operate for 20 years the offshore reserves of Petromar, a subsidiary of the state comnpany. Starved of investment, Peru's oil industry saw production drop by half in the 1980's, converting the nation from an oil exporter to an importer.
Private business participation accounts for the Government's confidence that it will sell all 70 companies by July 1995, the end of Mr. Fujimori's presidential term.
To get Peru's state companies in shape for sale to private investors, the Fujimori Government restored public utility rates to profitable levels and slashed payrolls and costs. The cutbacks, which eliminated tens of thousands of jobs, reduced state company losses to about $300 million in 1992 from $3 billion in 1990.
Although entrenched interests have tried to block each of the 14 privatizations carried out so far, completed sales have netted the Government $250 million.
"When we sold the gas stations, it turned out that the man responsible for renewing licenses was charging $50,000 under the table and had built up a small real estate fortune in Miami," said Jaime Yoshiyama, a Harvard-trained businessman who directed the privatization campaign before becoming president of Peru's Congress in January.
Initially, employees of Enatru, the state bus company, opposed its sale. It turned out that fare collectors were sweeping ticket stubs off floors, ironing them and reselling them, tripling their salaries but draining millions of dollars a month from the company.

HEADLINE: Wells Fargo's Rebate Card

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 18

 BODY:
Wells Fargo Bank has introduced a credit card offering consumers up to $1,000 in yearly rebates to trim their mortgage costs.
The new "California Advantage" Visa or MasterCard, announced last week, will offer a $5 rebate for every $100 purchase made with the card. The rebate can be applied to closing costs or interest charges when customers take out a home loan or refinance a mortgage from Wells. 
 The rebate limit on a regular card is $700 each year with a $3,500 five-year maximum; for the Gold Card, the figures are $1,000 each year up to a $5,000 maximum.
Wells Fargo officials hope the card will enhance the bank's mortgage lending business. It ranks far behind a main rival, the Bank of America.
Wells's standard card holder would have to charge $14,000 a year -- more than six times the average charged on credit cards -- to earn the maximum rebate.
Interest rates on the Advantage card are slightly higher than on other Wells cards. And if the customer cannot qualify for a home loan, the rebate would be worthless.

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 361 words

HEADLINE: Wicks Law Reform Can't Wait

 BODY:
Here's a simple question for New York State legislators: Do they answer to taxpayers, or to the powerful trade unions that contribute to their re-election campaigns? That's the issue as debate renews in Albany over a relic known as the Wicks Law.
Enacted in 1921, the law bars local governments from awarding construction jobs by low bid to a single general contractor. That's the system widely used in private industry, by the Federal Government and most states. In New York, however, municipalities must hire at least four separate contractors: for general construction, plumbing, electrical, and heating and ventilation work. 
 The law was intended to increase competition and reduce costs. But the result is a coordination nightmare that scares away responsible bidders and leads to huge overruns, shoddy workmanship and endless court fights.
Indeed, the state budget office has estimated that the multiple contracting requirement adds nearly $400 million a year to the cost of government construction. A new report by a team of outside economists hired by the New York City School Construction Authority concludes that projects exempted from Wicks cost 13 percent less and were completed 15.6 months more quickly than Wicks projects.
For years, the plumbing, electrical and heating trades have fought efforts to rescind the law with lobbying and political gifts to both parties. But with government money still tight, and local officials and school boards now joining the fray, Wicks law reform stands a chance this year.
A measure sponsored by Assemblyman Steven Sanders, a Manhattan Democrat, and Senator Roy Goodman, a Manhattan Republican, would give local governments the option of following the law or not. With fine-tuning to prevent unfair bid shopping by general contractors, the bill deserves passage.
Governor Cuomo pledged not to seek repeal of Wicks until next year, when the School Construction Authority's five-year exemption from the law expires. But, with a reform movement clearly under way, he has voiced strong support for scuttling Wicks now. His help is needed to persuade legislative leaders not to stall another year.

HEADLINE: Tax Balloons and Common Sense

 BODY:
President Clinton's agents have once again floated the notion of a national value-added tax to pay for universal health care. Until he broaches the health plan, though, it is idle to speculate about how he would finance it and senseless to let the financing divert everyone's attention.
As a seasoned politician, Mr. Clinton surely knows the risk of coupling two major controversies -- over health care and a new system of taxation. Indeed, the talk of a valued-added tax may be nothing more than the White House signaling that the health plan's cost will be formidable. 
 The President mentioned the possibility of a value-added tax in February, but acknowledged then that it would mark a "radical change" in the nation's taxation, suggesting that it might be considered at some future time, but not now. A value-added tax is a tax on the value that is added to goods and services at each step through the entire process of production and marketing -- finally, a tax on consumption.
Value-added systems are widely used in other industrial countries. They are favored by a growing band of American politicians -- at least partly because they can yield huge revenues -- and by economists concerned about America's low rate of savings and investment.
But liberal opponents argue that valued-added taxes, like sales taxes, are fundamentally regressive; they hit the poor disproportionately, because the poor spend more of their income than the rich do. And conservatives, worried about the growth of government, quail at the gusher of revenues the taxes can produce, undetected by consumers who can't see how much tax is built into a product's price.
Whatever the merit of a value-added system, one thing is sure: If President Clinton proposes yet another new tax, the Republicans won't let him forget it. On this move, all the political signs flash caution. Moreover, the rules of common sense say that before floating trial balloons about taxes, the White House should consult the bipartisan Senate group that is studying consumption-based taxes. If a consumption tax is coming, it should fit in with a considered plan for tax reform.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Economy Looks Up, at Least for Now

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR

 BODY:
When a blizzard gripped the East Coast in March, it took a wicked slice out of the economy and raised questions about the durability of the expansion. But as the weather has improved, consumers have been returning to stores -- and business executives and economists are breathing easier.
"Once the weather broke, they're flocking back into the stores," said Bernard Marcus, chairman and chief executive of Home Depot, the nation's largest home improvement retailer. 
 Judi Freni, an associate merchan
diser at London Fog Ladies Sportwear, a national chain of discount outlets, also saw an improvement. "In the last week our business has picked up dramatically," she said.
Nor are the gains limited to retailers. Car sales in early April were above early February's level. Mortgage applications remain at a high level. Weekly jobless claims have edged down. And the ABC/Money magazine poll suggests that consumer confidence has rebounded in the last month.
That is not to say that the rest of the year will continue on track.
Executives and economists alike worry that the talk of new taxes from Washington could hurt consumers' willingness to spend -- or throw even more sand into the gears of the sluggish jobs recovery. They are particularly worried that a national sales tax in the form of a value added tax would weaken consumption and that possible new mandates for employers -- like a minimal health insurance package for workers -- would drive up business costs, including the costs of hiring new workers.
"Merchants and shoppers are concerned that higher taxes would affect discretionary spending," said Mark Hunter, general manager of the Woodland Hills Mall near Tulsa, Okla.
And Kenneth A. Macke, chairman of Dayton Hudson, the department store and discount retailer based in Minneapolis, added: "We think consumers remain extremely leery, with good reason. They are being bombarded with budget news. They are being bombarded with health-care plans. Last Thursday, they were treated to the V.A.T. tax."
Nor does the improvement settle the question -- asked by Clinton Administration officials who are plugging for a public works jobs package -- of whether job gains will pick up strength.
A reliable reading on the economy's basic momentum, economists say, probably will not be available until May data start to come in. March was knocked down by bad weather. April is being affected by catch-up buying and the fact that Easter fell earlier this year than last.
The unexpected weakness in March may have reinforced feelings that the economy is still vulnerable, and could strengthen the President's hand in winning some kind of public works jobs program. At the same time, though, it could inhibit the Administration on other fronts.
Labor Secretary Robert B. Reich has said that he will not ask for a higher minimum wage now and, according to members of the health-care-policy task force, has warned that placing too great a burden on employers could lead to even fewer jobs for younger, less skilled workers.
For now, at least, economists are concluding that consumers probably will keep spending, if cautiously, and that the basic ingredients for modest increases in spending are there.
"We won't get back to the 4 or 5 percent rate of last fall," said David Lereah, chief economist at the Mortgage Bankers Association, speaking of the nation's growth rate, "but we'll grow at around a 3 percent rate when all this weather clears up."
Take income and jobs. The March drop in employment followed two months of solid gains, and the economy added twice as many jobs in the last quarter as in the fall, 713,000 vs. 297,000.
 
More Hiring Seen
 "We got a lot of output from the productivity boom at the end of last year," said David Kelly, an economist at the Boston Company. "But now, employers are biting the bullet and hiring more workers. That's generating wage income to fuel the recovery."
In the last six months, Mr. Kelly estimates, real disposable personal income has been growing at a 3.5 percent annual rate.
Then there is consumer confidence. Confidence, which zoomed after President Clinton's election, dropped sharply this winter, reversing more than a third of that rise between January and early April. But the ABC/Money magazine poll, a weekly survey that more analysts are paying attention to, suggests that consumers may be starting to feel a bit better, not so much about the economy in general, but about their own finances.
The latest reading of the poll, for the April 10-11 weekend, shows that 51 percent of the respondents rated their personal finances excellent or good -- the highest level since the mood started to darken at the beginning of the year. That was up from 43 percent a month ago
 
Home Prices Stabilize
 "Consumers feared taxes for 1992 were going to be horrendous, and it hasn't turned out to be quite as bad," said Jordon Goodman, who directs the poll for Money magazine. "A lot of people I talked to are getting refunds that they didn't think they'd get."
Consumers' balance sheets are also in slightly better shape than they were a year ago. The price of most Americans' biggest assets -- their homes -- is no longer falling. Income has been growing slightly faster than consumer installment debt. And refinancing of mortgages has put more dollars into many peoples' pockets. That has helped make consumers slightly more willing to squeeze savings and take on a bit more debt.
"Consumers have swung from being slight repayers to slight borrowers," said Edward McKelvey, an economist at Goldman, Sachs.
The biggest impetus for moderate increases in spending, though, is that consumers have put off buying for so long.
"The average age of a car is now 7.9 years," Mr. Kelly of the Boston Company said. "There's underlying pent-up demand."
Sales of clothing were especially strong last year, he added. "You can only go so long without new clothes," he said. "That pent-up demand surfaced strongly in 1992 even though the economic fundamentals weren't that great."
Some of that buying is already heartening merchants.
At J. C. Penney in Chicago, sales have rebounded since mid-March, said Ira Silver, a marketing manager for the store. Occupancy at the Woodland Hills Mall near Tulsa just hit 95 percent, according to Mr. Hunter, the general manager, and mall traffic has been heavy in recent weeks, he said.
 
Housing Is Optimistic
 Housing industry executives are also cautiously optimistic. "We expected housing to be very strong in February and March," said Mr. Lereah of the Mortgage Bankers Association. "Bad weather kept that from happening. So we expect better-than-modest home buying activity in April and May."
Of course, all this activity is still not expected to push the economy to the 4.7 percent growth rate of the fourth quarter of last year. It is widely expected that growth this year will be closer to 3 percent.
And despite the zigs and the zags, business experts say that number is likely to hold.
"When the year is done, it will be a little better than last year but a little less good than many retailers expected," Mr. Macke of Dayton Hudson said.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 1993, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about signs of improvement in the economy misstated the period in which employment growth more than doubled, and the comparative period in 1992. The economy added 713,000 jobs in the six months ended March 31, compared with 297,000 jobs in the six months ended Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Having a President to Battle With Gives Dole a New Spirit and Verve

SERIES: The Lawmakers: Portraits of the Titans Of Capitol Hill -- Fourth article
in a series.

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
In this power-focused capital, an ultimate insider is finding new satisfaction in a seemingly diminished role, the minority leadership of a party suddenly thrust from power.
 After eight years of trying to serve the competing interests of two Republican Presidents and a few dozen Republican senators as the party's leader in the Senate, Bob Dole is having the time of his life. He is now in a role that really suits his personality better, the scrappy underdog challenging a popular President. 
The Senate minority leader has baffled the Clinton Administration and united the sometimes fractious Senate Republicans in opposition to the President's plan to stimulate the economy. He has already won on that fight; President Clinton's retreat to $15.5 billion from $19.5 billion on Friday was probably only the first step on a road toward a compromise that will have to be counted an Administration setback.
 
Liberation From Defeat
 One reason Mr. Dole succeeds is single-mindedness and persistence. It is no burden for him to hold one meeting after another, with the same people, on the same subject, in search of consensus.
 "Politics is his life," observed Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the deputy Republican leader. "You might be sitting at a dinner with Bob Dole and somebody might be talking about ball scores and somebody else about Washingtoniana and Bob would say: 'I think there's a primary going on in the Fifth District of California. Let's see how it's going.' "
 Under President George Bush, Mr. Dole loyally supported White House programs despite doubts about them and a bitter 1988 primary campaign when he made it clear that he considered Mr. Bush privileged and shallow. Now Mr. Bush's defeat seems to have liberated the Kansas Senator.
 Mr. Dole did tell a recent Gridiron Club dinner that Mr. Bush's 1992 campaign had gone pretty well, considering it was Dr. Jack Kevorkian's first try as a campaign manager. But the Senator's conversation is not dotted, as it once was, with class-conscious references like charges that when Ivy League colleges admitted relatives of alumni, mostly white males, they were violating the Civil Rights Act.
 The political difference between having a Republican President to support and a Democratic President to challenge is even more obvious. In opposition "you sort of get to pick your shots," Mr. Dole said last week in his Capitol office overlooking the Mall and the Washington Monument. "But if you're out there for the Administration, every day is a new bucket of water," defending programs someone else devised.
 
Personality Is Unchanged
 Now Mr. Dole can gauge Republican sentiment, and decide not to battle a widely supported family leave bill, then mount a filibuster against a less popular economic stimulus measure after Republican anger over Democratic steamroller tactics mounted.
 But if the political environment has dramatically changed, the personality of the five-term Senator has not. Mr. Dole bantered easily with hecklers in New Hampshire several times last Thursday, until one said the Senator did not care about America. Then Mr. Dole glared and, before striding off, pointed to a lapel pin of the Society of the Purple Heart, which he earned from a wound in World War II that cost him the use of his right arm.
 Last Wednesday, on the 48th anniversary of the battle in the Po Valley where he was wounded, he told fellow veterans of the Italian campaign with the 10th Mountain Division, "Maybe those of us who have been in combat or somewhere, understanding how bad it can be, can understand" the need to provide aid to bolster democracy in Russia. "It's in our interest if we want to avoid future conflicts, which may involve our children or our grandchildren."
 He talked at one stop after another about the fight against Mr. Clinton's package to stimulate the economy, insisting that Republicans would rather cut spending than add to the deficit. Today on the NBC program "Meet the Press," Mr. Dole again rejected Mr. Clinton's proposal, saying it "doesn't focus on the basic issue, which is paying for it." But he has said that in a $6 trillion economy, the money involved in the bill itself was rather inconsequential.
 Mr. Dole has never been known as a legislative innovator, but instead as one who takes his greatest pleasure in untangling snarls -- that he may have helped to create -- and saving a crucial measure, like the civil rights and unemployment bills of 1991. And in fact he talks of the fight against the economic stimulus bill as a tactical success that may help on bigger issues.
 "I hope it's a signal to the people who run the White House, not just the President, but others, that we have quite a few thoughtful people on our side," he said in the Capitol interview.
 As he continued, Mr. Dole made it clear how that signal should be read. "We thought we were going to be consulted on health care," he said, "and we haven't heard zip, not since Mrs. Clinton stood right here and talked to 35 of us" on Feb. 4.
 He made the same points whenever he was questioned on the subject as he traveled the country last week. "If ever there was one issue that cried out for bipartisan or nonpartisan consideration, it's health care," he told the Chamber of Commerce in Manchester, N.H. Health care, he told former campaign workers there, is "one of the most important issues that I've been exposed to in all the time I've been here."
 But if health legislation is something he wants to help pass, there are plenty of other measures Mr. Dole would like to block. He predicted a successful filibuster against legislation to revise campaign financing, for example, saying Democrats would write a bill to help themselves, not the country.
 He is plainly sensitive to the risk that if a bill is popular the public will see the delayers as the villains. The Administration has earnestly shouted "gridlock" about the stimulus bill, saying Republicans were thwarting efforts to create jobs. In Praise of Gridlock
 So Mr. Dole is trying to rehabilitate the word "gridlock" itself from the scorn into which it fell as a description of the inability of the Democratic Congress and the Republican President to get anything done last year. "If you're against something," he told some editors in Concord, N.H., "you'd better hope there is a little gridlock."
 In fact, Mr. Dole says he does not expect to thwart Mr. Clinton all that often, although Senate Republicans have delayed almost every bill this year for a while. "You're not going to win them all by a long shot," he said, because Republicans "don't always agree on everything." The most obvious example was the family leave bill, which Mr. Dole strongly opposed but 16 of the 43 Senate Republicans voted for.
 And there will be times, as he insisted to one audience after another, when Republicans will be providing support that Mr. Clinton cannot do without, on issues like aid to Russia or international trade.
 Then he told the Chamber of Commerce: "We're not mad at each other. We're both adults. We both understand that from time to time we'll have differences." And he said again and again that while Republicans disagreed with President Clinton "we're not trying to embarrass" him.
 Mr. Dole's national reputation for bitter comments is at odds with the sense of most senators that his humor is a useful safety valve to relieve tension. Nationally, he is remembered for speaking of "Democrat wars" in his first national campaign, for the Vice Presidency in 1976, and in 1988 for demanding that Mr. Bush and his aides stop "groveling in the mud" in attacking his wife, Elizabeth, and "stop lying about my record."
 
Humor and Honesty
 But Senator Orrin G. Hatch of Utah recalls that Mr. Dole's dry humor relaxed Republicans uncertain about how to proceed with questioning in the hearings involving Prof. Anita F. Hill's accusations against Judge Clarence Thomas. And Senator John H. Chafee of Rhode Island recalled how Mr. Dole broke up Mr. Clinton and Republicans at a caucus; the President was given a mystery novel titled "Murder in the Senate" and observed that he was troubled that the victim was a Democrat. Mr. Dole quipped, "Yes, it had a happy ending."
 His humor sometimes turns on himself, as an instinctive check. Mr. Dole was holding forth in the Senate on Inauguration Day about how Republicans had no intention of blocking Mr. Clinton's initiatives. Then, as if overcome by honesty, he added, "Except maybe once in a while."
 And at one point in his complaints about exclusion from the President's health-care task force, he reflected: "I'm trying to be objective. What would we do if we had the majority in Congress and the White House? Would we care what the other party thought? I think we might." But he then acknowledged that Republican White House aides might not.
 One consequence of his new prominence as his party's leading spokesman is a flurry of talk about his running for President in 1996, and Mr. Dole enjoyed teasing New Hampshire Republicans about it last week.
 Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, says Mr. Dole would be "a formidable opponent" for President Clinton. But Mr. Mitchell and Mr. Dole are friends, who respect and try not to surprise each other. In fact, Mr. Dole's considerable political skills have rarely traveled well outside the singular circumstances of the Senate or audiences of highly partisan Republicans.
 
Great Strength in Senate
 But if there is little reason to think Mr. Dole can improve on his past performance as a national candidate, there is little doubt of his strength in the Senate. Senator John C. Danforth of Missouri, a less conservative Republican than Mr. Dole on most issues though a firebrand on the economic stimulus bill, nominated him for the leadership after the 1984 election and said, "Bob Dole has soul." Last week Mr. Danforth said Mr. Dole was "not a bomb thrower; he's a legislator."
 In the Bush Administration, Mr. Dole was often caught between conservatives who wanted to fight the President from one side and moderates who were dissatisfied from the other, though it was the conservatives who gave him the most trouble.
 But none of them are complaining these days.
 Senate Republicans are surprised to be so united and so effective. For, as Mr. Dole says, under the Senate rules, which require 60 votes to shut off debate, "As long as we have 41 standing together, they can't pass anything."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Radio Station Consolidation Threatens Small Operators

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

 BODY:
In the seven months since the Federal Communications Commission eased regulations to allow a single owner to buy up to four radio stations in one metropolitan area, 730 stations, or nearly 7 percent of the industry, have signed deals that will lead to ownership changes.
The consolidation set off by relaxing the ownership rules is likely to reduce the number of owners among the nation's 9,700 stations by 25 percent or more by 1994, industry experts estimate. 
 "If it unfolds to its natural conclusion, it will be an industry of haves and have-nots," said Dan Duman, president of York Street Partners, an investment banking firm that specializes in media deals. "Mom and pop broadcasters will be forced to sell."
Broadcasters have pressed for years for liberalized ownership rules, noting the many stations in distress. Since 1982, competition for advertisers has heated up, as the Government granted broadcasting licenses to 1,700 more stations and as cable television became a greater rival for both audiences and advertising dollars.
Radio industry revenue fell 3 percent in 1991, to $8.6 billion, the first decline in more than a decade. Nearly 59 percent of stations were unprofitable in 1991, according to the most recent figures available from the National Association of Broadcasters.
 
One Owner Can Have 36 Stations
 The new rules permit a station owner to have 18 AM and 18 FM stations, including 2 of each in a single market. Previously, an owner could have no more than 12 AM stations and 12 FM stations nationwide, with only one of each in a single market.
Proponents of the changes say listeners will benefit as economies of scale return financial vigor to stations, which can then afford more public-service programming and music aimed at niche audiences.
"The business dictated these changes," said Richard Blackburn, president of Blackburn & Company, a radio broker in Washington. "When revenue declined, even while the economy was healthy, new entrants in markets undersold each other and led to a downward spiral." He said that one of his clients, who owns a classical music station, had told him, "I'm a niche player, and if I don't get bigger, I'm going to go away."
It is also likely, however, that industry employment will shrink and that small broadcasters will be squeezed out. Some critics have opposed the changes for fear that broadcast mergers, by reducing the diversity of ownership, will reduce viewpoints and programming choices.
Bill Shearer, owner of KGFJ-AM in Los Angeles and former chairman of the National Association of Black-Owned Broadcasters, said most of the owners who are members of minority groups might find themselves at risk. The association's members own 160 stations, many of them poorly financed and with weak signals; if deals are done, they are more likely to be targets than buyers.
And Mr. Shearer said that he feared the new owners would be large, white-owned companies with little taste for black radio formats. "Fear is lack of knowledge," he said. "They will back away from urban music."
But radio executives say that programming at their newly acquired stations has largely been left untouched, while savings are coming from cuts among a station's average work force, usually about 20 employees. General managers, business managers, bookkeepers and receptionists typically are the first to get pink slips.
 
Group Owners Take the Lead
 As expected, broadcasting groups are leading the way in buying stations, making deals that would not have been permitted before the rules took effect in September.
For example, Shamrock Broadcasting, based in Burbank, Calif., has agreed to acquire the Malrite Communications Group of Cleveland in a stock swap valued at $300 million. The merger will be the industry's largest, and Shamrock's holdings will jump to 21 stations from 14. The company will own two stations each on AM and FM frequencies in San Francisco alone.
Most group owners are scrambling to double their AM-FM holdings in markets where they own a property. Many of the marriages stem from the exercise of option-to-buy clauses granted by hard-pressed broadcasters, who have effectively leased their stations to other operators under so-called local marketing agreements.
Such deals were unheard of three years ago, but now about 250 exist, according to Radio Business Report, a trade publication based in Springfield, Va.
 
Economies of Scale
 Established broadcasters say they achieve several objectives by pairing stations. They can consolidate operations, reduce costs, increase market share and typically increase advertising rates.
In a no-cash deal worth about $15 million, Viacom International Inc., based in New York, and Noble Broadcasting of San Diego, swapped stations in Seattle and Denver. Viacom's KDSG-FM in Seattle catered to adults 35 to 55 years old, with oldies music. Now it is paired with Noble's former station, KNDD-FM, known as the End, which plays modern rock with appeal to 18- to 34-year-olds.
"That gives us a real nice spread," said William Figenshu, president of Viacom's radio group. "It allows us to build market share to a completely separate market. We had no shot at beer or soft-drink money; now we do."
In Salt Lake City, Apollo Radio Ltd. merged KALL AM-FM, bought from the Communications Investment Corporation for $1.8 million in January, with its market-leading FM country station KKAT. Apollo estimates $1 million in annual cost savings.
"KALL did very little community involvement," said William Stakelin, president of Apollo, which now has 10 stations. "They didn't have the resources to do anything but stay on the air. When we are buying a second facility, we want to make it more successful. We don't go into any of these deals to strip them of their services."
Dana Horner, Apollo's Salt Lake City general manager, said the merger of KKAT with KALL's AM talk and FM oldies stations resulted in 37 job cuts. But the stations' combined 16 percent market share gave it new airwave-power allure.
"Larry King Live" was added. So was headline news from a local network TV affiliate. And a request for a KKAT promotion by a March of Dimes executive led to an unsought chat on KALL's AM morning show. "These are things that don't normally happen," Mr. Horner said.
Not surprisingly, one company's ownership of two AM or two FM stations is not popular among some advertising agencies. Kaye Bentley, a buyer of radio time for DDB Needham in Los Angeles, told participants in a Southern California Broadcasters Association seminar last month that the mergers rob advertisers of flexibility and present them with "must" buys.
And as combined stations end up with a single news director, that individual's biases will influence a larger audience, warned Andrew Schwartzman, director of the Media Access Project, a public interest group in Washington. Of the 70 dual-ownership deals approved, he could cite no specific example, however. "I'm sadly confident they are coming," Mr. Schwartzman said.
Ken Costa of the Radio Advertising Bureau said group owners were unlikely to try to cut costs by using the same broadcast on several stations. "Programming is what keeps them in the race," he said. "Syndicated material will never dominate our industry like television; stations want local flavor."
