HEADLINE: John Kluge Gives Columbia $60 Million to Aid Minorities

BYLINE: By MARIA NEWMAN

 BODY:
John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company and a 1937 graduate of Columbia University, presented his alma mater last night with $60 million for minority scholarships. It is the largest gift the university has ever received.
In making his gift, Mr. Kluge recalled what a hardship it was for him to afford his tuition -- only $500 a year at the time -- when he was earning $7 a week working in the school dining hall. Fortunately for him, he said, Columbia helped by giving him a scholarship. 
 "Columbia made a difference really in my life and I really want to assure that it will continue to make a difference for others," Mr. Kluge said in an interview from his office in Manhattan. At 78, Mr. Kluge, who made his fortune building up a string of radio and television stations, is one of the wealthiest people in America.
By itself, the $60 million donation is believed to be the fifth largest to any university or college. When added to the $50 million Mr. Kluge already donated to Columbia in two previous gifts, it would be second only to the $125 million pledged to Louisiana State University in 1981 by Claude B. Pennington.
One of Mr. Kluge's two previous gifts of $25 million, presented in 1987, was also for minority scholarships and the other, in 1990, went to aid young scholars and junior faculty members.
The new gift comes at a critical time as Columbia battles serious fiscal problems. With its $1 billion operating budget, the university has a $15 million deficit this year and is working to cut costs to balance its budget for next year.
 
Luring Minority Candidates
 But officials of the university said it was unclear whether the gift, because it was specifically for scholarships for undergraduates, would have any impact on the deficit.
The gift would, they said, help the university attract minority candidates who might otherwise go to other universities better able to help them with steep college costs.
Fred Knubel, a spokesman for Columbia, said last night that the gift would provide at least 300 students a year with grants of $10,000. Mr. Knubel said that the money would be used in the form of an endowment, and that its interest would go to help minority students selected for admission.
The university has a "need-blind admissions policy," dating back to the 1960's, which means that qualified students are admitted without regard to their ability to pay. The university then provides financial aid to all those who need it.
About 36 percent of the 3,422 students at Columbia College, the undergraduate school, are members of minority groups. Of the 862 students in this year's freshmen class at Columbia College, 421 receive some sort of financial aid, officials said.
Mr. Kluge (pronounced KLOO-ghee), who was named the richest American by Forbes magazine in 1989, '90 and '91, said he was not interested in having buildings named after him.
"I'd rather do something for human minds than for a monument," he said. "It's been offered to me time and again, not only at Columbia but at other colleges, but I'm not interested in having my name on a building. "This is really what this fund is about, for minority students who would ordinarily not be able to go to school," he said.
When he was asked why he particularly wants to benefit minority students through, Mr. Kluge answered simply: "I think the need is there. In my small way, I'm addressing that need."
 
Started With a Radio Station
 Mr. Kluge, who was born in Chemnitz, Germany, came to the United States when he was 8 years old. He has admitted to interviewers that he is as surprised as anyone that his financial gambits brought him from a poor upbringing in Detroit to the head of a company that is one of the largest private concerns in the nation.
Mr. Kluge served in Army Intelligence during World War II, and afterward bought a radio station and formed Metromedia. Eventually, he bought a string of radio and television stations that no one else seemed to believe were profitable, but he usually made money.
In later years, Mr. Kluge continued to amass a fortune, buying billboard companies, the Harlem Globetrotters, the Ice Capades and the Bonanza and Steak & Ale restaurant chains among other businesses. Last year, Forbes magazine estimated Mr. Kluge was worth $5.5 billion.
 
Known for Generosity
 Known for his generosity to other causes, Mr. Kluge delighted especially in timing his gift so he could announce it last night during a tribute to his friend Michael I. Sovern, who is stepping down as Columbia's president June 30.
Mr. Sovern, who was somewhat surprised by the gift, said he too was thrilled. "He really did want to give me a nice send off, God bless him," he said.
Historically, according to information from the university's Office of Undergraduate Admissions, Columbia has had the highest percentage of students on financial aid of any of the Ivy League universities.
Mr. Sovern said that dwindling Federal and state aid to education, coupled with the huge tuition increases that the university -- like many others -- has had to impose, has made it more difficult for some students to pay for a Columbia education.
 
About $24,000 a Year
 Tuition is $16,514 a year, and tuition, room and board and other incidentals bring the cost of a year at Columbia to about $24,000 per student.
When Columbia offered him a scholarship in 1933, Mr. Kluge recalled yesterday, he had offers from other colleges, and he did not believe he could afford Columbia with the amount they were offering. So he decided he would be aggressive, he recalled, and asked them to double the scholarship.
Columbia officials agreed, and four years later, he graduated with a bachelor's degree in economics.
"I really had no money at all," he said about those days.
"I guess taking the $50 million I already gave them, and doubling it is the basis in kind," he said. "They doubled my scholarship so I'll double theirs."

HEADLINE: New Country Is Like Prison to Asenhat, 18

SERIES: Children of the Shadows: The eighth of ten lives of the cities.

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ

 BODY:
Asenhat Gomez used to peer out the windows of her childhood home in the Dominican countryside and relish a landscape of willowy palm trees and verdant fields where her extended family would gather for daylong reunions.
In her new home in Brooklyn -- a cramped apartment on Williamsburg's South Side -- the windows frame a claustrophobic vista of brick walls, and the few relatives she has in this country are so preoccupied with making ends meet that family get-togethers seem as long gone as the father who died a dozen years ago. 
 It has been nearly a year since Asenhat was reunited with her mother, who six years before had left her children with their aunt and illegally entered the United States in search of the opportunities that had eluded the family in the Dominican Republic.
 
Longing for Home
 But the immigrant journey of Asenhat Gomez is only beginning. For 18-year-old Asenhat, the joys of reunion are constantly tempered by the struggles of life in a hard new land. Hundreds of miles from all that was familiar, unable to shake her longing for home, she tentatively ventures into a future that beckons with equal measures of promise and fear.
In many ways, hers is the oldest of immigrant stories, played out time and again by wave after wave of newcomers to America's shores. But for today's immigrant children, in places like Williamsburg, that process of adjustment is made all the more difficult by the modern plagues of drugs, guns and recession.
Asenhat, a shy girl, has become even shyer since arriving last May, the strangeness and the frustrations coalescing in a sometimes overwhelming feeling that she is trapped.
 
'Sense of Confinement'
 "Everybody talked about the sense of confinement," she said recently, recalling her first weeks in New York. "I expected that, but just not so much.
"Lying in bed I would think about what I left behind. There you got accustomed to visiting people, my friends from school, since we were infants. The whole place was different; you could go out to play. I miss my school."
Williamsburg -- its bumpy narrow streets lined with age-worn two-family homes and apartment buildings closed in by the shadows of hulking waterfront factories and the Williamsburg Bridge -- can seem forbidding to someone used to the easy freedom of the countryside. The family's two small bedrooms are shared by six people who subsist on meager earnings.
Still, even as she bridles at her confinement, it has become her defense mechanism in a city whose ways and language are not her own. She seldom ventures beyond her neighborhood, partly from fear of getting lost on unexplored streets and subway lines and partly from fear of drug dealing and violent crime on nearby blocks.
"It makes you feel insecure," said Asenhat, a short girl whose floppy ponytail and baggy jeans give her the look of someone just entering her teen-age years. "You can be going down the street and not know what can happen."
She has few friends, feeling that she has little in common with American-born teen-agers, who she says are too "liberal" -- so preoccupied with boyfriends, clothes and the latest fads that they squander the opportunities available to them.
She has tried, and failed for lack of English, to find a job. Even her hopes for improving the family's lot through education are in limbo. An honor student who breezed through high school and a year of premedical studies in the Dominican Republic, she plans to continue her studies at Hunter College in Manhattan. But she has been forced to sit out a year while she learns English and qualifies for financial aid.
In her own reticent way, Asenhat (pronounced ah-seh-NET) will admit to a certain disappointment with her new life. "It's been more difficult than I thought," she says. And while she allows that "there are more opportunities here," she is quick to add that "there, people looked out for you."
Still, she resolutely hews to the immigrant dream.
"After a while I'll feel better," she said. "Especially after I learn English. After I begin school. I like to study, and that's the best way to progress."
 
Death on a Farm
 Asenhat Gomez was born in the countryside near Moca -- a farming community in the Cibao region of the Dominican Republic -- where her family owned a comfortable three-bedroom house, with a big yard filled with fruit trees, on land where her father and uncles grew plantains and cassava.
She still recalls how on weekends, her father, Vicente, would take her and her friends to fairs or for a cool ice cream, or how they would all gather with relatives to spend the day eating, talking and playing.
But there were hints of darker times ahead, she said; her father suffered from depression that seemed to feed on itself.
"When he got sick with that problem, he would get depressed because he could not work," she said. "He went into a clinic."
 
'There Was No Other Way'
 When Asenhat was nearly 6, he accidentally shot himself to death while cleaning a pistol, the family says. She was in the room when it happened. She talks little about it.
With three children and no husband, Asenhat's mother, Esperanza, tried in vain to keep the family afloat, getting money and food from her in-laws. But seven years ago, she took the children to her sister's house, told them she was going to take a nursing course in a nearby city and slipped off on a nine-day journey through Guatemala, Mexico and California and finally to New York.
"There was no other way," she says now. "A mother does it only thinking of her children."
Working as a live-in maid in Brooklyn, she would send money back home, promising to send for the children as soon as she had legal residency, which happened last year.
Esperanza had told them some of what they could expect, but she knew, too, that her advice could go only so far.
"Talking about it," she said, "is very different from living it and seeing it."
 
Arrival
Disappointment,
4 Flights Up
Asenhat had barely arrived in New York last May when the disappointment hit. In her new home four flights up a dimly lighted stairway, she and her 20-year-old brother, Harold, shared a bedroom with their sister, Amalia, 14, who had preceded them to America by several months. Her mother slept in the bedroom off the kitchen with her new husband, Jose Aybar, and their 3-year-old daughter, Josephine.
"This house looked so strange to me," Asenhat said. "It was so confining, such a big building with so many people and such little apartments."
Life inside the apartment, with her new family, was strained. At first, Josephine would jealously cry "Mami mia!" whenever Asenhat approached her mother. Relations with her stepfather have remained cool.
"He is almost illiterate," she said. "We don't have that much in common." They barely speak.
"I would like to talk about my dreams," she said. "Sometimes I miss my father a lot because he was close to us. He was very caring, very sweet with us."
 
'I Don't Go Out Alone'
 For a while, however estranged she felt, fear of what lay outside, of being speechless in an English-speaking city, kept her imprisoned in the apartment. She spent her days reading the Bible or absent-mindedly watching television. She lost weight.
"There are no places for people to go around here," she said. "I don't go to the park. I don't go out alone."
While her block is relatively calm, the surrounding streets have seen an increase in drug dealing and violence. There was a shooting at her sister's school. Sometimes, she hears gunshots at night.
She remembers how in Moca, gunshots were sometimes heard ringing out in celebration of some holidays. "Here," she said, "it's not because people are happy."
The one solo venture she made early on -- to enroll in a summer youth program -- ended in tears in Bushwick after she couldn't speak English with the person taking her application, who angrily shouted at her. Her frustration and fear only increased when she wandered outside and quickly got lost.
"I was scared to ask for directions because I didn't think anyone spoke Spanish," she said. Finally, she got up enough courage to ask a Spanish-speaking passer-by.
"He said I was lost," she said. "I knew that."
Even now, her daily schedule is an unwavering routine played out within six blocks of home: a noontime visit to her mother's job, English classes, several hours at a local youth center and back home to her family.
Asenhat's confinement can be as much emotional as physical, made worse by being sidetracked in her schooling. While her parents were never able to go to college, they wanted to make sure their children would. Asenhat's belief in the bedrock American value of success through education seems absolute. When she talks about becoming a doctor, "a professional," her face brightens and she sits up a little prouder.
Both Asenhat and her brother Harold -- who studied civil engineering and worked in a medical laboratory in Santo Domingo but now works six days a week at a bodega -- plan to attend the City University of New York. But they have had to wait a year to qualify as New York City residents for the cheaper tuition and to learn English.
The only studying she does now is in her daily English class at the Brooklyn Public Library, where her afternoons are filled with children's songs and dialogues.
"It's like being little again," she said of the class, though she might have been describing the entire humbling experience of learning English.
Asenhat also realizes that while the constant presence of Spanish in her neighborhood makes it easier to adjust, it makes it harder, too.
"It's more difficult to learn English here because everybody speaks Spanish," she said. "If you hear more English, your ears get used to it faster."
A few nights ago, Asenhat slowed down as she approached her building, where two boys boxed playfully. As she got nearer, one of the boys smoothly pulled out a knife, opened it and feinted a slash at his friend. She barely blinked as she sweetly asked them if they had a key to the wrought-iron lobby door that always is locked.
After 11 months in Brooklyn, she still finds it hard to decipher the rituals of her American-born counterparts.
"For me the most important thing is to study," she said. "For them it's boyfriends, going places and buying clothes. That doesn't matter to me. A person's worth isn't what they wear, but what they are and how they feel."
Her friends at home, she insists, were different. "We were more united over there," she said. "I think sometimes that those who grew up here are more superficial. There may be more opportunities here, but over there people looked out for you."
Even the people she meets at El Puente, a youth center two blocks from her home, don't always understand what she is going through. Some don't even understand her language, although they are children of Hispanic parents. Her closest friends are Lilin Fong and Danilda Torres, both of whom came from the Dominican Republic several years ago.
The three are active in a natural healing class at El Puente, and they often sit together, chatting in Spanish. Lilin thinks Asenhat is adapting as well as she can.
"I used to count the days I had been here," she said. "I knew the hour I arrived."
Asenhat nodded. "I count the months, too," she said. "I wanted to return home." She lowered her voice. "Sometimes I still feel like going."
 
Dona Mercedes
Dispensing Advice
To 'Daughters'
Good thing Mercedes Mendez didn't hear that. The last time Asenhat revealed her homesickness, Dona Mercedes -- as she is known to all -- looked at her as if she were insane. "Don't even think of going back!" she scolded. "You have to be with your mother."
Each day, Asenhat passes by Dona Mercedes's apartment for lunch and a brief visit with her mother, who works as a home attendant caring for the 71-year-old Puerto Rican woman. Dona Mercedes, who walks stiffly because of knee replacement surgery a dozen years ago, busily looks after Asenhat, calling her "one of my adopted daughters."
Dona Mercedes is one of several women who have rallied around Asenhat, intent on making sure that nothing keeps her from her goals. Dona Mercedes, who came to the mainland in 1946 and worked for years packing tomatoes and cooking for the field hands on a New Jersey farm, often regales her with tales of how hard her life was when she arrived. She cautions her against talking to strangers or following the crowd.
 
Mother's Worries
 "Most of all, take care of your virginity," Dona Mercedes admonished. "Don't wander off with boys; you can get easily lost out there."
Esperanza nodded in agreement. But far from worrying that her daughter will be led astray by friends, she frets that she spends too much time alone.
She also wishes Asenhat would be a little more accepting of her new husband, who, she says, has had a hard enough time coping with his extended unemployment and his mother's illness.
Asenhat would like to get a job, to help the family out. She has looked a few times, to no avail.
"She talks about work, anything she can do," said Cecilia Figueroa, a health coordinator at El Puente. "But there's not much she can do with no language and no experience. She doesn't have anything."
Esperanza says she only wants her daughter to keep striving toward her goal of becoming a doctor. To help her learn English, she is buying her a $950 set of language cassettes, on the installment plan.
"There are few mothers who would do what Esperanza did," said Dona Mercedes. "She's only had God's help."
And the help of Esperanza's sister, Mirope Ortiz-Lisardo, who took in the three children when she came to the United States. Asenhat is so close to her aunt that she calls her "Mami," and after almost a year apart, she could barely contain her glee during Mirope's recent visit.
When it came time to leave, on a bitter-cold Saturday, the house grew quiet. Mrs. Ortiz-Lisardo walked up to Asenhat and reached out to her. They hugged, gazing into each other's eyes. A kiss, another hug, and then her aunt stepped into the hallway and began her journey back to the friends and places in the homeland her niece had left behind.
Quietly, Asenhat flopped onto the couch and sank into a corner, clutching her sister's talking teddy bear. Her mother sat next to her and stroked her arm. The girl shook her head when asked if she was sad.
Asenhat hugged the toy, and its voice broke the silence.
"Dream with me," the bear sang in tinny, electronic tones.
She hugged it tighter.
"Dream with me."

HEADLINE: Vietnam Report on Prisoners A Fake, Reputed Author Says

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam, April 19

 BODY:
A Vietnamese general denied today that he had written in 1972 that Hanoi held more than twice as many American prisoners as it ultimately released. Any such report attributed to Hanoi is a forgery, he declared.
And a special envoy, sent by President Clinton to tell the Vietnamese that relations could not improve until the matter was cleared up, said he saw no reason to disbelieve the Vietnamese denial. 
 Nearly two weeks ago, Russian archivists turned over to the United States a Russian translation of what was said to be a secret report to Hanoi's Politburo given by Gen. Tran Van Quang, described in the document as Deputy Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese armed forces at the time. The document said Hanoi held 1,205 American prisoners of war in September 1972.
 
591 Released in 1973
 Because Vietnam released only 591 prisoners in 1973 and has maintained repeatedly that there were no other prisoners, the Russian translation raised the recurring question of whether Hanoi had kept some prisoners back, and if so, what happened to them. An alternative explanation offered by some experts was that Hanoi might have killed hundreds of prisoners.
Hanoi immediately denied the accuracy of the Russian document, saying it was a "fabrication."
In a meeting today, General Quang told President Clinton's special envoy, Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., that he did not write the 1972 report on which the Russian translation was supposedly based. If the Vietnamese report exists, General Quang said, it is a forgery that may have been prepared by someone interested "in undermining advances in relations between Vietnam and the United States."
At a news conference today after meeting with General Vessey, General Quang said of the 1972 report: "I did not write it. I tell you, never in my life have I made such a report, because it was not in my area of responsibility."
He stressed that although he was Deputy Chief of Staff on two occasions, he was not serving in that post in September 1972 as the document states.
General Vessey, after meeting with General Quang and other senior Vietnamese officials, said he had new doubts about the accuracy of the Russian translation.
The general, a retired Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said at his own news conference in Hanoi: "I don't think that one can draw conclusions about the document simply based on General Quang's statements, but I would say that what General Quang has told us is not inconsistent with what we know about General Quang. I have no reason to disbelieve General Quang."
Asked whether he had new doubts about the accuracy of the document, General Vessey replied simply, "Yes."
[But the Harvard-based researcher who discovered the Russian document said in a telephone interview from Watertown, Mass., that he thought General Quang was lying.]
 
Given 'Important' Documents
 General Vessey said Vietnamese officials provided him with "important" documents this week "that may well shed light on the Russian document, at least they appear to, first blush."
The general and American investigators in Hanoi do not question the authenticity of the Russian translation, saying they believe that it is a genuine Russian archival document. Instead, they question whether it was prepared by a competent Russian-Vietnamese translator, and whether the Vietnamese document on which it was based was authentic.
Vietnamese officials have said this week that they are concerned that the documents and the dispute over their authenticity will prevent the Clinton Administration from lifting an 18-year-old economic embargo on Vietnam and will further delay billions of dollars in development loans for Hanoi from the World Bank and other international lending agencies.
 
Issue Linked to Relations
 Mr. Clinton, who is expected to meet with General Vessey when the general returns to Washington on Wednesday, has said he will not move to normalize diplomatic and economic ties with Vietnam until he is convinced that Hanoi is cooperating fully in determining the fate of more than 600 missing Americans.
In a joint statement, General Vessey and Hanoi officials said the Vietnamese documents turned over to American investigators include "archives listing American prisoners of war held during the war, as well as American servicemen who died in captivity in southern and central Vietnam."
On Sunday, the Vietnamese said they had given General Vessey an official Vietnamese Defense Ministry census prepared in the early 1970's stating that only 386 American prisoners had been captured by North Vietnam between April 1964 and February 1972.
American officials traveling with General Vessey said it might never be possible to prove or disprove the accuracy of the Russian translation and the authenticity of the 1972 Vietnamese report. But they said they were struck by discrepancies between information in the Russian translation and what is known about General Quang and his military career.
The Russian archives did not include a copy of the original Vietnamese document on which the translation was supposedly based, but the Russian translation lists General Quang as the Deputy Chief of Staff in September 1972.
According to official biographies published in Vietnam last year, before the Russian document became public, General Quang served in 1972 as a regional military commander in provinces in central Vietnam. He did serve as Deputy Chief of Staff twice, from 1959 to 1960 and from 1974 to 1978, but not in 1972.
"I was not in Hanoi at that time," said General Quang, who is now the director of a Vietnamese veterans' association. "I was never in charge of American prisoners of war. It's that simple and plain."
Asked who might have been responsible for fabricating the document, he replied, "You can ask the Russian intelligence services."
 
Researcher Attacked
 At the news conference with General Vessey, Foreign Minister Nguyen Manh Cam attacked the Harvard-based researcher, Stephen J. Morris, who found the Russian document during a search of the Communist Party archives in January.
"I would like to say something about Stephen Morris, the person who publicized this," Mr. Cam said. "He has a long history of opposing Vietnam, since the time he was an Australian student." Mr. Morris, he said, had taken part in "anti-Vietnam groups" in the United States.
The Foreign Minister said he believed that Mr. Morris, a researcher for the Harvard Center for International Affairs who is now working on a book about the Vietnam War, "had certain intentions when he chose the timing" of releasing the Russian document. The translation became public in the United States only days after news reports suggested that Mr. Clinton was prepared to move quickly to improve ties with Vietnam.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
A Liar, Researcher Says
 WASHINGTON, April 19 (Special to The New York Times) -- Mr. Morris, the researcher who discovered the Russian document, challenged General Quang's truthfulness as well as the Vietnamese Foreign Minister's comments.
"I think he's lying," he said of General Quang in a telephone interview from Watertown, Mass. "I think there's a Vietnamese copy in Moscow in the files of the G.R.U. I've got the only Russian-language copy, which is copy No. 6, which means there are five other copies floating around somewhere, and the original."
Told of Foreign Minister Cam's comments about him, Mr. Morris, an Australian, said: "I have a history of opposing the Communist Party of Vietnam, but not the people of Vietnam. I've always believed that South Vietnam would be better off under a non-Communist government."
He added that he does not oppose normalization of relations with Hanoi but believes that it should occur after a full accounting of missing Americans and after Vietnam stops what he called its interference in Cambodian affairs.

HEADLINE: Dredging Stays Mired In a Debate Over Dioxin

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 19

 BODY:
Dioxin is the most virulent industrial poison to date, or maybe it's not. It can destroy entire marine species, infect humans, make the Atlantic Coast unfit for swimming and destroy the fishing and tourism industries, or maybe it can't.
But even in small quantities -- 10 parts per trillion -- it has embroiled a half-dozen state and Federal agencies, a variety of environmental groups, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey and a divided Congressional delegation from New Jersey in a debate that shows no signs of ending. 
 There is, however, agreement on one point: It has been rough going throughout the process that began with the Port Authority's application on April 11, 1990, to dredge container-ship berths in Newark Bay and dump the muck in the ocean.
Until then, dredging had been an annual rite, a necessity to remove silt accumulation. Without it, ships will have to call elsewhere, threatening the port's 200,000 jobs and $20 billion in annual business. But environmentalists fear that while ocean dumping might save port jobs it could devastate industries like tourism and fishing.
"I start with the assumption that no regulatory process should be allowed to take three years," said Stanley Brezenoff, executive director of the Port Authority. "Prima facie, this is a process that has to be re-examined and retooled and recreated."
With so much time elapsed, there is finally room for hindsight as to how the agencies became mired in the dispute:
*No national standards exist for dioxin contamination in the ocean, so the regional office of the Environmental Protection Agency set about to determine them for this case. The initial threshold for contamination was later made more stringent, leading to more testing and more delays. There is still debate about how the tests were done and whether the E.P.A.'s findings adequately protect both marine life and human health.
*The Corps of Engineers had done considerable research on safe ways to dump contaminants in the ocean, but nothing specifically for dioxin. Environmentalists raised questions about whether dioxin-tainted muck could be effectively kept from spreading across the ocean floor.
*Over the last 36 months, advances in the precision of technology resulted in continual refinement of the scientific data on which regulators, environmentalists and the port were basing their decisions. In other words, the numbers kept changing, often in ways that led the environmental lobby to challenge the regulators.
For the port, the issue seemed straightforward. It asked to deepen about half the 62 berths at its Newark/Elizabeth Marine Terminal in Newark Bay, the harbor's prime container-ship port.
 
No Permit Yet
 But dioxin, a byproduct in the manufacture of the notorious herbicide Agent Orange, was found in the sediment, having leaked long ago from the shuttered Diamond Shamrock plant in Newark, a Superfund cleanup site upstream on the Passaic River.
To date, there is no permit for the dredging. The Corps of Engineers, the only agency authorized to allow the dredging, awaits results of a final review by the National Marine Fisheries Service on the effect dumping might have on endangered species of whales and sea turtles that migrate in or near the dump site, six miles east of Sandy Hook, N.J.
The E.P.A., in retesting ordered this year, recently determined that the dioxin level in silt in some berths is within acceptable limits for dumping. If the fisheries service has no problems, presumably the Corps of Engineers would grant the permit, perhaps by the end of the month.
But environmentalists hold out hope that they can pressure Gov. Jim Florio to halt the dredging, which he has the authority to do under an amendment to the Federal Coastal Zone Management Act.
A spokesman for the Governor, Jon Shure, said Mr. Florio would contemplate no action until the regulatory process had run its course. In any event, it is hard to see how the Governor could avoid political risk. If he fails to intervene, he alienates the environmentalists whose cause he has historically defended. If he seeks to ban dumping, he alienates labor at the port. The dispute has already divided the state's Congressional delegation, with northerners, citing the economy, backing the port, and southerners, citing coastal concerns, calling for alternatives to dumping.
 
'A Crisis Waiting to Happen'
 "This was a crisis waiting to happen," said Sarah Clark, staff scientist for the Environmental Defense Fund in New York, "because the science of testing and the evaluating system has only recently started to catch up to the regulatory process."
Cindy Zipf, executive director of Clean Ocean Action, a group based in Sandy Hook, N.J., that promotes tourism and environmental matters, said: "There seems to be no clear authority out there on ocean disposal. And the political situation is that they've cut the issue, jobs versus the environment. What we're saying is that you don't need to make the choice, that there are alternatives, that it is a win-win situation."
The environmental groups favor building containment islands for the dredged material or segregating the material on barges or ships until an effective and economical means of decontamination becomes available. The Port Authority contends that the cost for this would be exorbitant, and that finding space for ships or containment islands would be difficult.
Col. Thomas A. York, the district engineer for the Army Corps of Engineers, said: "You get to a point of frustration covering the same issues so many times. That's the wrong approach."
Speaking of the concerns of environmental groups, which have complained that the Corps of Engineers had excluded them from meaningful participation, Colonel York said, "It's easy to armchair quarterback, but open forums would have been a much healthier environment."
Mr. Brezenoff said: "This process is set up with many players, each of whom operates independently. That's by design. Maybe it needs to be more collaborative. Maybe the Congress has to take a look at the regulations it established."
There is a hint of change. William J. Muszynski, acting regional administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, is organizing a forum for regulators as well as labor and environmental groups to examine issues that came up in the dredging dispute.

HEADLINE: Italians Support Political Reform By a Big Margin

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ROME, April 19

 BODY:
After months of scandal, recession and Government paralysis, Italians voted overwhelmingly for political change in a referendum on Sunday and today that repudiated the country's leadership of the last 48 years, but that left the future uncertain.
Final computer projections late tonight, 10 hours after polls closed, showed 82 percent of voters endorsing a proposal to scrap the current system of pure proportional representation for most of the Senate and replace it with the majority voting used in other parts of Europe and the United States. 
 The magnitude of the vote is expected to put heavy pressure on legislators to enact similar changes in the lower house, or Chamber of Deputies.
The ballot had assumed the proportions of a popular judgment on Italy's postwar political system, and the result was widely interpreted as a mandate for a new government to press through broader electoral reform.
That, in turn, would set a political calendar for new elections -- and thus a fresh start -- after a debilitating corruption scandal that has tainted much of the political and business elite and exposed ties between some government leaders and the Mafia.
While some of Italy's traditional parties, notably the Christian Democrats and the former Communists, would probably survive the process of reform, many smaller parties and the discredited Socialists are seen as likely to fall by the wayside.
Within minutes of the first projections, the same politicians that had been rebuked by the referendum results fell into their characteristic bickering, promising not so much renewal as a repetition of the feuding and horse-trading that has stymied Parliament for months.
Under Italian law, referendums may abrogate legislation and suggest new laws. But it is up to the Parliament itself to enact the replacement legislation within 70 days.
The referendum thus means that Italy's Parliament must begin framing laws that will automatically mean its dissolution, an unsavory prospect for many in a discredited legislature who are certain to lose their seats in new elections under new laws.
As the results emerged, Prime Minister Giuliano Amato, the Socialist head of a collapsing four-party coalition, visited President Oscar Luigi Scalfaro to begin the process of resignation and to explain "the reasons he considers his Government's mission to be exhausted," a presidential statement said.
He is expected to go before Parliament this week to debate the Government's future before finally resigning. Before the referendum, Mr. Amato had indicated he was prepared to head an interim administration, but today it seemed his own party had disowned him and it was unclear who the next Prime Minister might be.
Giorgio Benvenuto, the Socialist Party Secretary General, was asked on television whether he favored a second term for Mr. Amato or a new government. "I'd say a new government," he replied. "Repeat performances don't usually last long."
Well before the final results, politicians began staking out widely divergent interpretations of the referendum's significance. "We are heading for a phase of political confrontation," said Sergio Garavini, head of the small, hard-line Communist Refounding and a loser in the referendum.
Former President Francesco Cossiga declared, "It will be chaos."
Supporters of the referendum, especially Mario Segni, a particularly reform-minded former Christian Democrat, reacted to the preliminary results with jubilation. Hundreds of people, playing guitars and drinking wine, gathered in Piazza Navona in Rome and other public places across the country to celebrate the yes vote, which far exceeded the reform movement's expectations.
"Today is the first real act Italians have made in rebuilding," Mr. Segni told reporters. "Let us leave the divisions of the past behind us and build a great future."
The result greatly enhanced his personal status because he is closely identified with the effort to force the authorities to hold the referendum, and some commentators said he could become Prime Minister.
Although he does not have a formal political party to support him, he heads a cross-party committee formed three years ago to promote a referendum and reform. "I was not the winner; neither was the committee," he said today. "The Italians were the winners."
The referendum on electoral reform was by far the most important of eight ballots held in the last two days. The others called for changes including softer punishment for personal drug abuse and the scrapping of government financing for political parties.
All eight referendums were approved.
The most contested was the referendum on drug abuse, which scraped through by some 55 percent. The least challenged question, sliding in with 90 percent yes votes, was the vote removing government subsidies from the country's disgraced political parties.
The results showed a high average turnout of more than 75 percent of Italy's 47.5 million voters, although the number of people voting in the north, the electoral fief of the reform-minded Northern League, seemed markedly higher than in the Mafia-dominated south, where the Christian Democrats have long held sway through the politics of patronage.
 
Billions in Bribes
 The leader of the Northern League, Umberto Bossi, a clear winner from the vote, took the result as a triumph for his brand of federalist reform. "The will to change has triumphed," he declared in Milan. "The people have triumphed. Courage has triumphed. The League has triumphed. Now people understand what federalism means."
For its supporters, the referendum on electoral reform represented a historic turning point 48 years to the day after Italy's existing political system took root.
It was on April 18, 1945, that the Christian Democrats took power in Italy's first Government after World War II to become permanent dominant figures in the country's politics as 51 frail coalitions followed one after the other.
The Christian Democrats dominated all of them, but, in national elections a year ago, their popularity, built on a broad anti-Communist platform, slipped, eroded by the end of the cold war and the sense among Italians that the political system no longer worked.
Since then, a widening kickback scandal has discredited most of the country's traditional political elite as investigators have uncovered a vast web of illicit deals between politicians and businessmen trading public works contracts for bribes totaling sums that reportedly run to billions of dollars.

HEADLINE: In Congress, Urgent Calls for Action Against Serbs

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 19

 BODY:
As pressure mounted today on Capitol Hill for the United States and its allies to take immediate military action in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the Administration continued its debate on what it can do to stop Serbian aggression without getting Washington too deeply involved.
The Administration remains divided about whether to press its allies to lift the arms embargo against the Bosnian Muslims and carry out air strikes against Serbian positions. 
 Despite a seven-hour meeting on Saturday and further discussions by telephone on Sunday and today, President Clinton's senior foreign-policy advisers have failed to agree on what options to recommend, senior officials said.
One official said that rather than shape the debate, Mr. Clinton preferred to wait until his aides agreed on their recommendations. "The President is still waiting for them to wrestle down the options," one offical said.
President Clinton had planned to speak today to President Francois Mitterrand of France but could not get through, and intends to try again Tuesday, a White House official said.
Leading a growing number of prominent lawmakers calling for more forceful action -- including strategic air strikes and the arming of Muslim forces -- is Senator Joseph R. Biden.
He presented Secretary of State Warren Christopher today with a strongly worded report that castigates the United States and its allies for "confusion and inertia" in responding to Serbian aggression. The report was requested by Mr. Clinton.
The Delaware Democrat, who returned last week from Bosnia, made eight recommendations. They include sending NATO warplanes to escort United Nations relief flights, eliminating the Serbs' heavy weapons by giving them an ultimatum or by launching airstrikes, strengthening the United Nations peacekeeping force to make it a "serious fighting force," lifting the United Nations arms embargo against the Muslims, closing all embassies in Belgrade and deploying a major United Nations force in Macedonia.
"The United States must lead the West in a decisive response to Serbian aggression," Mr. Biden said, "beginning with air attacks on Serb artillery everywhere in Bosnia and on Yugoslav National Army units in Serbia that have participated in this international crime."
 
Bridges on the Drina
 As one example, he called on the West to "destroy every bridge" along the Drina River; Serbia has been using the bridges to supply Serbian nationalists in Bosnia.
Until now, few lawmakers have urged military action against the Serbs, but appeals in recent days reflect the growing conviction that the Bosnian Serbs will never sign the peace plan negotiated by the United Nations and the European Community, and that economic sanctions alone cannot stop Serbian aggression.
In the clearest sign that the mood is changing, Senator George Mitchell, the Senate Majority leader, is urging the Administration and its allies to arm the Bosnian Muslims immediately and launch air attacks.
"If President Clinton proposes, as part of a multilateral effort, to end the arms embargo and to direct that there be some more active use of NATO air power to deal with Serbian aggression, it would be appropriate," Mr. Mitchell said in a telephone interview. "And I believe it would receive good support in the Congress."
Senator Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, said on the NBC News program "Meet the Press" that American policy "is a sham."
"All we're doing is standing by while the Serbs mop up Bosnia and divide it into 11 little pieces and slaughter all the women and children," he said. "In my view that's not a policy."
Secretary of State Christopher today described the policy review as urgent, and the White House spokesman, George Stephanopoulos, said the White House would continue to consult with the allies, adding: "There's a range of things we're looking at right now. Among those are military options."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

The Economy
One of the biggest law firms -- Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue -- will pay the Government $51 million to settle charges that it aided Charles H. Keating Jr. in the fraud that brought on the costliest bankruptcy in the savings and loan debacle. [Page D1.]
The Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, told the financial markets not to expect inflationary pressures to re-emerge soon because the banking system remains weak and lending is subdued. [A15.]

HEADLINE: British Urge a New Job For Balkans Be Set Up

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 19

 BODY:
Britain has proposed appointing a new high-level official to take charge of enforcing the economic embargo against the Yugoslav federation of Serbia and Montenegro, after the Security Council's decision over the weekend to tighten these sanctions drastically.
The idea is to give this post to a prominent figure such as a former foreign minister or a former defense minister who has the authority to make Yugoslavia's neighbors comply with the trade ban. 
 Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf, the American commander in the Persian Gulf war, and Lieut. Gen. Brent Scowcroft, who served in the White House as President Bush's national security adviser, have also been mentioned as possible candidates for the job, diplomats here say.

HEADLINE: OTB Is Planning Layoffs To Avoid Red Ink for Year

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB

 BODY:
Admitting that it is facing a financial crisis, the New York City Offtrack Betting Corporation yesterday said that it would soon begin laying off employees to avoid ending the year in the red.
Otherwise, the agency said, it could wind up losing $2.9 million in the current fiscal year that ends in June and having to reduce revenues that it could turn over to New York City. 
 Critics, including state and city officials, have repeatedly rebuked the agency for its managerial policies and warned that OTB could become the first legal bookmaker in the nation to actually lose money.
Hazel N. Dukes, president of the quasi-independent agency, announced the need for layoffs in a memorandum to 1,978 employees. She attributed OTB's poor performance at the betting windows to harsh winter weather in February and March, which, she said, cut the anticipated handle -- the total amount of bets wagered on horse races.
The dwindling profits are almost certain to increase demands by critics of the agency that it be sold to a private corporation or that it be drastically reorganized.
 
Cost-Cutting Moves
 But Marjorie W. Longley, an OTB spokeswoman, said that through layoffs and other cost-saving measures, the corporation still hoped to turn over about $33 million in revenues to the city this year, the same amount as in the 1991-92 fiscal year. She said the agency was also considering closing several of its 94 branches.
Ms. Longley said that the number of layoffs had not been determined but that all of them would come from 507 employees at the corporation's executive offices and headquarters at 1501 Broadway in Times Square. "It will include managerial people in all departments, at all levels," she said.
In her statement to employees, she said the agency was facing "a $2.9 million shortfall" to cover its operating expenses. She said the financial setback was caused primarily by the closing of all OTB branches for three days after a blizzard on March 13. On eight other days in February and March, she said, OTB parlors were closed or betting was curtailed by severe weather in the city or at thoroughbred and harness racing tracks.
"We have done everything possible to prevent laying off employees," Ms. Dukes said in her statement. "Regrettably that is no longer possible."
OTB is required by law to pay operational costs from "residual" income, profits left after it makes payments from the betting handle to the state and the racing industry. Most of the money OTB gave the city last year came from a 5 percent surcharge on winning bets. It is barred from dipping into the surcharge revenue, which last year totaled $26.7 million, to run its operations.
As profits have withered in recent years, OTB has come under increasing attacks by State Comptroller Edward V. Regan and members of the City Council's Finance Committee for its spending and management policies. Mr. Regan urged OTB in October to close its 21 worst-performing branches and to take other drastic steps to reverse its slide.
Mr. Regan, through a spokeswoman, Ellen Weiman, said yesterday, "We take no pleasure in saying, 'I told you so.' " Asserting that Ms. Dukes's administration had declined to act more quickly to cut overhead, he said, "Instead they became defensive and are now forced to act in desperation to avoid the unbelievable prospect of ending the year in the red."
In March 1992, the Council Finance Committee admonished OTB for what Council members called excessive expenses for office furnishings and entertainment and for poor management practices.
Ms. Dukes, the agency's top executive since July 1990, has maintained that she has reduced the annual operating budget to $96 million, a saving of $11 million since she took over.
Ms. Longley emphasized that 75 percent of the handle -- $669 million -- was returned to customers for winning wagers last year. The racing industry also got $53.9 million and the state received $17 million before any money could go to the city or for OTB overhead, she said.
Last year's handle was $887 million and the agency, in its budget this year, projected a handle of $831 million. However, Ms. Longley said because of the winter weather, the handle is now projected at $820 million, a record low.
"You can't fight God," she said.

HEADLINE: Victoria Journal;
Such a Lovely City! Still, Seattle Holds Its Nose

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VICTORIA, British Columbia

 BODY:
This is a city that is "clean, green and safe," says the Greater Victoria Visitors and Convention Bureau. The bureau does not say that this is the only major municipality in North America still dumping its raw waste in the sea.
Victoria's restored historic buildings, flowering lawns, parks, magnificent seascapes and alluring British influence, including dozens of tearooms and pubs, drew 3.2 million tourists in 1991, about two-thirds American. The visitors pumped $725 million into the local economy, nearly double the outlay five years earlier. When 1992 tallies are completed, numbers are likely to be even higher. 
 At the southern tip of Vancouver Island, Victoria is closer to Washington State than to mainland Canada, and therein lies some of the problem.
 
'Tremendous Conradiction'
 Despite the entreaties of their neighbors, the electorate of this capital and second largest city of British Columbia, one of the richest provinces in Canada, voted in November to continue handling waste about the same way it has been handled for the last 100 years, rather than invest in a sewage treatment plant.
"What a tremendous contradiction for a city that depends on tourist income," lamented Derrick Mallard, a 72-year-old electronics engineer, who with his wife, Gwen, runs a vegetarian restaurant and the Citizens Association to Save the Environment.
At Clover Point, a park where the discharge is screened and then pumped through outfall pipes to an area one mile away and 200 feet deep, several kite-flying enthusiasts are preparing to loft multicolored Tracers, Renegades, Spiro-Jets and Lady Roses. Across the water, structures of Port Angeles in Washington State 8 to 10 miles away are easily made out.
Barry Cameron, 40, a retail sales clerk, is taking the canvas wraps off his Tracer. On the sewage issue, there is no doubt about the way he feels. "When the winds are coming up from the south and the currents change, the smell is quite definite," he said, a half-smile and then a look of disgust on his face.
From Clover Point and another outfall at Macaulay Point, a couple of miles to the west, Victoria discharges nearly 20 million gallons of the untreated sewage daily, the equivalent of the capacity of the Exxon Valdez, into the Strait of Juan de Fuca.
Although Victoria officials cite scientific studies to argue that the effect on the environment is negligible, people across the water have reacted with anger, disbelief and now something a bit tougher, a grass-roots tourist boycott.
"Oceans are not for dumping," said Rob Johnson, a member of the state House of Representatives in Olympia whose district embraces Port Angeles, the San Juan islands and part of Bellingham, and who has been the prime mover behind the boycott.
Not only are tourists canceling trips, but big associations are scrubbing conventions. Gerhard Letzing, executive director of the Washington State Trial Lawyers Association, said the group, which would have poured $350,000 into Victoria in 1995, is going to Whistler, a British Columbia resort with state-of-the-art waste treatment.
"We didn't want to support a city where residents do little to improve the environment of the ocean," he said.
Every year the eighth-grade social studies class of the St. Anne School in Seattle makes a trip to Victoria. This year the class wrote to the Capital Regional District Chairman, Frank Leonard, Victoria's top municipal officer, to explain that it was canceling because of the sewage issue.
Mr. Leonard offered to pay for a delegation to come here, tour the installations and hear Victoria's side. Six students, accompanied by their teacher, Mary Lila Gary, came, heard, and left unimpressed. Interviewed around a picnic table just before boarding the ferry back to Seattle, they said they would recommend to their classmates continued support for the boycott.
Here are some of their sentiments: Tony Magnano, 13, "Raw sewage is wrong"; Lindsey McBride, 14, "Victoria must take precautions now"; Jaime Kopf, 13, "If they're worried about the price now, it'll cost a lot more when they do it later."
 
Victoria's Argument
 Essentially, Victoria's argument is that the area is unique because of its cold water and strong tides and that nature takes care of itself.
Mr. Leonard said in an interview: "We have reduced garbage 25 percent in three years through a recycling and composting program. We have brought in clean-air bylaws. We regulate stove-burning and backyard and incinerator burning. We like to think we are aggressive with toxic waste. On sewage, do we build whatever the Americans tell us to, or do we weigh the scientific advice?"
Provincial authorities are embarrassed. They have urged a reluctant municipality at least to agree to begin primary treatment of the sewage within nine years. Negotiations continue.
John Cashore, British Columbia's Minister of Environment and a United Church minister, said: "The province has made clear that dumping of raw sewage is unacceptable. The municipality knows the handwriting is on the wall."

GRAPHIC: Photo: While the 3.2 million tourists to Victoria, British Columbia, were dumping $725 million into its economy in 1991, the province's second largest city was engaged in dumping of another sort, sending millions of gallons of untreated sewage into the Strait of Juan de Fuca. At Clover Point, only 10 miles away from the state of Washington, a cyclist rode in the expanse of one of the city's big pumping stations. (Bruce Stotesbury/Canadian Press, for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A New Old Trade Policy

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 19

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration's combative pronouncements on trade have hit the Japanese Government like a series of earthquakes, leaving officials here fuming over the insistent demands that Japan reduce its yawning trade surplus quickly. Some have charged that the Clinton Administration has reversed years of America's commitment to free trade. But the real concern among some trade experts is not that the policy itself is new; it is the assertive new way President Clinton is using the old techniques of managed trade that were accepted when they were employed by the Bush and Reagan Administrations.
As one of its trade initiatives, the Clinton Administration has pushed for the devaluation of the dollar against the yen. This is expected to reduce America's trade imbalance by making Japanese goods more expensive in the United States and American products cheaper here. The dollar has already plummeted in value against the yen, hitting a post-World War II low in Tokyo trading today of 111 yen to the dollar. That was the ninth new low for the dollar against the yen in the last 13 trading days. [Page D25.] 
 Clinton Administration officials have also suggested that Japan set targets for the import of American goods over a period of years and specific reductions in its surpluses. President Clinton, Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Secretary of State Warren Christopher have made it clear recently that any Japanese response will have to go beyond the sort of one-shot measures frequently accepted in the past. Clinton Administration officials have insisted they also want the Japanese to purchase high-technology American-made goods, not just more agricultural products.
Government officials here agree with the need to strengthen the yen -- if more slowly than the current rate of increase. But just about every senior Japanese official from the prime minister down has insisted that Japan would never agree to specific targets guaranteeing American exporters a share of Japanese markets. The key element of the Japanese defense has been to brand this results-oriented policy a form of managed trade, which violates free trade principles.
The issue is, however, more complex than it appears.
While the previous Administrations pledged fidelity to free trade -- and eschewed any government controls in principle -- they did in fact agree to managed trade deals, saying that they did so reluctantly. The Clinton Administration, however, has unabashedly seized upon managed trade as a tool to pry open the Japanese market to achieve fundamental change.
 
Tokyo Has a Word for It
 The Japanese expressions for these differences between rhetoric and reality are "tatemae," which is one's surface meaning, and "honne," which is one's underlying intention.
"Clearly, the difference is that in the previous Administrations tatemae and honne were different," said Makoto Kuroda, a former top trade negotiator and now a managing director at the Mitsubishi Corporation. "Now the honne has come to the surface. Clinton is writing his policies on a line that already existed."
In fact, the United States has enforced quotas and other mechanisms for controlling the flow of goods across the Pacific since the early 1970's, when the Nixon Administration took steps to slow a flood of cheap Japanese textile products.
"The U.S. managed trade before Presidents Reagan and Bush; they just continued the previous policies," insisted Ryutaro Komiya, a highly respected economist here and now director general of the Ministry of Trade and Industry's research institute. "The speeches they gave were different, but they still managed trade in areas such as automobiles and semiconductors. Before that, it was textiles, then iron and steel, and then televisions. The change was in the shift from light-industrial products to medium-technology products to higher-technology goods."
 
Pressure on Government
 It is thus difficult for Japan to flatly reject President Clinton's form of trade hardball. But the President's stance does put pressure on the Japanese Government to come up with its own recommendations for achieving swift reductions in the trade surplus.
The Government has yet to introduce any new ideas. Some commentators have been critical of the Government's staid policy makers for being slow to realize that a whole new relationship has emerged.
"The conventional approach of meeting selective, specific U.S. demands with principles of free trade or abstract arguments no longer works," wrote the Asahi Shimbun, a leading daily newspaper, in an editorial. "Japan needs to respond with a clear understanding of changes in the United States."
The editorial went on, "One should realize that the Japan-U.S. relationship has entered an era of genuine competition in which any attempt at equivocation simply will not do."
Many influential officials admit that all the elements of the American policy have been used before, and were accepted by Japan. The 12 years of the Reagan and Bush Administrations were, from Japan's perspective, littered with deals that managed trade by having government decrees influence the movement of goods rather than the classic determinants, supply and demand.
 
Voluntary Deals Recalled
 These deals ranged from Japanese agreements to "voluntarily" limit exports of autos and machine tools to a pledge to help foreign computer chip makers obtain at least a 20 percent share of the Japanese market. There was also the Plaza Accord in September 1985, which used government intervention to sharply reduce the value of the dollar against the yen.
At times, these conflicts left American trade negotiators in a quandary. When Carla A. Hills, President Bush's trade representative, visited Japan in October 1989, she toed the free trade line and rejected in principle any targets for Japanese imports of foreign goods, including computer chips. But just last year, with Japan's trade surplus expanding again, Mrs. Hills insisted the United States would hold Japan to its 20 percent market share pledge.
The Nikkei Weekly, a leading economic newspaper, wrote in a recent editorial: "Our greatest concern is that the Administration appears to be inclined toward managed trade. This is nothing new for the U.S. -- actually, it is a legacy from the Reagan and Bush Administrations, which practiced managed trade while proclaiming allegiance to principles of free trade."

HEADLINE: METRO DIGEST

 BODY:

A NEW COUNTRY SEEMS LIKE A PRISON
Asenhat Gomez used to peer out the windows of her childhood home in the Dominican countryside and relish a landscape of willowy palm trees and verdant fields where her extended family would gather for daylong reunions. In her new home -- a cramped apartment on Williamsburg's South Side -- the windows frame a claustrophobic vista of brick walls, and the few relatives she has in this country are so preoccupied with making ends meet that family get-togethers seem as long gone as the father who died a dozen years ago. A1.

$ 60 MILLION GIFT TO COLUMBIA U.
John W. Kluge, the chairman of the Metromedia Company who graduated from Columbia University in 1937 with the aid of a scholarship, presented his alma mater with $60 million for minority scholarships, the largest gift the university has ever received. A1.

The Offtrack Betting Corporation said that it will soon begin laying off employees. B3.
 
MAN ARRESTED IN NURSING HOME KILLINGS
To many who knew him, Harold Green was a devoted son, who delivered home-cooked meals to his mother at a nursing home in Jamaica, Queens. But the police said he was also involved in an increasingly bitter family dispute over money and his mother's care. Yesterday, the police charged Mr. Green with shooting his mother and half sister to death. B3.

It sounds like one of those little secrets about New York that only someone with the right connections will ever hear about: a ride to Kennedy International Airport for $1.25. B3.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Chase Marks $2 Billion of Bad Loans for Sale

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
In an attempt to put the excesses of the 1980's firmly behind it, the Chase Manhattan Corporation said yesterday that it had set aside $2 billion in troubled commercial real estate assets that would be sold over two and a half years.
By selling the loans and foreclosed properties in a depressed market, Chase expects to receive only 39 percent of the money it originally lent. It took an $884 million charge against its first-quarter earnings to reflect the difference between the expected sale price and the book value of the assets. Because of a gain from accounting changes, the company nevertheless managed to report an 8.5 percent increase in first-quarter profits. 
 To replenish its capital after the charge, Chase said it would sell $750 million in new stock, which would also help finance future acquisitions.
"We are giving ourselves a little room here," said Thomas G. Labrecque, the chairman of Chase, the nation's sixth-largest banking company. "If we are not stupid about what we buy, the equity issue gives us more flexibility to grow the institution faster."
Chase reported earnings of $153 million, or 74 cents a share, for the quarter ended March 31. The loss from the real estate portfolio was offset by a $500 million gain from accounting changes related to income taxes. In the first quarter last year, Chase earned $141 million, or 81 cents cents a share, including $30 million in tax benefits.
Another banking company, the Nationsbank Corporation, the country's fourth largest, said yesterday that its earnings rose 55.2 percent in the first quarter. The company earned $481 million, or $1.89 a share, versus $310 million, or $1.28 a share, a year earlier. Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., also benefited from the accounting change on income taxes, which added $200 million to its bottom line.
The accounting rule allows banks to recognize the value of tax benefits that they will be able to take in the future because of previous losses.
 By segregating its troubled real estate assets, Chase is following in the footsteps of the First Chicago Corporation, which established a $2 billion portfolio of real estate for sale and took a $625 million write-off. Other banking companies, including the BankAmerica Corporation and Nationsbank, have sold large pools of troubled real estate assets in bulk to investment firms.
Chase is unlikely to make bulk sales of its real estate assets. It expects to receive more by selling the properties individually or in small packages.
At the end of last year, Chase had a $7.8 billion portfolio of real estate-related assets, including $2 billion of loans that were not current on their payments and $1.1 billion of property that had been repossessed. The $2 billion in assets designated for sale includes $622 million of loans that are current on payments but are considered low quality, $843 million of nonperforming loans and $578 million in property.
The bank cut the book value of the assets by half, taking the $884 million write-off and using $135 million from its existing reserve for bad loans. The markdown to 39 percent of the original loan value was made using the most conservative accounting techniques, the bank said. Chase may realize higher values, depending on actual sale prices.
 
Shifting Gears
 Until now, Chase's approach had been to hold onto its troubled real estate and wait for the market to improve. "We now see a clear picture that the depth and width of the real estate problems are greater than we expected two years ago," E. Michel Kruse, the bank's chief financial officer, said at a briefing for banking analysts in New York yesterday.
The real estate action will help Chase reduce the cost of raising capital, Mr. Kruse said. "The dominant factor in cost of capital for Chase currently is the perceived risk in our real estate portfolio," he said.
Stock market investors, however, are concerned that the new stock issue will lessen the value of existing shares. Chase's stock fell $2.375 yesterday, closing at $34.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.
"They are raising a lot of equity, well beyond what I thought they needed," said James M. Rosenberg, an analyst with Lehman Brothers. "I don't think it's optimal for long-term shareholder value. I think they could have gotten a significantly better price for their stock if they had waited for a year."
Mr. Rosenberg also expressed concern that the new equity would encourage the bank to make acquisitions that would not be in the best interest of existing shareholders.
Mr. Labrecque, Chase's chairman, said the bank company was interested in making acquisitions in all business lines, including mortgage banking, trading, securities-processing services and retail banking in the New York area. Analysts suggested that Chase would like to buy a bank in New Jersey, where it has no branches.
 
Ratings Review
 Although the new capital may be a concern for stock investors, it is good news for holders of Chase bonds. Yesterday, several credit rating agencies said they were reviewing Chase for possible upgrades. Chase's long-term debt is rated triple-B by the major rating agencies, and the bank hopes that rating will rise to at least double-A by 1995.
A higher credit rating allows banks to raise funds at a lower cost and increases their ability to profit from trading currencies and derivative instruments, like interest rate swaps.
 
More Lending at Nationsbank
 Analysts said the most significant aspect of Nationsbank's report was that lending increased by 8 percent, to $73.5 billion, even as commercial real estate assets declined by $2 billion. A big chunk of the overall lending increase, $3.1 billion in loans, came from the acquisition of the consumer finance business of Chrysler.
"The Southeast appears to have a somewhat brighter economic picture than other parts of the country," said Diane Glossman, a banking analyst at Salomon Brothers.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Protests Over Lilly's Prices

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: INDIANAPOLIS, April 19

 BODY:
About 150 protesters today urged Eli Lilly & Company shareholders to restrain the company's drug price increases, but the appeals, delivered at the company's annual meeting, were rejected.
Earlier this month, Lilly pledged to limit price increases for any single drug to 2 percentage points above the inflation rate. United Senior Action, a lobbying group for the elderly, said it wanted independent verification of the prices. 
 "We hope to bring to everyone's attention that we can do something to control spiraling costs that are killing our people," said Forest Handlon, a United Senior Action member.
One resolution at today's meeting asked the company to report to stockholders on its pricing policy. A second demanded that Lilly adopt price restraints.
Stockholders representing just 5 percent of outstanding shares supported the resolutions.
Edward A. West, a Lilly spokesman, said the company's prices were fair and reasonable.

HEADLINE: NO NEW INFLATION SEEN BY FED CHIEF

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Vowing that he would remain vigilant in fighting inflation, the Federal Reserve's chairman, Alan Greenspan, told the financial markets last night not to expect inflationary pressures to re-emerge soon.
In a speech to the Economic Club of New York, Mr. Greenspan said it was "difficult to imagine inflationary pressures intensifying" when the banking system remained weak and bank lending remained "exceptionally subdued." 
 He gave several other reasons for believing that inflation would remain low, among them a surplus of people looking for work and labor costs remaining under control. He also predicted that the recent run-up in the price of some raw materials would soon slow significantly.
Mr. Greenspan appeared to address his remarks to the bond markets, voicing frustration that long-term interest rates remained relatively high even though the underlying inflation rate was at its lowest level in two decades.
Mr. Greenspan, who has been criticized by conservatives for cozying up to the Clinton Administration, took the opportunity in last night's speech to indicate that he did not plan to bend with the political winds to adopt an expansionary monetary policy.
He vowed not to repeat the mistakes of the 1970's, when the Federal Reserve pumped up the money supply to fuel economic growth, only to produce high inflation. The Federal Reserve pushed up interest rates in the late 1970's and early 1980's to squeeze down inflation, creating a deep recession and surge in unemployment.
"It would be irresponsible for us to dismiss the experience of the post-Vietnam War years and once again allow the destabilizing forces of inflation to undercut economic growth and employment," he said.
 
Growth Seen Slowing
 In another sign that inflation would remain under control, Alan Blinder, a member-designate of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, expressed fears that growth was slowing. In a speech in Washington, he defended President Clinton's $19.5 billion stimulus package, saying the Administration believed that growth had slowed significantly from the fourth quarter. He said first-quarter growth might be just 2 to 2.5 percent, well below the 3 percent the Administration has forecast for all of 1993.
During his speech, Mr. Greenspan often sought to reassure the markets about some recent signs of inflation. He said the increase in wages that the Labor Department reported in March "may reflect nothing more than excess overtime costs of cleanup following the late winter storms."
As for the recent climb of raw material prices, including lumber, he said this probably had "more to do with improving demand" and restoring profit margins to normal levels "than to early signals of sustained inflationary pressures."
In emphasizing the importance of holding down inflation, Mr. Greenspan said low inflation played a pivotal role in the recent upsurge in productivity. He said that when inflation was running at a moderate pace, corporations could easily increase profits by raising their prices, but when inflation was low, "businesses seeking to increase their profit margins perceive that they can do so only by enhancing efficiency."
He said that low inflation -- by helping concentrate the minds of business executives on the need to increase productivity -- might have caused a jump in productivity that is not just cyclical, but perhaps the beginning of a long-term trend.
Mr. Greenspan said the nation had "made very substantial progress" toward achieving price stability over the last decade. He adding that "at current inflation rates, we are quite close to attaining this goal."
He signaled that the central bank would not shrink from its responsibility of protecting the value of the dollar from inflation and from erosion against foreign currencies.
"A society's central bank is rarely popular," he said, adding that it was required "at times to take difficult steps to preserve the value of the currency both domestically and abroad."
