HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
3 Drug Giants Post Mediocre Results

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Three large drug companies -- Merck, Warner-Lambert and Eli Lilly -- reported mediocre results yesterday for the first three months of 1993. The drug makers have come under sharp criticism of their prices by President Clinton, but many have already abandoned past reliance on aggressively raising prices to improve profits.
The industry says price flexibility has also been squeezed by large buyers amid growing competition as drugs are copied. Still, there were no surprises because previous company announcements had told investors what to expect. 
 Shares of all three companies rose yesterday on the Big Board, along with other drug stocks, bucking a general market decline. Merck rose $1.875, to $35.875. Warner-Lambert was up $2, to $72.625, after hitting a 52-week high yesterday at $72.875. Lilly rose 62.5 cents, to $45.25.
Merck & Company said profits before adjustments for accounting changes increased by 10 percent in the quarter, its smallest increase in many years.
Warner-Lambert's earnings were up 10.7 percent before accounting changes, although pharmaceutical sales declined 7 percent and overall revenues were flat.
Eli Lilly & Company said net income before accounting changes declined by 16 percent, also on flat revenues.
Following are details of the companies' results:
 
Merck

Merck said quarterly profits before the adjustments were $613.8 million, up from $559 million the year before. Net income a year ago, after the noncash accounting changes that recognized future health-care and disability costs was $96.6 million, less than one-sixth this year's net.
Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, Merck's chairman, said worldwide operations had strong gains in unit volume, while "price increases had virtually no effect on sales growth." The company adopted a policy two years ago of limiting price increases to the general inflation rate. Currency fluctuations reduced sales by three percentage points.
Merck, based in Whitehouse Station, N.J., has reported steadily declining earnings growth over the last five years.
Noting that Merck had warned investors last month of the latest slowing in growth, Joyce Albers, an analyst at First Boston, said earnings on a per-share basis were actually "better than we expected." She added, "Once they got our expectations down, it didn't look so bad."
Ronald Nordmann at Paine Webber Securities projected improving profits in the second half of 1993. He said Merck had extraordinary expenses, starting last summer, as it introduced Proscar, a new prostate treatment, and added salespeople for a joint venture with Astra A.B., a Swedish drug company.
 
Warner-Lambert
 Warner-Lambert, based in Morris Plains, N.J., reported a double-digit increase in profits even though sales rose only 1.5 percent. Including several accounting changes, its earnings rose 11.3 percent, to $182.2 million. The company said it had reduced spending for marketing, research and overhead, benefited from falling interest rates, and received increased royalties from product licenses.
Consumer lines, led by Listerine mouthwash and Schick shaving products, had stronger domestic sales in an improving American economy.
 
Eli Lilly
 Lilly, based in Indianapolis, said its operating profits were hurt by reduced sales because of a relatively mild flu season and by increased competition for several products. It was also hit by suspended production at its Physio-Control Corporation unit, increased rebates to state Medicaid programs, and German Government price reductions.
Including several accounting charges in the first quarter and in the 1992 quarter, Lilly's net income rose 11.3 percent, to $362.6 million.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
30-Year Bond Yield at 16-Year Low

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell again yesterday, closing at 6.72 percent, its 16-year low, but it could not dip below that level.
In what traders said was light trading, the price of the 30-year bond rose 14/32 , to 10506/32 in the seconday market. It was the second time since last Thursday that the yield dropped to its recent low at the end of trading. But on both occasions, traders and investors were apparently unwilling to buy enough to push the yield down to new lows. 
 "We are still in a trading range," said David Ader, a fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston.
Mr. Ader said that there was some selling in the morning as traders expected that the selling on Friday, which pushed the 30-year bond yield back up to 6.75 percent, would continue. But when it became clear that prices would not fall much further, a lot of sellers had to limit their losses by buying, which lifted the market.
There was no major economic news to trade on, which added to the slowness of the market. Because the weather-related slowdown in March is already apparent in the economic data, there may not be any crucial news -- unless there is a surprise -- until the first week of May.
That is when the Treasury will announce the quarterly auction data and is when traders and investors will find out if the rumored cuts in the size of the 30-year bond auction are actually going to occur. Speculation about a cut in the total amount of 30-year bonds to be sold has been one of the factors supporting the price of the bond and bringing the yield lower, traders have said.
In the same week, the Labor Department releases the employment data for May, which could help clear up the debate over how fast the economy is growing.
In other trading yesterday, the prices of Treasury notes were up slightly. At the weekly auction of Treasury bills, the average discount rates declined, again reflecting a belief by some investors that the Federal Reserve may have to cut short-term interest rates to insure that the recovery keeps on track. With the declines yesterday, the discount rates fell further below the Fed's 3 percent target for the Federal funds rate, the interest rate banks charge on overnight loans.
The average discount rate on the three-month bill was 2.81 percent, down from 2.89 percent last week and the lowest since 2.67 percent on Oct. 5, 1992. The discount rate on the six-month bill was 2.95 percent, down from 3.00 percent last week and the lowest since the 2.95 percent on Oct. 13.
 
Auction Study

A study by a group of economists for the Mid America Institute concludes that the Treasury should continue its experiment with single-price Treasury auctions and that the threat of reopening Treasury issues is a positive approach to dealing with possible market manipulations.
But the study, which was released at a news conference yesterday, opposes any radical changes in the current procedures in the $2.3 trillion government securities market. Specifically, the report contends that any major increase in regulation of the market or new demands for reporting by firms that trade government securities would not be cost effective.
The recommendations against any radical changes are like those from other organizations involved in the government securities market, for example, the Public Securities Association. Among those financing the Mid America study were Wall Street's major firms, including Merrill Lynch; Morgan Stanley; Goldman, Sachs, and J. P. Morgan.
The study supported both the new single-price auction procedure the Treasury is testing in the two-year and five-year note auctions and the reopening of current Treasury issues to add more supply if there is a squeeze, whether legal or not. Those were two of the major changes made by the Government in the aftermath of the Salomon Brothers Treasury auction bidding scandal in August of 1991.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar at Yet Another Low Despite Efforts to Curb Yen

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell to another postwar low against the yen yesterday despite remarks by Government leaders intended to slow the rally that has lifted the value of the yen more than 11 percent this year.
The dollar also declined against major European currencies as traders, seeking profits on the yen's recent advance, sold some of their yen holdings to buy German marks, Swiss and French francs and British pounds. But for the most part, they did not buy dollars. 
 Gold rose for the second straight session. Gold for current delivery gained another $1.30, to $340.30 an ounce, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $339.90 an ounce, up $1.40.
The yen began its advance overnight in Tokyo as a follow-through to Friday's increase in New York. The yen had soared on Friday after President Clinton made remarks welcoming a stronger yen as a way to curb Japan's trade surplus.
But early yesterday in Tokyo, Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa, who had met with Mr. Clinton in Washington last week, said the yen's rise was too rapid and that Japan's central bank should try to curb its appreciation, even if it was not joined by other central banks. Later in New York, a Clinton spokesman said that the President's comments on Friday were not meant as a major policy statement.
But the remarks in Tokyo and Washington did little to stem the yen's advance.
"The critical thing that's missing here is they want to slow the rise, but neither the U.S. nor Japan is willing to say this is far enough," said Ronald Leven, a currency analyst at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company.
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 111.00 yen, down 1.95 yen from Friday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at the same price. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar recovered slightly to a postwar low of 111.10 yen, down from late Friday's 112.30 yen.
In Paris, the French Government cut two key short-term interest rates, but the reduction did not lead to a selloff in French francs. Many participants had feared such a move would prompt speculators to try to drive the franc sharply lower as a way to test the new French Government's resolve to support the franc.

HEADLINE: Waco, Tex., Prices $33 Million Issue

 BODY:
Waco, Tex., priced $33 million of general obligation bonds yesterday through underwriters led by the First Southwest Corporation of Dallas. The underwriters, who had scheduled the financing months in advance, said the storming of David Koresh's headquarters outside Waco yesterday had no impact on the deal.
In fact, the deal went so well that underwriters were able to raise the price on most of the issues, thereby lowering yields by five basis points, or five-hundredths of a percentage point, as well as the cost of servicing the debt for the issuer. 
 The financing, to replace old debt at higher interest rates, offered a maximum yield of 5.65 percent for a general obligation refunding bond due in 2013. Yields on shorter-maturity serial bonds ranged from 2.55 percent in 1994 to 5.60 percent in 2010.
Also for sale were combination tax and revenue certificates of obligation with yields ranging from 3.50 percent in 1995 to 5.65 percent in 2013.
Because all the bonds are insured by the Ambac Indemnity Corporation for interest and principal payments, the issue carries a triple-A rating by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: Biologists Fear Sustainable Yield Is Unsustainable Idea

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS

 BODY:
THE concept of sustainability -- the idea that renewable natural resources like fisheries and forests should be exploited with restraint so that future generations can also benefit from them -- has become something of a mantra among environmentalists.
But if history is any guide, sustainability may be far more difficult to achieve than is commonly thought, three fisheries biologists argued in an article in the April 2 issue of the journal Science. 
 For one thing, they say, science is probably incapable of predicting safe levels of resource exploitation. And even if accurate predictions were possible, they contend, history shows that human shortsightedness and greed almost always lead to overexploitation, often to the point of collapse of the resource.
 
'Pretense' of Certainty
 "It's quite depressing," said Dr. Donald Ludwig of the University of British Columbia in Vancouver, an author of the paper, written with Dr. Carl Walters, also at British Columbia, and Dr. Ray Hilborn of the University of Washington.
The three scientists nevertheless say there is some hope if policy makers abandon "the pretense of scientific certainty," in Dr. Walters's words, and devise common-sense management plans that protect the resource,and the economy that depends on it, against a range of uncertain possibilities.
As an illustration of the problem, they note that commercial fish populations naturally fluctuate, often unpredictably, under the influence of varying ecological conditions. Yet scientists who advise fishery managers have historically calculated a single, unvarying "maximum sustainable yield," or set number of fish that supposedly can be caught without endangering the resource.
If the number is calculated on the basis of good ecological conditions for fish, as has often happened, fish stocks will be overexploited when conditions turn bad. To complicate matters, scientists disagree on how much exploitation is safe and can never hope to reach a consensus. Catastrophe sometimes results.
 
Loss of a Species
 The record is replete with such examples, the three experts say. In one instance, they wrote, California state scientists warned that limits should be placed on harvesting the California sardine. Fishing interests were able to produce opposing scientists who said it was impossible to overfish the species. Fishing was not reduced, the population collapsed and scientists still argue over why.
The Canadian cod fishery may be another such instance, said Dr. Walters, referring to what he called the "huge disaster" that has befallen the fishery. "That's a really good instance where the scientists were trusted to produce answers," he said. But, he added, "they were way overestimating how many fish were left in the ocean" and "the net result of putting trust in scientists was to put 20,000 people out of work" when the fishery collapsed.
Scientists may never be able to track the fluctuations well enough to advise fishery managers on safe exploitation levels. "The rate of learning might not be faster than the rate of change," Dr. Hilborn said. "That's one of the reasons that over time we might not get more certain. It's a very scary thought."
The only sensible course, he said, is to conceive of sustainability not as an effort to "hold the resource in one place" but rather as an effort to ride nature's cycles by "rolling with changes in the environment."
As an example of how this might be done, he cited the Alaskan salmon fishery. The number of spawners necessary to maintain a healthy population might range from 1 million to 15 million, depending on whether the population cycle is at a peak or in a trough. The safe course in view of this uncertainty would be to leave enough fish so that the fishery as a whole will do well whether it is a good year or a bad one. This would mean taking fewer fish than the fishery would yield in a peak year.
Quite apart from the prediction problem, the three critics contend that the human drive for wealth often leads to overexploitation in this way: Fishermen or loggers harvest as much of the resource as they can. When harvests are abundant and money is plentiful, large capital investments are made in equipment and entire local or regional economies base themselves on exploiting fish or trees. When the resource fluctuates, as in the case of fisheries, or diminishes, as in the case of forests, the vested interests plead for subsidies. The subsidies come, sometimes on a temporary basis, but the effect is to encourage further overharvesting
Here, too, the three scientists see a possible way out. It lies in a common-sense strategy routinely practiced by financial investors in the face of uncertainty: hedging your bets and spreading the risk. When a region or a locality relies for its prosperity on harvesting a fragile and unpredictable biological resource to the exclusion of other economic pursuits, Dr. Walters said, it is as if "an investment manager told his client to put all his money into one stock."
 
Spreading the Risk
 It would be safer for both the economy and the resource, Dr. Walters said, if communities tried to create a more diversified economy. The basic strategy, he said, should be to recognize the uncertainty and risk and "build in economic flexibility and risk-spreading." Had that been done in the case of the cod fishery, he said, it would not have been the disaster it has been.
But he recognized that this strategy is not always easy to apply once a region or locality has cast its economic lot with one resource, as in the case of the bitter fight between loggers and environmentalists over the cutting of old-growth forests in the Pacific Northwest.
"Nobody's come up with a way of doing it" in the forests of western North America, he said. Tourism, for example, "doesn't really seem to cut it" as an economic alternative to logging," he said. "The number of jobs it can generate doesn't seem that large." Of efforts by the Clinton Administration to find a way out of the dilemma in the Pacific Northwest, he said, "I sure don't envy those people."
By and large, the three critics "are right on target, said Walter Reid, an official at the World Resources Institute, a Washington-based research and advocacy group, who deals with the question of sustainability. He said that was particularly true on the basic point that "to wait for a uniform consensus from scientists is a recipe for disaster."
He also agreed that sustainability could not be conceived of as some permanent, steady-state condition. Rather, he said, the normal fluctuations of nature make the sustainable use of biological resources "a moving target." But he said science was of more value in managing resources than the article might suggest, not least because although science cannot remove uncertainty, "it can certainly narrow the envelope of uncertainty."
What science does not do at all, the authors said, is take into consideration the real source of difficulty: people. Most fishery problems, Dr. Hilborn said, "are a result of not understanding how the fishermen behave rather than how the fish behave."
"The resource itself is the easier research problem," he said.
 
New Conservation Ethic
 Including people and their economic needs as part of an ecosystem to be preserved is a major tenet of an emerging new American conservation ethic. Dr. Ludwig, Dr. Hilborn and Dr. Walters argue that such human attributes as the hunger for wealth and the tendency to disregard long-term consequences should also be included as part of the natural system to be studied and managed.
"Resource problems are not really environmental problems," they wrote. "They are human problems that we have created at many times and in many places, under a variety of political, social and economic systems.
These are among the guides to action they offer in summing up:
Rely on scientists to recognize problems but not to remedy them. Distrust claims of sustainability, since past resource exploitation has rarely been sustainable. And confront uncertainty honestly.
"As long as you recognize your limitations," Dr. Ludwig said, "you can begin to cope with things."

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton, Meet Mr. Gore

 BODY:
Bill Clinton's speech commemorating Earth Day later this week might answer some questions. Does he really care about the environment or was that just something he told the voters? And is he paying any attention at all to his Vice President?
Things have not been going Al Gore's way. Months ago, he had every reason to believe that Bill Clinton would become the "environment President" George Bush pledged to be but wasn't. And that he, as the President's political conscience and policy coordinator, would steer the onetime friend of polluters in the Arkansas chicken industry to new heights of global stewardship. 
 Mr. Gore has hardly been heard from on environmental issues since Inauguration Day. The White House has been doing most of the talking, and not in a way that pleases the Vice President.
First it approved a toxic waste incinerator in Ohio that Mr. Gore had pledged to keep closed pending further study. Then it withdrew its support for sensible proposals on mining and grazing offered by Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt. Mr. Gore had no personal stake in these proposals but his sensitivities must surely have been wounded by Mr. Clinton's quick capitulation to powerful interests.
Mr. Gore has a big investment in the issues Mr. Clinton is supposed to address tomorrow, particularly global warming. He knows and cares more about that subject than any other politician in Washington. In his best-selling "Earth in the Balance" he described global warming as "the most serious threat that we have ever faced," and urged the world to act "boldly, decisively, comprehensively and quickly."
At a minimum, Mr. Gore would commit the U.S. to stabilizing annual emissions of so-called greenhouse gases, chiefly carbon dioxide, at 1990 levels by the year 2000. This was the original goal of many of the nations gathered at the Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro last year. President Bush -- citing, among other things, scientific uncertainty and economic costs -- single-handedly engineered a weaker treaty that set no timetables or targets. Mr. Clinton pounced upon this in the campaign and pledged to support the original Rio goal.
Mr. Gore wants Mr. Clinton to fulfill that pledge, made when there were just the two of them riding the bus to the White House. The bus is more crowded now.
Treasury Secretary LLoyd Bentsen and Energy Secretary Hazel O'Leary resist Mr. Gore's plan. Neither is an unbiased witness; Mr. Bentsen has historically been tender toward business in general and oil in particular, and Ms. O'Leary's last job was as executive vice president of a power company. Both want more study of the impact of diminished energy use on American industry.
Mr. Gore argues that efficiency, conservation and new technologies can limit greenhouse gases without economic disruption. On the face of it, that seems glib, and he cannot expect Mr. Clinton to adopt his strategy without answering tough questions about costs and competing strategies. How much can be achieved through energy efficiency? Will a big carbon tax be required on top of Mr. Clinton's proposed energy taxes? And how much assistance will developing countries need to persuade them to limit energy use without sabotaging economic growth?
But this is not just about details. This is about the broad pathway the Administration intends to follow. What we're hearing from Mr. Bentsen and Ms. O'Leary is a lot like what we heard from George Bush, who shrank from leadership and found fearsome risks and reasons for delay everywhere, whether the issue was global warming or biodiversity or the spotted owl.
Mr. Clinton did not sign on to all of Al Gore's environmental policies when he chose his running mate. But he left the firm impression that he intended to confront environmental problems and educate the American people to their complexities. If he now follows the kinds of instincts that governed him in Arkansas and shuns Mr. Gore's advice, he will have put the Vice President in his place. But that's not the place Al Gore ought to be, which is guiding the President and the Cabinet on issues he knows better than any of them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
Money Without Strings Entangles Political Rivals

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Evanston, Ill., wants a basketball court. Birmingham, Ala., wants pool repairs. And it is now widely known that Manchester, Conn., wants what Senator Bob Dole, the minority leader, derides as "that infamous ice skating warming hut."
In the view of Mr. Dole and his Republican colleagues, proposals like these illustrate the wastefulness of President Clinton's plan to stimulate the economy, part of which would finance local wish lists. But to the Democrats, the assortment of proposals embodies something else: the principles of Republican social policy. 
 After all, they say, it is the Republicans who have spent a half-century railing against Federal bureaucrats' meddling in local affairs. And it is Republicans who, while calling for less Federal spending, want fewer Federal rules so that states and cities can spend the money they get as they see fit.
In fact, the Republicans created something called community development block grants to do just that. But ever since Mr. Clinton proposed pouring $2.5 billion into the program, Republicans have attacked it.
To be sure, the main Republican complaint is the cost of Mr. Clinton's plan, not the principle of local decision-making. But to sell their opposition, the Republicans have been mocking the local proposals with what sounds suspiciously like the second-guessing from Washington that Republicans say they oppose.
This has not escaped the notice of Henry G. Cisneros, who as Housing Secretary presides over the block-grant program, behind which he says is the paragon of Republican principles. "Republicans stand for decentralizing decisions out to the lowest levels," Mr. Cisneros said. "It is ironic now that it's been the Republican Senators who've attacked the C.D.B.G. program."
Among those who think that "Henry has a good point" is one of the Republican godfathers of the block grant concept, Richard Nathan, who served as a budget aide in Richard M. Nixon's White House when the idea was hatched. Mr. Nathan, who now teaches public policy at the State University of New York at Albany, said the drive for greater local flexibility had arisen as a response to the social programs of the Great Society under President Lyndon B. Johnson.
Scores of Federal programs blossomed under Johnson, he said, but each had a narrow scope. Federal bureaucrats and Congressional committees liked the power the restrictions gave them, but many local officials complained that the rules had become unworkable.
Among them was Mr. Cisneros, who in 1968 had just landed a job in the San Antonio city government. His first task, he said, was to comb through a Federal grants book.
"You might have to apply to one agency for the swimming pool and another for the land clearance money and another for the street improvement," he said. Since each program had different paper work, deadlines and requirements, "it was almost impossible to bring them together to make a coherent whole."
In a nationally televised speech on Aug. 8, 1969, President Nixon outlined a philosophical alternative. After three decades of centralizing power, he said, it was time for money and responsibility to flow "from Washington to the states and to the people."
In 1974 Congress partly complied by consolidating seven narrow programs into the community development block grant program. Current rules require 70 percent of the money to be used to benefit communities with low or moderate incomes.
The program emphasizes local control, and Republicans have often sought to consolidate other programs in a similar way.
Fast forward to 1993, when Mr. Clinton proposed spending $19.5 billion on programs that he said would jump-start the economy. Wary of increasing the deficit (and perhaps also of ceding power to Mr. Clinton), Senate Republicans were casting about for colorful items that might seem to embody wasteful Federal spending.
They found them in a thick volume published by the United States Conference of Mayors, detailing the projects the block grants might finance. These included $28,000 for the tennis and basketball courts in Evanston, $450,000 for the pool repairs in Birmingham and $30,000 for the much-maligned Manchester hut. Senator Hank Brown, Republican of Colorado, even submitted an amendment to ban those and 52 other projects.
Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, another leader in the Republican opposition, concedes that his party usually champions the cause of local control. "Granted, when we have money to spend, a lot of us would like to have fewer strings attached," he said in an interview last week.
But uneasy in finding himself attaching strings, Mr. Nickles switched the subject. "My big objection is adding money to the deficit," he said.

HEADLINE: Stimulus Set For Europe

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: LUXEMBOURG, April 19

 BODY:
An economic stimulus plan aimed at lifting Europe out of its worst slump in 50 years was approved today by the European Community.
The plan, intended to create 450,000 jobs in the next two years, received final endorsement at a meeting of finance ministers of the bloc's 12 countries. 
 The plan focuses on capital projects and research and development. Among the projects already approved for partial financing by the bloc's European Investment Bank are a $1 billion upgrading of electrical power grids in Spain, Portugal and Ireland and a Danish railroad modernization plan estimated at $832 million.
The package also aims to encourage private investment, improve support to small businesses and increase training. It has a further goal of holding down wages, especially in the public sector, in order to restrain public spending.
Restoring prosperity in the community could help the United States economy. The European Community countries are a significant market for United States exports; the United States had a trade surplus of $8.8 billion with the European Community last year.

HEADLINE: Crash Kills George S. Mickelson; South Dakota's Governor Was 52

 BODY:
Gov. George S. Mickelson of South Dakota, who followed his father's career path from a rural law practice to the state's highest office, died in a plane crash in Iowa yesterday, a spokesman for his office said. He was 52.
Governor Mickelson was one of eight people killed in the crash about 15 miles southwest of Dubuque as they were returning from a trip to Cincinnati to promote economic development in the state, the spokesman said. 
 A Republican, Mr. Mickelson was first elected in 1986 and won another four-year term in 1990. He also served six years in the South Dakota House, where he was Speaker in 1979-80.
Lieut. Gov. Walter Dale Miller will succeed him as Governor.
Mr. Mickelson was the son of George T. Mickelson, who served as South Dakota's Governor from 1947 to 1951.
The younger Mr. Mickelson had a home-grown style, often driving a pick-up truck to work. He was a popular member of the South Dakota House for six years, quitting in 1980.
In 1989, Mr. Mickelson's teen-age son, David, was charged with a sexual offense after a 16-year-old girl said she had been raped during a party at the Governor's Mansion. The Governor and Mrs. Mickelson were out of town at the time. David Mickelson was acquitted of the sex charge but was placed on probation for underage consumption of alcohol. He and another boy at the party were ordered to pay the girl's medical bills.
 
Served in Vietnam
 Mr. Mickelson was born in Mobridge, S.D., and lived in the eastern South Dakota city of Brookings and the state capital, Pierre. He received a bachelor's degree in business administration and a law degree from the University of South Dakota.
After two years in the Army in Vietnam, he practiced law in Brookings, S.D., then served as Brookings County state's attorney and assistant state attorney general.
In addition to his son, Mr. Mickelson is survived by his wife, the former Linda McCahren; a son, Mark, and a daughter, Amy.
An obituary on Tuesday, and in some editions on Monday, reported the death of South Dakota's Governor, George S. Mickelson, in an airplane crash.
The obituary included an account of a 1989 arrest of the Mickelsons' teen-age son after an incident during a party at the Governor's Mansion while the elder Mickelsons were out of town.
 While the incident was newsworthy at the time, there was no indication of any lasting relevance to the Governor's career. It should not have been reiterated in his obituary.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. UNVEILS PLAN FOR SOVIET LANDS

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
To help the former Soviet bloc's transition to a market economy, the International Monetary Fund unveiled a program today to provide billions of dollars in loans under less stringent conditions than usual to Russia and more than 20 other countries.
Michel Camdessus, the fund's managing director, said the program would provide $4 billion to $6 billion in loans during the next 18 months to help former Soviet bloc nations buy imported goods, ranging from food to spare parts needed to modernize industry. 
 Mr. Camdessus said at a news conference that Russia would qualify for about $3 billion of this money and that he hoped it could begin receiving some in a month or two. This $3 billion was counted as part of the $28 billion Russian aid package that the Group of Seven industrial nations announced last week in Tokyo.
 
Some Strings Attached
 The monetary fund is not planning to lend the money without any strings attached, Mr. Camdessus said, adding that Russia would have to take some initial steps to bring its inflation rate of 25 percent a month under control.
Yet he made clear that to receive the money, Russia would not have to commit itself to meeting specific targets in cutting inflation and its budget deficit. These are among the strict conditions the fund usually demands before lending money.
Mr. Camdessus said the fund would lend Russia up to $30 billion during the next four or five years to help its conversion to a market economy.
He said the new program, known as the "Systemic Transformation Facility," was being set up to help Russia, Ukraine, Belarus and other former Socialist countries that are hurt by the rapidly rising cost of exports. Many of their trading partners are demanding hard currency rather than soft rubles in payment for their exports.
 
Loans on Easy Terms
 He said several Eastern Europe nations, including Bulgaria, Hungary and Poland, might qualify for loans under the program, as might several Asian countries, including Laos, Cambodia and Mongolia.
The loans would be on easy terms, with repayment within 10 years and only interest payments required for four and a half years. The interest rate would be less than 6 percent.
Mr. Camdessus said he would like the fund's 175 member nations to agree to create more than $30 billion of the fund's own currency, known as special drawing rights, that could be used to help end the global economic slowdown and provide aid for developing nations. In recent years, the United States, Germany and several other industrial nations have blocked this idea.

HEADLINE: Japan Threatens Action to Brake the Soaring Yen

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday April 21

 BODY:
A shellshocked Japanese Government threatened tough action Tuesday to brake the yen's soaring value against the dollar, while complaining that the currency's rise was jeopardizing the economy's nascent recovery from a recession.
Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa attempted to sound an aggressive note when he commented to reporters here today that "it's time to intervene" in the market, by having Japan's central bank sell yen and buy dollars. He called the yen's rise "too rapid." 
 Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, also warned in a speech that the rise could have a "massive impact" on Japanese exporters, whose goods are now much more expensive for overseas consumers.
 
Called a Mixed Blessing
 But many economists said it appeared there was little the Government could do to reverse the powerful trend on its own, and described the yen's appreciation as a mixed blessing for Japan. They also noted that the United States and other governments supported a stronger yen as one way to reduce Japan's big trade surplus.
In spite of intervention by the Bank of Japan in the foreign exchange market Tuesday and today, the dollar tumbled to 109.90 yen here this afternoon, its lowest level against the Japanese currency since World War II, before rebounding above the 110-yen level in later trading. The dollar has seen a decline of more than 11 percent since the beginning of the year. Earlier in New York on Tuesday, the yen was quoted at 110.55 [Page D18.]
Yoshihisa Kitai, a senior economist at the Long-Term Credit Bank, said that by crimping exports, the strong yen, known here as "endaka," could eventually hurt Japan's economic recovery. A 10 percent appreciation of the yen, he said, decreases Japan's gross national product growth by a half percentage point.
"The point is simple, the profits of exporters are going to start to decline," he said.
On the other hand, he noted, endaka has a flip side: imports, particularly for critical goods like oil, will be cheaper. That is expected to keep inflation below 2 percent this year. The Government may also be pressured to reduce interest rates to temper the yen's rise, which will stimulate economic growth, Mr. Kitai said.
"The problem is just the short term, I think," Mr. Kitai commented. "In the long run endaka is good news for the Japanese economy. The lower interest rates may compensate for the higher yen."
 
Clinton's Remark Recalled
 One factor behind the the yen's rapid rise was President Clinton's remark last Friday after a Washington meeting with Mr. Miyazawa. He characterized the yen's appreciation as a positive trend to help reduce Japan's huge trade surplus, which could reach $150 billion this year.
Traders took the remark as a green light to sell dollars and buy yen, without fear that the Federal Reserve would try to moderate the movement.
Japanese Government officials have continuously said that they are not opposed to a gradual increase in the value of the yen. The swiftness of the latest rise is what has unnerved them and prompted the verbal assaults by Mr. Miyazawa and Mr. Mieno on the foreign exchange market.
Mr. Mieno sought to influence traders by offering his own analysis of what President Clinton meant by his remark on Friday.
The President, Mr. Mieno suggested, was not calling for a further rise in the yen's value against the dollar, but was only confirming that broadly speaking a strong yen was one means by which Japan's trade surplus could be reduced. The White House offered no clarification of its own.
European Community officials have also reacted positively to the yen's appreciation, thereby lessening the chances of concerted intervention by the central banks to slow the yen's rise.

HEADLINE: U.S. Prepares to Get Tough With Haiti's Generals

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 20

 BODY:
After weeks of quiet support for United Nations diplomacy in Haiti, Washington has begun sending strong signals that it will not tolerate delaying tactics or outright defiance by military leaders of international efforts to reinstate the country's exiled president.
In recent days, American diplomats have begun privately spelling out a series of new sanctions that the military leadership and its supporters here will soon face unless they accept a United Nations-brokered plan to end the 19-month political stalemate. American diplomats have begun to warn Haitian authorities publicly against further stalling. 
 But in a defiant speech to the nation tonight, Haiti's army-backed Prime Minister, Marc L. Bazin, rejected the United Nations mediation effort, calling it "doomed to failure." Mr. Bazin, whose Government is not recognized abroad, said that "any solution that is not the product of real and frank negotiation can only be imposed by force."
The stepped-up American role comes after United Nations mediators failed last week to conclude an agreement with military leaders that would have called for their resignation and the return of the Rev. Jean-Bertrand Aristide. In exchange for their cooperation, the army leaders had been offered a general amnesty for politically related crimes and violence.
The first sign of the stepped-up American involvement came Saturday, when Secretary of State Warren Christopher met with the United Nations envoy, Dante Caputo, just hours after Haitian commanders rejected Mr. Caputo's settlement terms.
Injecting the United States more directly into the diplomatic effort, Mr. Christopher said Saturday that Washington hoped that given a weekend of reflection, the Haitian military would reverse its decision. "It's time for the military leadership of Haiti to indicate its agreement on the key points of a settlement," he said.
Today, as he voted for a resolution authorizing the deployment of dozens of United Nations human-rights observers here, the United States representative to the United Nations, Edward Walker, said: "To the Haitian parties, we say, you must negotiate seriously, with promptness and flexibility. To the Haitian people, we say, the world has not forgotten you."
Since Mr. Christopher's statement, several Haitians said the special charge d'affaires, Charles Redman, had begun warning people, in private audiences with affluent backers of the September 1991 military coup against Father Aristide, that a series of finely targeted punitive measures were rapidly being prepared.
The United States Embassy here has declined to describe any of the measures, but officials familiar with diplomatic efforts said the sanctions would include the cancellation of visas for coup supporters and their children studying in the United States, the freezing of financial assets and the interruption of commercial air traffic.
If these measures failed, the officials said, stronger sanctions could also be imposed, including severing oil supplies to the island and cutting off trade across Haiti's border with the Dominican Republic. Asked if possible punitive measures had been described to those resisting a settlement, a spokesman for the embassy said: "Positively. We have made them clear."
Since the outset of United Nations efforts in December, many of Father Aristide's opponents have sneered at international diplomacy aimed at restoring him to office. To many of them the essential question has always been the determination of Washington to force the issue.
"The Caputo mission has precipitated a crisis, but in a good way," said one participant in the negotiations. "It has demonstrated that the military is not willing to give in without more pressure, and it is up to the United States to apply that pressure. This is not a time for quiet diplomacy."
Since the rejection of Mr. Caputo's proposals, American officials have said they have felt that, with the crisis close to settlement, a strong push was needed to seal the agreement before momentum was lost. "We really have to move forward," said one official "If we lose time we are really in trouble."

HEADLINE: George Mickelson, 52, Governor Of South Dakota, Dies in a Crash

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PIERRE, S.D., April 20

 BODY:
Gov. George S. Mickelson of South Dakota, who followed his father's career path from a rural law practice to the state's highest office, died in a plane crash in Iowa on Monday night, a spokesman for his office said. He was 52.
Governor Mickelson was one of eight people killed in the crash about 15 miles southwest of Dubuque as they were returning from a trip to Cincinnati to promote economic development in the state, the spokesman said. Engine trouble was suspected. 
 Mr. Mickelson was co-chairman of the National Governors Association's task force on health care.
A Republican, Mr. Mickelson was first elected in 1986 and won another four-year term in 1990. He also served six years in the South Dakota House, where he was Speaker in 1979-80.
Lieut. Gov. Walter Dale Miller, who succeeded Governor Mickelson today, vowed to try "to accomplish all he wanted to accomplish for us."
 
A Home-Grown Style
 Mr. Mickelson was the son of George T. Mickelson, who served as South Dakota's Governor from 1947 to 1951.
When he followed his father into the Governor's mansion, he focused on economic development, encouraging manufacturing growth in a state that is more dependent on agriculture than any other sector.
He sought to raise teachers' salaries, among the lowest in the nation, and in 1989 made two record increases in state aid to school districts by setting aside 56 percent of the state's sales tax revenue.
Mr. Mickelson tried to improve relations between Indians and non-Indians in South Dakota, naming 1990 the Year of Reconciliation. Several times he sat with Sioux leaders and smoked the sacred pipe.
He had a home-grown style, often driving a pick-up truck to work. He was a popular member of the South Dakota House for six years, quitting in 1980.
In 1989, Mr. Mickelson's teen-age son, David, was charged with a sexual offense after a 16-year-old girl said she had been raped during a party at the Governor's Mansion. The Governor and Mrs. Mickelson were out of town at the time. David Mickelson was acquitted of the sex charge but was placed on probation for under-age consumption of alcohol. He and another boy at the party were ordered to pay the girl's medical bills.
 
Served in Vietnam
 Mr. Mickelson was born in Mobridge, S.D., and lived in the eastern South Dakota city of Brookings and the state capital, Pierre. He received a bachelor's degree in business administration and a law degree from the University of South Dakota.
After two years in the Army in Vietnam, he practiced law in Brookings, then served as Brookings County state's attorney and assistant state attorney general.
In addition to his son, Mr. Mickelson is survived by his wife, the former Linda McCahren; another son, Mark, and a daughter, Amy.

HEADLINE: Dow Drops 23.50, as Profit Taking Sets In

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ

 BODY:
Investors could survey a procession of bad news yesterday -- upward pressure on interest rates, worse-than-expected housing starts, even some saber-rattling in the Senate about Bosnia and Herzegovina -- but they needed little excuse to accelerate the stock market's downward slide that began on Monday. "Profit taking" was the phrase of the day.
Moreover, in a paradoxical trading session, news that would have shaken the market a year ago -- a huge first-quarter loss at I.B.M. -- had little effect; I.B.M. shares even closed up by 1 3/8, to 50 5/8.
 
The New Direction: Down
 Market pessimists saw fresh evidence that a market adrift was at last finding a direction: all the major indexes were down. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average plunged as much as 46 points in early afternoon trading before recovering weakly to close with a loss of 23.50 points at 3,443.49. That followed a drop of 11.62 points on Monday after investors Friday had established a record-high Dow of 3,478.61.
The Dow Jones transportation average closed down 22.16 points, to 1,645.01, a sharper drop than Monday's 15.91-point decline. The Dow Jones utility average dropped 2.07 points, to 243.30, almost matching Monday's decline of 2.31 points.
The New York Stock Exchange composite index closed down 1.30 points, to 245.72, and volume on the Big Board was an especially heavy 318 million shares, up about 30 percent from Monday and about 4 percent higher than Friday's volume. Losing stocks yesterday far outnumbered the winners, 1,232 to 698.
 
Declines Across the Board

 
 The Standard & Poor's 500 closed down 2.36 points, to 445.10, a sharper drop than Monday's decline of 1.48 points. The Nasdaq composite index fell 1.06 points, to 661.97, a gentler dip than Monday's decline of 3.75 points.
The market decline seemed to cut through a variety of sectors. Nine stocks dragged down the Dow industrials 2 points or more.
The Dow declining stocks were led by Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, which fell 2 points; American Telephone and Telegraph, which slid 1 3/4, and Goodyear Tire, off 1 3/8. All of those companies' shares had been trading near their record highs and thus were vulnerable to profit taking. These three stocks alone accounted for nearly half of the Dow decline. Offsetting the decliners were shares of the International Business Machines Corporation, whose price rise lifted the Dow nearly 2 1/2 points.
An examination of the S.& P. 500 showed that a broad variety of interest-sensitive stocks were hurt by negative news. Regional banks and money center banks were especially hard hit. Nationsbank closed down 2 3/8 points, to 52 3/8, and Wells Fargo dropped 5 1/2, to 113 7/8, while BankAmerica closed down 1 1/2, to 50 1/4.
Also hurt were American General, a multiline insurance company, which closed down 1 point, to 30 7/8, and Merrill Lynch, the brokerage house, off 1 1/2, to 73 7/8.
The biggest percentage loser on the Big Board, at 21.76 percent, on a decline of 4 5/8 points, to 16 5/8, was Venture Stores. The regional discount store chain said first-quarter earnings would be sharply lower than analysts' expectations.

HEADLINE: Panel Receives Familiar Pleas To Retain Bases

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ARLINGTON, Va., April 20

 BODY:
They complained of shoddy staff work and secret back-room deals and evoked images of legions of skilled military technicians unfairly tossed out of work. In short, a truly nefarious situation.
In the first of nine hearings nationwide, a Presidential commission that will decide the fate of scores of military bases heard lawmakers, community leaders and union chiefs today make angry and anguished pleas to save their local installations. 
 The Defense Department has recommended closing 31 large installations and shrinking or consolidating 134 others; today's hearing focused on more than a dozen bases in Pennsylvania and Virginia. More than 500 people, including six busloads of off-duty Navy workers from the Naval Aviation Depot in Norfolk, squeezed into a community auditorium here and cascaded cheers and applause on speakers making their case.
No speaker today opposed cutting Pentagon spending in the post-cold-war world, so long as it didn't involve closing a local base.
Virginia, among the states with the highest military spending per capita, stands to lose nearly 15,000 civilian jobs from the proposed closings. In a refrain that has already become familiar from Norfolk to San Diego, speakers warned that the Pentagon's plan would bring economic disaster to their region and ruin to the armed forces.
"We in Virginia have been preparing for reductions in defense spending," said Gov. L. Douglas Wilder. "But we believe the Navy's findings are flawed, and deserve intense scrutiny by the members of this commission."
Commission members tried to sound sympathetic, but the torrent of mail and phone calls from concerned communities since the Pentagon's recommendations were made public a month ago seems to have already stretched thin the patience of most members.
"I can't imagine all the data from every base is flawed," said Beverly B. Byron, a commission member who is a former Democratic Congresswoman from Maryland, after listening to complaints from plant managers and legislators. Pentagon analysts vigorously defend their recommendations.
The eight-member Defense Base Closure and Realignment Commission has until July 1 to give its final recommendations to President Clinton, who must accept or reject the findings in their entirety. Congress would then approve or disapprove the package.
Commission members praised the presentations from Virginia lawmakers and community groups representing bases that include the Norfolk depot and a cluster of Navy offices in suburbs outside Washington. In the end, commission members said, the Defense Department simply cannot afford all its bases anymore.
With a panoply of colored charts and graphs, however, the Virginia base supporters made their case.
Senator John W. Warner of Virginia, a former Secretary of the Navy in the Nixon Administration, talked about the importance of keeping naval personnel and contracting offices near the Pentagon instead of transferring them 50 miles away to a base in Maryland.
Ross Haines, plant manager of the the Norfolk depot, contended that the Navy used inflated labor costs in its analysis and underestimated the military value of the depot, one of six the Navy uses to repair aircraft and ships.
Members of the commission nodded in acknowledgement, but they also asked the speakers for a little understanding.
 
Data Called 'Hard to Weigh'

"I assure you that every other depot will come in here and make their case and emphasize their strengths," said Harry McPherson, a commission member. "Not only is the data subject to question, but it is hard to weigh."
Not for the many people who crowded the auditorium, including many off-duty Navy workers. During a break in the hearing, Golden Shepard, a 60-year-old electronics technician who has worked at the Norfolk Depot for 38 years, said: "Jobs are very hard to find these days. I just pray to God that the commission will take the truth into consideration and take us off the list."
If the Norfolk depot closes, said James Jones, 43, an aircraft examiner, he would have to move to find work, just as he and his wife are building a new house.
"Working military aircraft is the only thing I've ever done since graduating from high school," Mr. Jones said. "We'd have no objections if we felt this had been done in a fair and reasonable manner. But it hasn't."

Scott, Herbert H. Bateman, Owen B. Pickett and Norman Sisisky spoke against the proposed moves. (Michael Geissinger for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Gambling stocks have been a better bet than gambling

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
CASINO gamblers would have fared well last year if they had hedged their bets and invested in stocks of the companies they patronized.
Gambling parlor stocks rose more than 50 percent in 1992, and some have done as well this year, despite concerns about growing competition. Over all, the industry is booming, with dozens of casinos planned for Indian lands and a small fleet of riverboats in the Mississippi River and the Gulf of Mexico. 
 Earlier this week two small operators, Primadonna Resorts of Las Vegas, Nev., and Jumer Hotels and Casinos, a Peoria, Ill., operator of riverboats, announced plans for public stock offerings to take advantage of the industry's expansion into more states.
With growing evidence that gambling has lost its stigma in the public's eyes, more states are looking to casinos as a source of revenue and economic development. Political leaders in staid Kansas, for example, want to allow casinos on Indian lands to compete with Iowa riverboats. New York last week decided to allow an Indian casino near Syracuse to help the local economy.
Although the opening of new markets is widely expected to steal customers from some existing casinos, many analysts expect spending on gambling to grow fast enough to satisfy old and new casinos, with occasional exceptions for saturated markets. At Wertheim Schroeder & Company, a recent report predicts that casino gambling will grow 15 percent this year and next, nearly three times faster than the economy.
"We are in the throes of a classic speculative bubble," said I. Nelson Rose, a professor of law at the Whittier Law School in Los Angeles and a consultant to the gambling industry. Although the industry may continue growing another two decades, he said some newcomers had "fantasy ideas about the amount of money to be made."
John J. Rohs, an analyst at Wertheim, prefers to ride the growth with stocks of larger, experienced companies. "Right now there are a lot of people trying to take advantage, and there will eventually have to be some shakeout," he said. His only recommended gambling stock is Mirage Resorts, though he has positive opinions on the Promus Companies, Caesars World and Hilton Hotels.
Others see opportunity in smaller, more nimble companies. Mark Manson, an analyst at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, recommends the Argosy Gaming Company as "a pure play on the proliferation of gaming in new markets." Competition is intense in new markets, but Argosy's managers have "demonstrated political sensitivity," he said.
Until last week Mr. Manson also recommended Showboat, which is expanding in New Orleans and Canada. Donaldson, Lufkin handled the public offering of Showboat stock last year, and its recommendation was suspended while the company prepared another stock offering.
Another New Orleans hopeful is the aptly named Boomtown Inc., of Verdi, Nev., which closed yesterday at $22.50, up $1.50, more than twice the $11 price when it was publicly offered last September.
Just as Iowa's riverboat gambling was decimated when Illinois was opened to riverboats, analysts warn that riverboats on the Mississippi and Gulf Coast should expect stiff competition from a Las Vegas-sized casino planned for New Orleans.
Apart from the dangers of too many casinos, Mr. Rose said the gambling industry could be hurt by a shift in public opinion similar to that after a scandal 70 years ago in the Louisiana lottery.
"Throughout history, every society that has allowed casinos to cater to locals has eventually outlawed gambling," Mr. Rose of the Whittier Law School said. "Nobody cares if the money is being sucked out of tourists, but when it is sucked from the local economy, there is a backlash."

HEADLINE: Gore Congratulates Poland on Its Democracy

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WARSAW, April 20

 BODY:
In his first major speech abroad as Vice President, Al Gore congratulated members of the Polish Parliament today on the progress their country had made in moving from Communism to democracy and capitalism.
Poland, where more than half the workers are in private enterprises and smooth democratic elections have been held, was showing the best economic and political health of the Eastern European countries that ousted Communist rulers in 1989, he said. 
 "In Poland the signs are, after all, a lot better than elsewhere," Mr. Gore told the main chamber of Parliament. "Travelers from the rest of Eastern Europe come to Poland and catch their breath. The Poles are keeping the promises of 1989. There is no lethargy in Poland; Poland is a land at work."
"The rest of Eastern Europe is inspired by your example, and so are we," he added.
Mr. Gore ended his two-day visit to Poland today after meeting with President Lech Walesa and talking to Polish environmental leaders. The focus of his trip was the 50th anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising.
On Monday he joined the Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin, and Mr. Walesa at a ceremony attended by thousands of foreigners and hundreds of Holocaust survivors at the ghetto monument.
Mr. Rabin flew today to the Auschwitz death camp, 200 miles southwest of Warsaw, where as many as 1.6 million Jews were killed by the Nazis. Last year, Chaim Herzog, who was then President, was the first Israeli leader to visit Auschwitz, where the gas chambers are preserved as a museum.
After meeting with Mr. Walesa today, Mr. Rabin went out of his way to advance the often tortuous relationship between Poland and Israel. "After two days I cannot be an expert, but I see a policy that tries to bring about improvement, a change of attitude, an opposition to any kind of discrimination, racism or anti-Semitism," Mr. Rabin said at a news conference.
He regretted, he said, a derogatory statement about Poland in 1989 by Israel's Prime Minister at the time, Yitzhak Shamir, who was born in Poland and whose family perished at the hands of the Nazis. Poles, Mr. Shamir said in 1989, sucked in anti-Semitism with their mother's milk.
"I do not like to comment on statements made in Israel from abroad, but I would have preferred that this statement had not been made," Mr. Rabin said.
Israel and Poland resumed diplomatic ties in 1990, after the Communist Government fell. The Communists had conducted several anti-Semitic campaigns, the most virulent in 1968, when many of the Jews remaining in Poland after World War II left for Israel.
But the prospects for improved relations between the Walesa Government and Israel dimmed when a nearly decade-old controversy over a Roman Catholic convent on the perimeter of the Auschwitz camp persisted. Last week, Pope John Paul II ordered the 14 nuns in the convent to vacate, a move that Jewish organizations had sought.
Mr. Gore suggested today that the new Poland could be a model for tolerance, saying: "Serbia and Poland stand at opposite ends of a moral world. I am here to state my faith in the proposition that the future belongs to Poland's resolve to seek a democratic society, where differences among people are celebrated, not feared."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
In a Reversal, Conde Nast Closes HG

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY

 BODY:
HG, a leading decorating magazine since its founding as House & Garden in 1901, will cease publication after its July issue, Conde Nast Publications announced yesterday.
"They had a beautiful sensibility about interiors and they really were always right on target about what was happening," said Stephen Sills of Stephen Sills and Associates, a residential and commercial design firm. "It's the end of an era."
 
Deal With Knapp
 HG was done in by its chief rival, Architectural Digest, which officially became part of the Conde Nast family yesterday. In a deal announced last month, Conde Nast acquired Architectural Digest and Bon Appetit from Knapp Communications for $175 million, giving rise to speculation about whether Conde Nast could profitably publish both HG and Architectural Digest, two of the leading interior design magazines. 
 When the Knapp sale was announced, Bernard Leser, president of Conde Nast Magazines, said that HG would not be closed and would co-exist with Architectural Digest. But yesterday it was a different story.
"We did the acquisition with the intention that we would continue the two magazines," Mr. Leser said. "But we reluctantly came to the conclusion that with the two magazines continuing as they were, both editors would be putting out a redundancy."
HG is the first core Conde Nast magazine to cease publication. Vanity Fair was discontinued during the Depression but was resurrected by the company in 1983.
As a result of the Knaap deal, Conde Nast now also owns two food magazines: its own Gourmet and Knapp's Bon Appetit. Mr. Leser said yesterday that these could co-exist comfortably, because unlike HG and Architectural Digest, they do not compete head to head for advertisers. Bon Appetit depends mostly on food advertising while the major source of ads for Gourmet, despite its name, is the travel industry.
Mr. Leser called yesterday's action "the hardest, most emotionally upsetting decision" that he and S. I. Newhouse, the owner of Conde Nast, have had to make in their many years at the company. He said the company would place as many of the staff as possible at its other publications. Nancy Novogrod, the editor in chief, will stay on, in the new position of editor, special book projects.
The news that HG would cease publication rippled through a meeting of the American Society of Magazine Editors in New York yesterday.
"It went like wildfire through the group," said Dorothy Kalins, former editor in chief of Metropolitan Home. "It was like the death of a friend. No matter how much of a competitor they were to me, they were like the worthy adversary on the hill. I think everybody was shocked."
The news also sent out a signal that the magazine industry's recovery from the advertising recession may not be as strong as publishers like to suggest. The home-decorating category has been hit particularly hard.
In 1992, Architectural Digest was down 10 percent in ad pages and HG, down 20 percent. Both magazines were privately held, so it could not be determined how much these drops affected their revenues.
But Architectural Digest, with 1,155 ad pages in 1992, was well ahead of HG, with 760. The two were almost equal in circulation. At the end of 1992 HG led with 695,958, compared with 653,648 for its rival, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations.
Kevin Madden, the publisher of HG who will become publisher of Bon Appetit, said that HG had expanded its advertising base to categories like fashion, beauty and automotive but that even these had not been able to counter the loss of business in its core category of home furnishing.
 
No Thought of a Sale

 Mr. Leser said that there had been no thought of selling HG or of downgrading it to a more mass magazine.
HG, in the days when it was known as House & Garden, was far more of a middle-class magazine than in recent years. In 1981, under its editor in chief, Louis Oliver Gropp, now editor in chief of Hearst's House Beautiful, it began to upgrade itself and compete against Architectural Digest.
In 1987, Anna Wintour, who had been editor in chief of British Vogue, took over and in an effort to revitalize it made the magazine younger and hipper, and changed its name to HG. Many readers were appalled and canceled their subscriptions. Ms. Wintour went on to become editor in chief of Vogue and Ms. Novogrod, second in command, became editor in chief.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

INDUSTRY: SIC2721 PERIODICALS: PUBLISHING, OR PUBLISHING & PRINTING (90%);

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Citicorp and Chemical Post Jumps in Earnings

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL

 BODY:
Citicorp and several other major banks reported sharply increased earnings yesterday, largely because their losses from bad loans had fallen faster than expected.
The loan income of many banks continues to be strong because of the wide gap between the interest they charge on loans and what they pay on deposits. And banks that actively trade currencies and securities have posted stellar results in these areas largely because of declines in European interest rates, which raise the value of their European bonds. 
 In addition, most banks enjoyed an earnings gain in the latest quarter because of new accounting rules that allow them to recognize now the value of tax credits that they will be able to use in the future.
Despite the overall solid performance, bank stocks fell. The Standard & Poor's index of money-center bank stocks declined by 1.9 percent yesterday, and its regional bank index fell by 2.5 percent. Analysts said investors might be worried about the prospect of rising interest rates.
"Every number reported was better than we expected," said Robert Albertson, a banking analyst with Goldman Sachs & Company. "The bottom line is the stocks are down for reasons other than the earnings."
Following are the details of the banks' results:
 
Citicorp
 Citicorp reported a profit of $670 million for the quarter, benefiting from a $300 million gain from the accounting change related to income taxes. The bank's revenue before accounting changes of $370 million was almost double the $183 million reported a year earlier.
The earnings increase at the nation's largest banking company was largely a result of a 44 percent decline in the amount set aside for future loan losses, to $689 million. The bank also benefited from lower losses on credit card loans and increased trading revenue.
The bank took a charge of $64 million to cover costs associated with getting out of the business of managing money in India.
Losses from Citicorp's huge North American real estate portfolio continued to decline. The bank wrote off $168 million of real estate loans, down from $194 million in the fourth quarter and $362 million a year ago. Citicorp sold $125 million in foreclosed real estate, mostly at 67 percent of the original value.
The bank's Tier 1 capital, a measure of its financial strength, increased to 5.2 percent from 4.9 percent at the end of 1992.
At Citicorp's shareholder meeting in New York yesterday, John S. Reed, the chairman, said Citicorp would probably not restore its dividend until next year.
Citibank reported a return on equity of 17.9 percent, or 14.3 percent before the accounting change, up from 7.2 percent a year earlier.
 
Chemical <HGE>
 The Chemical Banking Corporation reported a profit of $374 million, up 44 percent from $260 million a year earlier.
The latest results for the No. 3 banking company were reduced by a restructuring charge of $30 million for its acquisition of most of First City Bancorporation of Texas. The net gain from accounting changes related to income taxes and to retiree benefits was $35 million.
The bank's interest income rose slightly, to $1.2 billion, and the income from trading and fees climbed 15 percent, to $925 million.
Chemical's credit quality was stable, as it charged off $312 million of bad loans, other than loans to developing companies, and replenished its reserves by the same amount. The charge-offs were about the same as in the fourth quarter of last year and down from $375 million in the first quarter of 1992.
Chemical said its merger with the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation last year had reduced expenses by $110 million in the quarter. More than 5,500 jobs have been eliminated.
The bank's Tier 1 capital rose to 7.4 percent from 6.6 percent last year. And its return on equity increased to 16.5 percent from 13.24.
 
Banc One
 The Banc One Corporation reported a profit of $272 million in the first quarter, up from $171 million a year earlier. The 1992 results were restated to reflect several acquisitions, including the Valley National Corporation in Arizona.
Earnings at the nation's eighth-largest banking company were bolstered by a 10 percent increase in net interest income and by a sharply lower provision for possible credit losses. Fee income was down slightly.
Banc One, based in Columbus, Ohio, reported a gain of $18 million related to the accounting for income taxes and a charge of $20 million related to the Arizona acquisition.
Banc One's return on equity reached 19.24 percent, up from 13.22 percent a year earlier.
 
Bankers Trust
 The Bankers Trust New York Corporation reported earnings of $155 million for the first quarter, after a $75 million charge for accounting changes related to retiree benefits, against earnings of $600 million a year earlier, which were restated to include $446 million from accounting changes related to income taxes.
Excluding the accounting changes, profits at the No. 7 banking company rose 49 percent, to $230 million.
Bankers Trust, which concentrates on currency and securities trading, benefited substantially from the volatile European markets. Trading revenues were up 60 percent, to $346 million. Earnings from interest, which are largely related to securities held in the trading account, increased 70 percent, to $270 million.
The bank reported a return on equity, disregarding the accounting changes, of 24.3 percent, up from 19.8 percent a year earlier.
 
Wells Fargo
 Wells Fargo & Company reported net income of $108 million for the first quarter, down 9 percent from $119 million a year earlier.
The nation's ninth-largest banking company attributed most of the decline to higher expenses for salaries, foreclosed property and advertising.
The loan portfolio of the San Francisco-based company, which is a major California real estate lender, appeared to be improving. Wells set aside $210 million for future loan losses, down slightly from $215 million a year earlier and down significantly from the $300 million in the final quarter of 1992.
Charge-offs for bad loans decreased to $155 million from $199 million in the previous quarter, with improvements in commercial real estate and construction loans. The bank charged of $150 million in bad loans in the first quarter of last year.
The bank's profitability slipped, with a return on equity of 12.1 percent, versus 15.4 percent a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Serving Up Blackjack Along With Borscht?;
Catskills Resort Owners Put Their Hopes in New Attitudes Toward Casino Gambling

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KIAMESHA LAKE, N.Y., April 19

 BODY:
George Parker is fed up with the name Borscht Belt. As chairman of the Concord, one of the largest resorts in the Catskills, he is tired of being associated exclusively with the comedy, dance styles, decor, music and even food of another era. Sick, in other words, of running on nostalgia.
So as he strolls through his 1,225-room hotel, past the 1968 photograph of a youthful Woody Allen looking like a deer caught in headlights, past the club where his onetime baby sitter, Buddy Hackett, got his start, past the dining room where, indeed, borscht is still served, he is talking about a new vision. A vision with appeal to middle-class families and upscale singles, a vision more exciting than shuffleboard or even Simon Sez, a vision for the 90's. 
 Mr. Parker is talking about slot machines.
"We're already surrounded by casino gambling," he said. "By next year, you'll be able to drive three hours in just about any direction and reach a casino. It's going to be pervasive. And if New York doesn't do something, it will lose out."
For more than a decade, the resort owners of the Catskills -- a dying breed -- have argued that casino gambling was as important to their survival as liquor licenses, golf courses and indoor pools were in the 1940's, 50's and 60's. And for over a decade, the Legislature has voted against them.
But this year, the entreaties have gained a sudden urgency because of the spread of casino gambling nationwide. Last year, the Mashantucket Pequot Indians opened a casino in Connecticut, 1 of 19 states with Indian gambling compacts and the first in the Northeast. In the last five years, South Dakota, Colorado, Illinois, Iowa, Missouri, Louisiana and Mississippi have legalized some form of casino gambling off Indian reservations, joining Nevada and New Jersey.
And last week, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo signed a compact that virtually assures the opening of a high-stakes casino by the Oneida Indians near Syracuse. A second compact, with the St. Regis Mohawks near the Canadian border, may be signed within weeks.
Faced with the likelihood that New Yorkers will be traveling in droves to wager millions not only in other states but in non-taxable Indian communities within their own, state legislators are looking at gambling with a fresh and, many say, supportive eye.
"The dynamic is very different than last time this came up," said Assemblyman John J. Faso, a Republican from Coxsackie who opposes gambling. "Because of the bad economy and because people see other states doing it, they're saying, 'Let's jump on the bandwagon.' "
Quietly and largely behind the scenes, lobbying for statewide gambling is well under way. The Catskills Resort Association, which represents the region's nine largest hotels, has retained one of Albany's best known lobbyists, Lester M. Shulklapper, for $25,000 a year. A statewide hotel association is expected to add its support. And gambling proposals with bipartisan support have been introduced in both houses of the Legislature.
Opponents are hedging their bets. The Racing and Wagering Industry of New York, which represents race tracks, has begun telling Legislators that casino gambling is a bad idea unless it is done in Offtrack Betting parlors or at race tracks.
The battle could be a long one. A constitutional amendment is needed to make for-profit casino gambling legal, and that requires approval by two successive Legislatures followed by a statewide referendum. The earliest a gambling proposal could go before voters would be the fall of 1995.
 
Issue Has Changed
 By comparison, a 1988 Federal law allows federally recognized Indian tribes to open high-stakes casinos once they sign agreements with the states where they reside.
Legislative leaders have said it is too early to gauge support for the measures, and they said no proposal is likely to be brought to a vote soon.
John E. McArdle, a spokesman for Senate Majority Leader Ralph J. Marino, said: "He's troubled by the expansion of gambling opportunities. But he realizes with gambling on reservations, the idea has to be acknowledged."
From Far Rockaway to Niagara Falls, resort owners have been buoyed by the state's compact with the Oneidas, which they say will soften moral opposition to gambling. And while Indian casinos are exempt from state taxes, casinos in resort communities could fatten state coffers in otherwise lean times.
 
'Where It Does Most Good'
 In Illinois, six riverboat casinos that have been operating since last year generate $8.3 million in state and local taxes each month, according to the Illinois Gaming Board.
"People will now say, we've got gambling anyway, we might as well put it where it does the most good," said David A. Slutsky, vice president of the Nevele Hotel in Ellenville.
Nowhere has talk about casinos been more fervent than in the Catskills, where the once-thriving resort industry has become a shadow of its former self.
Though tourism still generates over $500 million each year and provides over 6,000 jobs in Sullivan County, those numbers have been declining steadily, county officials say. The county's unemployment rate, 11.3 percent, is almost 4 percentage points higher than the state average. And since 1990, three major resorts -- including the famous Grossinger's -- have filed for bankruptcy or closed.
"It's not what it used to be, let's put it that way," said Mr. Shulklapper. "You can see it in the deferred maintenance at hotels. And the attendance is not what it used to be. It's just as easy to go to Atlantic City."
 
Empty Pools, 'For Rent' Signs
 All along State Highway 52 between Ellenville and Liberty are signs of the Catskill's demise: empty swimming pools grown thick with ivy, bungalow colonies with cracked paint and loose shutters that bang in the wind, darkened hotels with "for rent" signs. Here, the billboards seem to advertise only themselves.
Even at major resorts which have weathered and sometimes prospered through recession, there is a sense that time is frozen in the 1950's, the region's heyday. Sound systems play Muzak versions of Broadway showtunes. Jell-O is a featured desert. And mirrors are a major component of every lobby.
To some, that is a sign the region has failed to stay competitive. "Once this generation passes on, they are going to need something to get their children to come," said Mike Cotton, a bartender at the Nevele. "Gambling could be it."
Catskill resort owners say they would market casino gambling as one attraction among many, no different than golfing or tennis, and just as suitable for families.
Mr. Parker of the Concord would convert a 24,000-square-foot lounge into a gambling room. "You could leave your kids and play blackjack for an hour," he said, "and your child wouldn't even know the casino was here."
The third generation of a family that has owned the hotel since 1937, Mr. Parker bristled at the notion that casinos would attract prostitution or crime. "I don't care where you go," he said, "you have those things."

GRAPHIC: Photo: As chairman of the Concord, George Parker heads one of the largest resorts in the Catskills and his vision, like his entertaiment rooms, is expansive. Where once nostalgia and borscht ruled supreme, he now sees slot machines. (Dan Cronin for The New York Times)
