HEADLINE: Democrats Muster Only Weak Majority on Stimulus Package

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
Senate Democrats barely mustered a majority on a test vote today for the scaled-down version of President Clinton's economic-stimulus bill and made no progress toward breaking a Republican filibuster.
Five Democrats deserted the President when the Senate voted, 52 to 46, to make the $15.4 billion measure he proposed last Friday, reduced from an earlier $19.5 billion, the bill it will consider if it ever gets to a final vote. A vote on ending the filibuster is scheduled for Wednesday morning, but most Democrats expect to fall short of the 60 votes that Senate rules require to halt debate. 
 Fifty-two Democrats voted for the $15.4 billion measure. Forty-one Republicans voted against it. They were joined by five Democratic Senators, James J. Exon and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska, Russell Feingold and Herb Kohl of Wisconsin and Richard Shelby of Alabama. Two Republicans did not vote.
Earlier, the Senate Republicans had offered an alternative of their own, which was rejected on a 53-to-45 vote. That plan proposed to spend $4 billion for extended unemployment benefits, and another $2 billion for highways, summer youth jobs, immunizations and small-business loans.
 
Wary of the Deficit
 Republicans have insisted that they oppose Mr. Clinton's program because it would add to the Federal deficit, so they proposed to make up for their $2 billion in stimulative spending with $2 billion in unspecified "administrative savings" in the Federal departments that handle those programs.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the majority leader, sought to make Mr. Clinton the issue. He said Republicans had voted for stimulus programs that increased the deficit when Ronald Reagan was President. But now, he said: "Our Republican colleagues don't want to give the President a chance. They want to embarrass the President and cause his program to fail."
Senator Mark O. Hatfield, Republican of Oregon, disagreed. "It's not to embarrass the President, but it's because we believe we have come to a day of reckoning," he said. "This is the day of accountability."
He said the issue was not "gridlock," as Democrats argued, but "a distinction of principle between the two political parties." While the 43 Senate Republicans often differ among themselves, he said, "fundamentally and basically we are all fiscal conservatives."
 
Whose Gridlock Is It?
 Mr. Hatfield had failed to persuade his Republican colleagues to support a slightly more expensive program, one with $4 billion in stimulus spending besides the unemployment money, and $4 billion in reductions in administrative expenditures.
Senator Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia, the Democrat who heads the Appropriations Committee, said Republicans were willing to pay for jobless benefits but not for programs that would create jobs and get people off the unemployment rolls. He said the "minority perpetuates the gridlock."
Some senators said they thought that the expected failure of Wednesday's vote to end debate would finally lead to the first serious efforts at compromise since the fight began three weeks ago. Others said the Democrats were likely to give up and settle for the unemployment money alone in the Senate and make the case to the country that the Republicans were the party of inaction and stalling.
Mr. Byrd would not predict what would happen if the vote to end debate failed. "We'll roll our britches up when we get to the creek," he told reporters.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Pfizer Inc. and SmithKline Beecham reported robust gains yesterday in American drug sales for the first quarter. The results reflected strong demand for new products at both companies, overcoming the growing pressures on prices that had depressed results at many drug companies.
Pfizer shares jumped $3.25, closing at $65.125 on the New York Stock Exchange, as drug stocks rose again yesterday, continuing Monday's upswing. SmithKline Beecham's American depository receipts gained $1.50, to $34.75, on the Big Board. The London-based company said its American pharmaceutical sales were up 25 percent. 
 Analysts said drug stocks were benefiting as investors sold airlines and other cyclical stocks. "Fear of radical changes in health care may be diminishing," Barbara Ryan, a pharmaceutical analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, said. "Tides have swung. The health-care marketplace is already visibly reforming, and President Clinton is having his share of problems."
 
Pfizer
 Pfizer's American drug sales were up 23 percent in the quarter over the year earlier, with only about 3 percent coming from price increases. Worldwide drug sales rose 19 percent.
"Virtually all our sales growth was from increased volume," William C. Steere Jr., Pfizer's chairman, said. The New York-based company has promised to keep increases within the general inflation rate.
Sales from continuing operations rose 15 percent in the quarter, and earnings before accounting charges and gains were up 25 percent.
Counting former revenues of three low-profit-margin units that Pfizer sold last year, overall sales rose 6 percent in the quarter. The company sold its Shiley heart valve, Coty cosmetics and minerals businesses for $824 million in all.
Noncash accounting changes last year for future retiree health benefits and new tax reporting rules had depressed 1992 earnings.
Arvind Desai, an analyst with Mehta & Isaly Worldwide Pharmaceutical Research, said Pfizer had the "best results so far of the U.S.-based drug companies."
Sales of Pfizer's Procardia XL heart drug increased 27 percent in the quarter, to $333 million. And Zoloft, an antidepressant, rose 23 percent, to $94.5 million.
 
SmithKline Beecham
 Reflecting a sharp decline in the British pound to $1.49 in the quarter, compared with $1.73 a year earlier, net income fell 4 percent in dollars. By contrast, profit in pounds was up 13.6 percent.
SmithKline Beecham's American results marked a turnaround from former heavy dependence on Tagamet, a $1 billion-a-year ulcer treatment. The company's worldwide drug sales rose 15 percent even though Tagamet declined 23 percent in the quarter.
Pointing to its success in selling to mail-order pharmacies and other managed-care discount buyers, SmithKline Beecham said its overall net prices had actually declined slightly in the quarter.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Yields Little Changed

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The yields on Treasury bonds and notes were little changed yesterday as investors and traders kept prices in a narrow trading range.
The yield on the 30-year bond rose to 6.75 percent, from 6.72 percent Monday, as the price fell 11/32 , to 10427/32 in secondary trading. The yield has bounced from 6.75 percent to 6.72 percent since last Wednesday. 
 Prices of Treasury notes were mostly unchanged, or up or down just 1/32 . But the decline in the discount rate on Treasury bills continued. Yesterday, the discount rate on the three-month bill fell to 2.77 percent, its lowest level since Oct. 8, 1992, when many investors and traders were betting that the Federal Reserve would have to cut short-term interest rates to assure that the economic recovery would keep going.
Fewer analysts and forecasters agree with that outlook today, but that has not slowed the recent decline in short-term interest rates.
There was little news to move the market, although the Commerce Department did report that housing starts in March were down 4.6 percent, in part because of bad weather.
But one analyst said that the report was basically ignored because traders and investors had already discounted for the bad weather effect last month.
 
California Issue
 The bond market swallowed a $3 billion issue from California yesterday, the largest single issue in the tax-free municipal market this year. The sale came as the state faced another round of budget cutting and revenue deficiencies that officials are hoping will not degenerate into another long legislative stalemate.
California, which is one of the largest issuers of municipal debt, sold an issue of short-term revenue anticipation notes through Lehman Brothers.
This type of note is used by many states, cities and towns for temporary borrowings in anticipation of revenue collection. The borrowing is needed to even out irregular income flows into the treasuries of states and local government.
The California notes, due on June 24, 1993, have a 3 percent coupon and are priced at a premium to yield 2.50 percent.
Moody's Investors Service gave the issue a MIG-1 rating, its highest for short maturities, while Standard & Poor's gave it an SP-1, a notch below its highest. The short-term top rating for California, given its fiscal problems last year, when it had to issue i.o.u.'s during a long budget stalemate, and the expectation of trouble again this year, is a plus for the state.
 
Lehman Ouster
 Mariel Clemensen, the director of high-yield bond research at Lehman Brothers, was ousted from the firm last week, it was disclosed yesterday. A Lehman spokesman said she would be replaced by Mark Grotevant, an analyst at the firm.
Neither Ms. Clemensen, who has built a reputation for careful analyses of corporate cash flows, nor a Lehman spokesman would say why she had left. But one person familiar with the situation called it a case of conflicting management styles.
Reached at her home, Ms. Clemensen said, "Lehman and I are exploring mutually acceptable means of concluding the relationship." She said she had a number of opportunities in the securities business and in investment management.
Ms. Clemensen came to Lehman almost two years ago, having previously run high-yield, or junk-bond, research, at Citicorp and Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. She said she was proud of "completely revitalizing" the high-yield research effort at Lehman.
Lehman said Glenn Reynolds had been appointed to the newly created position of director of investment-grade bond research. He and Mr. Grotevant will report to Martha Dillman, director of fixed-income research.

HEADLINE: Bank for East Europe Lives Well in London

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, April 20

 BODY:
Jacques Attali has never been accused of excessive modesty in his grand plans for the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, the institution set up two years ago by the United States and other Western governments to help speed Eastern Europe's transition to capitalism.
Whether the bank will live up to Mr. Attali's goal of promoting democracy and ultimately forging a single vibrant market from Lisbon to Moscow may not be known for years. But Mr. Attali, the bank's president, has made sure it has a headquarters to match his vision. 
 For the last week Mr. Attali has been criticized for spending more taxpayer money on the new headquarters -- and on his flights on private jets -- than the bank has lent so far to the struggling economies of the former Soviet bloc. The Financial Times dubbed the institution "the bank that likes to say yes -- to itself," after it was the first to compare the bank's $300 million spending on itself with the $150 million it has lent out.
Nearly $83 million of its spending was on the new London headquarters, a gleaming building in the financial district that looks more like a Hollywood set designer's version of Big Business than the home of a government-financed bureaucracy. Standard marble was not good enough for the lobby, bank officials decided. So they tore it out and replaced it with higher-quality stone. The cost: $1.1 million.
 
Meeting With Chairman
 Mr. Attali, a French intellectual who discussed the issue today in a meeting with Theo Waigel, the German Finance Minister who is chairman of the bank's board, has strongly defended the institution's record. The bank said it was "very cautious in the use of shareholders' money and is subject to auditing procedures, as well as the control of its governing bodies." It said the new building "was found and fitted out in record time, with value for money and within the approved budget."
After the meeting, Mr. Waigel said that there would be tighter controls on the bank's spending.
The timing of the flap is particularly bad for Mr. Attali, who next week will be host at the annual meeting of the bank to the nations that are its owners, including the United States, the largest shareholder.
Many nations, including the United States, have expressed impatience at times with the slow pace of lending to Eastern Europe. Bank officials said they had approved $1.66 billion worth of loans and other investments, and that through the end of March had disbursed $166 million of it. They said the gap was caused by the inability of companies, entrepreneurs and governments in Eastern Europe to complete deals on agreed-upon terms, not by problems at the bank.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar's Decline Continues; Key Low vs. the Yen Is Near

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar continued its tumble to postwar lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, closing in on the psychologically important 110-yen level.
The dollar also fell against most major European currencies but managed to end unchanged against the German mark largely because of heavy cross-selling, in which traders sold marks mostly to buy yen and British pounds. 
 Gold slipped in New York after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 40 cents an ounce, to $339.90. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $339.50, also off 40 cents.
Currency trading was light but volatile, with the dollar falling against the yen on Asian markets but then holding ground in New York.
In Tokyo, the dollar fell to another record low of 110.25 yen, down 0.75 yen from Monday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 110.63 yen. In late afternoon trading in New York, the dollar was quoted at 110.55 yen, down from late Monday's 111.10 yen.
Alison Gibbs, an analyst with MMS International, said that as the dollar neared the 110-yen level, traders were becoming nervous about possible action by central banks to stem the dollar's decline.
Many market participants believe that the 110 level is a floor used to guide international currency policy. The United States and other major industrialized nations have expressed support for a lower dollar as a way to reduce Japan's huge trade surplus.
The dollar seemed to decline initially in New York on a Commerce Department report that housing starts slumped 4.6 percent in March. But the market ultimately brushed off the slowdown in construction, concluding that it was largely a result of the mid-March blizzard in the East and was not a signal of a worsening in economic conditions.
Some analysts also traced the dollar's fall to a report of a $200 million sale by the Bank of Finland. The bank was said to have sold the dollars as the final phase of a deal that first involved buying yen, then selling the yen to buy dollars, and finally selling the dollars to buy marks.
"The best thing you can say about today is there was a lot of confusion," Mr. Gibbs said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Apple Computer Will Open Sales Operation in Mexico

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 20

 BODY:
Affirming its commitment to the personal computing market in Mexico, Apple Computer Inc. said today that it was opening Apple Computer Mexico. The new marketing and distribution development office will provide local sales, marketing, service and support to Apple's resellers, third-party software developers and partners in Mexico.
"The Mexican marketplace offers tremendous growth opportunities for both Apple and our partners," John Floisand, the president of Apple Pacific, said in a statement. "We're convinced we'll be able to build a strong infrastructure in Mexico capable of addressing customer needs in all market sectors." Apple Computer Mexico is part of Apple Latin America, which is one of five regions that make up Apple Pacific. 
 Emerging markets like Mexico are critical to Apple's continued growth through the 90's and beyond, the company said. Mexico has been identified as a key area of expansion for Apple; it is the fastest-growing market in Latin America and would probably grow further under the North American Free Trade agreement with the United States and Canada.
According to the International Data Corporation, the PC market in Mexico is projected to reach nearly $1 billion in sales in 1993, up 29 percent from the previous year. International Data also estimated that the market would grow 24 percent a year through 1995.
 
Mexico Will Be a Growth Area
 Apple would be the first personal computer company to establish a major sales force in Mexico, although the International Business Machines Corporation, the Hewlett-Packard Company and the Digital Equipment Corporation have had minicomputer sales organizations there, said Tim Bajarin, an analyst with Creative Strategies.
"The Mexican economy has always been viewed as too weak and unstable" to warrant a major effort, Mr. Bajarin said. Apple's move indicated that it expected "that possibly because of Nafta or other productivity gains, Mexico is going to become a growth area," he added.
Allan White, the managing director of Apple Latin America, will lead the organization through the 1993 fiscal year. "The Apple Computer Mexico team is executing on a long-term plan aimed at tapping the $1 billion PC market potential in Mexico," Mr. White said in a statement. "Over the next 12 months, we intend to aggressively expand our presence by implementing high-profile marketing and promotional programs supported by a strong local organization."
Apple said it was applying a proved business model to developing the Mexican market. The Apple Federation model is a network of affiliated, interdependent companies that join with Apple to meet the specific, local market requirements of its customers. In November 1992, Apple broadened its distribution in Mexico to include three new resellers: Vertex, Dicom and Edumac, while continuing a longstanding distribution relationship with Genetec. All four companies are based in Mexico City.

HEADLINE: Mexico Gets Trade Praise

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: GENEVA, April 20

 BODY:
The world trade body GATT praised Mexico's trade practices today as among the most open in the world but criticized its import limits on foreign automobiles.
A GATT report also said the North American Free Trade Agreement should stimulate investment in Mexico and enhance its access to markets in Canada and the United States, but it also warned that the pact might intensify preferential trade. 
 The ruling council of the 109-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade discussed the report at a two-day meeting ending today.
GATT economists said in their report that Mexico had become a largely open economy driven by the private sector. Inflation fell to 11.9 percent last year, the lowest rate in 20 years.
Although the average tariff rate is now 13 percent -- half of the rate 10 years ago -- GATT said tariff protection remained higher than average for automobiles, computers, iron and steel, metal manufactures, basic chemicals and electrical machinery.
Referring to automobile imports still being subject to foreign exchange balancing requirements and to a limitation of a given share of domestic sales, the GATT report said, "Such continued import protection seems incompatible with Mexico's overall policy of trade liberalization."
Japanese and Korean delegates joined in the report's criticism of Mexico's limits on foreign automobiles, according to trade sources who attended the closed-door talks.

HEADLINE: Run vs. Swim? Statistician Says The Score Is In

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA

 BODY:
DR. HOWARD WAINER, a swimmer and statistician at the Educational Testing Service in Princeton, N.J., first began wondering if runners spend energy as efficiently as swimmers when he was an undergraduate in the early 1960's, and used to argue with his runner friends over whose workout was harder.
Now he has put those two interests together in a study published in the current issue of Chance, the journal of the American Statistical Association. 
 The human body, it seems, simply was not meant to move quickly through water. Dr. Wainer's study found that champion runners can go about three and a half times farther than champion swimmers in the same amount of time. But in that time, the less efficient swimmers burn 25 percent more calories.
Swimmers can take solace, however, in the finding that they appear to be better conditioned as athletes. Runners' performances peter out as their distances get longer, while swimmers maintain a much more consistent pace. And female swimmers are faster, compared with female runners, than male swimmers are compared with male runners.
 
Data From Record Books
 If a person is running at top speed for a given length of time, say 20 minutes, and another person is swimming at top speed for that time, Dr. Wainer asked, how far will the runner go relative to the swimmer? To answer the question, he looked at world record times in running and swimming, so as to be sure he was comparing the very best performances in the two sports. He found that the theoretical maximum ratio is 3.75 to 1 for male athletes, which means that in 20 minutes a man can run 3.75 times as far as he can swim. The ratio was 3.5 for women in a 20-minute period. The ratio differs slightly for different times.
The study, said Dr. Sally Morton, a statistician at the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif., is "creating a buzz in the statistics community among the more athletic biathlete-triathlete types."
One immediate consequence of the results, said Dr. Al Loosli, a sports physiologist at the Center for Sports Medicine at St. Francis Memorial Hospital in San Francisco, is that it allows athletes to calculate whether they are more efficient runners or swimmers by looking at the ratio of their best times.
Some statisticians say they are already putting that idea into practice. Dr. Morton, who is a competitive long-distance ocean swimmer, said that she immediately calculated her relative speeds of running versus swimming to see if they came close to the theoretical maximum, which is 3.5 to 1 for female athletes. Her ratio, she said, was 2.6 to 1, indicating that she swims much better than she runs.
Dr. Richard De Veaux, a statistician at Princeton University who competes in triathlons, did the same thing. He said his ratio was exactly the same as the figure Dr. Wainer calculated for male athletes, 3.75 to 1. "The way I look at it, I'm equally bad at both sports," Dr. De Veaux said.
Dr. De Veaux said he was intrigued with Dr. Wainer's analysis. "I thought it was absolutely fascinating," he said.
 
Old Approach Rejected
 Dr. Wainer said that when he analyzed the relative efficiencies of running and swimming, he deliberately rejected an approach that had been tried in the past: to assume that the efficiency of exercise depends on the number of calories that are required to move one gram of body mass a distance of one centimeter. In this sort of analysis, the time factor is ignored, since whether someone walks a mile or runs it, the total energy expended would be the same. This is the basis of advice, often given by trainers in health clubs, who say that people wanting to lose weight are just as well off walking as running as long as they keep their distance constant.
"That idea seemed patently false," Dr. Wainer said. "It seemed to me that the distance traveled isn't the key thing. It's how hard it is to do it."
Dr. John Duncan, an exercise physiologist who is associate director of the Cooper Institute for Aerobics Research in Dallas, agreed with this approach. The idea that only distance matters in calculating efficiency "is an old myth," he said. Dr. Duncan said his group found substantial differences in calories expended when women strolled, walked quickly or race-walked for three miles.
Dr. Wainer theorized that the greater efficiency he found in female swimmers, as opposed to men, might be a result of women's having more body fat. He said the body fat might be an advantage for women in swimming, helping them to remain parallel to the surface of the water, but a hindrance in running.
Given the ratios he found for swimmers and runners, as well as measurements of oxygen consumption, Dr. Wainer deduced that champion swimmers burn 25 percent more calories than runners in a given time.
This finding, Dr. Duncan said, is somewhat surprising because swimmers in general tend to have lower heart rates when they exercise than runners. Also, many people who take up swimming to lose weight are disappointed when the sport does little to burn off extra fat, perhaps because they do not exercise at extremely high intensity levels, Dr. Duncan said.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
Mets Are Considering Building a New Stadium

BYLINE: By JOE SEXTON

 BODY:
After nearly two years of consideration, the Mets have begun serious exploration of a plan to demolish Shea Stadium and construct a new stadium -- perhaps domed -- as part of an elaborate development project that could begin construction by the end of the decade.
The plan, which would require the approval of the city and state as well as the participation of any number of private investors, might include a multipurpose convention center, underground parking garages as well as one or more hotels. Construction would be on the stadium's current site or perhaps an adjacent area in the Willet's Point section of Queens. A direct transportation link with LaGuardia Airport might also be involved. 
 The Mets refused to confirm or deny the plan last night. "There's nothing I can say," said Fred Wilpon, one of the team's owners.
 
Idea Floating Around
 But people in the Mets organization familiar with some of the details of the plan said that Wilpon, who has made successful as a real estate developer in New York, has floated the idea with state and city officials in an attempt to sound out the chances for executing the deal.
Evidently encouraged, the Mets have in the last month begun to undertake a complex assortment of feasibility studies -- environmental and economic impact projections among them -- that would be required to gain approval for such an project. According to one Mets official, if the club, the city and the state were to pursue the plan, a minimum of one to two years would be required for the studies and it would be difficult for construction to start much before the year 2000.
Shea Stadium, which opened in 1964, is owned by the city and is run by the Department of Parks and Recreation. The Mets are tenants, and their current lease runs through the year 2,004.
The Mets official stressed last night that the plans remain exploratory and that the Mets were not irrevocably wed to any of specifics, including the idea of a domed stadium. The official also said that no specific adjacent property had been officially targeted for purchase, but that the nearby Willets Point Industrial Park was being investigated.
Vincent Tese, the chairman of the New York State Urban Development Corporation, said last that he had been told by Wilpon several years ago that the organization might be interested in developing a plan for a new stadium, but that he had not been apprised of any more specific proposal.
"There has always been a morsel of a plan," said Tese.
Asked if the state would consider becoming involved in any such a development, Tese declined to be specific.
"If it makes business sense," said Tese.
The issue of stadium development in Queens and on Long Island has surfaced any number of times since the Jets decided to leave Shea Stadium for Giants Stadium in the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, N.J., after the 1983 season. In fact, a New York State Sportsplex Corporation was formed, and in 1986 the corporation investigated the idea of constructing a domed football stadium in Flushing Meadows in an attempt to lure back the Jets. That project, which involved Donald Trump as the developer, raised concern among area businesses which would have been forced to relocate. The plan did not go forward.

SECTION: Section B; Page 13; Column 1; Sports Desk

LENGTH: 756 words

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
3 Reasons To Stay Involved

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN

 BODY:
THE SPORTS industry is approaching full throttle: hockey playoffs are under way, pro basketball is rushing toward a dramatic conclusion, and pro football's annual draft is set for Sunday.
And baseball's back.
The boycotts threatened by Jesse Jackson and his Rainbow Coalition for Fairness in Sport never materialized: Players played; fans paid. 
 On opening day in Baltimore, a small group of demonstrators stood in a drizzle and sang "We Shall Overcome" as they picketed at Camden Yards. But their voices were drowned out by organ music and cheers from inside.
Meanwhile, critics within the sports industry advised Jackson that, with all the ills afflicting minorities in other areas of society, he would do better not to concern himself with something as trivial as sports.
Stick to the inner city.
Jackson should not allow himself to be run off. He is precisely where he needs to be, and his presence might encourage economists, historians and others who once passed off sport as a trivial pursuit in the black community to refocus on this small but fertile preserve.
But why, critics ask, is Jackson so concerned about sports? Ego? Visibility? Broadening his political base?
Perhaps a bit of each. But the deeper rationale may be a matter of correcting an oversight that he and other activists made 25 years ago.
The thrust of the civil rights movement has been the dramatic fight to secure rights for the disenfranchised and the battle for equal access. The movement overlooked adding athletes of color: Their numbers were not as high as they are now and, frankly, black athletes were not seen as a group the movement needed.
Twenty-five years later, Jackson has come to see a larger picture of sport as a sprawling industry. He now sees it as a viable industry whose raw resource for the last two decades has been black and Hispanic athletes, yet one that has largely excluded those groups -- and women -- from participating at the high ends of management.
Now all three groups are key pillars in a growing civil rights movement in sports, and are perhaps the three reasons Jackson should stay involved.
What seems to concern those who would have Jackson turn his attention away from sports is that the new movement is going above the playing field, beyond the stadium, and attacking the appendages of this billion-dollar industry.
It is as if someone has lifted a huge stone and discovered a flourishing subculture of private enclaves that have functioned as a boys' club in the industries surrounding sports: in journalism, merchandising, public relations, special-event planning, concessions and management.
Critics advise political activists to keep out of sport. But the absence of an aggressive push for equal opportunity beyond the playing field is precisely why so-called minorities find themselves in their present predicament: failing to have significant control in an industry they have played a major role in building.
"Many years ago we picked cotton balls," Jackson told a reporter for the Canadian Broadcasting Corporation on Sunday. "The dishonor and the disgrace was not in working, but that we could not own the land, we could not bale and sell the cotton.
"Today we're picking basketballs with as much skill as we picked cotton balls. But when it comes to the vertical growth beyond the field, we're still locked in at the raw material base. That is not fundamental progress."
The chief problem with Jackson's plan is that he began the movement by targeting professional athletes, presumably because their visibility is highest and the potential for wielding political and economic clout is greatest.
But he has had a difficult time getting this group to respond, primarily because professional athletes, as a group, have been increasingly held hostage by their checkbooks. Jackson cannot expect to come in at the end of a process that discourages activism -- beginning in junior high school -- and expect to have a following.
In any event, Jackson's presence in sport has created discomfort and resentment. He's leading a movement to exert pressure on an industry which for decades has played by its own exclusionary rules, made change at its own pace and on its own terms.
Critics once implored Jackson not to run for president, citing it as an unrealistic aspiration. Now critics advise that he not become involved in sports.
Quite the opposite, Jackson -- and others across the nation -- should add sports to their portfolios. It's a movement whose time has arrived.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jesse Jackson (Associated Press)

SECTION: Section A; Page 22; Column 4; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 527 words

HEADLINE: On Environmental Cost-Benefit Scale, Prevention Scores High

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your "What Price Cleanup?" series (March 21-23) raises valid questions about environmental priorities and economic imperatives, but your evidence, outlook and conclusions are gravely flawed. 
 Considerations of priority and efficiency are not the invention of a "vanguard" sweeping away a national environmental program "gone seriously awry." These are considerations every serious environmentalist in this country has dealt with for at least 10 years. They continue to shape and improve the complex, evolving -- and essential -- environmental protection program of the United States.
The series contains numerous inaccuracies. Some of the most troubling:
* Superfund is painted as a program that spends millions to clean minutely contaminated industrial sites. In fact, 82 percent of Superfund sites are in residential neighborhoods. Ninety-one percent are within a mile of an operating drinking water well. The vast majority are grossly contaminated. Further, because Superfund holds polluters, rather than taxpayers, responsible for clean-up, it operates as a powerful incentive for industries to avoid polluting.
* The series plays up the scientific debate over the health effects of dioxin. But the Environmental Protection Agency is discovering that dioxin's impacts on the immune system and on wildlife make it more, not less, dangerous than first thought.
* You portray the 1988 ban on ocean dumping of New York City's processed sewage sludge as hasty and of questionable environmental value. Congress passed an ocean-dumping phase-out law in 1977; yet New York City and eight nearby communities continued, though the practice helped turn a near-shore site into a virtual toxic dead zone, and its effects at a deep-water site were unknown. The series further suggests that converting sludge into fertilizer is uneconomical -- yet for years many other cities have created jobs and revenue by thus using sludge.
* The series maintains that scientists are questioning the use of animal studies in identifying chemicals that can cause cancer in humans. Yet the National Academy of Sciences just issued a report by a panel of the country's top experts, which repeatedly confirmed the need for animal testing. Scientists have long recognized that animal studies, like most scientific methods, have limitations; but they are the best available alternative for protecting human health.
Finally, the series heralded cost-benefit analysis as the future of environmentalism. But this country has already moved beyond the cost-benefit paradigm -- a stale, 19th-century reasoning -- which serves primarily as an excuse for the fortunate to ignore disproportionate toxic burdens borne by others.
Current environmental thinking focuses on preventing problems in the first place, by means of energy efficiency, safe substitutes for toxic chemicals, whole-ecosystem land-use planning and many other practices. Nothing scores better on the cost-benefit scale than prevention, and nothing protects health and ecology so completely.
 
JOHN H. ADAMS
Executive Director
Natural Resources Defense Council
New York, April 15, 1993

PUB-DATE: April 22, 1993

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 4; National Desk

LENGTH: 912 words

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Senators Prevail, Sinking Clinton's Economic Stimulus Bill

BYLINE: By ADAM CLYMER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Senate Republicans killed President Clinton's economic stimulus program today, maintaining their filibuster until Democrats surrendered and agreed to limit the bill to $4 billion for extended unemployment benefits.
Mr. Clinton's first serious legislative defeat was marked by complaints from Democrats in the Senate and the White House. But Bob Dole, the Senate minority leader, was satisfied that the Republicans had shown that they deserved to be taken seriously. He avoided gloating, and promised occasional cooperation with the President. 
 A brief, harsh outburst from Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who heads the Senate Appropriations Committee, served as the eulogy for Mr. Clinton's original $19.5 billion measure, which was proposed in February. He said Republicans would accept "billions for unemployment, not one cent for jobs."
 
A 'Difference of Philosophy'
 On the winning side, Senator Dole quietly argued that Republicans, too, want jobs. But asserting that "a fundamental difference of philosophy has brought us to this point," the Kansas Senator said his party viewed the plan as too expensive and fatally flawed because it added to the deficit instead of having its spending matched by cuts elsewhere in the budget.
As originally offered, the bill included about $4 billion to extend unemployment benefits, $2 billion for education grants, $6 billion for highways and public improvements and $2 billion for summer jobs. The Republicans were especially critical of $2.5 billion in community development block grant spending, which they said would pay for pork barrel projects.
Senator Dole minimized the ramifications of today's action. "It's just a bump in the road for President Clinton," he said, adding that Republicans would support him on other measures, including the North American Free Trade Agreement.
The White House was not buying his argument.
 
'Politics Before People'
 "The minority leader showed that playing politics is a lot more important than putting people to work," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "The real losers here are the hundreds of thousands of Americans who won't get jobs this summer and beyond, because a minority of Republicans put politics before people."
Mr. Stephanopoulos said the White House would "come right back next week" with another version of the parts of the legislative package that were killed. He did not say how, but a regular supplemental appropriations bill for some popular elements of the program could be brought up in the House quickly.
The House is expected to act on the $4 billion in unemployment benefits money on Thursday. And while Democrats are expected to denounce the Senate Republicans for their success in killing the Clinton package, the shrunken bill is all but certain to pass.
This morning the Democrats, who hold a 57-43 majority in the Senate, failed for the fourth time to break the filibuster; under Senate rules, it takes 60 votes to end debate.
Once again, they failed to get a single Republican to vote to cut off debate. Fifty-six Democrats voted to end debate, while one, Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, voted with the 42 Republicans who were present to keep the filibuster going. Senator Alan K. Simpson, Republican of Wyoming, did not vote.
Last Friday Mr. Clinton cut his original $19.5 billion package to $16.4 billion. Then, after today's vote to end the debate failed, the Democrats offered another version, with $12.9 billion in spending and $5 billion of it offset by cuts elsewhere.
But the Republicans spurned that suggestion and offered a counterproposal of their own, with $6.55 billion in spending, up from the $6 billion plan they offered on Monday.
There were brief talks about each of these schemes, but nothing approaching serious negotiation.
Democrats had hoped that some Republicans who frequently vote with them on other issues would desert their filibuster, and tried to put heat on them at home. But one of their prime targets, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, said he fully agreed with the rejection of the Democratic offers. The Republican proposal, he said, was offered in the knowledge that there was "no likelihood it will be accepted."
That same theme was heard again tonight from Mr. Stephanopoulos, who said other losers were "the good moderate Republicans out there who wanted to come forward with a real jobs package but were prevented by their leadership."
 
Moderates Did Not Waver
 But at no point during the Easter recess did any of the moderate Republicans in the Senate appear to be wavering. Some may have hoped that a deal would be struck, but none moved to make it happen.
After the Senate voted the unemployment money by unanimous consent, Mr. Dole told reporters that he believed the Clinton Administration would now understand the value of consulting with Republicans on such future issues as health care. "I think the White House may have misjudged the fact that when we stick together, we have some influence," he said.
But Senator Byrd was unwilling to see the issue that way.
"While the other side is busy congratulating each other on proving that they are a force to be reckoned with, they have only proved to the American people that they are the guardians of gridlock," he said. "While the champagne corks are popping, millions of Americans will open a can of beans and wonder whether they are going to find a job."

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 1438 words

HEADLINE: CLINTON DECLARES NEW U.S. POLICIES FOR ENVIRONMENT

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
Repudiating two major Bush Administration environmental policies, President Clinton said today that the United States would sign an international treaty protecting rare and endangered species and follow a specific timetable to reduce the threat of global warming.
In his first major speech on environmental policy, President Clinton declared: "We cannot walk away from challenges like those presented by the biodiversity treaty. We must step up to them." 
 Speaking on the eve of Earth Day observances to environmental groups who had gathered at the Botanical Gardens in the shadow of the Capitol, Mr. Clinton said, "We also must take the lead in addressing the challenge of global warming that could make our planet and its climate less hospitable and more hostile to human life."
 
Bush Rejection Based on Cost
 President Bush had rejected both initiatives, saying they might be too expensive and would unfairly penalize some American companies.
President Clinton committed the United States "to reducing our emissions of greenhouse gases to their 1990 levels by the year 2000." Greenhouse gases, so called because they trap heat in the atmosphere like the glass panes in a greenhouse, include carbon dioxide produced by burning fossil fuels.
Mr. Clinton said that his Administration would put forward a plan for limiting greenhouse gases by August. Such limits are not expected to impose immediate, significant new costs on private industry or on the Government, although opponents of the restrictions on greenhouse gases say the restrictions will raise costs in the long term and increase Government regulation of business. Many companies and Government agencies have already started taking steps to reduce emissions of greenhouse gases.
 
A Victory for Gore
 Though Mr. Clinton had pledged the action during the campaign, his announcement on global warming was an important victory for Vice President Al Gore over Treasury Secretary Lloyd Bentsen and Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary, who, among others, had argued that such restrictions would harm American industry.
The dispute had continued into late Tuesday, with Administration officials still unsure about what to put in the speech on reducing emissions.
The treaty to protect the diversity of the world's living things, known as the biodiversity treaty, will require the approval of two-thirds of the Senate. White House officials said they did not expect major legislative opposition.
The treaty also stipulates that biotechnology companies must share profits and technologies with any countries whose biological resources they use in developing products.
Mr. Clinton has said he shares some concerns raised by Mr. Bush that this provision would weaken patent protections for biotechnology companies, discouraging research and innovation.
To get around those misgivings, the White House met with biotechnology and pharmaceutical companies, as well as environmental groups, to draft an "interpretative statement" that Mr. Clinton will attach to the United States signature on the treaty.
Vice President Gore, who has been overruled on other environmental matters like his pledge to keep a toxic waste incinerator closed in Ohio, sounded elated today over Mr. Clinton's announcement. "There was no fight on global warming with me," he told reporters. "I made a commitment and we're going to keep it."
In campaigning last year as Mr. Clinton's Vice Presidential running mate, Mr. Gore frequently described Mr. Bush's refusal to support the environmental initiatives as an embarrassment to the United States.
Mr. Bush disregarded the advice of his own chief environmental official in opposing the treaty, angering environmentalists attending the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro last June.
The speech today raised Mr. Clinton's stock with environmentalists, many of whom had attacked his decision last month to back off from a shift in Federal land policy that would have led to increased mining and grazing fees.
 
'It's a Timely Move'
 "President Clinton has brought America back into step with the rest of the world on environmental protection," said Fred Krupp, executive director of the Environmental Defense Fund.
William K. Reilly, the former administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency who had pressed Mr. Bush to sign the biodiversity treaty, said of Mr. Clinton's action: "It's a timely move, a positive new direction for the Administration. It will be very welcomed, particularly in the developing world."
Mr. Clinton also announced that he would sign five executive orders directing the Federal Government to take steps to reduce pollution in Federal agencies.
They would instruct the agencies to change their purchasing policies to use fewer substances that are harmful to the ozone layer; commit the Federal Government to buy thousands more American-made vehicles that use fuels like natural gas, ethanol, methanol and electric power; require agencies to do more to buy and use recycled products; require agencies to purchase energy-efficient computers, and require Federal offices that use toxic chemicals to publicly report their wastes and releases.
The President also announced an energy and environmental audit of the White House, to find ways to reduce waste in the lighting, heating and cooling systems.
 
A Different Course
 "For too long, we have been told that we have to choose between the economy and the environment," Mr. Clinton said, "between our jobs, between our obligations to our own people and our responsibilities to the future, and to the rest of the world, between public action and private economy. I'm here today in the hope that we can together take a different course of action, to offer a new set of challenges to our people."
White House officials said the interpretative statement to accompany the biodiversity treaty would assure American companies that they would not have to share technology with developing countries that provide resources for products manufactured by those companies.
"We think we have done the work necessary to protect the intellectual property of American industries and to protect the environment," Mr. Clinton told reporters. "We believe that all the difficulties have been worked out and that this effort will be supported by both the businesses involved and the American environmental community."
G. Kirk Raab, president of Genentech Inc., which was part of the coalition that developed the interpretative statement, said, "This is a major step forward for both businesses and environmentalists."
But some environmental organizations, in a letter to Mr. Clinton, accused him of compromising the protection of species to insure profits for biotechnology companies.
 
'Dangerously Shortsighted'
 "The Clinton-industry proposal, which undercuts international attempts to regulate the creation and release of genetically engineered organisms, is dangerously shortsighted and scientifically naive," said Andrew Kimbrell, policy director of the Greenhouse Crisis Foundation, one of the groups that signed the letter.
Despite their general praise for Mr. Clinton, several environmental groups said their one concern was that he did not say whether he would move to cap greenhouse gas emissions after the year 2000. White House officials said no decisions had been made on that course of action.
"Unless the President commits America to capping emissions and leads the world in that direction," said Michael Oppenheimer, senior scientist of the Environmental Defense Fund, "it will be like going on a diet and then gaining all the weight back."
But John Shlaes, executive director of the Global Climate Coalition, a business group, warned that further targets and timetables for emissions reductions, if carried out in an arbitrary fashion, "could jeopardize the economic health of the nation."
 
'Greatly Encouraged'
 More typical from environmental groups were the comments from Jim Maddy, executive director of the League of Conservation Voters. "We were holding our breath on global warming," he said, "and we got everything we had hoped for. We were also pleased by what Mr. Clinton said on Federal facility compliance. We felt we were going to struggle with that issue for a long, long time."
Peter A. A. Berle, president of the National Audubon Society said, "With President Clinton's commitments today, integrating environmental and economic goals, setting an example from the White House and setting out an agenda of Federal actions to conserve energy, to curb or clean up pollution, we are greatly encouraged."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President Bill Clinton laughing as Vice President Al Gore made a remark at his own expense at the beginning of Earth Day ceremonies at the United States Botanical Gardens yesterday in Washington. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times) (pg. A10)
 
Chart: "Preserving the Earth's Bounty"
 As the global economy expands and the world's population soars, people are destroying natural ecosystems and habitats so fast that some biologists say up to a quarter of the world's plant and animal species could be extinct in the next 50 years.
 Last year, at the Earth Summit meeting in Rio de Janeiro, about 150 countries, signed a treaty aimed at protecting the world's living things. The agreement, known as the biodiversity treaty, commits countries to these goals.
 
Draw up national strategies for conservation.
 
Integrate plant and animal preservation into economic planning.
 
Set up protected areas and promote the protection of entire ecosystems as well as individual species.
 
Manage biological resources outside of protected areas.
 
Take steps to restore degraded ecosystems.
 
Take inventory and of biological resources and monitor them.
 
Allow countries that are rich in species but poor in cash to share in profits from sales of pharmaceutical products or other products derived from their biological resources.
 
(pg. A10)

HEADLINE: Brazilians Vote Down Kings and Keep Presidents

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: RIO DE JANEIRO, April 21

 BODY:
Rejecting appeals to restore the country's 19th-century monarchy, Brazilians voted today to retain the system they borrowed from the United States 104 years ago -- a presidential republic.
But in a reflection of the enduring fascination with the Bragancas, Brazil's royal family, about 12 percent of voters, or eight million people, apparently obeyed the monarchist command to "vote for the King." 
 Finals results are expected Sunday. Surveys of voters leaving the polls today indicated that Brazilians also rejected another option, a parliamentary system. In a plebiscite marked by apathy and abstention, many voters told interviewers that they voted only because they were required to by law.
Paradoxically, instead of strengthening Brazil's political system, the vote today is expected to unleash a new period of political instability for Latin America's largest nation. Brazil's $450 billion economy -- roughly the size of China's and Russia's -- appears destined to face two more years of low growth and high inflation.
"The vote marks the start of a very bitter presidential campaign," said Bolivar Lamounier, a Sao Paulo political scientist. "We could have a lame-duck President for the next 20 months."
Political support is expected to rapidly peel away from Itamar Franco, who assumed presidential powers after Fernando Collor de Mello was impeached in September. Already, half a dozen major political candidates are campaigning, each one trying to emerge as leader of the opposition.
 
 In the first seven months of his presidency, Mr. Franco has experimented with three Economy Ministers. But none have been able to reduce inflation below its current rate of 25 percent a month. Today, Brazil's highest denomination bank note, the 500,000 cruzeiro bill, is worth $16.
Mr. Franco's approval ratings, as measured by the DataFolha polling organization, have dropped from 36 percent to 18 percent since February.
Continued erosion of political and public support will strip Brazil's already weak executive of the power to combat inflation. For relief, Brazilians will have to wait until a new President is elected in November 1994 and is inaugurated on Jan. 1, 1995.
With recent headlines proclaiming "The Beginning of the End," and "Itomar Against Them All," the President has counterattacked, warning politicians about the danger of "a conflagration of ambition."
"Be careful with the matches, be careful with the gasoline tank," he warned two weeks ago.
Last Friday, he announced to a military audience, "The President of the republic will never be a hostage to the results of the plebiscite, of succession politics."
Despite an hour of daily prime-time television advertising, the plebiscite failed to create public interest. Last Friday, fewer than 100 people turned out for a march held by parliamentary advocates in Sao Paulo, South America's largest city.
 
Half the Voters Stayed Home
 Polls indicated that about half of the electorate of 90 million did not understand what the referendum was about. Today, voter surveys indicated that about half the electorate stayed home or did not cast valid ballots.
"People don't even have the money to buy a newspaper," said Roberto Bernardo, a 27-year-old salesman as he waited in line to vote in Rio. "Why bother with a plebiscite? Now the politicians have stopped working to dedicate themselves to the presidential succession."
The front-runners appear to be Paulo Salim Maluf, the conservative Mayor of Sao Paulo, and Luis Inacio (Lula) da Silva, a Socialist who is president of the Workers Party.
Whoever wins will face the challenge of forging a working majority in Congress from 19 political parties now represented.
The political track record is not encouraging. Since the army overthrew Brazil's last reigning Braganca in a coup in 1889, only one elected President, Juscelino Kubitschek, has finished his term in office.

HEADLINE: Distinct Choice in Los Angeles Race

BYLINE: By ROBERT REINHOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, April 21

 BODY:
The two victors of Round 1 in the Los Angeles mayoral race are expected to present Angelenos with the clearest clash of political ideals and approaches seen in modern memory here, a memory dominated by the pacifying aura of the sphinx-like Tom Bradley for 20 years.
In Tuesday's nonpartisan election a tough-talking Republican businessman and veteran power broker, Richard Riordan, ran a strikingly strong first in this liberal city, getting 33 percent of the vote in a field of two dozen candidates. The runner-up was City Councilman Mike Woo, a polished liberal Democrat who is heir to Mayor Bradley's multiethnic coalition, with 24 percent. 
 Since neither got more than half the vote, the two men will face each other in a runoff on June 8, with the winner taking office on July 1. The election comes after two years of turmoil in the nation's second-largest city that began with the videotaped beating of Rodney G. King by police officers and seems to have come to an end on Saturday with the conviction of two officers on Federal civil rights charges.
Despite widespread demands for better police protection, voters failed to approve a ballot measure that would have financed the hiring of 1,000 police officers with a surcharge on property taxes. The measure received 58 percent of the vote, short of the two-thirds required to increase taxes in California. They did approve a limit of two terms for mayor, council members and other top elected city officials.
 
Few Similarities
 The Riordan-Woo face-off brings a sharply defined clash over how to rebuild this ethnically riven and economically depressed metropolis.
"They are both men, but I cannot think of a lot of other similarities," said Joseph R. Cerrell, a political consultant here affiliated with neither camp. He predicted a "very nasty campaign."
The 62-year-old New York-born Mr. Riordan (pronounced REAR-dihn), a lawyer and entrepreneur, calls himself a fiscal conservative and a social moderate. His largely self-financed campaign calls for shrinking city government and leasing the operations of Los Angeles International Airport to raise money to hire 3,000 additional police officers. Given widespread fears over racial disorders, his tough-on-crime stance has earned him considerable support among white and older voters, though he denies making a racial appeal.
By contrast, the boyish-looking 42-year-old Mr. Woo, a former Vietnam war protester and an urban planner who has represented the Hollywood district for eight years, has a stronger faith in the government's ability to solve problems. He promises $100 million in city-backed loans to businesses in South-Central Los Angeles and hopes to hold together the fraying coalition of blacks, liberals, Jews and business leaders that kept Mr. Bradley in office for so long. Mr. Woo has also promised to place a homosexual on the Police Commission.
 
Ideological Swipes
 In his comments on Tuesday night, Mr. Woo signaled his plan to paint Mr. Riordan as a defender of the privileged and a right-wing Republican. "Dick Riordan gets his marching orders from Ronald Reagan and his economic ideas from Michael Milken," he said, referring to the junk-bond dealer who went to jail on security-fraud charges.
In an interview today, Mr. Riordan said the race was not about class but personal safety and jobs. "Mr. Woo is trying to define me as something I am really not," he said. "This race is not about race, party or class; it's about leadership, about which of us can face the issues of safety and jobs."
The unusual demographic facts of life in Los Angeles are such that Mr. Riordan has a fairly good chance of being elected Mayor of this heavily minority and liberal city even though only 30 percent of the voters are Republican. Though about two-thirds of the population of 3.6 million is made up of Mexicans, Mexican-Americans, Asians, blacks and other minorities, the electorate is still two-thirds Anglo, as non-Hispanic whites are called here. The city's huge immigrant population is largely disenfranchised because many of them are not citizens.
Only 32 percent of registered voters turned out Tuesday, meaning that Mr. Riordan led the race with only 1 in 10 voters. If turnout in the runoff is similar, the new mayor will be chosen by as few as 226,300 people, or 16 percent of registered voters or 6 percent of the population.
 
Candidates Eliminated
 On Tuesday, the other leading candidates were far behind. They were City Councilman Joel Wachs with 11 percent; state Assemblyman Richard Katz with 10 percent; Linda Griego, a former Deputy Mayor with 7 percent; Stan Sanders, a prominent black lawyer with 4 percent; and Councilman Nate Holden with 4 percent.
Mindful that he won only minimal support in minority communities, Mr. Riordan today tried to broaden his appeal, having breakfast with black and Hispanic business leaders in South-Central Los Angeles.
In a survey of voters leaving polling places on Tuesday, voters told The Los Angeles Times that the top issues in the race were jobs and the economy, crime and gangs, education and improving the Police Department. Of those voting for Mr. Riordan, more than two-thirds cited his record as a businessman as their reason for voting for him, while a good majority of Woo voters cited his reaching out to minorities and his early call for the ouster of the former chief of police, Daryl F. Gates.
The battle lines for the June 8 runoff, then, are clearly drawn.

HEADLINE: Miscalculation, Then Embarrassment

BYLINE: By GWEN IFILL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
As Democrats have been forced to negotiate away almost all of President Clinton's package to stimulate the economy, a vexing question has emerged: How did such a small economic initiative turn into such a large political embarrassment?
By holding out for a plan that even Administration economists knew would have modest impact, Mr. Clinton expended much of his early and precious political capital on a proposal that he had never intended to make his biggest fight. And the resulting political defeat has left the Administration vulnerable to future assaults by Republicans, who surprised even themselves by finding unity. 
 With the conclusion of a deal today between Senate Democrats and Republicans, Mr. Clinton was not even able to salvage a face-saving compromise.
In recent days the second-guessing of Administration strategy has come fast and furious among Congressional Democrats and Clinton advisers. Some suggested that the President should have cut and run early in the process when Senators John B. Breaux of Louisiana and David L. Boren of Oklahoma, both Democrats, proposed a compromise that would delay some of the spending.
Mr. Clinton and his advisers began investing political and intellectual capital in the stimulus plan even before the inauguration, making it a centerpiece of his plan to revive the economy.
Once the Administration became entangled in the fight for the plan, which they insistently called a jobs bill, they left themselves no room to retreat. House members who had supported the measure with the understanding that it would send money to urban development projects, summer-jobs programs and unemployment benefits called for it to remain intact.
And Mr. Clinton himself, flush with the early legislative success of his blueprint to reduce the budget deficit, insisted several times that the entire package was necessary.
There is evidence that Mr. Clinton missed critical opportunities to win support early on and handed his foes the weapons with which to embarrass him. In a recent interview, the Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, said he was surprised that the fight over the jobs package -- which he characterized as a "flyspeck" in the larger scheme of things -- developed into such a contest of wills.
"Nobody really thought much about this stimulus package," said Mr. Dole, who has missed no opportunity to criticize it since those early days.
 
Looking for the Silver Lining
 White House officials today continued to attack the Republicans as blocking a virtuous effort, but their arguments rang hollow compared with their previously vigor defense of the bill.
"I think the majority of the American people, a majority of the House and a majority of the Senate, all support the President's jobs package," said George Stephanopoulos, the White House communications director. "But the Senate leadership was tempted to score what they thought was a political victory."
Dee Dee Myers, the White House press secretary, was eager to focus on the larger picture, saying of the President, "Obviously, he's committed to the jobs bill, but that's just one component of his larger economic plan."
And Clinton allies in Congress, wary of battles to come on campaign finance and health care, were just as happy to change the subject.
"We need to move on to something else," Senator Breaux said. "We have other big battles to fight."
Others, mostly Republicans, contended that Mr. Clinton would have fared better had he more astutely negotiated the shoals of Senate politics.
"Bill Clinton has succeeded in doing something George Bush never did," said Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah. "He united the Senate Republicans."
But it is the recriminations within the White House that signaled the magnitude of Mr. Clinton's defeat most clearly.
"Anybody who claims that with hindsight they would not have done something differently is not to be trusted," one White House official said.

HEADLINE: For Neighbors, Plan to Replace Shea Hits Home

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
A day after the Mets disclosed plans to replace Shea Stadium with a new domed stadium and development project, public officials welcomed the initiative, while neighbors expressed dismay.
In discussing what were described as highly tentative plans on Tuesday, a Mets official indicated that a new stadium could be built adjacent to the present stadium in Flushing, Queens, or as part of a more ambitious scheme in the Willets Point neighborhood to the east. Plans could include hotels, shops and even a convention center. 
 A similar project was proposed for the area in 1985. Developers were planning a domed football stadium, but they never pursued the project, which had won the backing of city and state officials. The new plans were also welcomed by some officials yesterday.
 
Mayor's Office Interested
 Jeff Maclin, a mayoral spokesman, said that there had been no detailed discussions with the Mets but that Mayor David N. Dinkins's office would be delighted to "explore any viable plan that would keep the Mets and the Yankees in New York through the 21st century and preferably lure the Giants and the Jets back here, too."
Such a development would fit into the plans of the Queens Borough President, Claire Shulman, who has been looking for an "upscale" economic development in an area now dominated by heavy-construction companies, body shops, a sawdust factory and several towing and scrap-metal businesses, said her spokesman, Dan Andrews.
Mr. Andrews said Ms. Shulman's staff was putting the final touches on a report that would call for private development of hotels and other upscale businesses in the area, which needs an estimated $25 million in street, sewer and other repairs.
"You wouldn't want to spend that kind of money on the area as it is now," he said.
That is hardly news to Ralph St. John, who owns a construction company in Willets Point. He said he had complained often about the lack of what he considers basic, essential services to small-business owners like himself.
 
Some Would Suffer
 He objected to the plan because, he said, his own business and scores of other employers might be sacrificed to make way for an upscale development on his blue-collar ground.
"When it gets valuable, they have to destroy somebody," he said, describing eminent domain, the government's right to take over property after paying the market price, as "legal tyranny."
Others who might object to a domed stadium in Willets Point could be the Airline Pilots Association. In 1985, after the Federal Aviation Administration had approved a domed stadium just across Flushing Bay from La Guardia Airport, the group complained that the stadium would pose a hazard for planes.
Details of the stadium remained a mystery yesterday, although a model, designed by Jack Gordon, an architect, has been built and city officials have been invited to take a look at it.
Parks Commissioner Betsy Gotbaum, the Mets' landlord, expects to examine the model within the next couple of weeks, said Ms. Gotbaum's spokesman, Stewart Desmond.
That suggests that the Mets plan to build the new stadium on Parks Department property in Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, perhaps on a present Shea parking lot.

HEADLINE: Administration Offers Plan for Better Schools

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration today unveiled its plan to improve the nation's public schools through a set of broad guidelines not only on school and student performance but also on the skills that young people will need to survive in an uncertain economy.
Education Secretary Richard W. Riley was joined by Labor Secretary Robert W. Reich to announce the $420 million package of legislation, which would create a board of 28 educators and representatives from business, labor, state and Federal governments. The board, which would get $15 million under the Goals 2000 legislation, would identify a broad variety of occupations for students who are not bound for college and the skills needed for those jobs. 
 Labor Department officials today said that the specific jobs and skills had not yet been identified. But they are likely to include occupations in such industries as telecommunications and health care, two areas in which jobs have gone begging for a lack of qualified workers.
Establishment of the standards board would complement a separate $270 million program between the Education and Labor Departments to improve the transition from school to work for students not college bound.
 
Goals for Year 2000
 The legislation offered today would also write into law the six national education goals that were adopted by the Bush Administration and the nation's governors -- led by Bill Clinton of Arkansas -- in 1990. The goals are intended to make American students lead the world in math, science and other core subjects by the year 2000; the Clinton package would add foreign language and the arts.
"No one will disagree that our educational system must be improved," Mr. Riley said. "By encouraging education reform across America, Goals 2000 will help create a high-skill, high-wage work force that is the best in the world."
But despite some progress on each of the goals, many educators and analysts say it is unlikely that schools will meet any of them by 2000.
The goals and the standards in the package would be voluntary, but states would be under pressure to participate or risk falling behind those who do.
Some critics wondered whether states might gain too much power from localities as a result of the legislation and whether $420 million was enough to do all that the package proposes. But even skeptics of the plan said they supported the Clinton package because of it gave a national umbrella for the national movement to restructure schools and stressed job training, two areas that even those in education circles acknowledge have been deficient.
The Bush Administration began initiatives on both national school restructuring and improved job training, but analysts said the Clinton package went well beyond those initiatives, particularly in job training.
 
Seeking Some Uniformity
 "Clearly, we ought to develop skills standards," said William H. Kolberg, president of the National Alliance of Business, a group of 3,500 companies promoting a better work force. "You can't separate education from kindergarten through 12th grade from work, and you shouldn't separate it."
The Clinton package also includes a strategy to inject some unformity into the uneven effort to improve the nation's schools. It proposes to award grants totaling $393 million to states in the first year. Those grants would be used to develop 10-year school-improvement plans based on principles like setting statewide standards for local schools, allowing individual schools more say in decision making and upgrading teacher training.
The proposal would establish curriculum standards, national tests to check whether students were learning those subject areas and standards to judge how well schools were performing.
Efforts to set curriculum standards are already under way in several subjects. Already established, for example, are mathematic standards that call for introducing the concept of probability to 5-year-olds and emphasize math's real-life applications.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Choice and Journey's End In Canadian Hotel Venture

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL

 BODY:
Choice Hotels International, the franchise hotel giant, said yesterday that it had formed a joint venture in Canada with the Journey's End Corporation, Canada's biggest hotel management company. The venture, to be called Choice Hotels Canada Inc., will initially have 174 inns, 120 of them currently owned by Journey's End.
"Together we expect to have over 500 hotels in the Canadian market in the next four or five years," said Gerald Petitt, president and chief operating officer of Choice, who described the joint venture as "a truly equal partnership." The board of directors will be "50-50," he said, "and we'll split the profits right down the middle." 
 With headquarters in Silver Spring, Md., Choice, a subsidiary of Manor Care Inc., had franchise revenues last year of just over $100 million. Its seven chains operate under the banners Clarion, Comfort, Econo Lodge, Friendship, Quality, Rodeway and Sleep Inns. Because they range from economy to upscale, two or more sometimes operate side by side.
 
Revenues of $116 Million
 Journey's End, with headquarters in Toronto, had revenues last year of about $116 million. Most of its properties are in Canada, although it also has a hotel in midtown Manhattan. The company's stock lost 50 cents yesterday, closing at $5.50 (Canadian) on the Toronto Stock Exchange.
Maurice Rollins, its founder and chief executive, will become chairman of Choice Hotels Canada. Its motels will be called Comfort Inns by Journey's End, its hotels Quality Hotels by Journey's End and its suites Quality Suites by Journey's End.
The venture will not affect ownership of current Journey's End properties, most of which are owned through limited partnerships.
The venture links the management ability of Journey's End with Choice's marketing muscle and sophisticated reservations system. That two-year-old system lets each hotel monitor and change its own room rates and inventory, as well as book guests at other Choice-brand hotels at their prevailing rates.
 
Strategy Accelerated
 The venture also accelerates the strategy of Choice to seek growth outside the United States through relationships with local franchise operators.
Canada is an especially good markeplace for Choice's strategy, Mr. Petitt said, because about two-thirds of its hotels there are independent operations, compared with only one-third in the United States.
James Carper, editor in chief of Hotels, the magazine of the international hotel industry, said the venture appeared to be a good one.
"One reason the franchise operations have to grow outside the United States," he said, "is that there isn't much more opportunity in this country. That's why they're grabbing each others' hotels and going abroad."
While only about 310 of Choice's 2,900 hotels are outside the United States, in 29 countries, many more are under construction or in development abroad.
For example, Choice signed a franchise agreement last year with CDL Hotels International of Singapore, to develop more than 30 hotels in Singapore, Malaysia, Brunei, Hong Kong, the Philippines and mainland China. Choice's partner in Mexico, Hoteles Calinda, has 16 Choice-brand hotels there. Other franchise agreements call for 20 new Choice-brand hotels in Venezuela and 10 in Costa Rica.
