HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
Agency executives unite to urge the ad cure for ailing branded products.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott

 BODY:
BRAND-BUSTERS, beware! The American Association of Advertising Agencies is getting its act together and going after you.
As the industry organization opens its 75th annual meeting in Laguna Niguel, Calif., its members -- the top executives at the nation's leading agencies -- seem united in a single cause: a concerted plea to their clients, the country's consumer-product marketers, to recognize the brand-building powers of advertising. 
 "We've got to proclaim the value of advertising, we've got to prove it, and we've got to protect it," said Roy J. Bostock, chairman and chief executive at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in New York.
At a meeting yesterday, the association's board elected Mr. Bostock as the 1993-94 chairman of the Four A's, as the organization is known, effective at the end of the conference on Saturday.
The remarks by Mr. Bostock, who is the Four A's vice chairman for 1992-93, echoed those last year of Robert L. James, the chairman and chief executive at McCann-Erickson Worldwide in New York, who is the outgoing Four A's chairman. That continuity contrasts with the zig-zag pattern the association often traced in previous years, as each chairman pursued a different project during his one-year term.
"I met with Roy last year and I told him what I was going to be doing," Mr. James said, "and I asked him to agree that there would be a two-year focus on this issue. And I'm sure Ed Wax will be agreeable, too." The reference was to Edward L. Wax, chairman and chief executive at Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York, whom the board elected 1993-94 vice chairman, also effective Saturday, making him the association's likely chairman for the 1994-95 term.
The organization's unanimity of purpose on the need to bolster brands could not come at a better time. Since April 2 -- or "Marlboro Friday" -- advertisers, their agencies and the media have been fixated on the question of whether name-brand products are losing their appeal among consumers. On that day, Philip Morris said it would begin discounting the price of Marlboros in the face of surging sales of cheaper cigarette brands. That announcement, which plunged the company's stock 23 percent and stirred a wave of selloffs among consumer product stocks, also set in motion a frenzied re-examination of the concept of branded merchandise sold at premium prices.
For advertising agencies, still struggling amid an industrywide recession about to enter its fifth year, the fate of familiar name brands is a matter of survival. After all, marketers spend far less on advertising for store brands and private-label products, and any cut in brand-name advertising threatens to deny agencies the main source of their profits.
Mr. James acknowledged that the association's concentration on brand-building might make agency executives appear as "guys in the advertising business who have an ax to grind." Even so, he asserted, unless marketers "communicate what a brand is, consumers will buy on price -- and you won't stay in business if they buy on price."
Mr. Bostock said, "We've got to make advertising work harder to build into brands the equities that make them more attractive to consumers."
The Four A's joined with the Association of National Advertisers and nine media organizations last November to form a group called the Coalition for Brand Equity, intended to help make the case for advertising's ability to increase marketers' profits by increasing the value of their brands. Larry Light, the coalition's chairman, is scheduled to address the Four A's meeting this morning on "reselling the role of advertising in building brands."
"A lot of people are saying, 'Larry, I feel so sorry for you,' " Mr. Light said in a telephone interview Tuesday from Stamford, Conn., where he is president of the Arcature Corporation, a marketing consulting company.
"I tell them, 'I couldn't have choreographed this better,' " he added. "You couldn't give me a better time than this to talk about refocusing our attention on the importance of creating, maintaining and restoring the economic value of brands."
Providing a preview of his address, Mr. Light said that Marlboro Friday and its aftermath "don't mean that brands are going out of business or that consumers are less brand loyal." Rather, he added, marketers have been "brand milking" by stinting on ad spending in favor of alternate bouts of sharp price rises and short-term promotional price cuts.
"You can't say, 'Because I make a quality product, I can charge anything I want,' " he continued. "If you don't put quality and value together, at some point consumers will say your product is not a good value."
About 445 people are expected to attend the annual meeting, which is being held at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in Laguna Niguel. That compares with about 420 at last year's meeting in Naples, Fla.; the increase in attendance would be the first in several years.

HEADLINE: Europe, U.S. Reach Partial Pact

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration announced today that it had reached a partial agreement with the European Community in a Government contracts dispute, but that it would proceed with trade sanctions anyway because a full settlement had not been achieved.
Mickey Kantor, the United States trade representative, said that the United States had agreed to drop "Buy American" rules for the Tennessee Valley Authority and the Energy Department's five electric power administrations. 
 In exchange, the European Community agreed to eliminate "Buy European" rules for its $20 billion electric utility equipment market.
But Mr. Kantor said the Administration would impose sanctions soon because the community did not agree to abandon its "Buy European" rules for its $13 billion telephone switching equipment market.
 
 
Scope and Timing Are Unclear
 Under the sanctions, European companies would be barred from bidding for certain Federal contracts, he said. But Mr. Kantor was unclear about their scope and timing, but said that he expected them to take effect soon and that no further negotiations were scheduled. The sanctions were originally scheduled to take effect on Thursday.
Mr. Kantor said that the sanctions would have to be narrowed and redrafted to reflect the compromise on electric power equipment, and that this could not be done today.
Sir Leon Brittan, the European Community's commissioner for external economic relations, praised today's agreement but not with much enthusiasm. "It is very important psychologically that we have withdrawn from the brink of a trade war," he said, while adding that the community reserved the right to retaliate if it did not like the American sanctions.
While the dispute over Government contracts was not as large in financial terms as those involving auto exports or computer chips, it was the first trade issue taken up by the Clinton Administration after it took office. As such, it has retained symbolic importance as a barometer of trans-Atlantic trade relations.
The American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the General Electric Company led the lobbying for the Administration to confront the European Community on Government contracts. Randall L. Tobias, A.T.& T.'s vice chairman, said in a telephone interview today that his company supported the Administration's handling of the issue, but that it would prefer an agreement to sanctions.
R. Michael Gadbaw, General Electric's vice president for international law and politics, said that he was "definitely satisfied" with the deal. The pact will allow General Electric to compete for $400 million to $500 million a year in European contracts for giant turbines used in power generation, he said.
Mr. Kantor had originally threatened to bar European companies from bidding on Federal contracts worth nearly $50 billion a year. But European businesses have been winning only $40 million to $50 million a year of these contracts, which were mostly for such local services like maintaining cafeterias in Federal buildings.
Another American official said that no decision had been made on how much the sanctions would be narrowed, but said that the narrowing would be figured in terms of the overall $50 billion in contracts on which bidding would be barred rather than focused on the $40 million to $50 million that European companies have traditionally won.
The deal reached today did not come up in talks with Sir Leon here on Monday and Tuesday, said an official involved in the negotiations, who insisted on anonymity. Instead, it was developed during the first of three trans-Atlantic telephone conversations between Mr. Kantor and Sir Leon an hour and a half before Mr. Kantor's news conference, the official said.
Mr. Kantor threatened trade sanctions at the start of February in a hard-line stand that drew praise from Congress. But there were also criticism from the European Community that the United States was engaging in "unilateral bullying" and was risking a trade war.
Mr. Kantor presented today's partial deal as one that expands trade rather than closing markets. In addition to the electric utilities deal, each side also agreed to put $7 billion to $13 billion of Government service contracts, like those for the construction of Federal buildings, under international free-trade rules. The rules guarantee that foreign companies will receive equal treatment for their bids with American companies.
 
 
New Rules
 At the heart of the Government contracts dispute is a provision of the European Community's new rules on Government contracting. The new rules took effect on Jan. 1, as part of the creation of a single European market, and replaced widely differing rules in the community's 12 member nations. American Administrations have been trying unsuccessfully since the 1960's to open the European market for electric power generation equipment.
The disputed provision requires that state-owned and private European utilities award contracts to European suppliers unless they are underbid by at least 3 percent by a foreign supplier. The rules also authorize utilities to dismiss any bid for which more than half of the goods are manufactured outside the European Community.
Six Federal power utilities, which supply 8 percent of the United States' electric power, award contracts to American companies unless they are underbid by at least 6 percent by a foreign supplier.
 
 
Today's Agreement
 The United States agreed today to drop the 6 percent price preference in exchange for the community's agreement to drop the 3 percent price preference and European content requirement for the community's electric utilities. But the community retained these restrictions for telecommunications, municipal water supply and urban mass transit.
According to a recent study, European companies hold 13 percent of the American telephone switching market, 28 percent of the gas turbine market and more than half of the steam turbine market. By contrast, American companies hold less than 2 percent of the European telephone switching and steam turbine markets and 13 percent of the European gas turbine market.
But European officials interviewed recently in Brussels said that these figures were deceptive, since most of the equipment sold in the United States was manufactured here by American subsidiaries of European companies. As such, they say, very little trade takes place that actually creates jobs for European workers.
The community officials also contended that the new rules replaced varying and more restrictive regulations by the community's 12 member nations.

HEADLINE: New Jersey Voters Approve 69% of Education Budgets

BYLINE: By CHARLES STRUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEWARK, April 21

 BODY:
For the second year in a row, New Jersey voters treated their school districts with relative kindness, approving 69 percent of the local budgets.
The approval rating Tuesday was far above the recent low -- 52 percent in 1990 -- but a bit less than the 73 percent recorded last year. Education officials said the 31 percent of the budgets that were defeated were victims of the perpetual concern about property taxes and a low turnout at the polls. 
 Unlike New York City, where liberal and conservative alliances have formed to elect candidates in battles over social concerns like condom distribution and curriculums that teach respect for homosexuals, New Jersey had no statewide ideological furor this year that carried over to local school board races.
But state and local officials said that voters, particularly in the state's many middle- and upper-middle-class suburbs, were still sensitive to stringent reductions in state aid that were ordered almost three years ago, when Trenton directed that large amounts be shifted from the suburbs to poor urban and rural districts.
Nevertheless, the relatively high percentage of budget approvals continued what appeared to be a calming trend among voters, who in 1990 and 1991 passed barely 50 percent of the budgets statewide in direct response to Gov. Jim Florio's $2.8 billion tax package and the Quality Education Act, which redirected aid and put caps, or limits, on local school budget increases. The caps have forced many districts to present leaner budgets by eliminating administrative jobs, special enrichment programs and elective courses.
"This strong showing of support for school budgets across the state indicates taxpayers' willingness to stand behind school officials who exercise prudence and responsibility," said Mr. Florio, who must overcome an enormous residue of anti-tax anger to win a second term in November. "People are willing to invest in quality education programs, as long as school districts are accountable and live within their means."
The state Education Commissioner, Mary Lee Fitzgerald, echoed Mr. Florio's comments and pointed out that nearly half the districts that sought voter approval to spend beyond the budget cap received it. The cap limits spending increases to 5.6 to 6.6 percent.
Although the 69 percent approval rate was slightly below last year's, the executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association, Dr. Robert E. Boose, took heart.
 
No Cuts in State Aid
 "Considering the nagging recession, high unemployment and the sentiment of many taxpayers," Mr. Boose said, "an approval rating in excess of two-thirds is remarkable."
In a statement, he said the results were attributable to several factors: a compromise school financing plan worked out in January between the Governor, a Democrat, and the Republican-led Legislature, that insured almost all districts the same amount of state aid in 1993-94 that they received this year; the fact that the plan held down property-tax increases and program cuts, and the response by school boards, which generally produced streamlined budgets.
But voter turnout, which the association estimated at 12.8 percent, was the lowest since 1987, when only 10.1 percent of the registered voters went to the polls. Turnout last year was 16.8 percent.
The association blamed low interest on frequent changes in election dates over the years and on the fact that more than two-thirds of the electorate do not have children in the public schools.
For school boards whose budgets were rejected, there is some recourse. The local board has 48 hours, or until Thursday, to submit its spending plan to the local governing body for review. The governing body can choose to adopt the original plan, compromise with the board on some reductions or order cuts. This must be done by May 14. If cuts are made, the school board can appeal to the Commissioner, the State Board of Education or the courts, though such lengthy appeals are rare.
Much of the horse trading will take place in Monmouth County, a center of anti-tax anger that approved only 37 percent of its budgets in 1991 but voted for 75.9 percent of them last year. On Tuesday, only 29 of the county's 53 budgets passed, 10 fewer than last year, for an approval rate of 54.7 percent.
Bruce Quinn, the school business administrator for the county, said Monmouth had a number of fairly wealthy districts that were ineligible for more state assistance.
And voters in some communities, like Neptune, which has had high taxes for years, continued a tradition of rejecting budgets. For the Neptune board it was the 13th defeat in a row.
"Once you get into a habit of voting them down, it's hard to break," Mr. Quinn said.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Airlines Lead Rise in Corporates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Prices of corporate issues moved slightly higher yesterday, led by a jump in the bonds of the three major airlines.
Prices of tax-exempt municipal bonds held steady and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond bounced a little, but finished at 6.75 percent, unchanged from Tuesday. 
 The corporate market was flooded with more than $1.86 billion of new issues yesterday as corporate treasurers continued to take advantage of low interest rates.
But the real focus was on the airline bonds, which seemed to move higher as one after the AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, reported a net loss of $22 million in the first quarter, a much smaller loss than expected. The results also started a rally in airline stocks.
 
Hard Times Over?
 The news seemed to make many investors believe that the worst of the hard times for airlines was over. The prices of long-term bonds for American, Delta Air Lines and the UAL Corporation, the parent of United Airlines, were all up about a point as their yields fell by about 10 basis points, said Geoffrey Kurinsky, a vice president at Massachusetts Financial Services.
That means the bonds have now rebounded from the lows they hit when they were downgraded to below investment grade by Standard & Poor's on March 11. At that time, the spread, or differential, between the yield on the airline bonds and the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond was 350 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, for Delta, 240 for American and 260 for United. Yesterday, the spreads narrowed to 300 basis points for Delta, about 200 for American and 210 for United.
Mr. Kurinsky said that the recovery of the bonds still had a way to go, however, noting that the spread between the yield on American Airlines bonds and the Treasury's 30-year bond was 150 basis points before the price of the bonds began to decline.
 
Municipals
 The prices of municipal bonds have rebounded from declines that came when the rally in the Treasury market stalled in the first week of March. And this has pushed yields lower again.
The recent low in yields, based on a basket of long-term, high-rated bonds kept by the Bond Buyer, was 5.71 percent on March 4. As Treasury yields rose in March and early April, the yield in the Bond Buyer index jumped to 6.17 percent by April 2. By late yesterday, the yield had fallen back below 6 percent to 5.92 percent.
But the yield has still not been able to regain its recent lows, although the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond has retouched its 6.72 percent low of March 8 and the yield on the 10-year note has neared its 5.82 percent low of March 4.
Traders and analysts said the reason was the continued heavy selling of new issues into an already saturated municipal market.
"The thing that has kept us away from the lows is supply," said Michael A. Bauer, a vice president in the municipal bond department at Gruntal & Company. "We are seeing up to $8 billion a week in new issues and we can't swallow all of that and move the price upward."
 
Treasuries
 The Treasury announced yesterday that at its regular monthly auction it would sell $15.25 billion of two-year notes Tuesday and $11 billion of five-year notes Wednesday. Because there was no change from the previous month in the amounts to be auctioned, the announcement provided no new clues on what revisions the Treasury might make in the quarterly auction next month.
The speculation that the Treasury may cut the size of the 30-year bond auction and even skip the auction scheduled for May has sent the price of the bond higher. The Treasury is under pressure to find some borrowing-cost savings by shifting its mix to shorter-term, lower-interest-rate securities because the Clinton Administration has assumed $16 billion of such cost reductions over the next five years in its deficit reduction plan.
In late trading in the when-issued, or pre-auction, market yesterday, the yield on the two-year note was 3.78 percent and the yield on the five-year note was 5.05 percent.
Prices of Treasury bonds and notes were little changed at the end of a volatile trading day yesterday. The price of the 30-year bond was unchanged at 10427/32 and the yield remained at 6.75 percent. Prices of Treasury notes were only 1/32 or 2/32 higher although the market got a little help when traders saw the Federal Reserve buying Treasury notes.

HEADLINE: High Mexican Interest Rates Are Luring Wall Street Cash

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
Lured by eye-catching interest rates of 16 percent or more, American money managers and a few risk-taking individuals are investing billions of dollars in Mexican Treasury securities and thus helping to finance Mexico's move to an industrial economy.
The investors are gambling that their investments will not be wiped out, as many were in the late 1970's when Mexico ordered a sweeping devaluation of the peso that when measured in dollars immediately shrank the size of the savings that thousands of American retirees had built up in Mexican banks. 
 This time, the American risk takers are not retirees but Wall Street money managers, brokerage houses and mutual fund operators with names like Fidelity, Scudder, Merrill Lynch and Bear, Stearns. Over the last year alone, foreigners -- mainly these American organizations -- have amassed $9 billion worth of Mexican Government securities, or nearly triple their holdings at the end of 1991, according to Banco de Mexico, the nation's central bank.
"There is no other country in the world where I can buy Government securities that yield so much and are safe," said Robert Beckwitt, manager of various mutual funds at Fidelity Investments with big holdings in Mexican Government securities.
Americans have been buying these securities since January 1991, when the Mexican Government first made them available for foreign purchase. In addition to the $9 billion in Treasury holdings, foreigners hold about $20 billion in Mexican bank certificates of deposits, which earn as much as 22 percent annually. The booming investment in Mexican securities reflects the American quest for interest rates higher than in the United States.
 
Other Nations Succeeded
 The higher rates also reflect President Carlos Salinas de Gortari's policy of keeping rates high enough to reduce inflation and to draw foreign capital to help finance rapid industrialization. Inflation has fallen to an annual rate of 12 percent, low for Mexico.
Other developing nations bent on rapidly creating a modern manufacturing industry have also sold short-term securities to foreigners to finance big outlays to equip new factories. South Korea, Taiwan and Singapore, for example, relied on foreign investment to pay for imports of capital goods until export income rose sufficiently to cover the purchases. And these countries managed the transition to manufacturing economies mostly without major devaluations.
The gamble for Americans buying Mexican securities is that Mexico might become the exception. The Salinas Government hopes to pay off the securities with dollars raised from a rapid increase in exports of manufactured goods. Right now, that is not happening. Instead, Mexico is importing huge quantities of machinery and materials for the new factories. Imports, as a result, shot up by 26 percent last year while exports of manufactured goods rose by only 4.4 percent.
If those percentages are not reversed in a year or two, many experts say, then the Government may be forced into a major devaluation -- one that might help exports by making them less costly, but at the expense of foreign investors. A sudden major peso devaluation might make a $10,000 investment in a one-year Treasury note worth, say, $6,000, including the 16 percent interest that it had earned. The interest earnings are free of Mexican taxes.
"These investors have been extremely lucky until now," said Rogelio Ramirez de la O, an economist and consultant in Mexico City. "But there is a point at which you cannot eat your cake and have it, too. You cannot have high rates of return and not have a devaluation risk."
The last major devaluation came in 1987. Since then, the Government has adhered to a policy of tiny, almost daily devaluations that have added up to no more than 5 percent a year. "We have enough flexibility to continue this policy and to maintain a sufficiently stable exchange rate," said Guillermo Ortiz, an Under Secretary of the Treasury.
Perhaps no American counts on that assurance more than Mr. Beckwitt of Fidelity. The funds he manages include holdings of $750 million in Mexican Treasuries. Various other Fidelity funds managed by others hold hundreds of millions of dollars more, making Fidelity probably the largest single owner of Mexican Treasuries, Mr. Beckwitt said.
"I am as convinced as I can be that the risk of an overnight major devaluation is extremely small," he said. "The Mexican Government knows from its experiences in the 70's and 80's that if it did that again it would return itself to the status of a third world country."
A 5 percent annual devaluation still allows Mr. Beckwitt a handsome profit. It means that the peso will go from 3 pesos for one American dollar today to 3.15 pesos to the dollar a year from now. Even at that, an American investor holding a one-year $10,000 Treasury note yielding 16 percent, for example, would come away with a net gain of 11 percent, or a total of $11,100, once the Mexican security was converted into dollars.
That is still far above the 3.15 percent yield today for a similar Treasury bill in the United States. But if the Mexican Government were to change course and suddenly decree a 50 percent devaluation in a single day, the American investor would end up with only $5,800 in his pocket.
 
Parking Cash in Mexico
 Brokerage houses like Nomura and Bear, Stearns also invest their own money in short-term Mexican securities, and they act as agents for various mutual funds, as well as a few wealthy individuals who purchase Mexican Treasury securities. Often, the mutual funds, having sold American stocks or bonds, park cash temporarily in the high-yielding Mexican Treasuries.
"Keeping cash in Mexico is a sign of huge confidence in that country," said Lawrence Kudlow, chief economist at Bear, Stearns.
A similar confidence in the 1970's prompted thousands of American retirees living in Mexico to keep their savings in Mexican banks. The peso had remained steady against the dollar for years. But with foreign exchange reserves nearly depleted, the Government lacked enough dollars to maintain this stability. So it suddenly decreed a huge peso devaluation that greatly increased the number of pesos necessary to purchase a dollar.
That reduced the drain on the nation's foreign exchange reserves, but it also diminished the savings of the American retirees, when measured in dollars. Today, in contrast, Mexico's central bank boasts an $18 billion dollar reserve as a buffer against a sudden devaluation.
 
Burned on Oil Collapse
 In the late 70's and early 80's, American banks took a different gamble. They lent billions of dollars to Mexico, and counted on revenue from that country's oil exports to service the debt. When oil prices collapsed, Mexico defaulted and has still not repaid much of this debt.
This time the peso's strength is tied to manufactured goods rather than oil. In a nation bent on rapid industrialization, the hope is that exports of manufactured goods will rise sharply, especially with the successful conclusion of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
That would bring sufficient revenue without having to sell so many Treasury securities and bank certificates of deposit to Americans. Normally, revenue from exports would have paid the $46.3 billion import bill last year. But export revenue was only $25.2 billion, so the dollars to pay for the imports came in effect from the sale of Treasuries and C.D.'s to foreigners.
When revenue from other international transactions like tourism are included, Mexico's total shortfall, or current account deficit, is $23 billion at an annual rate -- unusually high for a nation of Mexico's size. This is the shortfall that the Mexican Government is financing mostly through the sale of securities to foreigners.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Fund Yields Mixed As Focus Turned to Taxes

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields offered by tax-exempt and taxable money market funds were mixed in the latest week, reflecting seasonal tax pressures and uneasiness in the stock market.
According to the most recent survey by IBC's Money Fund Report, tax-exempt money fund yields rose sharply in the week that ended Tuesday. Yields jumped an average 8 basis points, and investors withdrew $2.7 billion from tax-exempt funds, which now total $108 billion, The Money Fund Report said. 
 Walter S. Frank, chief economist for The Money Fund Report, said that the April 15 deadline for filing tax returns prompted investors to withdraw money from funds to pay tax bills. Another factor for the decline in assets, he said, might have been that the very low short-term yields were forcing investors out of money market funds and into bond funds and longer maturities in search of higher returns.
For the week, fund managers shortened the average days left to maturity of securities held in their portfolios to 49 from 50.
 
 
Tax-Exempt Yields Up
 The IBC/Donoghue's average seven-day compounded tax-exempt fund yield rose 8 basis points, to 1.95 percent, with the average seven-day simple yield up 9 basis points, to 1.95 percent. The average 30-day compounded yield was 1.96 percent, and the simple yield was 1.94 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percent.
Not including state and local taxes, the taxable bond equivalent yield for the average seven-day yield is about 2.74 percent for investors in a 28 percent tax bracket and about 2.86 percent for those in a 31 percent bracket.
Among the tax-exempt funds with more than $100 million in assets, the Money Fund Report said the Strong Municipal Money Market fund had the highest yield for the week, at 2.61 percent, up 3 basis points from last week's best.
The average seven-day compounded taxable fund yield slipped 2 basis points, to 2.66 percent, in the week that ended yesterday, according to IBC/Donoghue. The average seven-day simple yield fell 1 basis point, to 2.63 percent; the average 30-day compounded yield was 2.69 percent, while the average 30-day simple yield was 2.65 percent.
 
 
Assets of Taxable Funds Rise
 Assets of taxable money market funds rose by $7 billion, to a total of $490.5 billion. Assets of institutional funds rose by $4.8 billion, to $173 billion, and retail assets rose $2.2 billion, to $317.5 billion. Analysts noted that about a third of the gain in retail assets came from the addition of two new funds.
Analysts said the average days left to maturity of securities in taxable money market portfolios rose to 63, from 62. They said that this trend left the impression that money managers were not worried about yields.
"If they were, they would be shortening up," Mr. Frank said. "Instead, the managers are reaching out for higher yields in the longer maturities as yields continue to slump."
Dreyfus Basic Money Market Fund turned in the highest return this week among general purpose taxable money funds, yielding 3.48 percent, or a basis point better than last week's best.
Banks, which compete directly with money market funds for investors' cash, shaved a basis point off their average yield in the week, to 2.58 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Japan Intervenes and Lifts ollar From Historic Lows

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Waves of intervention by the Bank of Japan lifted the dollar from historic lows against the Japanese yen yesterday, inspiring a broader advance that spilled over into key European currencies.
As many traders had expected, the central bank's tolerance for a lower dollar was tested when the United States currency broke below the crucial 110-yen level in Tokyo. The Bank of Japan was widely reported to have intervened three times, and the dollar managed to touch 111 yen during the New York session. 
 The rally helped the dollar advance against the German mark despite a report of a sharply higher money supply in Germany, which seemed to diminish the chances for a supportive cut in German interest rates.
Gold slipped in New York after sharper declines overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold for current delivery fell 40 cents a troy ounce to settle at $339.50. The Republic National Bank quoted a late bid of $339.25 a troy ounce, off 25 cents.
 
Reports That Others Helped
 Geoffrey Dennis, a currency strategist with James Capel & Company, said there were unproved rumors that other central banks had joined the Bank of Japan actions. But the widely reported Japanese intervention was significant enough by itself to spur participants to take profits on the yen's recent gains, he said.
"The 110 level is a key psychological point," Mr. Dennis said. "Now that we got there, the market has turned a bit nervous."
In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 110.35 yen, up 0.10 yen from Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 110.95 yen. By 4 P.M. in New York, the dollar was worth 110.71 yen, up from late Tuesday's 110.55 yen.
In Germany, the mark failed to gain against the dollar despite the report that the money supply rose 3.2 percent in March, much higher than expected.
The report, which raised inflationary concerns, deflated some hopes that the Bundesbank would cut short-term interest rates. Lower interest rates, which would increase the dollar's value, can also aggravate inflation. Later comments from a top Bundesbank official that the money supply increase was not abnormal seemed to soothe some concerns.

HEADLINE: Budget Gap Is Narrower

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
The United States posted a budget deficit of $44.577 billion for March, but the shortfall was down 12.1 percent from a year earlier because of higher revenues, the Treasury said today.
Taxes and other kinds of income were higher than in March 1992, when the Government posted a deficit of $50.712 billion. Interest payments also fell, reflecting lower rates. 
 "The economy is improving a tad," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM MoneyWatch in New York.
In addition, the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency in charge of disposing of bad loans and other assets of failed savings and loans associations, reported a small profit last month. In years past, the agency cost taxpayers money as it liquidated or sold off failed savings institutions.
By category, the Government's March receipts totaled $83.453 billion, while expenses totaled $128.029 billion, including $18.007 billion in interest on the public debt.
For the fiscal year to date, the United States is running a budget deficit of $182.825 billion compared with a $199.361 billion deficit for the similar period of the 1992 fiscal year.
For all of the 1992 fiscal year, the United States reported a record deficit of $290.203 billion. The 1993 fiscal year deficit could widen to $321.954 billion, according to White House projections.
For February, the United States reported a budget shortfall of $47.594 billion.

HEADLINE: Bond Refunding For Los Angeles

 BODY:
A $559.4 million refunding by Los Angeles County for the Metropolitan Transportation Authority was by far the largest municipal offering yesterday as debt issuers continue to take advantage of low interest rates to refund issues sold when rates were higher. Some of the Los Angeles bonds to be refunded carry interest rates as high as 6.90 percent.
Strong demand allowed underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company to reprice the sales tax revenue refunding bonds a little higher, thereby lowering yields. The maximum yield is about 5.7419 percent for a bond due in 2013, with a bond due in 2021 priced to yield about 5.6603 percent and one due in 2018 priced to yield about 5.7377 percent. 
 Shorter-maturity serial bonds were priced to yield from 3.50 percent in 1995 to 4.50 percent in 1998, 5.20 percent in 2003 and 5.65 percent in 2009.
The bonds due in 2018 and 2021 are insured by the Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corporation and the Financial Guaranty Insurance Company, respectively. They are rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation. All other maturities are rated A-1 by Moody's and A+ by S.& P.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The U.S. could regret getting its way on trade with Japan.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
ANYONE for Japan-bashing? It has long been a riskless sport in Washington. Labor approved, as did most big businesses. And Japanese leaders, loath to tamper with the alliance, have carefully confined their contemptuous ripostes to domestic audiences.
But the tone of the relationship is changing. While President Clinton and Prime Minister Kiichi Miyazawa agreed to disagree, no one familiar with the bland diplomatic rhetoric that the Japanese have honed to an art form could interpret last week's exchange on trade as business-as-usual. 
 Mr. Miyazawa's reluctance to assume the traditional position of little brother does not mark the beginning of a cold economic war. The American connection is simply too important to Japan to be allowed to rupture over the details of rice quotas and imported auto parts. Indeed, to many economists dismayed by the Clinton Administration's campaign to guarantee American companies a minimum share of the Japanese market, the biggest worry is that the gods may punish Mr. Clinton by giving him much of what he wants.
Stripped to essentials, Washington's beef is twofold. First, American products have been discriminated against by Japan's clubby corporate system in which back-scratching matters more than quality or price. As important, Japan has locked itself into an export-or-stagnate mode in which growth can come only at the expense of foreign competitors and domestic consumers.
But in the view of many economists, this conventional political wisdom is at odds with the facts. Gary Saxonhouse, an economist at the University of Michigan, concedes that Japan is guilty of trade protectionism. But he points out that America has been an equal sinner, notably in clothing, steel, dairy products, sugar and autos.
What's more, Japan has walked many a mile to mollify Americans in recent years, transplanting much of its export capacity to American shores. "Since 1985," Mr. Saxonhouse notes, "our exports to Japan have grown more rapidly than our exports to Europe, while our imports have grown more slowly." The only reason the trade gap between the two countries has recently widened, he argues, is because Japan is heading into a recession while America is already out.
Jagdish Bhagwati, an economist at Columbia University, worries less about the nature of the American trade complaint than the proposed fix. The President, Mr. Bhagwati points out, is taken with "managed trade" -- the trade equivalent of affirmative action. Mr. Clinton is not asking the Japanese to plead guilty to discrimination against American products, and then agree to go and sin no more. Rather, he wants Tokyo to guarantee that a minimum percentage of Japan's industrial needs will be purchased from American suppliers.
That might seem harmless enough if the products in question were, say, microprocessors or communications satellites, where American technology and prices are very competitive. But once you start down this road, Mr. Bhagwati says, it is the weak industries that fight hardest for guaranteed markets, not the strong ones. "If you don't want to become a cynic," he concludes, "don't study trade policy."
The new political enthusiasm for managed trade has driven much of the free market-oriented economics establishment to embrace what is seen as lesser evils: managed currency exchange rates or managed Japanese domestic demand.
Fred Bergsten of the Institute for International Economics in Washington thinks an additional 5 to 10 percent appreciation of exchange value of the yen with respect to the dollar would go a long way toward pricing Japanese products out of America and pricing American products into Japan. And he thinks governments can pull off a managed appreciation by buying and selling the two currencies. "Intervention works," he said flatly.
An alternative, pursued by the Bush Administration and certainly not opposed by the Clinton White House, is to encourage the Japanese to consume and invest more at home, leaving less surplus production to export. That is one reason why Japan announced a big fiscal stimulus package on the eve of the Miyazawa visit to Washington.
One catch is that the stimulus probably will not have as much oomph as advertised. The $115 billion-plus package looks more like $60 to $70 billion to economists who know their way around arcane Japanese fiscal accounting -- enough to generate only a mild economic recovery in domestic demand. The Japanese, it seems, loathe budget deficits even more than they loathe conflict with the man from Hope.
But the bigger catch, one that calls into question the whole thrust of the Clinton diplomatic exercise, is that we may soon regret any success in making the Japanese more like us. Among the rich countries, only Japan is, on balance, a major exporter of capital. And if Japan is bullied into joining the no-money-down crowd, where will the trillions of dollars worth of fresh capital be found to bring Eastern Europe, the former Soviet Union, China, India and most of Latin America into the community of developed economies?
